many complayntes made y• oppreſſion church monaſteries pope chapleine named williā teſta archdeacon araine ye church couentrie ſame clearke forbidden vſe moe ſuche extortion diuerſe ſtatutes ordayned touching religious perſōs theyr principal houſes realmes came parliamente ſente pope cardinall called petrus hiſpanus treate mariage betwixte edwarde prince wale frenche courſe fleete dike london ſore decayed vvhich ſometime bare ship ſmal burden holborn bridge great commoditie citie vveſt part king daughter amongſt many ſutes made ther earle lincolne complayned whereas time paſt courſe water running london vnder holborne bridge fleete bridge thamis hadde bin ſuche large breadth deapth ten twelue ſhips merchaundiſes wonte come forſayde bridge fleete ſome holborne bridge nowe y• ſame courſe filth tāners ſuch ſore decayed alſo rayſing vp wharfes eſpecially turning water ye new temple made theyr milles without baynardes caſtel diuerſe perturbation ſayde ſhippes nowe coulde enter wont oughte wherefore deſired maior london sherifes certain diſcrete alderman might appointed ſée courſe ſayde water othe honeſt men forſayde hindraunces might remoued made wont old time c aunſwered recorded roger le brabazon coneſtable tower maior sherifs aſſigned taking honeſt diſcrete men make diligente ſearche inquirie howe ſayde riuer old time leaue nothing may hurt ſtop kéepe ſame ſtate wont king edwarde remayning winter sommertho walſing carlile diſpoſed manye thyngs scotlande hys pleaſure meane tyme robert de bruis going aboute countrey ſlewe manye woulde obey hym ſente parte hys armye two hys brother thomas knyghte alexander prieſte deane glaſco another parte countrey myghte allure people vnto gentle perſwaſions whyche comming engliſhmen vppon taken ledde iuſtices condemned hanged headed carlile kyng edvvarde ſente meſſengers englande commaundyng oughte hym ſeruice bée readye carlile wythin thrée wéekes feaſte saint iohn baptiſte▪ himſelfe vexed bloudye flixe ſente ſonne ſhoulde come ſpéede heare hys laſte word whome among thyngs hée counſelled bée mercifull iuſte conſtante hys wordes déedes hée commanuded hym bée haſtye take hym crowne englande tyll hée hadde reuenged iniuries done scottes ſtaye thoſe partes cauſe hys father boanes beyng cloſed cheaſte bée borne aboute wyth hym tyll hée hadde gone thorow scotlande ouercome hys aduerſaries alſo commaunded hym honoure hys mother loue hys two brother thomas earle marſhall edmvnde earle cornewall moreouer hée charged hym hys curſſe ſhoulde preſume call home pierce glauaſton cōmon decrée baniſhed without common fauour ſpende xxxij • ſiluer otherwayes buſineſſe holy land whiche purpoſe prepared willed heart bée buried king alſo called vnto henrie lacy earle ofwil pakington lincolne guy earle warwicke aymerde valence earle penbroke robert clifford baron deſiring bée good ſonne ſhould ſuffer pierce gauaſton come againe england ſet ſon riot vij july departed life brugh vpō y• ſands yere 1307 raigned body vnſteadfaſt maners diſpoſedcro dun lightneſſe haunting company vile perſons giuē wholy pleaſure bodye regarding gouerne common weale diſcretion iuſtice cauſed great variaunce betwéene hys lord foke hys counſell patricke earle lincolne otho de granſon ordayned walter reignald chauncellour cauſed walter langton biſhoppe chester bring king father bodye carlile waltham croſſe arreſted layetie ſhould giuen king 27 october king edward firſt buryed westminster heade henrie third father vnto church giuen land value one hundred pound yeare twentie pounde thereof yearely diſtributed went ouer france married iſabel french king daughter bolloigne y• xxij januarie preſent marriage phillip king fraunce hys ſonne king nauar king almaine king cicile many xxiiij day februarye king edward quéene crowned westminster henrie biſhop winchester admitted ſo robert archbiſhop canterburie king offered firſte pounde golde made like king holding ring hande offered marke golde whiche eight ounce made like pilgrime putting forth hande receyue ring sir iohn bachauell knyghte thruſte deathe hys coronation king gaue vnto pierce guaston ſuch giftes andghro • n jewel bin giuen crownes hys father anceſtours treaſure many thing affirming could ſhould ſuccéede kyngdome calling brother granting thing without conſent lord therfore enuying told king father pierce traytour king fraunce ſame executed mother burned witch ſaid pierce baniſhed conſenting mother witchcraft hée bewitched king himſelfe beſought kyng heare therefore petition whiche ſhoulde owne honoure wealth people firſt woulde confirme vſe ſuche auntiente1 lawes cuſtomes contayned charter kyngs hys predeceſſonrs woulde graunt twentith part good true ſubiectes secondly woulde take nothyng man but2 price owner ſame payde vttermoſt thyrdlye ſoeuer alyenated the3 crowne ſince hys father death might reſtoared therevnto fourthly would obſerue oth made before4 father reuoking peter gauaſton proſecuting scottiſh warre amiſſe ſhoulde amended leaſte hys enymies reioyce c iuſtice iudgemente mighte done the5 lande well ryche poore accordyng auntiente olde approued lawes cuſtomes englande man ſhoulde bée reſtrayned kyngs writte proſecuting hys ryghte defend himſelfe law king taking counſell pierce hugh spencer treaſurer y• chancellour others appointed anſwere baron parliamēt hocday baron departed london citie gate ſhut vp chayned great watch kept hugh spencer made coneſtable london king peter gauaſton wēt towarde wallingford caſtel wyth great company ſouldiours well ſtraungers engliſh hugh spencer taried ſtill london parliament hocday kepte kyng baron decréed ſame pierce ſhoulde baniſhed lande departe morrowe midſommer day neuer returne agayne king gaue two thirtie townes ſo manyepierce gauaſtone banished caſtels gaſcotgne great ſummes money earledome cornwall life king accompanyed bristow ſēt ireland aſſigning y• whole gouernment reuenewes countrey king ſente william lorde latimer hundred horſſemen fetch henrie lacy erle lincoln forewarned kept himſelfe caſtell ſo preuented theyr purpoſe onely lord latimer talked ſo departed king entended giue gaſcoigne french king scotland robert bruis ireland wale others hoping thereby haue ayde againſt baron robert archbiſhoppe canturburie returned rome reſtored good anno reg 2 sherifes maior 1309 tho de la iohn troklowe anno reg 3 william baſing iames botener 28 september nicholas faringdon goldſmith 28 october king ſent pierce gauaſton ireland lā ded kerneruan euen saint iohn baptiſt kyng mette caſtel flint great ioy gaue earle glocesters ſiſter marriage maried barkamsteed cauſed riſe pride ſcorning noble realme abuſe kyng done conuaying treaſure theanno reg 3 realme forraine countreys amongſt treaſure conuayed table treſtles golde treaſurie westminster deliuered one armery friſconband cōuayed gaſcoigne baronscro pet coledge therefore declared king except would expell ſayd pierce company would riſe agaynſt againſt periured prince wherevpon aduicechro dun pierce gauaſton king ſent ayde gaſcoigne earle foys y• uicount henoy came thrée hundred horſemen france phillip french king empriſoned chiefe ſlew hanged alſo king england word robert bruſe scotland robert fitz thomas ireland woulde take part king againſt baron wherevpon king wroth fortifyed windſore caſtell beganne build tower ſtrange thing abbot saint denis france béeing ſent legate pope demaund legacie king edward father gaue holy land earneſtly requeſt king edward remoue peter gauaſton whoſe conuerſation world infected king appoynted parliamente northhampton determining thence paſſe scotland baron came parliament well furniſhed king ſente worde woulde come yet laſt came stony stratford whither ſente baron earles warwike clare requeſted come owne profite commoditie realme length went habite squire baron met without armour ende louingly embraced made friend voyage scotland reiourned til another time michaelmas parliament holden london vnto whiche parliamente came lewes french king brother biſhop poytow kyng fraunce▪ entrenie vnitie betwixt king lordes diuers get ordinaunces made agayne though ſore agaynſt king mind cauſed pierce obiure condition added baron founde agayne lande ſubiecte king dominion ſhoulde taken common enimy condempned beyng done • paſſed flanders thence country ſéeking reſte coulde finde iames saint edmond roger palmer 28 sept sherifes maior 1310 anno reg 4 thomas romaine 28 october pierce gaueston conceyuing truſt friendſhippe king earle gloucester▪ whoſe ſiſter marryed taking many▪ ſtraungers returned into▪ englande▪ little before▪ chriſtmas came kyngs preſence fo • ioy comming forgettyng othes promiſes receyued hym heauenly gift king kept chriſtmas windſore walter langton biſhop chester biſhop saint andrew scotland releaſed priſon ſeconde daye september night horrible tempeſt thunder happened ſo hedge trées loſte gréeneneſſe church middleton dorcetſnire wyth stéeple september sherifes maior 10 rouſe richard r ••• mercer 28 october bl • ckeney deceaſſed whoſe place ſucceeded iohn •• combridge▪ prouinciall counſell holden london agaynſtetemplers condempned thomas dele templers england vppon hereſie article accuſed denyed facte ſauing one two • notwithſtanding confeſſe coulde purge themſelues therefore condempned perpetuall penuance ſeuerall monaſteries haued themſelues well paris frauuoe liiij templers brent by1311 iudgement french king thomas maryed daughter henry late earle lancaster hel de hys handes earledomes lancaster lincolne saliſbury leyoester ferra • libertie pickering honoure cokermore beſides greate landes wale earledome arthoys france king edwarde wyth peter gauaſton hys companion went yorke king lodged palace archebyſhoppe peter caſtle cauſed citie fortified walles repayred ſent robert bayliol scotlande ayde againſte lordes robert made anſweare woulde forth scotland▪ neyther woulde diſquiet man lyke aunſweare made welchmen earles aſſembled bedford▪ gilber earle glocester one came london ordayned sea kept leaſte ſtraungers ſhoulde enter ayde kyng eaſter brother pierce gauaston taken greate treaſure whiche hadde conueyed oute kyngs treaſurie ſhippe beyng toſſed wyth tempeſte sea driuen taken treaſure brought london carles time king edward recreation tooke sea leauing peter gauaston yorke vpon barous brought power entred citie yorke peter fled scarborough baron beſieged scarborough took committed ye cuſtody aymerde valence erle penbroke brought manor dedington betwixt oxford warwike▪ • left kept ſ • fer ye next day y• morning guy earle warwike company armed men took▪ thence brought warwike caſtell deliberation taken earles lancaster warwike iohn treklow pierce gauaſton beheaded anno reg 5 hereford cauſed preſence place called gaueſice blacke lowe xix june head ſtricken body frier preacher conuayed oxford▪ kept two yeares till king cauſed ſame tranſlated manor langley frier church builded buryed simon merwood richard wilford 28 septemb▪ sherifes maior 1312 tho de la roades vvonne chriſtians sir iohn giſors peperer▪ 28 october quéene iſabell deliuered hir firſt ſonne named edward windſore xiij day nouember knightes order saint iohn baptiſt called saint iohn hieruſdlem put turkes iſle roades wan vpon ſayde turkes dayly long time religion greatly preferred fall templers whoſe poſſeſſion giuen counſell holden vienna anno reg 6 robert de bruce gote againe almoſt scotland caſtels munition engliſh garriſons caſt tooke agayne power yeare therefore tho de la hugh spencer yonger conſent prelate certayne noble hugh spē cer ſonne appoynted king chamberlayne place peter gaueſton whome rather preferred bycauſe knew king hated neuertheleſſe long great diligence brought himſelfe king fauour father hugh béeing olde▪ yet liuing▪ knight great vertue counſell wi • e armes valiant whoſe confuſion ſhamefull end wanne vnto himſelfe naturall loue though diſordinate towardes hys ſonne body comely ſpirite proude action moſt wicked whoſe couetouſneſſe ambition diſheriting widdowes ſtrangers wrought death noble fall king vtter deſtruction himſelfe father iohn lambin richard wilford 28 september sherifes maior 1313 tho de la sir iohn giſors peperer 28 october king edwarde gathering greate power marched towards scotland breake ſéege striueling caſtell lodged himſelfe people fielde euen saint iohn baptiſt neuer afore time wasbattayle striuelin ſéene like preparation pride coſt time war affirmeth robert paſton carmelite frier preſentrobert paſton taken scottes ſorowfully bewayled heroycall uerſe while priſoner firſte night ſayeth yée might haue ſéene engliſhmen bathing themſelues wyne caſting gorge cry ſhowting waſſaling drinking rioting farre aboue meaſure ſide yée might haue ſéene scottes quiet ſtill cloſe faſting ſhe euen saint iohn baptiſt labouring loue libertie countrey morow scottes hauing gotten moſt conuenient place fielde victorie made ditch grounde thrée foote déepe ſhe like breadth right wing army vnto leaſt couering y• ſame weake twigges herdles agayne ouer turffe graſſe whiche ſtrength beare horſemen armie scottes béeing deuided certayne troupe ſtoode farre dike whiche betwixt engliſhmen ſide armie engliſhmen comming weaſt ſunne riſing caſting beames golden target bright helmet armoure gaue ſuch reflection wonderfull terrible beholde firſt warde light horſemen heauie courſers ſecond archer footemen appoynted chaſe aduerſaries thirde king biſhops religious amongſt whome hugh spencer horſemen firſt front making vpon enimies foundered foreféete ditch laye ther • tumbling abiding cruelty scottes comming vpon ſlewe ſo • e tooke greate many richemen raunſome ſlayne gilbert de clare earle glocester whome scottes woulde gladly haue kept raunſome hadde knowne hée hadde forgotten putte hys coate armes wyth hym flaine sir edmond manly syr roberte clifford sir paine • ptofte syr wyllyam marſhall syr giles dargenton many knight eſquiers taken humfrey de bohun▪ barvvike betrayed iohn wengraue 28 october aboute midlent towne berwicke betrayed scottes throughe treaſon peter spalding engliſhemen whome kyng scottes cauſed hanged béeyng traytors theyr countrey caſtell held oute till wante victualles wythin conſtrayned delyuer scottiſhmens handsthe scottes inuaded england richard south iohn • • ucklowe wanne alſo ſame tyme caſtelles harbotel warke mydforde ſo poſſeſſed parte northumberlande euen newecastell vppon tyne ſauing certayne caſtels defended agaynſt may entred lande brenning al tyll came rypon whyche towne ſpoyled tarrying thrée dayes receyued thouſande markes thoſe gote churche bycauſe ſhould put town fyre hadde done townes northallerton borough bridge c theyr returning backe brent knareſburghe skipton crauen afore carrying scotlande maruellous multitude cattel beſides pryſoners men woman yorkeſhiremen gathered togither number oftho walſing ten thouſād met scot town mitton ten myles northweaſt yorke loſte thréew packington thouſande ouercome scottes whych kyng hearde tell hée lefte ſiege barwike haſted méete scottes returned way pope ordayned parſons ſhould haue one benefice péece wherevpon patron ſtraight preſented foreſaide noble ſore amoued humfrey earle hereforde complayned thomas earle lancaster whyche twoo earles allured almoſt al earles baron take part thomas erle lancaster captainethe baron • armour came length kyngthe elder spencer banished graunted petition ſo hughe spencer elder baniſhed yonger hugh fell ſpoyling ſea taking two dronionds aboute sandwiche goodes value 40000 poundes reignolde conduit william produn 28 sept sherifes maior ievves leaper poyſoned vvaters conradus memdember nicholas farendon goldſmith 28 october certaine leaper made couenaunt iewes poyſon chriſtians europe layde poyſon welles spring pittes whiche many conuict brēt died almain cauſe aboue twelue thouſand iewes feaſte saint michaell iſabell quéenet de la came canterbury ye caſtle lede kent purpoſing haue lodged night ſhe coulde permitted enter king herewith beyng offended beyng done inleedes caſtell beſieged contempte hym calling hym common eſſex london beſieged caſtle whyche belonged bartholomewe de badelſmere hauing lefte hys wyfe chyldren therein gone wyth reſte noble men ranſacking spencer goodes meane time leedes caſtle diſpayring ſafegarde noble men wyth armye came kyngston uigill saint simon iude demaunding byſhoppes canterbury london earle penbroke ſent betwéene king woulde gyue ouer hys ſiege promiſing nexte parliament woulde delyuer caſtell kyngs handes become obedient vnto kyng woulde graunte noble men petition beyng returned partes kyng wyth muche laboure obtayned caſtell hanging ſixe chiefe thoſe whome hée founde therein ſente wife child badleſmere tower london kyng edwarde helde hys chriſtmaſſe circister chriſtmaſſe leanyng gloucester wircester hée wyth hys armye wente shrewſbury bridgenorth mortimer méeting king reuerently peaceably ſubmitted themſelues vnto kyng ſente themmortimer ſente tovver tower london mawrice barkeley hugh audley like ſorte ſubmitting themſelues ſent wallingforde caſtel humfrey earle hereforde gilbert talbot raufe damary adherent ſonne lorde chamberlayne roberte baldocke lorde chauncellour procured ſayde ambaſſadours declare theyr meſſage king yet ſhoulde depart admoni • hing come ſayd ſyr andrew de florence notarie made publike inſtrument ſayde citation admonition iohn grantham richard ely 28 septem sherifes maior tho de la hamond chickwel peperer 28 october frenche king made proceſſe againſte king englande charles de valoys vncle king charles fraunce moſt deadly enimy engliſhmen ſea • e dukedome angue countie portowe vnto vſe nephew king length going forward towne ryall founde wel defended edmond woodstocke earle kent betwixte whome finall truce taken continue vntill ſuche time coulde determined betwéene king concerning peace towne yelded vp army departed home next lent parliament holden london adam tarleton biſhoppe hereforde accuſed treaſon buthenrie blanford 1323 archbiſhops cāterburie yorke dubline ſuffragan biſhoppes taken barre away notwithſtanding inquiſition made lawefull men country founde y• ayded mortimer horſſe armour againſt king wherevppon hys temporality ſeaſed king hand parliament king graunted petition y• prelate body noble men hanged gallowes ſhoulde taken downe buried eccleſiaſticallanno reg 17 ſepulture king alſo aſked ſubſidie cleargie people redéeming iohn britaigne earle richmonde adam tarleton biſhop hereford depriued hys temporall good hate spencer deadlye ſo dyd henrie burwaſhe lincolne friendes withheldetho de la handes reuerence king lammas daye roger mortimer wigmore byhenrie blanford giuing kéepers ſléepe drinke eſcaped tower breaking▪ wal comming y• kitchin neare adioyning king lodging getting toppe thereof came warde tower ſo cordes knitte ladderwiſe prepared afore hande friende hys got another warde ſo greate feare got thamis helper two moe counſell paſſed riuer auoyding high wayes came ſea finding ſhippe paſſed ouer fraunce adam salisburie iohn oxforde 28 septem sherifes maior 1324 tho de la anno reg 18 nicholas farendon goldſmith 28 october kyng ſente ambaſſadours french kyng byſhoppes winchester norwiche iohn brytaine earle richmonde take order dukedome brytaine long debatings toke certayne forme peace king king edwarde ſente quéene hys wife vnto hyr brotherthe queenſēt • fraunce french kyng eſtabliſhe peace went ouer ſmall company hyr mediation peace fullye finiſhed witte kyng englande ſhould giue eldeſt ſonne edwarde dukedome aquitaine earledome po • •• e french kyng ſhoulde receyue homage hym wherevpon edwarde king ſonne wente ouer wyth competent houſholde aboute feaſte saint mathewe homage vnder certaine proteſtations vncle frenche king bennet fulham iohn cowſon 28 september sherifes maior 1325 hamon chickwel peperer 28 october while quéene wyth hyr ſonne remayned fraunce longer king pleaſure would come agayne wythout roger mortimer noble fledde englande eſpecially hatred ſhée bare two hughe spencer kyng diſpleaſure baniſhed bothe toke theyr partes wherevppon manye fledde ouer sea quéene amongſt whych one ſubtill knyght sir robert walkefare ſlaying coneſtable corfe caſtel brake long line priſoner sir oliuer ingham knight yong duke edwarde oliuer ingham hadde made kéeper aquitaine gathered great armye inuaded prouince aniowe whiche frenche king contrarie couenauntes dydde wythholdeanno reg 19 broughte wholby dominion england moreouer king nauie tooke hundred ſhips norman brought england cauſe gret hatred grew betwixt two king realmes q perceyuing y• noble france corrupted gift ſent englād ſo ſhe could truſt none ſecretly conueyed hir ſelfe hir ſonne erle heynalde deſiring ayde receyued intreated hyr honourably ſo long ſhe remayned gilbert mordon iohn cotto • 28 september sherifes maior 1326 richard betaine goldſmith 28 october iſabel quéene made mariage betwixt hir eldeſt ſon edward phillip earles daughter heynalde hir ſonne edwarde edmunde woodstocke erle kent king brother roger mortimer many noble men fledde englande iohn brother earle heynalde captaine ſtipedarie knightes almaine henalde ſhe toke ſeas hir power whiche number mm dcc luii menne well armed arriued vrewel orwel hauen beſides harwich eſſex▪ michaelmaſſe whether immediately earle marſhal earle leicester biſhops lincolne hereforde diuelyn ely▪ came ioyned quéene made great army anno reg 20 queene iſabel returned biſhops ſpecially canturburie ayded hyr mony ſhe refreſhed hir armye saint edmondeſburie▪ ſhe went forwardes purſuing hir enimies whoſe good ſhe applyed hir owne vſe king requeſted ayde citizen london made aunſweare wouldethe king requeſted ayde due obedience honour king quéene theyr ſonne lawfull heyre realme woulde ſhut theyr gate againſt forraine traytors realme would go citie fighte except might according theyr liberty return home againe ſame day sunne ſette k hearde fortified tower london lefte hysproclamation king yonger ſonne iohn eltham cauſed alſo proclaimed euery ••• ſhould reſiſt arriued inuade vttermoſt theyr power quéene hir ſome edward erle kent brother excepted wholoeuer coulde bring heade roger mortimer ſhoulde haue thouſande pounde ſ ••• proclaymed quéenes behalfe al menproclimation queene ſhould haue good peace except diſturbers realm wit spencer y• father ſon robert baldocke byſhop norwich king chancellour theyr fautours whoſoeuer bring quéen head hugh spencer ſhoulde haue pound citizen london without reſpect beheaded ſuch took quéenes enimies among whiche beheaded one owne citizen named iohn marſhal bicauſe familiar hugh spencer yonger toke alſo maiſter walter stapleton biſhoppe excester xv day ofbishop exceſter beheaded october beheaded eight twētith march next following buried excester great ſolemnitie two ſeruauntes ſquire yeoman named william atwall iohn padington ſtanderd cheape bycauſe ſaying gathered greate army withſtand quéene alſo wreſt keyes tower london coneſtables handes deliuered al priſoners richard rothing roger chaunteclere 28 septem sherifes maior saint iames richard britaine goldſmith 28 october thys richarde rothing sherife builded pariſhe church saint iames garlike hithe london quéen beſieged bristow ſoone rēdered tothe queen beſieged briſtovv hir morrow hir cōmyng hugh spencer elder drawen hanged armour beheaded spencer elder executed wil pakington body hanged vppe againe foure dayes cutte al péeces caſt dogges eaten heade ſent winchester king hugh spencer yonger robert baldocke determyned flée ile lunday whiche mouth riuer seuerne twoo mile length euery waye verye fruitefull pleaſaunte harde conquer beyng greate daunger sea ſpace athe king taken tho de la alexan netha • wéeke laſte arriued wale taken ſixtéenth daye nouember monaſterye neth kyng committed henrie earle lancaster kinſman broughte hym kellingworthe caſtellthe k ſent killingvvorth hugh spencer robert baldocke symon readyn broughte quéene hereforde earle arundell iohn daniel thomas muchelden procurement roger mortimer beheaded theyr comming hugh spencer condemned without aunſwere hereforde drawen hanged vppon aspencer yō ger executed gallowes thirtye foote hygh headed quartered foure twentith nouember simon reading drawen hanged ſame gallowes ten foote lower robert baldocke dyed newgate manye torment theſe thing beyng done quéene wyth hyr ſonne edwarde roger mortimer went wallingforde caſtell little chriſtmaſſe twelfth daye came london ioyfully receyued morrowe ſayde feaſte helde parliamente common decrée elected edwarde hys eldeſte ſonne ſente name whole parliament thrée biſhoppes iohnk edvvard ſecond depoſed stratforde biſhoppe winchester adam tarleton byſhoppe threates declaring vnto hym theyr election required renounce kyngly dignitie crowne hys ſonne kyng aunſweared teares hée ſorie hée hadde behaued hymſelfe ſo euill towardes people hys kingdome ſéeyng matter ſo vnrecouerable prayed forgiue hym thanked choſen eldeſt ſonne meſſengers renounce homage dueties due edwarde carnaruan late king thomas blunte knight ſtewarde houſholde brake hys rodde king edward preparing army scotland commā ded baylifes citizen canterburie furniſh twelue horſſemen ſende nowcastel towarde charge citizen required ayde monkes aunſwered without aſſent kyng theyr archbiſhoppe would agrée therevnto ſo much king englande founded theyr churche frée perpetuall almes wherevpon william chilham baylife many common citie aſſembled themſelues preaching frier gathered vſe common 4 man ſhoulde ſende ſel monkes anye victual 5 ſhould ſell horſſes beaſts y• came citie cariage monkes 6 al ſuch monk came forth houſe ſhold ſpoyled garment 7 trench ſhoulde caſt brother henalt came helpecro pet coledge edwarde thirde againſte scottes fiue hundred men armes whiche henawders engliſhmen fell chaunce trinitie sonday yorke 80 lincolnſhire men ſlaine buried vnder ſtone clements churchyarde foſegate king wente againſte scottes entrediourney tovvards ſcotland englande farre stanhope parke wardale beſieged thrée dayes eſcaped iames douglas one night ſecretly entring engliſh campe came néere king tent haue taken ſlain chaplein bolde man well armed ſome beyng ſlaine much adoe got backe vnhurte iſabel quéene perſwaded earle leicester muche fauoured olde king hyr huſbandetho de la walter barker swinebroke ſubtile deuiſe hyr ſcholemaſter adam tarleton biſhop hereforde appointed thomas gornay iohn maltrauers knightes hauing receyued theyr cuſtody ſhould carrie whether would ſo none hys well willers ſhoulde haue acceſſe vnto vnderſtand made long abode theſe brought nighte kenilworth firſte brought caſtell corfe bristow ſeaſon kept ſhut vp cloſe caſtel vntil ſuche time vnderſtoode certaine burgeſſes ſame towne deliueraunce ſaid edward conueyed themſelues ouer sea whoſe determination béeing knowne kéepers certaine darke night conueyed thence berkeley theſe tormentours forced ride bareheaded woulde ſléepe would ſuffer hym neyther hungry would giue ſuche meate liked ſuche lothed euerye worde ſpake contraried giuing moſte ſlaunderouſly madde conclude matter coulde imagine contrarie hys wyll eyther colde watchyng vnholeſome meates melancholy infirmitie myght languiſhe dye contrariwiſe thys man good diſpoſition nature ſtoute ſuffer patiente throughe god grace abyde griefes hée endured wicked deuiſes hys enymies touching poyſons whiche miniſtred benefit nature diſpatched away theſe chā pion ſayd bring olde king towardes barkeley guarded rabble helhoundes along graunges belonging caſtell bristow wicked man gerney making crown hey put hys heade ſouldiours aboute mocked ſaying tprut auaunt ſir king making kinde noiſe theyr mouthes though farted theſe doubting meete ſome hys friendes bent theyr iourney ouer mariſh ground lying ruier seuerne moreouer diuiſing meanes diſfigure hée mighte knowen determined ſhaue well heare hys heade alſo bearde wherefore comming little water whiche ranne ditche commaunded alighte horſſe ſhauen whome ſet molehill barbour came baſon colde water taken ditch whō edwarde ſayd ſhall haue warme water barber anſwered wyll ſerue quoth edward ye nil yée haue warme water might kéepe promiſe beganne wéepe ſhed teares plentifullye reported william byſhop ſir thomas de la knight length came berkeley caſtel edward ſhutte vppe cloſe like ancher iſabel wife taking grieuouſly hir huſbāds life thus prolonged made complaint adam biſhop hereforde fayning ſhe certayne dreames interpretation whereof ſhe miſliked like ſorte biſhop hys conſcience guiltie treaſon ſtoode feare like feare alſo ſtoke heartes ſame offence diuer gathered together effect wherfore ſéemed good many great dignity bloud wel ſpiritual temporal yt al ſuch fear ſhould taken away ye death edwarde whervppon letter ſent hys kéepers blaming ſuffering enioy ſo much libertie nouriſhing ſo delicately moreouer priuie motion made thatsophiſtical letter procuring murder olde king death edwarde woulde miſliked vnto pointe great deceyte sophiſters ſtoode force ſet downe biſhoppe hereforde wrote thus edwardum occidere nolite timere bonum est kyl edward feare good thing thus ſeeke ſhed king edward bloud refuſe feare counte good thys ſaying reſolued two propoſitions whereof firſt conſiſting thrée wordes witte edwardum occidere nolite ſeconde thrée timere bonum est ſéeme perſwade ſubtilly receyuers letter ignorant sophiſtical writing chaunged meaning thereof thys ſenſe edwardum occidere nolite timere afterwarde ioyned theſe wordes bonum est nowe olde king broughte caſtell aforeſayde curteouſlye receiued thomas lorde barkeley tormentor receyued letter concerning gouernemente caſtell thomas lord berkley commaunded departe thence wherefore taking leaue ſighes goeth dwelling place olde king ſhutte vp cloſe chamber ſtincke deade carkaſſes layde celler vnder miſerablye tormented manye dayes ſuche ſorte well nyghe ſuffocated therewith paine almoſt intollorable appeared complainte made certayne daye chamber windowe certayne carpenter working righte ſide thereof hearing ſame theſe tyraunts perceyuing woulde force hys death one night xxij september came ruſhing vppon laye bedde greate heauyethe old king murdered • eatherbeddes muche weyghte xv menne coulde beare wherwyth oppreſſed ſmoothered hym alſo thruſt plummers yron made redde hotte vp bowel throughe certaine inſtrumente like end trumpet gliſter pipe put hys fundiment burning thereby inward partes prouiding thereby leaſt wound founde king bodye might cauſed aunſweare ſort ſtoute king oppreſſed cry lowde voyce ſo many well within caſtell without heard perceyuing cry one ſuffered violente deathe cauſed many berkeley affirmed take 28 october certaine men land y• intent try friendsk edvvard ſeconde bruted aliue england craftily deuiſed edward ſecond king england aliue caſtell gorffe bée ſéene daye time therefore vſed manye nightes make ſhewes maſkyng wyth dauncing vpon tower wals caſtel perceyued people countrey thoughte bin ſome great king vnto dyd theſe greate ſolemnities rumour ſpredde ouer englande witte olde king aliue whence came paſſe earle kent ſente thyther fryer precher trye truth matter thought hauing corrupted porter caſtell rewardes isanno reg 3 let lay day porter lodge verye cloſe whē night come willed put y• habit lay mā brought hal wher ſaw thought edwarde father king ſitting royally ſupper great maieſtie frier thus perſwaded returned againe earle kente reported thought ſaw whervpon y• erle ſaide affirmed othe would indeauoure meanes coulde deliuer brother priſon ſame yeare earneſt requeſt ſome king1329 held parliament winchester procurement olde quéene roger mortimer ſayde earle ofparliament vvincheſter kent manye noble men religious perſons witte prouincials white carmilit frier blacke preaching frier frier richarde wliten accuſed conſpiracie touching ſayde deliuerye king father matter although deuiſed fantaſie méere lye yet ſayde earle certaine confeſſions whyche made certayne letter founde beheaded wit y• prouincials predicants erle kent king vncle beheaded vvincheſter carmilites baniſhed biſhop london ſet libertie robert de taunton prieſt ſome certain carmilite frier predicants condemned perpetual priſon death ſayde earle leſſe lamented bycauſe familye ſeruauntes aboue meaſure afflicted common taking vp thing trauayled king price paying nothing verye lyttle richarde lazer wyllyam giſours 28 septsherifes maior richarde swanland 28 october parliament holden notingham roger mortimer ſuche glorie honoure without compariſon man durſt name earle marche greater rowt men wayted héeles king perſon would ſuffer king riſe would walke y• king equally ſtep ſtep chéeke chéeke neuer preferring y• king would go formoſt himſelfe officer greatly rebuked earle lancaster couſin kyng withoute hys conſent hée appointed certayne lodging noble men towne demaundyng made ſo bolde take vppe lodging ſo nighe vnto quéene wyth whyche wordes coneſtable béeyng greatelye feared appoynted lodging earle lancaster one myle oute towne lykewiſe lodged earle hereforde iohn de bohune estſex highe coneſtable englande others whyche meanes contention roſe among nobleman greate murmuring among common people ſayde roger mortimer quéenes paragon kyngs mayſter ſought mean could deſtroy kyngs bloude vſurpe regall maieſtie whyche reporte troubled muche kyngs friendes wéete william mountacute ſafegarde kyng ſware themſelues true perſon drew vnto robert de hollande hadde long tyme béene chiefe kéeper caſtell vnto whome ſecreate corner ſame knowne vppon certayne night kyng lying without caſtel bothe friendes brought torchlight ſecrete waye vnder ground beginning far y• ſaid caſtell til came euen quéenes chamber whyche chaunce found open therfore beyng armed naked ſwords hāds went forward leauing king alſo armed without dore chamber leaſt mother ſhould eſpie entred ſlew hugh turpinton knighte reſiſted mayſter iohn neuell horneby giuing deadly wound thence went toward quéene mother whome found earle march readie haue gone bedde hauing taken ſayde earle ledde hall whome quéene followed cry bele fit bele fit ayes pitie de gentil mortimer good ſonne▪ good ſon take pitie vpon gentle mortimer ſhe ſuſpected hir ſonne though ſhe ſaw keyes caſtell ſent euery place furniture yéelded vp king hand ſuche ſecret wiſe none without caſtell except king friend vnderſtoode thereof next day morning early bring roger mortimer friēds taken horrible ſhout cry earle lancaster blind one made ſhoute ioy towards london committed tower afterward condemned westminster preſence whole parliament saint andrewes euen next following drawne elmes hanged common gallowes whereon hung two dayes two nightes king commandement buryed grey frier church condemned péeres yet neuer brought anſwere cuſtome death earles lancaster winchester glocester kent wherefore earle law ſelfe appoynted cauſes death laid againſt theſe firſt conſenting murthering king father secondly receiued great ſumme money whereby king honor greatly abated stanhope parke gaue ſigne vnto scottes ſhould flie thirdly cauſed certayne auntient déedes charter brent wherein king scot ſtood bound vnto king englande eſpecially cauſed contra • made betwixt king ſiſter dauid ſonne robert le bruis fourthly vnprofitably conſumed greate deale treaſure found king treaſurie treaſurie earles winchester glocester fiftly appropriating vnto himſelfe wardes mariages england sixtly euill counſeller king quéene mother ouermuch familiarno iuſtice hir died friend simon de burford knight brother sir william burford juſticeanno reg 4 iohn deuerell eſquier deſirous haue made open confeſſion king father baron stafford fulx fitz williams many noble men affirming right inheritance scotland deſired licence ayde king englande recouer ſayd kingdome landes due king hauing regard peace lately made alſo ſiſters ſake quéene scottes woulde ſuffer leade armie lande wherefore ſayde lordes getting fléete shippes entred sea ſayling toward scotland landed kinkehorne earle fife robert bruſe baſtard ſonne robert bruſe tenne thouſand scottes reſiſted néere vnto dunfermeling engliſhmen put flight ſlew many afterward wéete saint lawrence day ſore conflict gledeſmore two thouſand engliſhmen ouercame fortie thouſand scottes reaſon great throng multitude amongſt themſelues fiue earles many thronged death morrow engliſhmen tooke towne saint iohns well furniſhed victualles ſeauen twentith september edward baylioll edvvard baylioll reſigned crovvne scotland king edvvarde england sherifes maior hoſpitall leyceſter crowned king scottes afterward reſigned king edward england remayned vnder protection many poore impotent people prouided thing neceſſarie edward baylioll foreſayde lord noblesanno reg 6 iohn maundeuill continued warres scotland vnto whome came many nobleman realme england voluntarily ſeruing owne charge beſéeged berwike king england gathered great power beſéeged1 •• 2 berwike length yéelded want victualles ſéege scottes ſought many wayes remoue ſame leuying great army ouer scotland▪ comming ſéege could bring purpoſe effect yet ſtill prouoking king army battell wherevpon length two army appoynted fight ſetting vpon halidowne hill commeth forth scottes campe certayne parliament holden yorke decréed king ſhoulde paſſe armie scotlande beyond scottiſh sea thing quickly performed done scottes deſirous fight fielde fayned woulde haue peace obteyne many came aboute feaſt saint michaell chiefely earle daſcels wherevpon came paſſe afterward earle morefe taken priſoner edenborough ſente kept priſoner england richard talbot ranſomed two thouſand fiue hundred markes earle daſcels willing ſhew truly reuolted king england rode againſte scottes ſéege certayne caſtell falling hand enimies bycauſe woulde yéeld ſlayne thirtéene men feaſt saint michaell king continuing ſtill march scotlande dayly entreated meſſengers french king concerning ſome peace made feaſt saint martine edwarde bohune noble man drowned march scotland driuing bootie cattell ouer riuer felte himſelfe danger cauſing guide ride hym water ſmoothneſſe ſtone whereon water ranne guide able take ſure footing fell downe mayſter armed help could come drowned bottome channell iohn archbiſhop canterburie went ouer sea phillip de valoys king france requeſting continuance peace amitie betwixt two kingdomes mainteyned secondly townes caſtels taken time father ſhould reſtored king england thirdly ſayde french king ſhould ſweare neuer giue ayde scottes agaynſt king englande vnder condition two king realmes ſhoulde prepare trauell towardes holy lande fight agaynſt enimies chriſt french king accompted king englande worthie friendſhip ſo long continued warres againſt scottes friendes whome ſayde iuſt men unto ſeconde petition woulde otherwiſe conſente therevnto charge repayde agayne father charles de valoys layde warres gaſcoigne thirdly ſayde friend louer iuſtice equitie whiche woulde neuer ſwarue neyther friendſhip affinitie woulde meanes could moleſt vex breaker peace kingdome king charge exchequer vntill prouided commodiouſlie liue art although statute ſéemed beginning nothing profitable yet ſhort time arte clothing increaſed ſo much thereby twentie time vſed alſo enacted man ſhould time buy cloth made beyond sea none ſhould weare furres ſuch might diſpend one hundred pound yeare iohn clarke william curteis 28▪ september sherifes maior sir iohn poultney draper 28 october▪ feaſt saint michaell parliament holdentho de la anno reg 11 1337 london connocation aſſembled archbiſhop wherein cleargie graunted tenth thrée yeares common fiftenth conſideration king warres hote scotlande alſo reſiſt french king made great bragges ſhewed great crueltie outlawed ſlew empriſoned engliſhmen confiſcated goodes cattayles found kingdome france threatning would reuenged friendes scottes moreouer left ſo muche one towne caſtell county aquitayne poyters ſeized handes wherevpon king edward ſente brabant take vp woolles whiche merchant brought thither made ſale thereof readie money alſo wrote letter french king exhorting woulde continue olde amitie sir walter many béeing embaſſadour king englande deſirous reuenge bloud two engliſhmen ſlayne comming lande freſhe water certayne iſlande called ile agnes nigh vnto flanders cauſed hée founde ſayde iſland put ſworde tooke priſoner earle flanders brother captayne ile certayne iſland men béeing fled churchtho walſ ordering peace betwixte two kingdomes comming westminſter declared king cauſe comming wherevnto king anſwered although without reaſon dyd ſéeme reſtreyne hym right equitie hée ought ſuccéede kingdome hys forefather whyche hys aduerſarie phillip de valoys dyd denye hym expelling murthering empriſoning hys people taking away dukedome aquitayne earledome poyters without cauſe maynteyning scottes rebelles agaynſte hym yet theſe iniuries notwithſtanding hée contented coulde take order quiet enioying aquitayne fées belonging vnto hym whiche hys predeceſſoures enioy moreouer diſmiſſing ayde french king ſhoulde gyue vnto scottes tyme rebellion offered money alſo mariage eldeſt ſonne alſo reſigne ſuche rite intereſt hadde kyngdome france cardinalles béeyng greately comforted aunſwere departed hoping warres nowe ended tooke iohn archbiſhoppe canterburie richarde biſhoppe durham geffrey lorde scrope altogyther wente meſſage kynges aunſwere frenche kyng hauing full authoritie treate conclude à peace theſe béeing ſo reaſonable offer coulde pacifye furious minde frenche king repoſed greate truſt scottes hopyng theyr meanes quite diſpoſſeſſe diſherite king england title walter neale furniſhed came southampton nine clocke ſacked towne towneſmen running away feare breake next day fledde helpe countrey came againſte pirats fought whiche ſkirmiſh ſlayne number thrée hundred pirate togither captayne yong souldioure king sicils ſonne yong man french king giuen whatſoeuer got kingdome england béeing beaten downe certayne man countrey cried rancon notwithſtanding huſbandman layde clubbe till ſlayne hym ſpeaking theſe word yea quoth know well ynough thou art fran • therefore ſhalt thon dye vnderſtoode ſpéech neyther anye ſkill take gentleman priſoners kéepe raunſome wherfore reſidue thoſe gennowayes ſet towne fire brent vp quite fledde galleyes theyr fléeing certaine drowned inhabitantes towne compaſſed ſtrong great wal king ſtill mayntayning warres fraunce euen annuntiation lady▪ • j galleyes▪ approching towne harwich caſt fire therein force whereof contrarie winde ſtayd ſo gret harme done thereby furthermore ſame yeare feaſte pentecoſt certaine pirate normandie geno • ſhipped gallenes pinaces made ſhew ſea southampton woulde haue come alande threatned ſore ſpoyle towne againe perceyuing towneſmen ready reſiſt returned ile wight entred put backe inhabitauntes wherevppon ſayled ſea coaſtes ſéeking lande place leſſe defended came hastings brente fiſhers cotages theyr boates ſlewe many men alſo made greate ſhewes many time againſt ile thanet douer fulkestone thoſe place little harme excepte poore fiſhermen thence ſayled hauens cornewall deuonſhire place much harme fiſher men ſuche ſhippes founde vnmā ned fiered length entred plimouth hauen brent certain great ſhippes great parte towne theſe met hugh curtney earle • • onſhire knight foure ſcoure yeares olde accompanyed manye ſouldiours countrey hauing loſt firſte fronte fewe men whiche ſlaine quarrel french ioyned fighte wyth hande hande ſlaying many pyrates vpon drye lande chaſed reſidue fled take galley able come nigh wading •• ere drowned • ea nūber fiue hundred new • bare downe péece towne wall ſixe pearches length neare place called walkenew • 20▪ men woman drowned u • g •••• saint matthy king edwarde beganne ryde banner diſplayed twelue thouſand men armes againſt frenche king burnyng townes caſtels whereſoeuer came firſt night verye darke geffrey lord scrope one king juſtices led one cardinal wit bertrand de mount fa •• ntyne title ladie vp high tower ſhewing hym whole lande towarde fraunce compaſſe fiftéene league euery place • ſaying theſe wordes ſir doth ſi •• en threed wherwith fraunce compaſſed ſeme broken cardinall aunſwering nothing fel downe deade ſorowe feare thys ſort king edward made • ourneyes france dayly continuing ſpace fiue wéekes cauſed • • ▪ armye trauell ſuch ſort deſtroyed whole countrey cambray tourney vermode • landenewe▪ excepting thoſe city wer ſword wt church caſtels inhabitauntes countrey fledde neyther anye man durſt reſiſt enterpryſes althoughe frenche king gathered greate army within walled city himſelf lying ſtrōg towne saint quintines time brabanders determined returne home againe entred theyr iourney forced vnto partlye wante victual partlye coldneſſe winter whyche▪ grew faſt french king vnderſtanding thereof beganne moue himſelfe hys armye towarde campe king england gladly loking comming called back brabanders hauing receyued letter frō frenche king woulde ioyne battayle againſt hym ſent worde back againe woulde ſtay thrée dayes wherefore fourth daye kyng loking frenche king comming whiche woulde come nearer two mile breaking bridge felling trées king englande mighte followe hym fled paris wherevpon king edwarde returned hanonia brabrant continued almoſt whole winter william thorney roger froſham 28 septe • sherifes maior andrewe awbery grocer 28 october winter time king edwarde grewe greate friendſhippe flemmings prepared themſelues time ſhewe ſelues good ſubiectes vnto ſwearing doe homage fealtie vppon condition would call himſelfe king fraunce token thereof would thence forth giue armes flouredeluces otherwiſe durſte obey feare pope curſe layde vppon time rebelled againſt king fraunce wherefore co •••• friend flemmings conſent noble men agréed vnto tooke vppon name armes king france alſo toke flaunders vnder gouernement people wherof long matter obedient vnto king fraunce conquerer touching title armes aforeſayde frenche king ſayde certayne engliſhmen ſent vnto couſin quoth doth wrongfully beare quartered armes england fraunce whiche matter notwithſtanding doth much diſpleaſe v y• deſcended weaker ſide kin therfore batcheller woulde content graunt licence beare part armes fraunce wheras ſeales letter patent nameth hymſelf well king englande fraunce doth ſet firſte quarter armes leopardes quarter liles doth grieue v muche making apparaunt beholder little iſlande englande preferred great kingdome france unto ſir iohn shordich knighte made aunſwere cuſtome men thoſe dayes ſet title armes theyr progenitor armes title righte deſcending mother thus dutie reaſonanno reg 14 ſayde doth lord king englande preferre hys armes king edwarde thus buſied mariner cinque port embarked themſelues pinaces ſmal beates wel appointed feaſt hillarie arriued bononie vpō ſea coaſt weather ſo cloudie darke could ſcarſely perceyued hauen brent lower towne nintéene galley four great ſhippes twentie ſmall boates theyr tackling ſuche houſes ſcituate nyghe ſea coſt amongſt one great houſe full dare ſayles weapon neceſſaries ſufficiente furniſh ninetéene galley men thē ye length ſkirmiſh betwixt townes men engliſhmen many land men ſlaine beginning februarie king edwarde returned englande came vnto gaunt quéene layiohn gaunt parliament • vveſtminſter 1340 childbed hir fourth ſonne named iohn helde parliament westminster▪ wherein temporalty granted hym euery ninth fléece wool euery ninth lambe euery ninth ſheafe ſorts corne cleargie gaue newe tenth immediatety eaſter earles saliſburie suffolke accompanyed fewe men gaue aſſault towne lile flaunders town confederate french king chaſing frēch men far within gate percolices let fal beſet multitude men armes taken conueyed fraunce fettered ſhackeled yron although •• orne true priſoners drawen cart middeſt euery citie towne uillage hamlet greate ſhoutes cryes rayling length béeing brought preſence french king woulde haue moſt ſhamefully ſlaine bin otherwiſe perſwaded counſel king boemia king edward kept whitſontide ipſwich intended thence take paſſage flaunders certified french king ſent great nauie spaniſh ſhips alſo whole fléete fraunce ſtoppe paſſage cauſed ſhips cinque port aſſembled ſo fléete great ſmall 260 ſhippes wherefore thurſdaye matiuity saint iohn baptiſt hauing proſperous winde began ſayle nexte daye euen ſayde feaſte eſcried french fléete lying swine hauen wherefore king cauſed fléete come ancker next day feaſt iohn baptiſt • arly morning french fléet deuided themſelues thrée part remoued themſelues myle approching towards king fléete whiche king perceyued nine clocke hauing winde ſunne backe ſet forwarde met enimies woulde haue wiſhed wherewithall whole fléete gaue terrible ſhoute ſhowre arrowes long woodden bowes ſo powred downe french men thouſandes ſlaine méeting length cloſed came hand blowes pike powle ax • ſwordes ſome threw ſtones toppes ſhippes wherewith many brained greatneſſe heigth spaniſh ſhippes cauſed many engliſh men ſtrike many ſtroke vaine ſhort french ſhippes ouercome al men ſpente firſte parte engliſhmen entred tooke french ſhippes chayned togyther ſuche ſort coulde ſeparated one another ſo fewe engliſhmen kepte part fléete wherfore ſet vpon ſecond ward greate difficultie gaue charge whiche done ſooner ouercome firſte french men leauing ſhips many leapt ouer borde engliſhmen hauing thus ouercome firſt ſeconde parte fléete hauing night drawyng partly want light partly wearie determined take ſome reſt till next morning wherefore night xxx ſhippes thirde crewe fled awaye greate ſhippe called iames deepe thinking haue carried away certaine ſhip sandwiche belonging prior canterburie ſtayde saylers ſo ſtoutely defended themſelues helpe earle huntingdon ſaued themſelues theyr ſhip frenchman fight continued al night morning norman ouercome takē wer found ſhippe aboue 400 men ſlaine moreouer king vnderſtanding xxx ſhips fledde hée ſent fortie ſhips well appointed followe ouer made iohn crabe gouernour good ſpéede knowen firſte companye ſhippes taken founde theſe conquered ſhippes deniſe george chriſtopher blacke cocke whiche ſhips taken erenchmen sluce carried normandie number ſhippes warre taken 200 30 barge number enimies ſlaine drowned aboue fiue twentie thouſande engliſhmen foure thouſand among foure knightes ſir thomas mortimer king couſin ſir thomas latimer ſon ſir william butteler seortkorne ſir thomas poynings ſame time scot came great power englande burning ſpoyling march fire ſworde returning wyth great bootie cattayle neuer withſtoode nobilitie march common people wold ſuffer ſo paſſe ſet vpon toke theyr bootie ſlewe manye toke 80 scot good reputation whome kept raunſome whiche fact noble menne march highly diſpleaſed lammas certaine french pirats gaue aſſault ile wight ſodainly entred ſir peter ruſſel knight méeting people ile put backe made flée ſtaying manye ſkirmiſh ſayde knight wounded wherof dyed theſe pirate ſayled thēce toward coaſt deuonſhire comming teygnemouth ſette fire towne brent thence ſayled towardes plimouth towne ſo defended coulde hurte burnt farmes fayre place nigh adioyning toke knight priſoner caried ſame yeare king edward beſieged turney vpon entreatie made frenche truce taken michaelmaſſe til midſommer wherfore king comming gaunt flaunders ſtayed looking money england came adam lucas bartholmew mari 28 september sherifes maior andrew auburie grocer 28▪ october king edwarde eight men fayning hée woulde ride abrode pleaſure ſecretly came • elande taking ſhippe ſayled thrée dayes thrée nightes saint andrewes day night aboute cock crowing entred tower londō water wayted earle northampton nicholas cā tilopo reignalde cobham giles de bello campo iohn de bello▪ campo knightes william killesby phillippe weſton prieſtes earely morning ſent chā cellour treaſurer juſtices london biſhop chichester chauncellour biſhop couentrie treaſurer put office minding alſo haue ſent flaunders haue ben pledge money owed saint paule michael wathe henrie stafforde certaine exchequer maiſter iohn thorpe many moe king commaunded impriſoned ſome one place ſome another neyther woulde ſuffer diſcharged thence til hée throughlye pacified anger conceyued ſendyng money whiche ſhoulde haue ſerued ſiege torney yeare chriſtmas henrie biſhoppe lincolne geffrey lord scrope chiefe juſticiar kyng chiefe counſeller dyed gaunt anno reg 15 king edwarde kept chriſtmaſſe gildforde great juſting reading alſo candlemaſſe hée kept greate iuſting langley honor noble men vaſcon • trayned vp feates war made robert de bourſier knight lord chancellour englande robert parnike knighte treaſurer one ſuccéede alſo ſent juſticiars thatiuſtice tral • baſton ſhoulde ſet euerye ſhire enquyre concerning collectours tenthes fiftéenthes wool ouerſée al officer bicauſe citie london would ſuffer ſuch officer ſhould ſet juſtices within theyr citie inquiſitours ſuche matter contrarie theyr liberty king prouided thoſe juſtices ſhoulde holde theyr seſſions tower london make inquiſition domages londoner bycauſe londoner woulde aunſwere vntill theyr liberty fully confirmed neyther anye ſuche confirmation coulde eyther king chauncellour touching writ charter towre roſe thereof ſuche greate tumulte juſticies appointed ſit fayned woulde holde ſeſſion till eaſter wherevpon king highly offended ſayde tumult deſirous know name rayſed coulde vnderſtande certaine meane perſons claymed theyr liberty wherevpon king pacified troubled minde forgaue offence committed londoner juſtices breaking vp theyr ſitting touching ſayde place1 • 41 parliament london yeare within quindene eaſter parliamente holden london wherein earles noble realme common others amongſt thing requeſted charter called magna carta carta foresta liberty béelonging churche kingdome ſhould obſerued officer chiefe ruler king houſe ſhoulde choſen péeres realme parliament theſe peticions king would confirme could abide heare talked beginning moneth julye kyng edwarde receyued letter lodowike duke bauarie vſurper romaine empyre whyche pretendyng friendſhippe betwixt phillip french king hée ſignifyed thoſe warres whyche king england begonne fraunce greately miſlike therefore deſired ſhoulde concorde amitie betwixte king realmes whyche bée performed offered beſtowe ſome labour requeſtyng kyng edwardes letter aucthoritie thereof treate conclude truce one yeare twaine towarde ende whiche letter addeth theſe wordes deputation lieutenauntſhip whiche gaue vnto diuerſ • ſundry cauſes reuoke dated frankeford fourtéenth june ſeauen twentith • ure raign empire fourtéenth letter king edwarde wrote inſcription ſorte followeth renoumed prince lodowicke grace god romaine emperour alwayes auguſtus edwarde ſame grace king fraunce englande lorde plowman tho de la king edwarde gaue earledome cambridge iohn lord henault vncle quéene phillip keptanno reg 16 feaſt saint katherine newcastel chriſtmas alſo untill time dauid king scottes threatned themſelues william mountacute earle saliſburie hauing gotten1342 greate fléete entred iland belonging scotlande moſt victoriouſlye conquered ſame ile called ile man kyng gaue conquerour franckelye fréely poſſeſt cauſed hymking man called crowned king ile king edward returning towards ſouth part kept ſolemn torneymentes dunstable beyng accompanyed wyth 230 knightes ſame yeare parliamente westminster wherein archbiſhoppe canterburie reconcyled king archbiſhoppe ſware althoughe kyng hys counſell conſente hadde done homage french king dukedome aquitaine earledome poytowe yet neuer conſented therto anye hurte preiudice kyng hys counſel myghte incurre fauoure ſéeke pleaſe french king preſente tyme thoughte beſte done obtayning peace alſo profit kyng realme parliament king general ſuruey vvhole realme england fée value one hundred ſhillings name ſuche ſhoulde enrolled giuen vp recorde alſo certaine put aucthoritie ſignifie howe many ſufficient able bowman euerye ſhire alſo ſufficient men able beare armour defence theyr country ſée practiſed ſuche kinde weapon wherein beſte ſkill thus aſſembled part realme ſpeciallye ſuche lawfull age commaundemente giuen ſhoulde readye kyngs commaundemente fyghte agaynſte theyr enimies king edwarde noble perceyuing derogationro de aueſbury gual homingford done realme ſuch reſeruations prouiſions collation benefice pope practiſed england wrote requiring ſith church englande bene founded endued noble worthy men ende people might inſtructed people owne language beyng ſo farre coulde vnderſtande defaultes yet hys predeceſſours bene vſed diuerſe reſeruations prouiſions collation made diuerſe perſons ſome ſtraungers yea ſome enimies realme whereby money profit carried forth theyr cure prouided according founder mindes therefore vpon due conſiderations therof ſignifyed coulde ſuffer ſuch enormity longer therefore beſought reuoke ſuch reſeruations prouiſions collation wholy auoyde ſuche ſlaunders miſchieues harmes mighte enſue cure might committed perſons méet exerciſes ſame beſéeching wythout delay ſignify intention ſith ment beſtow diligence remedie matter ſée redreſſe might giuen ful parliament westminster xviij may yeare 1343 iohn steward iohn ayleſham 28 september sherifes maior iohn hamonde 28 october many called ayde king againſt scot ready contributed money wherewith king might hyre ſouldiours place remayned home king edward cauſed called togither great many anno reg 18 tho walſing 1344 round table vvindſore▪ artificer caſtell windſore began builde houſe whiche called rounde table floure wherof center midde point compaſſe hundred foote whole diameter 200 foote circunference thereof 600 foote thrée quarter ſame time phillip de valoys king fraunce buyldedround table fraunce scala croni rounde table countrey ende mighte allure menne warre germanie italie ſo kéepe kyng englandes rounde table kyng edwarde ſuccour iohn mountfort duke ofth • de la brytaine wife child remayned king cuſtodie ſent earles northampton oxforde hugh spencer richard talbot knightes maiſter william kilesby clearke euerye one hauing vnder many mē armes archer britaine entred thereinto deſpight al theyr enimies whych reſiſted making many conflictes toke well walled townes diuerſe fortreſſes caſtelles aſſaulte ſurrender whiche meanes whole countrey vnder theyr ſubiection conquering till came towne morleis charles de bloys mette wyth greate armye therfore champion grounde nygh vnto morley thebattayle morley two armyes made greate moſte ſtoute battayle wherin worthineſſe ſortes dyd full well appeare fought ſo ſtout ſides firſt conflict chaunced like bene ſéene chiefe captaines charles de bloys frenche king hadde giuen dukedome countrey william de bohune earle northamton defence ye right iohn de mountfort naturall heire duke lande king englande made generall ouer army engliſh men foughte ſo long wyth hande ſtrokes fielde daye manne lyar coulde giue prayſe one thrée tymes daye beyng wearied ſides wythdrewe themſelues take breathe fell speare ſhielde ſworde targe ye ende right worthy ſtoute charles de bloys men fléeing away alſo forced flée himſelfe wherevppon many ſlaine ſides victorie fell engliſhmen geffrey wichingham thomas legge 28 sep sherifes maior iohn hamond 28 october king edwarde ſente ouer henrie earle darbie ſon earle lancaster couſin fiue hundered men armes amongſt earle ofro auesbery▪ anno reg 19 penbroke walter de many manye archer gaſcoigne ralph baron stafforde seneſhal gaſcoigne come thyther ſayde earle made fiftie knightes armye wanne manye walled townes caſtelles making many worthy ſkirmiſhes length towne dagu • lown aſſaulte kéeping wherof appointed ralph stafford afterward appointed thrée iourneys toward townes eſpecially brigerecke ſo called ſtrength thereof alſo called chamber fraunce alſo ye town saint iohn de laruel many greate ſtrong townes well fortified great toyles diuerſe daungerous aſſaultes wan earle darbie ſouldiours vndermining tower wals ſayde towne ſore aſſaulted whiche defended thus conquered city townes caſtelles fortreſſes number one hundred fiftie bringing greate parte gaſcoigne vnder ſubiection euen tolouſe vnto whiche citie domage neyther inhabitantes therof made wonderfully afrayde certaine tolde ſayeth aucthour fear ſuch religious people conſtrayned beare armour prior carmelitetho de la frier lady tolouſe hauyng banner ladye golde ſet fielde ſiluer diſplayed ſame prouoking thereby many take armour ſecond ſonday lent earles fully fraught bootie priſoners gold ſiluer returned towardes burdeaux iohn de valoys eldeſt ſonne french king accompanyed great number hyred dutche ſouldiours beſieged towne agnlowne captaines thereof earle stafforde ſo entrenched ſame towne without greate daunger engliſhmen coulde haue acceſſe vnto earle darby bet awaye beſieged citie e • ſoones new victualled ſame notwithſtanding able raiſe ſiege bycauſe hadde ſo entrenched themſelues without towne refuſing fight fielde would aunſwere came pitch fielde beſiege town wherefore continued ſame ſiege vntil decollation saint iohn vnderſtanding king england chaced father phillip ſore grecie fearing ſhoulde come verye late ayde hys father gaue vppe ſiege ſetting tentes fire fled darke earle stafforde wyth hys power purſued cut theyr tayle tooke greate manye theyr horſſes priſoners retourned certaine bowman muſtered england appointed ſente ouer ſea commyng ouer layde garriſon fordefence countrey alſo twenty thouſande ſackes wooll graunted king moreouer geffrey de harecourte norman came king requiring ayd againſt french king wrongfully withhelde hys landes firſt comming fealtie ſware homage king edward afterward reuolted thomas hatfielde king secretary meanes oftho walſing kyngs letter pope admitted byſhoppe durham certaine cardinalles ſayde ſayd thomas light perſon lay man pope anſwered truly king england timeanſvvere pope made requeſt aſſe ſhould haue obteined ſame yeare dyed adam tarleton biſhop winchester bin long time blind whome ſuccéeded william edendon treaſourer england man founded monaſterie edendon religiousliber edendon bréethren whereof called bonhomes ſame yeare dyed henry earle lancaster father henry earle darby buryed leycester monaſterie channons king olde yong quéenes preſent archbiſhops biſhops earles baron manner lande whoſe ſonne gaſcoigne chiualrous actes yeare scottes number thirtie thouſande william dowglas leader entred westmerland brent carelile penreth many townes wherefore biſhop carelile thomas lucy robert ogle great number compaſſed night ſeaſon lightes noyſe ſo diſquieted neuer durſt go victual giue bodyes ſléepe laſt alexander stragan ſtoutely prepared go victualles whome biſhopscots ouercome robert ogle mette ſpeare killesby clerke euery one theſe leading great armie souldioures well appoynted embarqued wayted winde firſt june fifth july thentho de la more▪ tho walſing ro de • esbury hauing good winde beganne make sayle number one thouſande shippes burthen pinaces thirtéenth day july landed hogges normandy ſhore sea king edwarde made eldeſt ſonne knighte alſo prince wale immediately prince made knightes mortimere montacute roſe night king lodged towne hogges next day towne brent armiehogges normandy brent night following king edward lodged mercels ſtayde fiue dayes whiche time countrey towne barbefleete men conſumed fire thence departed veloygus ſet fire went senet combe de mount whiche nigh sea garantam thence serius saint lewes paſſing along vnto towne turney waſting fire night kyng lodged carmalin gerin religious houſe belonging vnto cane leauing nothing behinde vnſpoyled afterward made aſſaulte entred citiecane normandy beſeeged edvvard third cane making entrance bridge whiche ſtrongly defended ſlayne hundreth thrée fortie knightes among whiche earles ewe camberlin de tankeruill dyuers captaynes whyche ſente england lady abateſſe cane citie ſlayne aboue one thouſande thrée hundred citie armie remayned ſixe dayes ſpoyle thereof ſolde thoſe marriners whiche followed coaſt king went wente monaſterie towne toward ſtrong thyng well defended afterwarde came vnto argon nighte burning ſtill wente till came citie licens founde cardinalles clarimount naples one archbiſhop offered king treatie peace king continued thrée dayes refuſing treate peace wente lestentnoland towne briue lodged new burge selelefe vpon sayne welchmen •• amme water segan béeing reſiſted inhabitantes ſlewe many paſſed nigh towne caſtell pount darch béeing ſtrong place ſautable thys nighte lodged lury vpon segan nigh vnto good towne louars whiche burne paſſed towne caſtell gaylon whiche tooke brente lodged lingeuie whiche nigh good towne caſtell vernon whiche touched firſt entred france ſame night brente caſtell roche blanche whiche ſtandeth ſide segan lodged fremble vpon segan paſſed towne de maunt lodging night oporne nexte day paſſed frigmas nexte daye good towne poecie béeyng bridge paſſe ouer riuer segan frenche ſpoyled kyng cauſed bée reedifyed nexte daye came vnto amia thrée greate army appoynted kéepe king paſſing way hée making greate conflicte ſlewe thrée hundreth firſte charge put reſidue flighte ſpoyled tentes burning thrée hundreth two carte and▪ wagon ladē croſſebowes quarels armor victual king ſtaying two dayes went greſile nigh vnto pountoys antell next day paſſed citie wenneys touched ſo tr • ſolours water lodged next day wan towne poys brent caſtell thence went aregnus achen lodged next day came noell vpon sea ſide frenchman dabuile countrey came f •• rdes ſide hinder paſſage whome king ſore conflict enimies put worſſe two thouſand ſlayne towne croytoy taken brent aboue thrée hundred germanes ſlayne next day followed king riuer banckes ſide king hoſt lodged came trauelling phillip de valoys french kingtho de la king boheme malegre leading army men innumerable deuided eight great battels king edward ſent french king offering frée paſſage ouer foorde would come chooſe place apt fight field phillip would fight went another place paſſage morrow king edward remoued creſifield ye armie french king met king therefore ſet ſonne prince wale gouerne vaward middle warde earle ofbattayle crecy northampton third tooke guide himſelfe army frenchman deuided nine troupe vaward committed king boheme french king commaunded banner called oliflam french banner oyly flame ſignifyed mercy • han fire oyle ſet vp time lawfull vnder payne death take man ſaue life banner might differ ſtandard lillie gold broade ſide king edward commanded banner erected dragon ſignified fierceneſſe crueltie turned againſt lillie theſe army thus appoynted ſtoode fielde one clocke vntill euening aboute sunne ſetting army iuſted beganne ſound trumpettes giue ſigne battayle themſelues felt force engliſh archer quarels fell ſhort great way moreouer footemen placed among owne horſemen gaulled engliſh ſhotte arrowes ouerrunne troden vpon great outcrie made starres whole forme array broken fighting engliſh armed men beaten downe poleax ſo terrible bickering prince wale ſixtéene yeares olde ſhewed wonderfull towardneſſe laying hotely speare shield battell dured thrée partes night time frenchman gaue fiue great aſſaultes againſte oure men length conquered ranne away morrow came four army freſh souldioures french ſide making ſemblant though part ſuffered harme come againſt engliſhmen gaue freſh battayle ſide engliſhmen withſtoode ſtoutely ſharp conflict forced foe flie chacing togither ſlayne conflict ſlew thrée thouſand men ſayd two dayes ſlayne battayle crecy king boheme maiorica archbiſhop zanxinus biſhop noyone duke lorayne burbon earles alanſon harecourt awmarle sauoy nois mountbilliard niuars flanders graund priour hoſpitall france foure thouſand men armes beſide common ſouldioures without number third day king edward paſſed abbey mounteney next day came towne mountney thence nunrie saint ioce paſſed ouer foorde came newcastell ſtayde two dayes thence came caleis preſently entrenched beſéege beingking edvvarde beſeeged caleis fourth day september iohn croydon william clopton 28 september sherifes maior geffrey witchingham 28 october french king meane time ſent number genoways hired souldiours vnto dauid king scottes earneſtly requeſting would inuade england force wherefore ſeauenth october mightie power entred england paſſing along berwike ſtrongly defended engliſhmen ſo ranging ouer forreſt alnewike wonne certayne mannour place called luden belonging lord walter wake yéelded himſelfe conditionsir vvalter vvake ſonnes cruelly ſlayne scottes ranſomed selby knight béeing deſirous law armes ſaue life taken knowne dauid commanded ſlayne selby intreated mought bée brought aliue preſence dauid hauing obteyned requeſt falleth downe dauid requeſting life raunſome agayne adiudged dye malice tirant ſuche commaunded two child poore knight bée ſtrangled ſight father afterwarde himſelfe béeing almoſt madde ſorrow beheaded thence scottes paſſed forwarde waſting along countrey wherein many farmes belonging monaſterie durham comming within two mile durham tooke certayne monkes kept priſoners raunſome making couenant reſidue certayne ſumme money corne redéeme theyr mannoures ſpoyling engliſhmen march fléeing face enimie william de la zouch archbiſhop yorke uizegerent king march calling togither biſhop carelile earle anguiſe lord mowbrey lord percy lord neuell north ayde togither archer lancaſhire went towards armie scottes euen saint luke mette place called bewre parke • éere neuels croſſe scottiſh nation accuſtomed flée withſtoode ſtoutly hauing headpéeces head target armes preaſing ſore vpon engliſhmen abode brunt archer men armes forefront gaue enimies many deadly woundes marſhall scottes earle patrike charge rereward perceyued men beaten downe fledde away priuie cowardlineſſe fled reſidue scottes continuing faithfully theyr king ſtoode like round tower kéeping hym middle ſo continued till ſcarſe fortie left aliue one coulde eſcape away length dauid king béeing taken priſoner iohn copland reſidue aboute béeing taken or▪ ſlayne engliſhmen purſued chace whiche fledde ſlaying taking reaſon two deadly woundes head arrowes ſeconde january brought vp conuayed westminster y• tower london ſight people lodged blacke nouke ſayd tower néere conneſtables gard kept theſe thing done england king wasanno reg 21 tho de la buſied ſéege calleys towne ſcituated march artoys cloſed aboute double wall double ditche hard ſhore engliſhecalleis deſcribed sea right ouer againſt caſtell douer longing ſame towne hauen wherein shippes may lie ſafe withoute danger towne ſometime caſtell thereof ſtrongly built force valiantneſſe romanes iulius caleys builded romanes caeſar broughte france vnder ſubiection hée built calleys artoys caſtell chipstowe venedocia southwales caſtel douer kent timecaſtels chepſtovv vvales douer kent built romanes conquered britayne king edward caſt ditch aboute camp layde nauie shippes againſt caleis hauen intente frenchman ſhould make inuaſions vpon souldioures neyther within receyue victualles water norman pirats ſundry time tooke fiftéene shippes whereof ſome caried away owne occupying brent sir thomas haclut sir william borton knight ſailing england taken priſoners sea king edward hauing fortified ſéege lay without giuing1347 aſſault knowing poſſible fight enimies without great loſſe men conſidering deapth ditch heigth walles neyther woulde erect engins againſte towne wanted firme grounde vpon place beſides ſhould beate downe walles yet ditch ſo déepe full ſalt water let euery ſide able withſtande world little ſtrength defence ſide towne bolloners wont victuall caleis along sea ſide eſpecially shippes could ſuffered paſſe sea alongſt ſhore ſmall boates earle northampton made rampire wherewith kept awaya rampire builded caleis beate backe ſuch boates afterwarde admirall france purpoſed come shippes warre fight againſt engliſh shippes lay ſéege thinking meane time whileſt fighting ſmall boates ſhould paſſe caleis victualles ſayd earle northampton méeting valiantly put flight ſéege ſuch ſort feaſt natiuitie lady whole winter great part ſommer ſtill waxing ſtronger ſtronger monday next feaſt saint iames frenche king came caſtell gyſnes eldeſt ſon iohn french king came reiſe ſeege caleis king ſonne boheme great power haue remoued ſéege caleis alſo emperour promiſing oth would remoue ſéege eyther warre peace leaſt would victuall beſéeged came armie towards engliſh camp lodged ſcarſe mile thence requeſting meſſengers treatie peace ſent duke detenes earles bulone darminake parleing duke lancaster earles northampton huntington touching truce could obteyne conſente whervpon exerciſed little warlike iuſting returned tentes ſecond day following french king offered king england day battellthe french king profered battayle king certayne condition accepted gladlye meane ſeaſon beſéeged made knowne ſtate french king ſignes token firſt comming within towne ſet vp auntient chiefeſt tower caſtell alſo ſet banner duke earles france little ſhutting euening made great light toppe one higheſt tower towards armie frenchman therewithall made greate ſhoute noyſe wyth trumpet drommes ſecond night made like ſomewhat leſſe third night ſmall fire giuing forth therewith ſorrowfull voyce ſignifying thereby ſtrength touching kéeping towne quite ſpent done ſame night tooke flagges antients except standart laſt day battayle drew againſt tyme came england dutchland toward helpe king edwarde ſeauentéene thouſande fighting men wherevpon french king betimes morning thethe french king fleeth ſecond day auguſt making fire tentes fledde whoſe tayle duke lancaster earle northampton wil norwell cutting ſlewe tooke many caleis perceyued thys tooke standart downe greate ſorrow caſt tower downe ditch saterday following iohncaleis yeelded de vienna captayne man ſkilfull warlike affayres opening gate towne came thethe order hovv caleis vvas yeelded king england ſitting little nagge lame féete could well goe halter necke burgeſſes ſouldiours following foote bare headed bare footed hauing halter neckes captayne comming thus king offered warlike ſword vnto chiefeſt prince armes amongſt chriſtian king one taken towne mightieſt chriſtian king noble cheualrie deliuered keyes towne thirdly requeſting pitie aſked pardon deliuered ſword peace wherewith ſhould giue right iudgement ſpare forbeare humble lowly chaſten proude harted king receyuing offered ſente captayne fiftéene knightes many burgeſſes england enriching large giftes common ſort people ſuch found towne ſomewhat refreſhed king almes commanded ſafe conducted caſtell guiſnes guiſnes taking towne caleis souldiours king commandemente september sherifes maior tho de la great peſtilēce tho wa • ſing iohn loueken fiſhmonger 28 october beganne amongſt eaſt indian tartarians certayne peſtilence length waxed ſo generall infecting middle region ayre ſo greatly deſtroyed saraſins turkes sirians palestinian gretians wonderfull rather incredible death ſo much thoſe people béeing excéedingly diſmayde terrour thereof conſulted amongſt themſelues thought good receyue chriſtian faith sacramentes intelligence chriſtians whiche dwelte ſide gréekiſh sea ſo greatly common cuſtome troubled wyth ſickneſſe mortalitie length terrible ſlaughter paſſed ouer thoſe countreys ſide alpes thence partes france called heſperia ſo order along germany dutchland ſeauenth yeare beganne came england firſt beganne townes port ioyning sea coaſtes dorſetſhire euen countreys made countrey quite voyde inhabitantes ſo almoſt none left aliue thence paſſed deuonſhire somerſetſhire euen vnto bristowe raged ſuche ſort glocesterſhiremen woulde ſuffer bristowmen haue anye acceſſe vnto countrey anye meanes length came gloce •• yea oxforde london finally ſpread ouer england ſo waſted ſpoyled people ſcarce tenth perſon ſortes lefte aliue church yardes
