almoſt two yeares ended without concluſion peace truce richard lion william woodhouſe 28 septem sherifes maior anno reg 49 1 • 75 iohn walworth fiſhmonger 28 october ſixtéenth aprill died iohn haſtings earle penbroke comming englande raunſomed himſelfe great maſſe money neuer payde iſle constantine deliuered french king great detriment englande whiche cauſe afterward sir iohn anſley appeached thomas catrington trenſon great heate england ſo many botha ho • e ſommer men woman died thereof iohn hadle william newport 28 september sherifes maior anno reg 50 good parliament iohn ward grocer 28 october parliament commonly called good parliament holden westminster which▪ subſidie demaunded anſwere made peter de la mare proloc • tor parliamente king néeded ſubſtance poore subiects well faithfully gouerned offered proue effectually promiſed found king néede ſubiects ſhould readie moſt gladlye help according power knightes required haue lord latimer with1376 remoued king whome ſayd giue euill counſell whiche done certaine prelate earles ordeyned gouerne king olde man endured long common alſo requeſted haue remoued king houſe certayne proude woman called alice perce ouermuch familiaritie ſhe king cauſe muche miſchiefe realme ſhe excéeding manner woman ſate king juſtices ſometimes doctours conſiſtories perſwading diſſwading defence matter requeſting thing contrarie law honeſtie great diſhonor king alſo richard lious adam bury citizen london adam bury late maior richard lion late sherife goldſmith accuſed commōs diuers fraudes deceipts done king richard lion money wiſely compoūd eſcaped conuayde himſelfe flanders sir peter de la mere tolde troth inſtance alice pierce condemned perpetuall priſon notingham eyght day june prince edward departed ofblacke prince deceaſſed adam meri • life time floure chiualrie buried canterbury king edwarde created richard ſonne prince edward earle chester duke cornewall prince wale bycauſe king waxed féeble ſicklie betooke rule lande iohn gaunt duke lancaster earle warwickes men made great ſpoyle theeuisham ſpoyled abbey euiſham tenementes thereto belonging beating ſleying many abbot men king agréement made betwixt full ſatiſfaction iohn northampton robert laund 28 septem sherifes maior adam staple mercer 28 october parliament london granted ſuche taxe neuer heard wit euery lay perſona great taxe man woman aboue age fourtéene yeares four penny euen religious perſon man woman eccleſiaſticall promotion twelue penny promotion four penny except four order begging frier alſo statute good parliament diſanulled abiured perſons reſtored londoner iohns inne ipres ſtirred vpthe londoner meant haue ſlayne duke lancaſter furie ſought kill lancaster certayne proud word ſpake againſt biſhop brent manour suuoy b ſtaid rage called wood saterday duke fledde kenington beſide lamheth wher richard prince remayned made lamentable complaintes vpon citizen forthe maior alderman london depoſed king cauſed adam staple maior put downe place nicholas brember elected 21 day march alſo alderman depoſed ſet place sir iohn minſterworth knight drawne hanged time roſe vp oxford certayne northren adam meri iohn vvicklefe man called iohn wickleffe doctour diuinitie scholes elſewhere held certayne concluſions contrarie publike ſtate eſpecially againſt monkes religious men poſſeſſions companion dwelling togither apparelled long garmentes downe héeles ruſſet going barefooted c king edward ended life manour shene theking edvvard deceaſſed nevv abbey iohn rouſe xxj day june yeare 1377 raigned 50 yeares four monethes odde dayes▪ whoſe body buried westminster builded abbey lady grace tower london newly builded stephen chappell westminster caſtell windſore nunrie dertford alſo founded maſondieu poore towne caleis ¶ richard burdeaux richarde ſecond borne anno reg 1 burdeaux ſonne prince edward eleuen yeares olde beganne raigne xxj daye june yeare lord god 1377 crowned westminster ſixtéenth day july hand simon sudbury archbiſhop canterburie coronation ſet agréement betwéene duke lancaster citizen london ſet libertie sir peter de la mere aforeſayd inſtigation alice perce caſt priſon beautie bountie liberalitie farre paſſed progenitours ouermuch giuen reſt quietneſſe louing little déedes armes yong moſt ruled yong counſell regarded nothing counſels ſage wiſe men realme thing turned land great trouble himſelfe extreame miſerie theſe uerſes declared king firſt beganne raigne lawes neglected werevox clamantis iohn gower wherefore good fortune forſooke thearth quake feare people alſo whome pollde againſt rebell time doth yet bewayle woe chronicle tell fooliſh counſell lewde yong receyue graue aduiſe aged head reiect leaue greedie thirſt coyne ſome ſubiectes accuſed gayne goodes hand thus realme abuſed king coronation made foure earles thomas earles created woodstocke king edwardes yongeſt ſonne earle buckingham northampton gaue 1000 markes yearely treaſurie til prouided land value thomas moubray earle notingham gifford angoliſme gaſcoigne earle huntington whome likewiſe gaue 1000 markes yeare treaſurie till prouided landes value henry percy earle northumberland peter day frenchman 50 ship arriuedthe tovvne rye ſpoyled ile vvight taken rye ſpoyled towne brent ſame time scottes brent towne rokeſborow kalendes september frenchman tooke ile wight ſauing caſtell sir hugh tirell kept manfully frenchman ſpoyled countrey tooke 1000 markes inhabitant ſpare houſes vnbrent taking ſaid ile frenchman entring theirthe frenchman lye vvinchelſea galley againe coaſted sea ſtrond till came ouer againſt towne winchelſea vnderſtanding abbot battaill come thither defend ſent ſhould redéeme towne abbot anſwered néeded redéeme thing loſt frenchman requeſted might ſente forth fight mā man number trie matter view armes abbot anſwered religious man therefore lawfull admitte anye ſuche petition came thither fighte defend towne countrey theſe thing heard frenchman ſuppoſing abbot people wanted courage aſſayled towne ſuch inſtruments warre caſt forth farre whereof plentie ceaſſing noone till euening proweſſe ye abbot ſuch french preuayled nothing meane time whileſt buſie thus winchelſea ſent part company vntothe tovvne haſtings brent frēchmen hastings finding towne almoſt emptie brent frenchman perceyuing could good winchelſea departed thence left found andrew pikeman nicholas twiford 28 sept sherifes maior sir nicholas brembar grocer 28 october ſame yeare frenchman comming vp y• towne rotingdon suſſex néere towne lewes wheretho walſing prior lewes ſmall companie met bythe prior levves taken frenchman multitude frenchman came vpon taken ledde shippes two knightes wéete sir iohn falleſley sir thomas cheynie squire called iohn brokes died battayle almoſt hundred engliſhmen frenchman therefore nauie returned home 37 galley eyght caruales spayne certayne barkes ſtreightwayes therefore came land ſome went vnto ſéege arde treaſon alwayes familiar kéeper caſtell almayne wéete lord gunney deliuering towne ſtreight got caſtell alſo ſame kéeper taken sir hugh caluerley kéeper caleis ſent england committed priſon parliament holden london ended saint andrewes tide whiche parliamente alice peres baniſhed lande hir moueable goodesalice peres banished forfeited king vſe graunted king cleargie twotvvo tenthes granted cleargie tenthes payde yeare condition thenceforth king ſhould extort ſubiectes ſuch petition demaundes liue owne continue warre aunſweared owne good pertayning crowne ſufficed finding1378 houſe mayntayning warres ſame beſtowed fitte miniſters kéeping money two citizen london appointed william walworth iohn philpot engliſh men hearing number spaniſhe ſhippes remayne ſluce wante winde aſſembling great companye armed men great nauie meant take ſeas chiefe captaynes thomas woodſtocke erle buckingham duke brytaine lord latimer lord robert fitz walter ſir robert knowles many valiaunt perſonages entred sea taſted fortune diſfauourable tempeſtuous winde roſe theyr ſhippes ſcattered ſunder theyr maſtes broken downe theyr ſayles rent many ſmall veſſels victualler drowned length ſhippes got togither againe arriued englande nowe rigged eftſoones freight men sea go y• ſame time ſir hugh caluerley making iourney towards bulloign found barge y• hauen ye town y• bare ye name towne another french king xxvj veſſels leſſe great part ſuburbes bulloigne cauſed diſpoyled taking whatſoeuer deſired certayne priſoners droue afore alſo gret bootie ſhéepe beaſtes whiche founde paſturing néere towne might well ſerue victuall caleis great time recouered ſame day caſtel marke negligence bin loſt engliſh fléete whereof ſpake returned without great good ſucceſſe toke eyght spaniſh ſhippes brytiſh coaſtes neare brest takē buſineſſe bin ſo well done pretended therefore fléete returned home ſo toſſed ſtormes contrarie weather inteſtine diſcorde ſéemed wanted among god fauour lorde percy fléete remaining mending ſhippes whileſt abrode went ſea wyth great ſhip ſome ſmaller veſſels méeting fiftie ſhips laden french ware marchandize whiche ſome flaunders ſome spaine ſet al beholding bolde enterprice thinking hadde ſome ayde hande gaue ouer make reſiſtaunce ſo xxviij eſcaping flight xxij yéelded themſelues ſayd thomas lord percy sir hugh caluerley power ſecretly armed wente towne staple fayre come manye merchauntmen bulloigne mutterel amience paris falling vnarmed ſlewe many toke many put ranſomes ſacked al good ſet fire town ſo wholy conſumed place excepted done returned caleis men ſafetie bringing faire ware turned greate profit caliſians many yeares men winchelſe rie gathered gret number people togither imbarqued themſelues towardes normandie deſirous requite ye loſſes receiued ſo night arriuing town called peter hauen entred ſame ſlaying ſo many met thoſe thinke able pay raunſome carry ſhippes ſpoyled houſes church founde many rich ſpoyles ſometime bin french men fet ric eſpecially belle ſuch like ſhipped ſet reſt fire thē land wilet far thence wher practiſed ye like cheuance ſo theyr riche ſpoyle returned home ſame time iohn duke lancaster requeſted ye ye mony granted k ye cleargie laitie might cō mitted cuſtodie affirming yt would kepe ye enimies coaſtes england ſpace one yeare yt mony moreouer bring paſſe ſome great commoditie whoſe importunate petitiō lord although againſt theyr willes agréed appoint therfore ye firſte day marche méete counſel euery thoſe ſhold go forth iourney leaſt ye ſea ſhould ye mean time want thoſe y• ſhold kéepe wer ix ſhips hired thē baion defend ye ſea land frō incurſions frēch others theſe ſhips furniſhed ſufficiēt nūbers armed mē wein ſhort time coaſting ye ſeas met nauy marchandice ye spaniard entring battayle ſhort time take xiiij ſhips laden wt wine marchandize returne england ioyfully vnto ſir robert knowles captain brest giue firſte fruites theyr pray c tunne beſte wine paſſed homewardes meane time henrie ye baſtard calling himſelf king spain hearing y• baion done ſuch harme vnto people lācaster prepared gret nūber enter ye ſea ſore afraid thinking ye minded defēd ſea rather ſéeke kingdome right wife ye lawful inheritour spaine ment chalenge wherfore ye ſaid henrie cōmanded nauie prepared al land yt might ſtay ſaid entring country might take priſoner happily done ye king portingale wt almoſt inumerable nūber entred ye kingdome spain ye ſelf ſame time yt baſtard henrie prepared ſelfe againſt ye deferring iourney day day y• wer appointed captain ouer nauie certain mē war got thē ye ſea ſtay duke comming eſtéeming glorious liue ſea prayes taking frō enimies liue ſpoile owne countreymen home certain dayes wa • ted vp downe sea spaniardes met armed company men ſo either part hope pray ioyned togyther fighte oure menne hauyng winde weather contrary loſt victory theyr enimies ſome eſcaping flight ſome taken amongſt ſir hugh courtney noble knight one ſame time iohn mercer scotte gathering togither ſmall number french men scot spaniard ſet vpon certaine ſhips scaborow toke led scotlande reuenge father iniurie taken engliſh men kept priſoner caſtel scarborow iohn philpot citizē london mā iolly wit rich ſubſtance conſidering want ye duke lancaster lord ought haue defended ye realmanno reg 2 lamenting oppreſſions inhabitauntes hyred wyth owne money number thouſand ſouldiours whiche mighte take ſayde iohn mercer ſhippes good whiche reuenge takē defended realme england ſuche incurſions came paſſe within ſmall time hyred mē toke ſayde iohn mercer ſhips violently taken scarborow fiftéene spaniſh ſhippes laden muche rich hym ayde preſent greate ioy made among ye people men prayſing worthy man bountifulneſſe loue towards king earles baron ſéeing ſo laudable acte atchieued iohn philpot tooke grieuouſly althoughe knewe themſelues guiltie firſte ſecretly lye awayte ſome diſpleaſure ſpake againſt openly ſaying lawfull doe ſuch thing without counſell king realme certayne lordes chiefe hugh earle stafforde rehearſed theſe thing thus againſt aunſweared ſame iohn philpot ſir know ſayth neyther ſente money men daunger sea ſhoulde take fellowes good renoume chilualrie winne ſorrowfull ſée people myſerie countrey whych nowe ſlouthfulneſſe moſt noble lady nation brought lye open ſpoyling euerye vileſt nation one doth put hys hande defence thereof haue therefore ſet forth ſelfe mine ſauing nation countrey earle aunſwere xi auguſt certaine wicked perſons kingsmurder church vveſtminſter tho walſing houſe armed high maſſe tyme entred churche westminster abbay ſet vppon two valiaunt eſquiers iohn schakel robert hawley whyche eſcaped tower london ſayde abbay refuge sanctuarie ſlewe ſayde robert hawley quire priours ſtal ſlewe monke intreated ſpare ſayde robert place syr ralph ferreis▪ ſir alan buxule captain tower ſome ſay lord latimer wer captaines miſchiefe aforeſayd two eſquires robert hawley iohn shakell battayle nazers spaine toke erle dene poiſoner deliuered vnto ſō pledge bycauſe would preſent ſayde earles ſon king woulde giue little nothing hym foreſayde allen buxule ſent thys myſchiefe ſlewe one caſte priſon iohn boſeham thomas cornewalis 28 septem sherifes maior iohn philpot charitie sir iohn philpot grocer 28 october iohn philpot maior london gaue ſame citie certaine tenementes chamberlain payeth yearely xiij poore people euerye ſeauen penny wéeke euer thoſe thirtéene perſons dyeth maior appointeth one recorder another scottes beganne rebell squire theirs1379 tho walſing called alexander ramſey fortye perſons nighte toke caſtell berwicke ninth day following erle northumberland recouered ſlew scots▪ therein marchauntes london wickedly ſlew rich marchaunt genu woulde carry better market ſpices promiſed bring country doer wherof apprehended ſome fact executed ſhal appeare great mortality men hapned north partspeſtilence north tho walſ england neuer bin ſéene scot ſéeing raunged ſlewe aſked mean payment ye sommer following common kent eſſex ſodainely rebelled beingcommons rebelled iohn bal sermon tho walſing animated therevnto iohn ball ſeditious prieſte hys ſermons vſed take neuertheleſſe ſo pleaſed common people cryed hée ſhould archbiſhoppe canterburie chauncellour england rebellion began dertford kent manner asrebellion begā dertford cro albons followeth collectours ſoone wit toke mayde violently diſhoneſtly ſearched whether ſhe age wherwith mother made outcry hyr huſbande ye towne worke tidyngs came caughte lathing ſtaffe hande ranne réeking home reaſoning collectour made ſo bolde collectour proude fellow let flye tiler tiler voyding ſtroke ſmote collectour heade wyth lathing ſtaffe braynes fell throughe great noyſes aroſe ſtreates poore people glad euerye man arrayed hym ſupport iohn tyler thus common drewe togither went maidstone thence backe againe blacke heath ſo forth london entred citie corpus christ day deſtroyed many goodly place coulde méete withall ſet al priſoners libertie king pacifie furie offered peace oneſſex men pacified condition woulde ceaſe burning houſes ſlaughter men whiche eſſex men toke returned home kentiſhe men remayned burning ſlaying afore wherevppon king ſent ſir iohn newton k ſent vvat tiler knight wat tiler captaine intreate come talke owne demaundes knight meſſage wat tiler aunſwered hée woulde come hys owne pleaſure neuertheleſſe followed ſoftly came neare smithfielde king aboade comming ſame knighte ſent againe méete hym knowe requeſtes wat tiler ſéeing knight come néere vnto horſſeback ſayde hadde become hym better bée foote preſence knighte aunſwered harme • ith himſelfe alſo horſſebacke therewith watte tyler drewe dagger offering ſtrike called knightthe •• outneſſe vvat tiler traytour knighte aunſweared lyed drew dagger king ſéeing knighte daunger comaunded hym alighte one foote deliuer dagger vnto watte tiler proude minde woulde pacifyed woulde néedes runne knighte came king maior london william walworth manye knightes eſquires affirming ſhamefull reproche ſhoulde permitte knyghte murdered wherevppon kyng taking boldeneſſe vpon hym commaunded maior arreſte rebell whiche maior man incomparable boldeneſſe ſtreyght arreſted hym head ſuche ſorte aſtonyed hym forthwyth whyche attended kyng inuironed rebell thruſte diuerſe place bodye▪ theyr weapon drewe hym among people féete hoſpitall saint bartholmewe whenvvat tiler areſted ſlaine common perceyued cryed theyr captaine trayterouſlye ſlayne king rode ſayde meane doe king wil captaine followe fielde haue whatſoeuer ye require therefore followed hym fieldes wythout ſuburbes towards yſeldon meane time maior rod citie rayſed citizen ſhortly returned thouſande wel armed men sir robert knowles theyr leader king citizen lon deliuered king hys companye reioyſing vnlooked ayde ſodainelye compaſſed multitude common wyth fighting men common forthwyth throwing downe bowes billes weapon fel themſelues grounde truth ſhal helpe raigneth pride price couetiſe holde wiſe leacherie without ſhame gluttonye without blame enuie raigneth treaſon ſlouth taken greate ſeaſon god doe bote time amen iacke milner asketh trueth hath bin ſette vnder locke falſeneſſe raigneth euery flocke man maye come trueth hee ſings si dedero ſpeake ſpende ſpeede quoth iohn bathon therefore ſinne fareth wilde floude true loue awaye thouſande horſſemen ſéemely ſort armed muſtered blacke heath himſelfe ryding greate courſer hys ſtandarde borne hym therefore ſo myghtye armye aſſembled kyng aduertiſed kentiſhe men eftſoones london ſitting iudgement cauſed malefactours tryed well citie alſo kente eſſex southſex norffolke suffolke countryes might taken within liberty citie thoſe whome founde guiltie foreſayde treaſon cauſed hoppe headleſſe among iacke strawe iohn kirkeſty alen threder c alſo iohn starling eſſex gloryed haue beheaded archbiſhoppe beheaded hymſelfe king remayned nowe london nowe waltham greate armye armed menne conſidering done commoditie realme length counſell thoughte good ſende king commiſſion euerye ſhire reſiſting diſquieters peace kyngdome theſe commiſſions muche comforte faythfull ſubiectes troubled falſe nowe compelled ſéeke corner toke vpon doe thing abroade lawyer nowe durſt come forth dennes thoſe fledde tyrannie time looked th • ſe nowe feared iudgement iuſtice bée done common thus feared place alike eſſex gathering newe multitude togither byllarica village neare hatfielde peuerell decréed eyther inioye lybertye gotten force dye fyghting ſame ſente kyng béeyng hateful land sea worthy liue yée require equall lordes yée worthy put moſte ſhamefull death fith yée come meſſengers yée ſhall dye nowe ende yée may declare anſweares fellowes declare therfore kyngs behalfe huſbandmen bondman ſo ſhall remaine bondage vile without compariſon far vnto thys whileſt lyue god ſufferaunce ſhal gouerne kingdome wit strength good wil endeuour ſelues kéepe vnder ſo duety realmes lingered ſo long vayne nothing brought effect hearing new quéenes comming caleis parliamēt proroged diuers ye noble ſent méete bride ſhe conuayde glorie world vnto douer many hir countrey alſo england attending hir feaſt epiphany nobilitie the1382 realme aſſembled london preſent king mariage ſeruice according cuſtome euery one auntient time vſed uirgin namedthe king maried anne countrey men pro • eſſe quéenes dayes began deteſtable vſe piked ſhoes tied knées cheines ſiluer gilt alſopiked shoe high head long tayled govvnes vvith vvomen riding aſide firſt vſed england noble woman vſed high attire head piked like horne long trayned gownes rode ſide saddle ye example quéene firſt brought faſhion land woman vſed ride aſtride like men ſolemnitie mariage ended parliament counſell iohn northampton maior▪ william eſſ • x iohn andstirre againſt fishmonger richard northburie greatly troubled hindred liberty almoſt deſtroyed congregation made againſt parliament london kings1383 charter patent reſtored liberty moneth may biſhop norwich ſayled ouer sea flanders greate power wanne townes graueling brugh dunkerke newport whileſt theſe thing thus flanders king england parliament london sir nicholas brembar grocer 28 october feaſt saincts parliament holden london halfe fiftéenth granted king laytie ſhortly halfe tenth cleargie portion money lord north demaunded bycauſe parliament appointed defende thoſe partes againſt irruption scottes whome anſwere made sir william wikeham biſhop winchester made cauſe poore men rich mē lord might franckly kéepe scottes king lord south partes ſhould leſſe troubled bycauſe scottes came parliament according couenant beſide diſpleaſures vnto inhabitant north part decréed parliament vnto faithbreakers faith ſhoulde broken againe choſen power ſhould ſent thither forth englande vnder leading thomas woodstoke tothomas vvoodſtocke ſent againſt scottes wéete thouſand launce two thouſand archer reſtreyne attemptes theſe thing knowne scottes afrayde themſelues ende parliament came deſirous entreate peace truſe engliſhmen hauing tried falſehoode ſo often time woulde neyther treate compounde commanded returne home warned ſaue head well might defend rightes scottes returned lordes north tooke vpon defende countrey till thomas woodstoke earle buckingham readie come greater power king tooke temporality biſhop norwich temporalty bishop norvvich ſeaſed hand bycauſe diſobedient commandement ſent haue ſtayde iourney flanders knightes ouer put priſon till redéemed gold king richard held chriſtmas manour eltham quéene anne chriſtmas iohn duke lancaster chriſtmas went ouer france treate peace betwixt realmes returned england bringing abſtinence warre till feaſt saint iohn baptiſt at1384 time returne treate againe confirme peace might agréed vpon betwixt ye king night purification lady great lightning thunder happened put men great feare ſhortly iohn northamptō otherwiſe called combartowne bin yeare maior london ſeditions filled citie full comber attempted new trouble contempt maior elected yeare sir nicholas brembar knight went vp multitude ſeditious people gard oftentimes terrour manie ſaid brembar maior woulde haue withſtanded attemptes fauourers ſaid iohn combertowne turned ſuche furie cobler owne eſtimation ſéemed maior required voyces communalty cauſe counſell sir robert knowles knight drawne houſe committed priſon ſtirrer inſurrection acte time ſtaide commotion common ſayd haue conſpired time haue murthered elect maior many worthie men lente aproched iohn duke lancaster brother thomas woodstoke earle buckingham innumerable number knightes eſquires archer went toward scotland ſtayde north till victualles countrey conſumed hurt inhabitant scottes done length feaſt eaſter entred scotland little good cuſtodie caſtell douer vacant death robert aſhtonwald made conneſtable thereof simon burley eaſter noble came parliament saliſburie parliament salisburie whither certaine iriſh frier order carmelite white frier batcheler diuinitie named iohn latimer haſted accuſed duke lancaſter duke lancaſter accuſed deuiſed king death frier committed sir iohn holland knight reg 8 domages northumbers earle northumberland henry percy prepareth inuade scotland requite domage domage enterpriſe accompliſhed earle ſooner returned ſent home army scottes came againe heaped vp domage vpon domage countrey sommer sir iohn philpot knighte moſtsir iohn philpot deceaſſed noble citizen london trauelled commoditie realme expences laide forth good affection borne oftentimes reléeued king departed life leauing none behinde like good affection beginning auguſt duke lancaster went france treate frenchman peace elſe truce duke company noble men remayning long thought ſhould haue brought glad ioyfull newes countrey returned knowledge warres followe beginning next sommer truce endure ••• firſt day may ſo returned ſpente 500000 markes siluer many noble aſſembled reading repreſſe theiohn northampton conuict committed perpetuall priſon ſeditious ſturres iohn northampton late maior london attempted greate heynous enterpriſes whiche conuict hys owne chapleyne vttering manye thynges hée wente aboute hadde deuiſed well hinderance harme king citie london ſentence ſhoulde haue bin pronounced againſt king preſente wicked man made exclamation mainteyned ſuch iudgemente ought paſſe abſence lorde duke lancaster yet juſtice vſed ſuch word iohn ſayth naughtie déedes obiected agaynſte thée thou oughteſt refell battayle elſe lawes land drawne hanged quartered ſtoode mute would vtter one word déecréede ſhould committed perpetuall priſon goodes confiſcate king vſe ſhoulde come within one hundred mile london life ſente therefore caſtell tintagell confines cornewall meane ſpace king ſeruants ſpoyled goodes iohn richard northbery likewiſe conuict condemned perpetuall priſon goodes confiſcate king certaine congregation made againſt fiſhmongers citie london nicholas exton iohn french 28 september sherifes maior sir nicholas brembar grocer 28 october feaſt saint martine parliament holden london whiche nothing done worth memorie ſtill hand exacting money cleargie common people mainteine men warre beſides combate fought liſtes betwixte eſquire englande one ofa combate fought nauarre accuſed engliſh eſquire whoſe name iohn welch treaſon king realme effect captayne cherbrugh forced wife nauaroys ſayde nauaroys afterward ouercome readie ſuffer death • penly confeſſe cauſe king iudgemēt drawne hanged although quéene many make earneſt interceſſiō haue life ſaued parliament yet ended newe • camebervvike loſt vvo ••• againe north taking berwike caſtell scottes cuſtodie whereof earle northumberland sir henry percy poſſeſſe right predeceſſors scottes mediation money got entrance caſtel one put truſt kéeping duke lancaster loued earle glad happe knew came paſſe therefore duke procurement earle condemned iudgement lord preſent execution within ſhort releaſſed earle northumberland king fauour reſtored life poſſeſſions without long delaye • prepareth al furniture warre beſéege winne ſayd caſtell thē within gathered mighty armie ſodeinly beſéeged layne certaine time compounded betwixt without within within ſhould forſake caſtell haue liues moueable goodes ſurrendring caſtell ſhould haue earle two thouſand markes engliſh money meanes earle recouer caſtell foorth scottiſhmens hand certaine yong men brought vp kingtho wal • aroſe great diſſention betwixt duke lancast • r departed court wente caſtell pomfret whiche fortified meanes king mother diſcorde appeaſed time third may earthquake1 • 85 king entred scotlande▪ king richard▪ great armie entred scotlande enimies would ſhew themſelues wherfore brent countrey returned eightéenth july earthquake sir iohn de vienne ſerued french king ſent scotland great multitude shippes men warre ioining scottes might • e • england whilſt might • draw power realme way forth frenche king nauie army might liberty enter partes realme none left home prohibit entrie arriuall ſayd iohn knowne england king nobilitie prepared themſelues make iourney thitherthe king maketh iourney scotland came flocking vnto king ſuch number knightes eſquires archer like bin heard thoſe dayes ſo much number horſſes amoū ted thrée hundred thouſand iudged king reioyced héereat well might reioycing ſhortly darkened yorke fierceneſſe sir iohn holland king brother ſlew lord ralph stafford ralph stafforde • ayne ſonne earle stafford way went quéene whoſe ſeruant houſhold greatly fa • eur hir leſſe beloued king bin brought vp bin playfellow tender age king taking greate indiguation determined purſue ſayd sir iohn holland cauſed therefore goodes cōfiſcate sir iohn holland fledde beuerley enioy libertie church lady iane king mother ſente intreate hir ſonne brother meſſengers returned wallingforde mother could perceyue hope grace gotten behalfe king ſhe tooke heau •• ie fell ſicke andqueene iane king mother dyed within foure •• ue dayes departed life hir body ſeared cloſed leade kept wallingford till king returne forth scotland buried stanford church frier minor moneth auguſt king england mightie power entred scotland whoſe force scottes frenchman perceyuing themſelues able matche ſéeke get wooddes place might way engliſh army hath bin ſéene fairer ſtronger greater rideth countrey deſtitute inhabitantes •• yd cattell wanting victualles land left deſolate men confeſſed ſaw ſo much bird owles excepted found gréene corne grounde faire plentifull whiche eyther eate vp horſſes treade downe theyr féete enimies fléeing battayle men nothing accompted brent abbey melroys themeltoys edenborough brent towne edenborough ſuch houſes found way armie come edenborough victualles fayled many beganne ware ſicke ſome die hunger wherevpon king returned armie england king richarde scotland scottes frenchman entred englande brenning townes taking ſpoyles leading away many priſoners returned home countrey iohn organ iohn churchman 28 september sherifes maior sir▪ nicholas brembar grocer 28 october souldiers caleis went ſecretly forth france got bootie four thouſand shéepe thrée hundred head great beaſtes draw holdes feaſt saint martine parliament london laytie granted king fiftéenth halfe cōdition cleargie ſhould giue tenth halfe william courtney archbiſhop canterbury ſtanding againſt ſaid church ought befrée wiſe taxed laytie whiche anſwerea bill put againſt cleargie temporalty ſo moued common forthwith preſented king bill againſt cleargie realme mouing take temporality thereby abate pride king hearing inordinate cry ſide iuſt anſweres commanded bill ſhould cancelled ſuch inordinate petitiōs ceaſſe ſaying would preſerue churche time good ſtate found better archbiſhop therefore hauing made cleargie priuie wente king declared cleargie whole conſents frée willes prouided vſes tenth graunt king ſo thankefully receyued hée openly affirmed rather haue frée graunt foure time double conſtreyned eleuenth noueinber robert vere earle oxford state created made marqueſſe diuelin ireland thomas woodstocke duke glocester brother edmonde earle cambridge duke yorke michaell de la poole chancellour england made earle suffolke giuē king thouſand markes yeare earle march mortimer proclaymed heire apparantlib peter col crowne alſo king richarde earneſt requeſt biſhops reſtored biſhop norwich temporality holden manye yeares king richard quéene anne wife kept chriſtmas eltham whether came king ermony vnder pretence reforme peace betwixte king england comming profited onely vnderſtoode beſide innumerable giftes receyued king noble king granted charter thouſand pound yeare life affirmed chaſed realme tartarians cauſe got great giftes chriſtian1386 tonne wine whiche theyrochell vvine taken brought diuers part england wherby wine ſold thirtéene ſhillings four penny tonne robert de vere duke ireland ſooke wife yong lady noble faire borne lady iſabell daughter y• noble k edward maried another came quéene anne forth boheme ſhe called vulgar tong hir conntrey lancecrona lordes tooke indignation héerewith eſpecially duke glocester unkle ye yong lady forſaken duke ireland ſtudied take duke glocester ye way eaſter paſt time whiche duke ireland ſhoulde haue tranſported ireland leaſt ſhoulde muche ſturre realme among lord king bring water ſide goeth wale leaue kéepe might deniſe take away glocester earles arundell warwike darby notingham thē earle suffolke michaell pole robert treſilian juſtice many ſlowly ireland conſpired death ſaid noble mē great time paſſed king duke irelāds iourney bin forgotten returned forth wale caſtell notingham treate ofanno reg 11 death ſaid noble men therfore ſent diuers lōdon whome knew would readie way ſoeuer ſhould moued called thither alſo sherifes juſtices realme interdited lord many crime king imagined againſt meane time rumor came lord eares whervpon firſt ye king unkle glocester might mitigate king diſpleaſure biſhop london manye noble ſwearing vpon euangeliſtes tooke vpon oth neuer imagined thing king hinderance done thing diſpleaſure except giuē good countenāce ireland would héereafter giue diſhoneſted kinſwoman firmelie determined reuenge william venor hugh forſtalfe 28 september sherifes maior sir nicholas exton fiſhmonger 28 october glocester calling togither ſecretly earles arundell warwike darby like danger cō demnatiō prouided ſpéedily diſcouereth thē matter therfore gathering army togither determine talke king vpon premiſes contraryly king party deliberate howe might take thē themſelues way firſt ſent caſtell rigate earle arundell lay earle northumberland many ſo arreſt perceyuing great nūber mē warre fearing commanded departed without errand came whome ſent many night ſhould haue takē haue ſlaine meſſenger ſent frō gloceſter preuēted cōming cauſed ride al night ſo morning come haringey hauing paſſed army xxx mile without great trauayle found aſſembled glocester earle warwike great power men k enformed aſſembly harneſey wood ſaid demāded familiar done caſe y• end mediation thē came betwixt thē matter brought iſſue y• lord ſhould come westminſter receiue anſwere y• king thoſe thing biſhop ely many mē worthy credit taking oth y• king part fraude deceipt peril ſhould prepared whē lord prepared thēſelues according ye couenant foreſaid mediator peace ſent thē word yt treaſon deuiſed ambuſh laid thē place called mewes néere charing croſſe therfore willed thē come ſure hand whervpō ſtayd k demanding lord kept couenāt b ely anſwered bycauſe ſaith ambuſh laid armed men ſuch place contrary couenant therefore neyther come repute faithfull king moued forthwith ſware knew ſuch thing therefore commanded sheriffes london going mewes ſhoulde kill founde aſſembled cauſe thomas treuit nicholas brembar knightes ſecretly ſente away armed men london king therefore ſent agayne lord ſtreightwayes came westminster ſtrong power agaynſt whoſe comming king adorning himſelfe kingly robe crowne scepter entreth westminster hall biſhop elie lord chancellour ſpeaking king demanded cauſe aſſembling ſuch power whervnto lord anſwered done king profit realmes plucke traytors whiche kept whome named robert de vere duke ireland alexander neuell archbiſhop yorke michaell pole earle suffolke robert triſilian falſe juſtice nicholas brembar falſe knight london therevpon threwe downe gloues ſwearing would proſecute battayle nay ſayth king ſhall ſo next parliament appoynted holden morrow purification lady pacified time maner exhalation likeneſſe fire appeared y• strange likeneſſe fire iohn leyceſter night many place england went men went ſtayde ſometime like whéele ſometime like barrell ſometime like timberlogge many went togither appeared farre lord departing frō k notwithſtanding kept togither ſéemed great wiſdome ireland partes chester wale aſſembled great nūber whoſe captaine ye conneſtable cheſter thomas moleneux mā great wealth hardy ireland ſuch multitude haſted towards london yt ioyning londoner might make thē inuincible army ye ireland riding forth ſtately glorious array ye armie thinking none durſt haue encountred ſodeinly loked one ſide beheld hoſt lord ready far frō tarying cōming midſt valley ſight heart ſtreightwayes fayled ſaid friend muſt flie greater puiſſance ſéemeth yōder againſt haue quarell ſo ye ſhifted away ye ſhall eſcape wel ynough forthwith ſetting ſpurres horſe fléeth away ye foreſaid tho moleneux y• prepared himſelfe battayle lordes yet al come place fought awearied entred riuer amōg ſir thomas mortimer knighte exhorted come vp elſe would ſhoote riuer come vp ſayth thomas moleneux wilt thou ſaue life doe make ſuch promiſe ſayeth eyther come vp yu ſhalt ſteight die whō anſwered ſuffer come vp let fight eyther thée ſome dye like man came vp knight caught helmet plucked heade ſtreighte wayes hys dagger ſtrucke hym braynes duke ireland fléeing came riuer thamis forced horſſe enter made horſſeman ſwimmer gotte ſide horſſe helmet gauntlet breſt plate came ſhare lordes ſo thoughte long drowned▪ got ouer flaunders archbiſhoppe yorke fledde robert treſilian michael de la pole got caleis lord béeing returned battayle bin nere burforde faſt bablack made great ioy ouerthrowe enimies muche lamented eſcape duke ireland heade earthe made oxforde arte negromancie time appointed ſpake theſe word caput decidetur head ſhall cut caput eleuabitur heade ſhall lift vp pes eleuabuntur ſuper caput feete ſhall lift aboue heade diſſention fel oxford betwéen hanged drawne iohn vske sergeaunt armes drawn hāged laſtly fifth may ſir simō burley lord chamberlayne king coneſtable douer beheaded although earle darbie coulde ſaue great diſſention roſe betwixt
