cleargie half tenth laytie half fiftéenth marchāts twelue penny pounde thrée ſhillings tunne liij ſhillings foure penny ſack wool duke glocester ſir iohn cobham aſked pardon abbot westminster violence done ye ſanctuarie westminster taking juſtice triſilian laſte ſaue one may deliuered tower w elmhame treuet nicholas dagworth knight alſo firſt june iohn holand king brother created erie huntington thirde june king church westminſter renewed othe toke crowned lordes ſware homage fealtie biſhoppes excommunicate thoſe would go hinder ſtatutes laſt parliament y• anno reg 12 great charter whitſontide richarde earle arundale companye valiaunte men wente ſea foughte certain ſhips enemy taking drowning▪ brē ning lxxx ſhippes entred ile beas ſpoyled brent ſame yeare scottes prepared themſelues ſoone truce exſpired mighte readie inuade north partes great army entred englande committing gret ſlaughters people toke booty euery place ledde away manye priſoners burned▪ townes approched newcastel vpon tyne picht theyr tentes farre thence ſame towne ſir henrie percy yonger syr ralph brother deſirous warlike renowme ſore enimies scottes thys ſir henrie came vpon ſodayne aſſayled campe making greate ſlaughter william douglas alſo chiefe captaine scottes beholding thing thouſande time hadde wiſhed ſir henrie percy within campe rydeth againſte ſlayne ſayde henrie commeth earle dunbar exceſſiue number scottes toke ſayd henrie brother ralphe ſlaying many engliſhe menne place yet scottes loſte manye theyr beſte men thys battayle otterborne ſoareſt fought thatbattaile otterborne iohn belandine iohn maior • froſert • • h rudborae parliament cambridge euer betwéene engliſhe menne scottes ſayeth froyſert ſeauenth september parliament holden cambridge newe ſtatutes ordayned ſeruauntes wage beggers weapon born playes game none vſed ſhooting ſtaple brought middleborow caleis c ende tenth cleargie fiftéenth laytie thomas auſtine adam carlehul 28 september sherifes maior sir nicholas twyforde goldſmith 28 october ſixth october ſir iohn treuet rode wyth king king lodging whiche bernewel forced horſſe much ſpurres horſſe falleth breaketh inner part rider liued tyl next day king richard diſcharged olde officer courte1389 alſo counſellours appointing pleaſure toke seale thomas arundale archbiſhop yorke deliuered william wickam byſhoppe winchester made chauncellour biſhoppe excester treaſurer edmund stafford kéeper priuie seale truce graunted thrée yeares betwixt englande fraunce fighting among gnat king maner shine ſo thicke gathered ayre darkned fought made great battaile two partes ſlayne fel downe grounde thirde part hauing got victorie flew away mā knew whether number deade ſuch mighte bée ſwepte vppe wyth beſomes buſhels filled wythanno reg 13 michael pole ſometime earle suffolke chauncellour england deceaſed paris iohn walcotte iohn loueney 28 september sherifes maior sir william vener grocer 28 october moneth nouember iohn duke lancaster came party beyonde ſeas englande abidden spaine gaſcoigne thrée yeares ſpace spaine firſt taſted great miſfortunes yet ende brought matter good caſe force men fauour god came firſte yt partes spaine armye ſufficient ynoughe wante victualles firſt dyed hunger flixe ſo 1000 famous knightes hys armye dyed miſerably reſidue leauing duke fled french army king richard quéene anne held chriſtmaſſe woodstocke duke lancaster caſtle hertforde ſame time iohn haſtings earle penbroke deſirous juſt ſtroken priuie partes knight ranne againſt called1390 ſir iohn saint iohn dyed parliamente london ordayned none ſhoulde purchaſe prouiſions pope hand ther graunted king xl ſhillings euery ſack wool pound ſixe penny iohn duke lancaster made duke aquitaine rood bonet king gaue edward duke yorkes ſonne made earle rutlande king gaue caſtell okam anno reg 14 great peſtilence north part england ſo little ſpace 1100 buried citie yorke merchant dertmouth waged nauie ſhips port charge 34 ſhips laden wine ſumme 1500 tunne wofull variaunce roſe oxforde welche southerne schollers aſſaulted northerne whereby many murder done ſide fielde appointed helpe duke glocester appeaſed welch men banniſhed iohn francis thomas viuent 28 september sherifes maior adam bawme goldſmith 28 october x xj xij october king helde greate courte london biſhops palace greate inſting smithfield whyche courte came many ſtrangers forth fraunce almain zealand many part bringing horſſes armour paſtimes giuen firſt badge white harte wyth golden chaines crownes vpon saint edwardes day king helde feaſte regalibus ſitting crowned maſſe scepter c likewiſe quéen ſat likewiſe table kenington crowned ſolemnitie preſente earle sainte paule hys wyfe ſiſter kyng englande earle ostreuaunt made knyghte garter duke glocester toke hys iourney toward spruys 1 • 91 toſſed infortunate ſtormes driuen nowe hyther nowe thyther ſo farre diſtant hope diſpayred life length paſſed barbarous coaſtes denmarke norway scotlande arriued northumberlande came caſtel tinmouth hauing refreſhed himſelf certain dayes toke iourney towards maner plecy mortalitie increaſed norffolke many country vnlike greate peſtilence within yorke dyed xj thouſand perſons citizen london toke orphan cheſteanno reg 15 2000 markes buye victualles xxiiij alderman eache layde twentie pounde like purpoſe buying corne beſtowed diuerſe place poore mighte buye appointed price ſuche lacked money pay downe put ſuretie pay yt yeare following brewer dwelt ſigne cocke westcheape little conduite neare vnto powles gate murdered night time théef came gutter windowe knowne long confeſſion ſame théefe gallowes bée hanged fellonie brewer wife firſte brente therefore thrée men drawne tiborne hanged wrongfully iohn chadworth henrie vamer 28 september sherifes maior sir iohn hinde draper 28 october parliament began london friday next feaſt al saintes wherin halfe tenth ceargie halfe fiftéenth laitie granted king mony ſhould ſerue treatie peace french men whiche treatie duke lancaster ſhould proſecute king richarde quéene anne wife foure biſhoppes many erles duke yorke many lord fiftéene ladyes helde royall chriſtmaſſe langley neare saint albons ſame chriſtmaſſe day dolphin came forth ſea playde himſelfe thamis london bridge ſhewing hapily tempeſts follow within wéeke ſéene citizen followed much difficultie intercepted broughte againe london ſhewing ſpectacle many height bodye ten foote length theſe dolphin fiſhes ſea yt followe voyces men reioyce playing inſtrumentes wont gather themſelues muſicke theſe play riuers haſtie ſpringings leaping ſignify tempeſt follow ſeas containt nothing ſwift nimble oftentimes theyr ſkippes mount ouer ſayles ſhippes king ſent londoner requeſting borrowe of1392 tho walſing one thouſande pounde whiche ſtoutely denyed alſo euil entreated bette néere hand ſlew certain lumbard woulde haue lent king ſayde ſu •• king heard maruellouſly angried calling togither almoſt noble lande hée opened malitiouſneſſe londoner cō playned theyr preſumption whyche noble men gaue counſell inſolencie ſhoulde ſpéede oppreſſed theyr pride abated king iudgement therefore maior london sherifes beſt citizen arreſted maior ſente windſor caſtel priſons til king counſell ſhould determine ſhould done determined thenceforth londoner ſhoulde choſe haue anye maior king ſhoulde appointe one knightes ruler citie priuiledges reuoked liberty adnulled lawes abrogated king appointed warden citie certayne knighte called ſir edwarde de dalingrige quicklye depoſed king bicauſe men ſaid fauoured londoner baldwin radinton conſtituted place meane time throughe ſute certaine knightes butanno reg 16 ſpecially duke glocester king ſomewhat pacified little little abateth rigor purpoſe calling minde diuerſe honor greate giftes receyued londoner wherevpon determineth deale mildely call ſome hope grace pardon ſendeth commaundement come windſore ſhewe pryuiledges liberty lawes whyche ſhewed ſome ratifyed ſome condemned could obtaine king full fauour till ſatiſfied ye king iniuries whiche ſayd done king thys aſſembly windſor hadde got togither almoſt lordes ſo greate army londoner cauſe afrayde thereof aboute whiche preparation greate charge whiche ſure londoner muſte pay therefore ignoraunte ende theſe thing money matter ſubmitted themſelues king pleaſure offering ten thouſand pound yet diſmiſſed home returne againe vncertaine ſatiſfaction ſum ſhoulde pay citizen returned noble gone home king hearing londoner hauens diſmayde ſayde men wil go ſayth london comforte citizen longer diſpayre fauour ſentence ſooner knowne citie al menne filled incredible ioy ſo euery generally determined méete liberal gift coronation king therefore hée came shine surrey london quéene anne wife xxj auguſt principall citizen rode méete wandeſworth sainte gorge churche southwarke receyued proceſſion rob braybroke biſhop london cleargie citie conuayed london citizen men woman child order méeting king honor attended westminster paſſed citie ſtréetes hanged cloth golde ſiluer ſilke conduite chepe ran red white wine childe angellike preſented coſtly crowne golde quéene another table trinitie gold giuen king valued worth eight hundred pounde another quéen saint anne▪ bycauſe hir name anne diuerſe giftes horſſes trapper plate golde ſiluer clothes gold ſilke veluets baſons ewer gold alſo golde coyne precious ſtones iewels ſo rich excellent beautifull value price mighte well eſtéemed ſo citizen recouered auntient cuſtomes liberty king bench yorke chauncerie notingham returned london granted might chooſe maior time done londoner beléeued y• theſe giftes eſcaped daunger thenceforth ſhould quiet wer deceiued wer cōpelled giue k 10000 pound collected cōmons gret bitterneſſe minde ſo trouble y• citizen came quietneſſe trouble dolphin thamis chriſtmaſſe laſte paſt happily ſignifie far w caxton robert fabian report theſe trouble happen fray fleetſtreete horſſe loafe taken baker baſket yeoman biſhop saliſburies ſame trouble pacified liberty reſtored meanes richard graueſend biſhop london rewarde wherof citizēs repaire place burial midle ile saint paul church c vntrue time rob brabroke biſhop london richard graueſēd bin biſhop deceaſed time edward firſt anno 1303 almoſt 90 yeares time moreouer place burial saint paules whervnto maior citizen london haue repayred william biſhop london time william conqueror purchaſed firſt charter ſaide king william ye ſame citie haue declared gilbert maghfelde thomas newington 28 sep sherifes maior sir william stoudon grocer 28 october albeit vere created erle oxforde parliamēt winchester william scrope uizechamberlaine ſame william scrope bought william mountacute erle saliſburie ile man crowne lorde ile called king lawful crowned1393 crowne golde ſir iohn euers knighte coneſtable douer king ſtewarde died ſodainely percy brother e northum made king ſteward place yt king vnderchamberlaine beamond made coneſtable douer certainanno reg 17 théeues brake chappel lady pewe westminster toke many iewels muche treaſure alſo ſhortly ye ſame théeues brake ye churche iohn clerkenwel duke lanc glocester paſſed ouer france make ſomewhat ye truce conclude final peace betwixt ye kingdom ſo brought paſſe wiſhed reaſon frenche king ſickneſſe september lightning thunder manye place england much hurte eſpeciallye cambridgeſhire ſame brent houſes corne neare tolleworke towne brent terribly drewe barentine richard whittington 28 sep sherifes maior sir iohn hadley grocer 28 october aboundaunce water fell october bury suffolke church ful water newmarket bare wals houſes ſo men woman hardly eſcaped drowning ſame yeare lorde de ro 1394 returned forth holy lande citie paphos ile cipres intemperauncie ayre departed life octaues hillerie parliament holden london whiche ſubſidie demaunded king minded go irelande wherefore cleargie graunted full tenth would paſſe thyther went graunted halfe tenth certaine lordes scotlande came england get worſhip force armes erle marre challenged earle notingham iuſt ſo rode togither certaine cources ful chalēge erle marre caſt horſſe man two ribbes broken fall ſo borne smithfielde conuayed towarde scotlande died way yorke sir william darrel knight ye king bā ner bearer scotland challēged ſir pierce courtney knight king bannerbearer englande rū certain courſes gaue ouer without concluſiō victory cockborne eſquire scotland challenged ſir nicholas hawberke knight rode v courſes cockborn borne ouer horſſe man ſeauenth june quéene anne dyed shine southerie buried westminster anno reg 18 k toke hir death ſo heauily beſides curſing place ſhe dyed alſo anger throw building vnto whiche former king beyng wearyed citie wonte pleaſure reſorte moneth auguſte proclamation made iriſhmen ſhoulde auoyde realme gette home feaſt nauitie lady pain life william bramſtone thomas knowles 28 sept sherifes maior sir iohn froyſh mercer 28 october king richard went ouer ireland ye duke glocester earles march notingham rutlande iriſh men afrayde ſuche preparation made durſt ſhewe themſelues openly ſecrete aſſaultings often troubled king army yet engliſhmen preuayled many lord land ſubmitted themſelues king ſome kyng helde wyth hym leaſte ſhoulde attempte ſome new ſtyre king helde chriſtmaſſe dublin irelande feaſt held parliament alſo ſame time lord warden england called parliamēt london came ſent forth ireland duke glocester al ſtates ſhewed king néed ſpent treaſure amongſt iriſhme ſo tenth granted cleargie fiftéenth the1395 laytie voiage chargeable king came ſmall effect eaſter forced returne england appeaſe certaine trouble begon ſir rycharde sturry ſir thomas latimer ſir lewes clifforde ſyr iohn montacute yeare england ſuffered great loſſe pirate ye quéene donmarke ſpoyled marriners merchātsanno reg 19 eſpecially men norffolke aſſembled multitude togither toke vppon fight enimies preuayling many ſlaine verye many taken priſoners reſerued grieuous redemption loſſe twentie thouſande poundes borde make merchandice roger elles william sherington 28 september sherifes maior sir william vintener 28 october month nouember king richard cauſed body deare friend robert de vere duke ireland brought louaine buried priorie colne eſſex ſolemne funeral honored wt preſence cauſing co •• en cipres wherin body embalmed lay opened y• might behold his1 •• 6 face touch finger openly ſhewing loue dead carkaſſe ought aliue iohn duke lancaster k giuen duchie aquitaine nowe laide forth eſtimable ſumanno reg 20 treaſure thoſe partes purchaſe good wils thoſe countreymen ſhould haue deſire ſodainelye called home k returning england came langley k held chriſtmaſſe receyued k honor taking leaue courte made haſt lincolne toke wife katheren swinford yeare according couenaunt made eſtabliſhed betwixt king england fraunce ſayde king mette place caleis appointed talke wher concluded peace toke corporal othe performe ſame k richard toke wyfe iſabel little daughter french king ſeuen eight yeares old parliament westminster robert bolgnope iohn holt william brough knightes bathe reuoked ireland pardoned theſe wer men law judge thomas wilforde william parker 28 septem sherifes maior sir adam bawme goldſmith 28 october richard whittington ſixth june tenth nouember k marryed caleis wt great ſolemnitie ſhortly returned england xiij nouember quéene came london southwarke ſuch multitude people went ſée hir vpon1 • 97 lon bridge nine perſons crowded death y• prior tiptor eſſex one worſhipfull matrone cornehil another chriſtmaſſe parliamēt holden lond lancaster cauſed iſſue katheren swinford made legitimate alſo thomas ſon lancaster ſaid katheren created e somerſet gaue ſurname bello fortie bewfort graunted k halfe tenth cleargie yeare realme england ſéemed inioy chiefeſt peace y• might reaſon king marriage great rich y• heaped vp togither ſame reaſon y• truce 30 yeares eſtabliſhed preſence ſo many noble men y• like forrain realme able ſhew ſodainely thing troubled brought turmoyle while king atanno reg 21 plaſhy eſſex vpon ſodaine toke vncle glo force armes ſuſpecting ſuch thing cauſed hym conueyed caleis kept priſon cauſed earle warwicke arreſted impriſoned ſame day biddē dinner notwithſtanding ſhewed good countenance promiſed great friendſhip beſide deceiued e arundale wt faire word wel able haue defended himſelf haue deliuered friend glocester e warwick▪ notwithſtanding yéelded himſelf quietly ſent ile wight impriſoned vntil y• parliament y• end ſhould cō motion among y• cōmons impriſoning noble cauſed proclaymed y• apprehenſion old diſpleaſure new tranſgreſſions committed againſt y• k ſhortly cauſed y• ſaid noble indited notinghā ſuborned ſuch ſhold appeach thē next parliament wit ed erle rutland moubery e marſhal tho holland e kent iohn holland erle huntington tho bewford erle somerſet mountacute earle saliſburie thomas spencer william scrope king chamberlayne mean yeſeaſon kyng aſſembled togither guarde parſon many malefactor countie chester kept watch warde day night k cauſed greate generall parliament ſummoned westminster cauſed great hall builded midſt pallaice betwixte clocke tower doore greate hall parliament began aboute fiftéenth september beginning whereof edwarde stafforde byſhop excester l chanceller made propoſition ſermō affirmed power k alone perfect ſelf thoſe impeached worthye ſuffer pain law parliament al noble came retinue armes feare king prelocutours knight whō goodneſſe al could found natural couetouſneſſe vnſatiable ambition intollerable pride hatred truth name wer iohn buſhy william bagot thomas grene theſe requiredtho walſ chiefely haue charter pardon reuoked diſſanulled buſhy ſayde k bycauſe charged ſay haue committed offence againſt maieſtie regall aucthoritie ſaye tho duke glocester richard e arundale xviij yeare raigne haue trayterouſly compelled mean new archbiſhop canterburie lord chancellour graunt commiſſion gouerne realme diſpoſe ſtate thereof preiudice youre maieſtie royaltie ſame daye commiſſion diſſanulled article dependyng therevppon alſo generall pardon graunted greate parliament procured one ſpeciall pardon erle arundale reuoked alſo peticion made ye common buſhy ſpeaking generall pardon procured gotte forthe archebyſhoppe canterburie lorde chancellor procuring ſhould diſanulled iudged traytor granting wherevpon archbiſhop roſe would haue anſwered king ſayde morrow morrow came parliament houſe againe king ſaid would deliberate common petition alſo eſtabliſhed traytor conuicted ſtand againſt king regalitie ſhould adiudged worthie ſuffer puniſhment appoynted ſuch offence alſo enacted criminall cauſes thenceforthſhould determined euery parliament licence depart great ſturre made vſed wherevpon king archer number four thouſand compaſſed parliament houſe thinking bin houſe ſome broyle fighting bowes bent arrowes ſet drawing readie ſhoote terrour king héerewith comming pacified next day prelate inioyned vpon payne loſing temporality ſhould ſame day agrée vpon ſome procurator conſent name al thing parliament diſpatched king theſe word sir iohn buſhy bycauſe many deſire would explane fiftie perſons exempted y• general pardon wil briefely man ſoeuer deſireth worthie death firſt bicauſe fléeth ſecondly bycauſe haue excepted thoſe impeached parliament thirdly bycauſe aſſociates hearing thē oppreſſed would afraide feare next day archbiſhop canterbury commeth palace appeare parliament king commanded biſhop carelile ſhoulde returne houſe thenceforth appeared prelate made thomas percy king steward houſhold procurator conſent thing parliament done alſo sir iohn buſhy theſe word ſoueraigne lord king bycauſe ſecond article parliament puniſhmente appoynted ſuche violate king royall authoritie beſéech grace authorice way appealing accuſing impeaching licence make declaration one reſt ſo often fellowes may ſéeme expedient graunted buſhy theſe word accuſe thomas arundell archbiſhop canterbury thréefold treaſon frſt commiſſion granting regiment gouernement realme thomas duke glocester richard earle arundell inſtance rather bycauſe chancellour ſhould haue refuſed secondly vnder pretext trayterous commiſſion trayterouſly vſurping iuriſdiction regalitie royall authoritie held ſolemne parliament trayterouſlie preiudice regalitie thirdly bycauſe ſayde trayterous vſurping sir simon de burley sir iames barnes knightes faithfull liege trayterouſlie murthered put death thing common demaund iudgement worthie ſo high treaſon terribly pronounced bycauſe archbiſhop man great conſanguinitie affinitie power moſt politike witte cruell nature preſeruation eſtate whole kingdomes petition preſent parliament require may put ſafecuſtodie vntill finall execution iudgemente king héerevnto anſwered excellence dignitie would take deliberation till next morrow put ſame commiſſion pronounced faithfull liege people voyd treaſon eſpecially alexander neuell late archbiſhop yorke sir edmond langley duke yorke unkle king sir william wikeham biſhop winchester put ſame commiſſion teares fell downe ground king gaue humble thankes grace benefite beſtowed alſo saint mathewes day earle rutland earles kent huntington notingham somerſet saliſburie lordes spencer scrope ſute redde gownes silke garded bordered white silke embrodered letter golde proponed appeale king notingham ſet foorthe accuſed thomas duke glocester richard earle arundell thomas earle warwike thomas de mortimere knight premiſed treaſons armed inſurrection haringey parke trayterouſlie attempted againſt king putting ſureties proſecuting appeale richarde earle arundell arreigned redde gowne scarlet whood forthwith duke lancaster ſayde lorde neuell take hym hys girdle whoode ſo done héerewith article appeale béeing ſayde earle declared valiaunt bolde mynde hée denyed hée traytor required benefite pardon proteſting would goe fauour king grace duke lancaster ſayde hym thou traytor pardon reuoked earle anſwered truely thou lyeſt neuer traytor alſo duke lancaster ſayde diddeſt thou purchaſe thy pardon earle anſwered eſcape tongue myne enimies whome thou arte one verily farre forth toucheth treaſon thou haſt néede pardon king ſayde make anſwere vnto thyne appeale earle anſwered ſée well theſe perſons haue accuſed treaſon ſhewing appealementes▪ truely lye neuer traytor aſke alwayes benefyte pardon whyche youre grace granted within theſe ſixe yeares laſt paſt full age francke good proper motion ſayd king ſo grant ſhould againſt ſayde duke lancaster graunt auayleth erle anſwered truly pardon know leſſe thy ſelfe ſide sea ſaid sir iohn buſhy pardon reuoked king lordes v faithfull people earle anſwered thoſe faithful people know thée well thy company ye gathered togither deale faithfully faithful people realme héere therefore people lamente well know thou haſt bin euer falſe buſhy fellowes cried behold ſoueraigne lord king traytor goeth reyſe ſedition betwixt v thoſe people home earle anſwered ye lye traytor roſe earle darby ſayde didſt thou ſay thus huntington firſt aſſembled togither riſe beſt afore thing take king earle ſayd earle darby thou lyeſt thy head neuer thought ſoueraigne▪ lorde king good honor ſayd king didſt thou ſay time thy parliament bath behinde white hall sir simon de burley worthie death many cauſes anſwered knew cauſe death yet thou thy fellowes didſt trayterouſlie put death duke lancaſter pronounced iudgement againſt manner richard iohn steward england iudge thée traytor condemne thée drawne hanged beheaded quartered thy land tailed tailed thée thine heires thy body deſcending confilcate king reuerence bloud commanded beheaded ledde tower hill beheaded buried auguſtine frier london alſo ſame day king appoynted lord cobham accuſed common arraigned alſo vpon saterday sir thomas de mortimer ſommoned vpon payne baniſhed traytor within ſixe moneths come tried iudgement ſaide king peraduenture earle march take therefore ſo long ſtay certificate ireland alſo declaration made benefice gift granted alienated thoſe already condemned condemned parliament whatſoeuer graunted ſith tenth yeare king raigne ſhould reuoked alſo monday following certificate giuen earle notingham captayne caleis whoſe cuſtodie duke glocester ſame duke might brought tried iudgement bycauſe dead cuſtodie caleis petition yet ſaide appellents ſame ſentence pronounced againſt bin pronounced earſt againſt earle arundell alſo archbiſhop canterbury firſt temporality confiſcated baniſhed realme tueſday rikell king juſtices borne ireland read certayne confeſſions drawne writing vpon ſaid treaſons put forth affirming ſame confeſſions ſaid duke put forth diſcouered written owne hand alſo earledome chester aduanced honor duchie annexing thereto land ſayd earle arundell confiſcate alſo ſame day earle saliſburie made requeſt haue scire facia graunted againſt earle march lordſhip denbigh wale king anſwered therevpon would take deliberation alſo wedneſday ordeyned land ſayde earle arundell annexed duchie chester ſhould enioy liberty ſame duchie excepted welchmen thoſe partes olde lawes cuſtomes ſhould ſtill remayne continued alſo ordeyned ſuch gaue eyther counſell ayde fauour child condemned ſhoulde condemned parliamente ſhould puniſhed traytors friday king appoynted prefixed day archbiſhop canterbury wéete third ſixt wéeke depart realme alſo ordeyned lord spiritual temporall ſhould ſweare inuiolably obſerue whatſoeeuer parliament enacted cenſures church ſhould pronounced prelate againſt thoſe ſhould go againſt ſame alſo earle warwike arreigned whood taken appeale read bin ſome miſerable old woman confeſſed thing conteyned appeale wéeping wayling howling done trayterouſly ſubmitting himſelfe king grace thing ſorowing euer bin aſſociate vnto appellant king demanded whome allured ioyne anſwered thomas duke glocester abbot saint albons monke recluſe westminster euer beſought king grace mercie king granted life led perpetuall priſon realme goodes moueable vnmoueable confiſcate earle arundels bin king commanded ſhould tower london conuayde • uer caſtell within iſle man vnder wardſhip william scrope lord ſayd ile remayne perpetuall priſon morrow king granted wife fiue • markes yearely liues alſo writ scire facia granted earle saliſburie againſt earle march ſayd lordſhip denbigh fiftéene dayes reſpite giuen put anſwere item ordeyned thoſe ought money rochester bridge ſhould put execution payment vſe ſame bridge alſo henry bolenbroke earle derby ſonne heire ofdukes created iohn gaunt lancaster created hereforde edward earle rutland created duke aumarle thomas earle kent duke surrey earle notingham duke norffolke iohn earle huntington duke excester iohn earle somerſet marque dorſet thomas lorde spencer earle glocester lorde neuell earle weſtmerland thomas percy earle worceſter william scrope l treaſourer earle wiltſhire sir iohn mountagew earle saliſburie k added armes k edward confeſſor bare togither part pale parliament proroged till octaues hillary holden shrewſburie iohn woodcocke william askam 28 septemb sherifes maior vveſtminſter hall repaired sir richard whitington mercer 28 october king richard cauſed great hall westminster repaired walles windowes ruffe maruellous worke great coſtes whiche leuied stranger baniſhed countreys obteyned licence remayne coūtrey king charter purchaſed great ſommes money king richard kept chriſtmas liechfield then1398 tooke iourney towardes shrewſburie parliament lately proroged began againe ordeined statute ordeyned westminster xj yeare y• king raigne ſhould reuoked diſanulled al y• article ſame heires thē adiudged y• ſaid parliament ſhould recōciled reſtored land inheritance poſſeſſions excepted y• ſhould haue clayme againſt withholder profile reuenues thoſe land meane time morrow ordeyned heires whiche iudged conuicted foure article high treaſon ſhould enioy land poſſeſſions progenitor ſhould excluded euery action clayme euer firſt article high treaſon man condition ſoeuer imagin king death ſecond article man ſhould haue imagination depoſe king third man ride armed within realm england manner warre againſt king fourth mā diſclaymed y• king homage alſo ſame day lord cobham arraigned make anſwere vnto two article high treaſon firſt ſayde lorde cobham counſell make one commiſſion againſt ſtate king likewiſe vſed ſame commiſſion iudgement againſt king preiudice ſeconde ſate iudgement iudge sir simon de burley iames barnes knightes king abſence againſt vpon cō uict iudged perpetuall priſon within ile ierſey morrow henry duke hereford accuſed thomasthe duke hereford accuſeth duke norffolke mowbray duke norffolke certaine word ſpoken rode betwéene london brayneford tending diſhonor king perſon duke norffolke vtterly denayd haue ſpoken vpon combate granted king fought ata combate granted couentry vpon ſeauentéenth september fiftéenth halfe granted cuſtomes woolles fiftie shilling euery sacke euery engliſhman borne thrée pound euery stranger parliament ended king viſited many place weaſt part england worcester hereford bristow place wéete glastonbury bath alſo king cauſed theatre made atanno reg 22 bristow combate fought betwixt two scottes wéete one béeing eſquire appellant knight defendant appellant ouercome hanged time made great maruellous ſtrong theatre couentrie combate betwixte duke hereford duke norffolke gaue day fight ſixtéenth september wéete feaſt day saint edith day place great concourſe aſſemble people gathered partes englande ſayde champion appeared liſtes readie fighte king commanded quiet fight kyng ſitting hys royall apparell within tente girt sworde hée commanded hys decrée bée proclaymed thys king decrée henry duke hereforde hys diſobedience towardes kingdukes • anished ſhoulde bée baniſhed tenne yeares likewiſe duke norffolke baniſhed euer england taking reuenues thouſand markes yeare till towne caleis repaired iohn wade iohn warner 28 september sherifes maior sir drew barrentine goldſmith 28 october feaſt saint michaell king cauſed ſeauentéene county east england bée indited layde theyr charge bin agaynſte duke glocester earles arundell warwike wherefore hée ſente honourable men induce lord spirituall temporall make ſubmiſſion writing ſealed theyr owne handes acknowledging themſelues bée traytors king though neuer offended word déede moreouer compelled religious gentleman common ſetblancke charter seales blanckes ende might pleaſed oppreſſe ſeuerally ſome common payde thouſande markes ſome thouſande pounde c alſo ordeyned euery prouince englande gentleman mē ſubſtance ſhould ſwornevn • cuſtomed othes firmely maynteyne according poſſible power statute article conſtitutions ordeyned laſt parliament newyeares day néere vnto bedforde déepe water ranne betwixt townes swelstone harleſwode ſtoode ſodeinly ſtill deuided ſelfe ſo ſpace thrée mile botome remained drie wonder many one thought ſignifie deuiſion people falling away king whiche hapned ſhortly roger mortimere earle march vlstar ireland earle march ſlaine irelād cro pet coledge w l wilum lying caſtel came great multitude wilde iriſhmen aſſayle iſſuing fought manfully till hewen péeces whoſe death king determined reuenge candlemas dyed iohn gaunt lancaster biſhop elyes inne holborne london wasduke lancaſter deceaſed 1399 honourably buryed paules church london ſonne henry duke hereford beyond ſeas whitſontide king richard nauie 100 ship ſayled milford hauen towards ireland arriuedking richarde ſayled ireland waterford laſt day maynfrem whence marched armie thirtie thouſande kilkenny foureſcore mile within countrey remayned xiiij dayes tarying edward duke aumarle midſommer euen went thence toward mackmore whoanno reg 23 remayned amongſt wood 3000 mē right hardy ſuch ſéemed little feare engliſhmen entring wood king commanded fire vſed ſo many houſe many village brent king made duke hereford ſonne knight ten 2500 pioners appoynted fell wood make wayes ye engliſhmen iriſhmē feared greatly ſhot engliſhmen yet dartes aſſayled ſlewe diuers caught aduantage unkle mackmore came yéelded himſelfethe vnkle mackmore ſubmitted king richard king withie necke many naked bare legged like king pardoned king ſente mackmore promiſing would come unkle done withie necke ſhould pardoned vtterly refuſing ſayd would fight death defending right knew engliſhmen wanted victualles brought could bought gold siluer already ſuch ſcarcitie ſome four ſome ſixe ſmall lofe bread liue day ſome eate grayne fiue dayes togither king therefore departed 28 day june toward diuelin time mackmore ſent beggar notice king hée would friend aſke mercy elſe pleaſed treate peace ſend ſome noble mē whervpon earle glocester ſent led reregard wherof captayne two c lance archer betwixt two wood farre sea mette iriſh mackmore himſelfe rode whitemackmore good horſeman horſſe without ſaddle furniture coſt ſayde foure hundred kowes whiche horſſe ranne downe hill beholder reported neuer ſéene hare déere haue runne ſo ſwiftly hys righte hande bare darte greate long whiche threwe excéeding well mightie ſtrong man perſonage earle hée talked good whyle aboute murthering earle march thynges agrée coulde ſo departed earle aduertiſed king foūd nothing enimie woulde crie mercie ſo might ſure haue peace without griefe otherwiſe would ſo long liued defend himſelfe wherefore king wrath knowing lette might happen ſware would neuer depart irelande till eyther aliue dead hoſt diſlodged lacke victualles thirtie thouſands comming ouer lay diuelin fiftéene dayes king forthwith deuiding armie thrée partes ſente ſéeke mackemore promiſing hundreth markes could bring offer well hearkened vnto ſounded well could caught ſame day edwarde earle rutlande duke aumarle conneſtable englande arriued hundreth sayle whoſe comming king verie glad though indéede taried long mighte haue come muche ſooner remayned ſixe wéekes diuelin heard newes englande paſſage ſo dangerous winde béeing contrary tempeſtes ſo greate length came shippe heauie newes duke hereforde deceaſſe father duke lancaster arriued england rauenſpore duke hereford returned englande beſide wadlington yorkeſhire beheaded william scrope earle wilſhire treaſourer englande iohn buſhy henry greene cauſed thomas arundell archbiſhop canterbury preach againſte king richarde alſo ſhewed bull procured rome promiſing remiſſion ſinnes thoſe whiche ſhould ayde ſayde henry conquering enimies death placed paradiſe preaching moued manye cleaue duke upon newes king perſwaded make haſt ouer duke aumarle ſayde better ſtay till hys shippes mighte bée brought togither hundreth readie make sayle wherevpon iohn mountacute earle saliſburie ſente power whileſt king going waterforde mighte gather hys fléete promiſed within ſixe dayes haue followed hym earle salesburie landed conwey hée ſoone aduertiſed howe duke taken parte englande lord got thréeſcore thouſand men earle saleſburie cauſed ſommon welchmen cheſhire come ſo wéening king bin arriued conwey within foure dayes come togither fortie thouſand men ready goe againſt duke hereford ſtayd fourtéene dayes ſaw king came ſtealed away left earle saliſburie manner alone ſo vnneath c men duke hereford aduanced towards earle saliſburie withdrew conwey king euill counſellking richard returned ireland landed milford hauen ſtayd earles departure eyghtéene dayes arriued milford hauen whence midnight following deſguiſed like prieſt feare knowne thirtéene perſons went conwey thinking earle saliſburie helde fielde duke excester surrey earle glocester continued faithfull vnto laſt houre thrée biſhops alſo two like good men biſhop lincolne saint dauids third continued faithfull biſhop carelile alſo two knightes stephen scrope william fireby ianico gaſcoigne king rode ſo warely came conwey breake daye great ſorrow lamentation made king earle méeting earles hoſt diſperſed gone ſome duke ſome otherwayes duke aumarle conneſtable chiefe gouernour king armie milford immediately whē king departure knowne ſayde souldiers let v ſhift ſelues mayſters king fledde wherevpon euery man truſſed away sir thomas percy steward houſhold talking conneſtable alſo departed tooke way wale welſhmen ſéeing ſuch diſorder aſſembled togither ſpoyled engliſhmen goodes ſent packing dublets white ſtaues hand rode héere tenne héere twentie héere fiftie héere hundred ſo welchmen comming downe mountaynes engliſh loſt king many horſſes beyond sea broode great rich apparell iewels kéeping sir thomas percy conneſtable came duke henry hereford fiue hundred companye naked whome welchmen deſpoyled beaten well king conwey great diſcomfort ſent duke excester surrey henry duke hereford lancaster know meaning himſelfe remayning ſtill conwey great perplexitie earle saliſburie biſhop carelile sir william ferebe knight sir stephen scrope mine author another frenchman xvj perſons newes brought king conneſtable demeaned likewiſe steward cauſed rich brought aland going wale welchmen taken king aduiſe earle saliſburie departed conwey vnto beawmareis ten mile thence went carnaruan beawmaris ſtrong fortreſſe bin manned victualled carnaruan faire towne ſtrong caſtell theſe vnprouided thing ſo fiue ſixe nightes lay hard baſe victualles none wherefore returned againe conwey ſore lamented eſtate duke excester surrey entring citie cheſter duke henry taken brought ſtreight caſtell duke glad ſée forthwith aſked duke excester newes tolde poynt poynt ſhame diſhonour woulde dealt ſo vniuſtly towardes prince depoſed hée therefore demaunded • ſpéede duke lancaster ſlow diſpatch tolde hym ſhoulde goe one wéeke king well aduiſed ſende hym fellow béeing men ſuch calling ſith ynow meaner eſtate meſſage ſo remayned great diſcomfort duke excester duke henry ſtill kepte hys company duke surrey committed ſafekéeping within caſtell chester caſtell ſixe mile chester called beston caſtell builded rocke verye ſtrong ſcituation therein hundred men armes choſen able men diligent deliuered duke might well ynough haue kept aſcending ſo ſtéepe victualled ſixe yeares founde within coyne better hundred thouſande markes beſide jewel king richard cauſed kepte value two hundred thouſande markes duke henry tooke wyth returned chester taking counſell friendes beſt bée done archbiſhop canterburie ſayde ſith kyng wale whych countrey ſtrong reaſon mountaynes ſo impoſſible armie paſſe wyth bagge baggage hée thought beſt ſende vnto king richarde make hym beléeue hée ſought nothing peace parliamente bée made wherein thoſe offended putting death unkle duke glocester ſhoulde bée puniſhed ſo thenceforth king duke good friendes ſhould king pleaſure appoynte day place thys parliamente withoute thys ſhifte ſhoulde bée vnpoſſible duke gette hym handes hée mighte departe sea hée woulde hauing retayned conwey shippes purpoſe lord aſſenting counſell duke appoynted earle northumberland go king four hūdred launce thouſand archer earle came flint castell deliuered hand thence haſted rudland alſo giuen ouer laying vnder rocke two great embuſhments people commandemente kéepe paſſage went fiue company sea coaſt till came towne ſent herault king ſafeconduct come preſence declare meſſage duke agréement ſafeconduct granted paſſed water entred caſtell conwey founde king earle saliſburie declared peace woulde made would good judge true cauſe thoſe ſhould named tried iuſtice certayne day parliament westminster duke ſhould holde togither duke might kéepe place high judge father aunceſters done ſpace one hundred yeares thoſe would haue tried law duke excester duke surrey earle saliſburie biſhop carelile thomas marke fiue giuen king counſell put unkle y• duke glocester death ſhould pleaſe pardon duke wrath would readie come knées aſke mercie ſo might goe london togither one one way another earle offered ſweare ſhoulde perfourmed duke aſſured oth ſtand king liking ſhould libertie go eyther companie duke alone vnto london purpoſed take offer ſo pretend ſome excuſe going alone ſhould méete duke lacke victualles ſuch like ſo take byway thorough wale rayſe power accorded goe duke maſſe celebrate earle northumberlande ſware vpon hoſt duke ſhould holde tolde king earle haſted king forwarde horſſebacke king prayed erle go vnto rutland prepare dinner erle rode pace till came mighte ſée people vnder mountaine muche commended obſeruing commaundement king paſſing water rode four mile came rock ſawe ambuſhes wask r betraye • ▪ ſore abaſhed knowing well betrayed earle ſuch place coulde eſcape sea beating one ſide rock kéeping ſhoulde haue fled backe woulde haue caught could haue come conway paſt thrée twentie company k diſſē ding rocke earle came knéeling excuſed matter ſaying▪ hadde cauſed thoſe people come guarde perſon king tolde fewer wold haue ſerued contrarie othe promiſed haue ſixe company ſayde therefore would goe backe conway earle aunſweared nowe ſith would leade duke promiſed ten dayes ſince ſo cauſed breade wine bee broughte offered king durſt refuſe leaping horſſebacke againe rode rutlande dinner flinte lay night morrow two twentie day auguſt king got caſtell wals beheld al hoſt hundred thouſand men comming ſands came departed army archbiſhop canterburie ſir thomas percy earle rutland duke taken office coneſtable colour diſpleaſure bare duke order harte whyche king archbiſhoppe entred firſte great traine went vp dungeon king came downe walles vnto whō reuerence lowlye knées king toke vp drew archbiſhop apart two talked lōg togither earle rutland kept aloof toke horſſe againe rode towards duke approched neare kyng went vp againe walles lamē ting ſore ſaw duke hoſte within two bowe ſhootes caſtell compaſſed rounde ſea earle northumberland wente forthe duke long talke concluded duke ſhould enter caſtel king dyned faſting ſo earle returned king ſet dynner whome ſate aſſured friend earle salisburie biſhop carlile ſir steuen scrope feribe ſat long eate little haſte riſe dinner duke entred caſtel armed baſenet excepted king richard came downe méete duke ſoone ſaw king fell downe hys knées comming neare vnto knéeled ſecond time hat hand king put hoode ſpake firſt faire couſin lancaster yée righte welcome duke bowing lowe grounde anſweared lord come ſent reaſon wil ſhew cōmon fame among people ſuche yée haue ſpace twentie two twentie yeares ruled rigorouſly pleaſe lorde helpe gouerne better kyng aunſwered fayre couſin lancaster ſith pleaſeth pleaſeth mée wel duke ſpake yée haue heard king ſpake alſo biſhop carlile ſir stephen scrope feribe earle saliſburie ſpake whereby earle perceyued duke hated deadly duke high ſharp voyce bad bring forth king horſſes two little nagges worthe fortie frank brought forth king ſet one earle saliſburie thus duke brought king flinte chester delyuered duke glocesters ſonne earle arundales ſonne loued little put theyr father death ledde hym ſtrayghte caſtel thirde day went nantwich next daye newe castle earle warwickes ſon mette thē ſo iournying forth next day came stafford departed lichfield k thought haue eſcaped ſlypping downe gardaine windowe great tower eſpyed thruſt tower againe liechfielde duke went couentrie coulde come thyther welchmen much harme ſlew many engliſhmen great chaunce coulde take anye welchmen tyed horſſe tayles drewe way ful ſtones cauſed die miſerablye duke paſſed couentrie deintrie next day northampton thence dunstable saint albons fiue ſixe mile hys comming london maior companyes lyueries greate noyſe trumpet mette duke doyng reuerence hym kyng reioycing god ſente ſuche prince conquered realme within one monthes ſpace duke came within two mile citie duke cauſed hoſte ſtay ſaid common citie maiſters beholde youre king conſider yée doe wyth anſwered woulde ſhould ledde westminster wherevppon deliuered vnto ledde westminster thence water tower london entred london ye chief gate rode cheape sainte paules lodged biſhops pallace fiue ſixe dayes saint iohns without smithfield remained xv day thēce remoued hertforde abonde thrée wéekes came backe london hold parliament began firſte wedneſday october westminster hall hung trimmed ſumptuouſly hadde cauſed ſet vp royall chayre purpoſe choſe new king neare whiche prelate ſet ſide ſat lord commōs order firſt ſat duke lancaster duke yorke duke aumerle duke surrey duke excester marque order earles arundale norfolke march stafford penbroke saliſburie deuonſhire erles northumberlande westmerlande ſat went vppe oftentimes knéeled fell theyr office archbiſhop canterburie made sermon toke theame▪ habuit iacob benedictionē prē ſuo ſermon ended latin doctour law ſtoode vp red inſtrument contained k richard owne confeſſion diſabled himſelfe worthy raigne woulde reſigne crowne ſuch one ſufficiente rule inſtrument red archbiſhop perſwaded thē procéede election new k perceyuing al cōtented ther wer paſt four perſons wer king richards part durſt ſay nothing aſked thē whō wold haue king whether duke yorke aunſwered aſked would haue eldeſt ſon aumarle ſayd aſked would haue yongeſt ſon ſayd ſo diuerſe thē ſtaying aſked wold haue lancaster aunſwered would haue none diamounde made thrice drew certain inſtruments charter red preſence thē ye archbiſhops cōming duke fell theyr knées declaring choſen king willed take regarde would conſent thereto thē knées roſe declared y• accepted realm ſith ordayned god thē ye archbiſhop red yt new k bound vnto certain ceremony ſigned croſſe thē kiſſed achbiſhop toke ring king wedded realme bare lord percy coneſtable receyuing ſhewed al aſſembly put king finger king kiſſed coneſtable archbiſhops led 〈◊〉 royal y• k made prayer knées ſpake vnto firſt ye prelate lord al ſo ſet ſeate thus inueſted k richard put ſat good kept ſilence ſo reſt prayer proſperitie gouernement ended wher office voyde k created lord percy coneſtable toke ſtaffe choſen ralph earle westmerland marſhal iohn skirley chanceller ſir richard clifforde kéeper priuy ſeale many officer newely confirmed arcbiſhoppe ſpake certayne thing latin praying y• king proſperitie realmes ſpake engliſh exhorting preſent pray like euery man ſat king roſe made eldeſt ſon prince wale lord ſworne true prince done father hys ſeconde ſonne made duke lancaſter thus king richard depoſed raigned two twenty yeres thrée monthes odde dayes ¶ henrie bolengbroke henrie fourth ſon iohn g canterburie duke yorke surrey aumarle earle glocester bare canapie ouer ſir thomas dimmocke champion rode thrée time hall noble valiaunt prince ciuill warres appeaſed ſhewed himſelfe louing ſubiectes made henrie ſonne prince wale duke cornwal erle cheſter heyre apparaunt crowne william waldren william hyde 28 september sherifes maior sir thomas knowles grocer 28 october ſolemnitie coronation lord common ſtreight procéeded parliamēt inquired death duke glocester hée bin murdered caleis duke norſfolke vpon y• king commaundement king hent • e created hys eldeſt ſ •• ne prince wale duke 〈…〉 earle cheſter duke aquitaine parliament ordained ſtatutes made parliament holden 21 yere king richard westminster proroged vnto shreweſburie circūſtances adnulled reuoked made voyde vtterly blotted alſo parliament holdē westminster xj yere k richard holden firme ſtable alſo lord perſōs iudged forth parliament holden 21 yere king richard heires deade ſhoulde wholy reſtored poſſeſſions without • uing liuèrie thereof made excepted lord ſhal haue nothing ye iſſues receiued ye mean time • gaue e northumberland ye ile man holdē k ſeruice beare ſword wt entred england • westmerland gaue coūtie richmond alſo judgement giuen againſt appellauntes duke glocester maner lord preſent parliament ſhe king aſſent iudge duke •• erle surrey excester preſent appellantes ſhal lo • e thryr name duke h • nors hēceforth togither dignity duke marque dorſet preſent loſe hys name macques e glocester preſēt loſe name heires ye aboue named perſons al • caſtels poſſeſſions manor thē belonged thoſe appelled frō ye day y• arreſt glocester lord time ſimply without fauour mercie ſhal loſe thē al caſtels poſſeſſiōs manours lordſhips liberty helde king gift day ſh • ld reſt kinge grace ye h •• letter patent charter whiche y• ſaid name caſtels dominion poſſeſſions liberty ſhold ſurrendered vp ye chancerie canceled ſtand ſtate whiche name poſſeſſion ſaide daye • f ſayde arreſt king ſhew men part ſore oppreſſed great pe ••• lence entred enimies thoſe part toke coſtell warke kept ſame certain time lēgth ſpoyled •• terly ruinated many miſchients country thomas manbery duke norffolk exiled dyed venide returne ieruſalem alſo duches glocester dyed hir ſonne heir • humfrey dyed peſtitence hée ſent forth irelande king helde feaſt chriſtmaſſe caſtel windſor iohn holland late duke excester erie huntington thomas holand late duke surrey earle kente edwarde late duke aumerle earle rutlande ſonne duke yorke iohn mountacute eri • • sabſburie thomas spencer ſir ralph lumley ſir thomas blunt ſir benedict cely knight fauoures king richarde conſpired againſt king henrie appointed priuily murder vnder colour juſting paſtimes pretended time approching theyr purpoſe ſent meſſengers london letter duke aumerle ſhoulde fayle come ye day appointed company helpe feate whervnto ſworne minde altered hée bare letter ſtreighte father duke yorke cauſed number men forthwith carrye ſon king ſhewing letter king woulde beléeue ſame morning came maior london court informed matter whervpon king made tariance got forth toward london companye maior king coulde gette london backe enimies come windeſore entred caſtell armed band 400 mē fourth januarie night vnderſtanding king eſcaped theyr hand ſore amazed withdrewe windeſore vnto sunning certaine manour neare reading quéene wife king richarde lay perſuaded hyr houſhold king richarde eſcaped romfrete • aſtel would go thence went walling forde abingdon mouing people take armes vppon goe méete king richarde came farindon vale white horſſe barkeſhire ſame daye circester xij day late eneni • g harbored greate number men ar • e many archer ther bruted k richard eſcaped forth priſon hée make word tō haue credite got chaplaine king richardes called madeleine ſo like hym proportion fauor one could vnneth deſcerned many time ſayth mine aucthour haue ſéene ireland ride king maſter ſo faire prieſt goodly perſon lightly ſéene put armoure crowne helmet ſo men mighte take king richard morrow wedneſday people towne miſliking procéedings fought againſt length toke chiefeſt ledde abbay put fayre chamber vnder ſafe cuſtody thurſday ſaid lordes fearing people imagined howe eſcape theyr handes cauſed ſome ſeruauntes ſette fire certaine houſes towne thinking therevppon people woulde departe ſéeke ſtaunche fire chaunced contrarie people turned maruellous rage againſt ranne vppon great violence drew market place beheaded duke excester duke surrey earle saliſburie thirde day epiphanie • ſeruauntes taken priſoners bound brought richarde aliue andconſpiracie againſt k henrie ſhould ſhortly ſhew himſelf openly reward y• wer faithful vnto certain prieſt taken warwike written ye name many aucthours theſe trouble hope feare conſpiracie vaniſhed prieſt drawen hanged quartered alſo walter waldocke late priour lande priorie leicesterſhire bycauſe confeſſed knew euill againſt king conceale likewiſe hanged headed moreouer certaine gray frier taken whiche one richard friſeby doctour diuinitie beinga ſtout frier executed aſked would k richard preſent anſwered woulde fight quarrel againſt man euen death wherfore condemned drawen hanged religious habit wéede daneburie eſſex vpon corpus christi day diuell appeared likeneſſe gray frier entring church raged inſolentlye greate feare pariſhioners ſame houre tempeſte whyrlewinde thunder toppe stéeple broken downe halfe chauncel ſcattered abrode shortlye ſir roger claringdon knighte baſtard ſonne edward blacke prince wyth squire yeomanne beheadded eyghte graye frier hanged beheaded london two leicester whiche hadde publiſhed king richard bée aliue owen glendouerdew company welchmen inuaded ſhires bordered neare vnto hym wherefore ſir edmund mortimer wyth manye knightes eſquiers wente encounter owen ſtronger countrey came martial affayres owne archer turned theyr handes againſte whome ſhoulde haue defended flayne aboue eleauen hundred men sir edmunde mortimer taken welchwomen ye battayle done vſing deade carcaſſes ſhamefullye bée ſpoken woulde ſuffer buryed without great raunſome kyng went wyth greate power wale purſue owē glendouerdew profited nothing loſte muche welchmen conuayed themſelues vnknowen place wherefore king conſtrayned neceſſitie returned englande ſpoyled brent countrey ſame time scottes cruelly entred england ſuppoſed lord beyond humber occupyed party wale erles northumberlande henrie percie ſonne henrie earle dunbarre good whyle agone hauing forſaken scottes ſworne true king england number armed men plentie archer ſodainly came reſiſte scottes woulde haue retourned home hadde ſpoyled brente countrey nowe vppon ſodayne theyr waye forelayde ſo muſte néedes abyde take place fighte vppon choſe therefore mountaine neare towne wollor called halydowe hill whiche place themſelues wyth theyr armed men archer men beheld leauing way ſtoode againſt scottes clynie hill ſtoode ouer againſt scottes without delaye time archer placed valley ſet arrowes againſt scottes battayle might ſome mean force come downe ſide scottiſhe archer let flye men yet felt grieuous waighte bin ſhower tempeſt arrowes ſhotte engliſhmen fledde earle dowglas perceyuing men ſo flée generall leader tooke hys speare manfullye wyth multitude came hyll truſting doubtleſſe armour ye armour hys complices hadde bin thrée yeares makyng forced himſelfe runne vpon archer whiche archer ſawe ſtepped backe ſhotte ſo fiercely pierced armed men body ſtroke throughe theyr helmet ryued speares rente theyr armoure wyth lyghte adoe earle dowglas hymſelfe wounded fiue place reſidue scottes come beſide hyll turnyng backe arrowes flewe fledde awaye theyr flyghte nothing auayled whileſt archer followed compelled yéelde themſelues earle dowglas alſo taken manye drowned riuer tweede whyleſt knewe fourdes number fiue hundered ſayde thys battayle lorde knighte squire gaue anye ſtroke enimyes onely god gaue victorie engliſhe archer lordes armed menne béeyng onelye looker daye flower scottiſhe chi • alrye taken witte earle dowglas murdake eldeſt ſonne duke albanie heyre apparente realme scotlande earles murrey angus orkeney lordes mountgomorie erskin gram manye knyghtes▪ number foureſcore beſides eſquires yeoman whoſe number knowne ſlayne baron lord gordon lord iohn swinton falſe realmes c battayle fought fourtéenth september counteſſe oxforde mother robert de vere duke ireland ſayde died louaine cauſe ſuche familiar hir brute throughout part estſex king richard aliue ſhould ſhortly come chalenge old eſtate dignitie cauſed many hart siluer ſome gold made badge ſuch king richarde wont beſtow knightes eſquires friend diſtributing king name ſhe might ſooner allure knightes valiant men countrey hir deſire alſo fame brute whiche dayly blazed abroade one william serle ſometimes king richards chamber ſame king richard scotland tarried power french scottiſhmen cauſed many beléeue aliue william serle forged priuie▪ seale ſaid king richards name ſent diuers comfortable letter vnto ſuch familiar king richarde meanes many gaue greater credite counteſſe ſo much ſome religious▪ abbot countrey giue credite vnto hir tale afterward taken af king commandement empriſoned bycauſe beléeue giue credit counteſſe behalfe counteſſe hir goodes confiſcate cōmitted cloſe priſon william serle drawne frō pomfret chiefeſt city stephen spilman 28 september sherifes maior sir iohn hinde draper 28 october feaſt saint faith king called parliament couentry ſent proceſſe sheriffes ſhould chooſe knight burgeſſes knowledge lawes realme reaſon wherof called lay man parliamēt theſe piked knightslay man parliament burgeſſes could deuiſe none way reléeue king lacke money depriue cleargie temporall land goodes thomas arundell archbiſhop canterbury made anſwere cleargie alwayes giue king much lay people conſidering •• er giue king tenthes laytie gaue fiftéenes moreouer tenant ſerue king warres thā tenant lay fée beſides prayed proſperitie king faithfully ſerued whē ſpeker ye parliamēt ſaid loud voice little regarded ye prayer church archbiſhop cāterbury anſwered quoth know end fortune realme come whē ſuffrages ye church ſet wherwith ye godhead wont appeaſed ſurely kingdome neuer cōtinueth ſtable y• voyde prayer deuotion notwithſtanding thinke thou ſhalt without puniſhmēt take away poſſeſſiōs church archbiſhop canterburie liue thou ſhalte haue euill taking thing archbiſhoppe roſe vppe knéeled downe kyng deſiring hym conſider howe gratiouſlie god fauour atteyned kingdome▪ would cōſider firſt promis would preſerue vnto euery man right title ſo farre lay alſo willed remember oth voluntarily made would honor defend church miniſters thereof wherefore deſired permit ſuffer church enioy priuiledges liberty time predeceſſors enioy feare king whome king doe raigne archbiſhop ſaid theſe like word king commanded go ſeate againe ſayde intent purpoſe leaue church good ſtate better found archbiſhop ſpeaking knightes burgeſſes ſayde ſuch like haue giuen ſuch counſell vnto king predeceſſors▪ confiſcate goodes thein edvvard third time celles whiche frenchman norman poſſeſſe england ſayd ſhould heape vp great rich déede woorth many thouſands gold notwithſtanding moſt true king day richer thereby halfe marke haue extorted leaſt begged handes haue appropriated ſaide goodes vnto ſelues ſo may coniectured requeſt haue temporality king profite owne couetouſneſſe without doubt king god forbid ſhould fulfill wicked purpoſe ſhould one farthing richer next yeare following ſurely ſooner let head cut churche ſhould deſtitute leaſt right perteyneth c cleargie granted tenth halfe common two fiftéenes condition lord furniuall ſhould receyne ſpend king warres ſame time ſuch abundance water brake ſodeinly ouer bankes kent neuer ſéene like thoſe partes whereby drowned beaſtes cattell without number neyther england bewayle theyr loſſes alſo zeland flanders holland ſuſteyned like great exceſſe water yeare died william wikeham biſhop wincheſter colledge oxford whoſe charge trauell cleargie england much encreaſed builded notable colledge oxford encreaſe learning placed warden company number lxx beſides child ſeruants tenne prieſtes kéepe dayly ſeruice enduing ſayd company ſufficient land beganne foundation new colledge winchester colledge vvincheſter ſixe yeares finiſhed ſame placed like number schollers learne grāmer principle ſent afterward colledge oxford theſe two colledges called new colledges dedicated bleſſed lady builded great body church saint swithens winchester sermon made body enterred princely worke neyther diminiſh thing ordinarie houſholde charge fedde writing engraued sepulchre ſheweth rich poore deceaſſed age foureſcore yeares dyed rich beſide gaue kinſefolke poore gaue ſomewhat euery church dioces gaue many thing king owne ſeruants colledges neyther doubt yt thus liued god whome beſéech reyſe vp many like biſhops england iohn leyland writeth reporte doctor londoniohn leyland william wikeham borne wickham hampſhire ſonne one william perot pariſhe clarke place tooke ſurname one mayſter wodale wickham brought vp ſchole learned grammer write faire conneſtable winchester caſtell time great ruler hampſhire gote perot alias wickham w • dall made clearke edward third comming winchester caſtell liked wickham tooke ſeruice vnderſtanding mind prieſt made firſt parſon saint martin london deane saint martin le graund archdeacon buckingham made alſo ſurueyor building windſore quinborow kent building preferred bearer priuie sealt mayſter wardes forreſts treafourer king reuenues france biſhop winchester chancellour treaſourer england manifeſtly ſayth iohn leyland appeareth writing blacke prince ſcant fauoured wickham wherefore wickham procured kéepe prince battell realme length iohn gaunt duke lancaster alice peeres concubine edward third cauſed baniſhed realme dwelled normandy picardie ſeauen yeares edward thirde yet liuing reſtored ſecond yeare richard ſecond whome generall pardon aboute feaſt saint valentine ſonnes thebarle march ſonnes earle march taken caſtell windſore ledde away wale owen glendouerdewe ſhortly recouered againe smith made keyes conuayde got firſt hand head cut lady spencer siſter duke yorke widow thomas lord spencer executed brestow apprehended committed priſon accuſed hit brother duke yorke chiefe author ſtealing away earle march ſonnes wherefore ſayde duke kept sir iohn pelham caſtell pemſey till next parliament feaſt purification lady king aſſembled baron london treate gouernement realme haue ayde money giuen noble would time obey requeſt lent following therefore king cauſed cleargie baron aſſemble saint albons matter aforeſayd reaſon noble ſtroue againſt nothing done ſo departed palme ſonday fiftéenth march fight betwixt engliſhmen 1405 conſpiracy againſt king henry archbishop yorke welchmen ſonne owen glendouerdewe taken fiftéene hundred taken ſlayne henry percy earle northumberlande richard scrope archbiſhop yorke thomas mowbray earle marſhall thomas lord bardolph cōſpiring againſt king henry aſſembled togither citizen yorke many ſtand commoditie realm animate common readier vnto buſineſſe ſet article vpō dores monaſteries church ſame citie written engliſh agaynſte king bycauſe put downe king richard offering themſelues thoſe article liue die cauſed great number people reſort ralph neuill earle westmerland farre togither iohn duke lancaster king ſonne enformed theſe thing gathered armie ſpéede goe againſt archbiſhops company vayne archbiſhops power farre greater wherevpon earle westmerland ſente meſſengers enquire archbiſhop cauſe ſo great aſſembly armour contrarie king peace wherevnto archbiſhop anſwered tooke nothing hand againſt king peace armour munited men feare king whome could ſafely come vnto ſpeake purpoſe ſaid good cōmodious ye king realme happily would know thē ſhewed ſcedule ye article conteyned earle westmerland read word countenance prayſed biſhops holy vertuous intent promiſed would proſecute ſame archbiſhop archbiſhop glad beléeued earles word perſwaded earle marſhall vnwilling therevnto go place appointed talke togither whome like number came writing article read ouer ſtreightway earle gaue aſſent theſe article ſayde earle ſubtiller reſt behold labour haue takē hand come ſuch end would haue people hath bin long armour let ſome mē beare word vnto people go way home lay downe armour euery mā fall occupation accuſtomed labour meane ſeaſon token concord drinke togither people ſides ſhall ſée without delay takē hand knight ſent archbiſhops behalfe beare word ye people peace command euery man lay downe armour go owne home people beholding ſignes peace lord drinking togither awéeried vnaccuſtomed trauell war turned reines bridle homewards ſo came paſſe y• whē people ye archbiſhops ſide went away ye nūber aduerſaries increaſed appointed archbiſhop perceiue yt betrayd vntill ſuch time ye earle arreſted arreſted marſhall alſo many promiſed yt ſhould haue harme promiſe kept archbiſhoparchbishop yorke beheaded earle marſhall beheaded king came yorke morrow whitſonday whē king puniſhed mē yorke pleaſure ſet forth armie purſue earle northumberland thomas lord bardolph tooke maner munition armie 37 thouſand fighting men earle northumberland perceyuing king intent gote himſelfe berwike thrée hundred horſſe frō thence scotland king bent againſt earle northumberland went berwike whence earle fledde scotland lord bardolph whome dauid lord fleming scotte receyued alliance king vnderſtāding earle fled commanded caſtell render vnto whiche refuſed king cauſed greate gunne ſhotte whiche ouerthrewe parte tower wherevpon caſtell gaue ouer ſubmitted themſelues king cauſed ſome beheaded reſidue ſent priſons caſtell alnewike reſt earles caſtels ſmall ado rendred handes ſucceſſe king encouraged went ſtreight wale contrarywiſe nothing proſpered wherefore returned looſing charets carte wagon number 50 treaſure ſo comming backe worcester ſent archbiſhop biſhops declared miſfortune deſiring thē help whome archbiſhop anſwered woulde talke cleargie matter meane ſeaſon frenchman came ſuccour welchmen 140 shippes l • nded milford hauen hauing loſt almoſt horſſes lacke freſh water lord barkley henry pay burnt fiftéene thoſe shippes ſame hauen theſe frenchman beſéeged towne carmarden tooke graunting inhabitant moueable goodes goe whether would ſame time foreſayde lorde barkley thomasanno reg 7 swinborne henry pay tooke fourtéene shippes french whiche tooke lord knightes one party maior communaltie partie citizen preuayled vertue charter statute parliamente beganne whiche laſted nigh oneparliament great taske 1406 whole yeare knightes parliament long delayde graunt king ſubſedie yet ende ouercome granted taſke demanded prieſtes frier liued almes forced euery one pay halfe marke henry percy earle northumberland l bardolfe counſell dauid fleming fled wale declared scottes conſpired deliuer vnto owne king exchange priſoners dauid fleming trayterous scottes flew reyſed ſuch ciuill warre amongſt thē ſelues ende conſtreyned requeſt truce yeare obteyned scottes ſente iames ſonne robert king scottes butthe king scottes ſonne heire taken sea nine yeares olde towardes france brought vp inſtructed pleaſant eloquence french tongue whome certayne marriners cley norffolke tooke sea biſhop earle orkney whome father committed brought england deliuered king forth burſt laughter ſayde ſurely scottes mighte haue ſente ſpeake french biſhop eſcaped doctor france therefore called daunce machabre daunce richly paynted saint innocent cloyſter paris metre french ſignifyingthe daunce death commonly called daunce paules ſpéeches death eſtates ſeuerall anſweres againe death whiche tranſlated engliſh iohn lidgate monke bury afore ſayde richly paynted ſayd cloyſter saint paules church therefore commonly called daunce paules henry pay fiue porte withtho walſ fiftéene shippes tooke hundred twentie shippes lay ancker sea briteine laden iron salt oyle rochell wine sommer corruption ayre ſo great plague ſhedde vpon men bodyes ſéene like many yeares land ſo men might ſay south windes warme blow heate peſtiferouspeſtilence peſtilence beare great rule city populous london ſhort conſumed aboue thirtie thouſand men woman countrey townes great mortalitie fell among huſbandmen ſo great houſeholds dyed cleane vp houſes emptied fiftéenth day auguſt deceaſſed sir roberte knowles knight manour sconethorp norffolke sir robert knovvles iohn leyland brought london honourably buried white frier church newly reedifyed builded sir robert knowles bin moſt valiant captayne warres france raigne edward third richard ſecond whoſe force realme france felt feared ſo dukedome briteine regiſter bermondſey people hence spayne life made uerſes latin may engliſhed thus robert knowles moſt woorthy fameverſes thy proweſſe france made tame thy manhoode made frenchman yeeld dint ſword towne field sir robert knowles founded towne ofcolledge hoſpitall pontfract pontfract colledge honor holy trinitie hoſpital ioyned therevnto colledge placed
