vvas vvritten ſir thomas moore king edvvarde name fourth lyued fiftie thrée1483 yéeres ſeuen monethes ſixe dayes thereof raygned twoo twentie yéeres one moneth eyght dayes dyed westminster ye ninth day aprill yeare redemption thouſand foure hundreth foure ſcore thrée leauing much fayre iſſue witte edward prince thirten yeares age richard duke yorke two yéere yonger elizabeth whoſe fortune grace quéene wyfe vnto king henrie ſeuenth mother vnto eight cicelie ſo tunate fayre briget repreſenting vertue hyr whoſe name ſhe bare profeſſed obſerued religious life dertforde houſe cloſe nunnes anne honourably married vnto thomas lord heyward earle surrey katherine long time toſſed eyther fortune ſometime wealth ofte aduerſitie laſt laſt yet ſhée liueth benignitie hir nephewe king henrie eyght proſperous eſtate worthie hir birth vertue noble prince deceaſſed palaice westminſter loue people great funerall honour heauineſſe people thence conueyed entered windſor king ſuch gouernaunce behauiour time peace warre eche part muſt néedes others enimie neuer prince lande attayning crowne battaile ſo hartely beloued ſubſtaunce people himſelfe ſo ſpecially part life time death fauour affection yet deceſſe crueltie miſchiefe trouble tempeſtuous world followed highly toward increaſed ſuch time dyed diſpleaſure thoſe bare grudge king henry ſake ſixt depoſed well aſſwaged effect quenched many deade twentie yeares raigne great parte long life many meane ſeaſon growne fauour neuer ſtraunge goodlydeſcription edvvard fourth perſonage princely beholde harte couragious pollitique counſell aduerſitie nothing abaſhed proſperitie rather ioyfull proude peace iuſt mercifull warre ſharpe fierce fielde bolde hardie natheleſſe wiſedome would aduenturous whoſe warres ſo well conſider ſhall leſſe commende wiſedome voyded manhoode vanquiſhed viſage louely body mightie ſtrong cleane made howbeit latter dayes ouer liberall dyet ſomewhat corpulent boorely natheleſſe comely youth greatly giuen f • eſhely wantonneſſe health body great proſperitie fortune without ſpeciall grace hardly refraineth faulte greatly gréeued people neyther could one man pleaſure ſtretch extend diſpleaſure many without violence ouer latter dayes leſſed well left time latter dayes realme quiet proſperous eſtate feare outward enimies warre hand none toward ſuch man looked people toward prince conſtrained feare willing louing obedience among themſelues cōmons good peace lordes knewe variaunce himſelfe death bed appeaſed lefte gathering money onely thing withdraweth harte engliſhmen prince thing intended take hande ſhoulde driuen thereto tribute fraunce obtaynedtribute yéere foregoing death obtained barwike albeit time raigne people ſo benigne courteous ſo familiar part vertues eſtéemed yet condition ende dayes many prince long continued ſoueraintie decline proude porte frō debonair behauiour beginning maruellouſlye grew increaſed ſo farre forth sommer laſt y• euer ſawe highneſſe windſor hunting ſent maior alderman london none errand haue hunt merie made ſo ſtately ſo friendly ſo familiar theare ſent veniſon frō thence ſo fréely citie one thing many dayes gat either • heartes heartie fauour amongeſt common people whiche oftentimes eſtéeme take greater kindneſſe little courteſie great benefite deceaſſed haue ſayd noble king time lyfe moſt deſired whoſe loue people entire affection towarde béene noble child hauing themſelues alſo many giftes nature many princely vertues much goodly towardneſſe age could receiue maruellous fortreſſe ſure armour diuiſion diſſention friend vnarmed left deſtitute execrable deſire ſoueraintie prouoked deſtruction either kind kindneſſe holden place muſt néedes haue bene chiefe defence richard duke glocester nature vncle office protector father beholdē themſelues othe allegiaunce bounden bandes broken binden man man togither without reſpect god world vnnaturally contriued bereue dignitie alſo lyues much duke demeanor miniſtreth effect whole matter whereof booke ſhal intreate therfore conuenient ſomewhat ſhew ere farther goe manner man could finde heart ſo much miſchiefe conceiue richard duke yorke▪ noble man mightie began warre law ſo chalenge crowne puttingrichard duke yorke hys claime parliament cauſe eyther right fauour ſo farre forth auaunced kyng henry bloud albeit goodly prince vtterly reiected crowne aucthoritie parliamente entailed vnto duke yorke iſſue male remainder immediatly death king henrie ye duke enduring ſo long tarrie intending vnder pretext diſſention debate ariſing realme preuent time take vpon rule king henrie life many noble realme wakefielde ſlaine leauing thrée ſonnes edward george richard thrée great ſtates birthe ſo great ſtately ſtomack gréedie ambitious aucthoritie impatient partner edwarde reuenging hisedvvarde father death depriued▪ king henrie attained ye crowne▪ george duke clarence goodly noble prince atgeorge duke clarence al point fortunate either owne ambition ſet againſt brother enuie enimies brother againſt hym quéene lord hir bloud highly maligned king kinred woman commonly malice nature hate whō huſbandes loue proude appetite duke hymſelfe intending king leaſt wiſe heinous treaſō laid charge finally faultie faultleſſe attaynted parliament iudged death therevpon haſtily drowned butte malmeſey whoſe death king edward albeit commaunded wyſt done piteouſly bewayled ſorowfully repented richarde thirde ſonne wée nowe intreatethe diſcription▪ richard third wit courage egall either body prowes farre vnder little ſtature yll featured limmes crooke backed left ſhoulder much hygher right hard fauoured viſage ſuch ſtates called warlye men otherwiſe malicious wrathfull enuious afore byrth euer froward truth reported dutch mother ſo much doe hir trauaile yt ſhe coulde deliuered vncut came world féete forward mē borne outward ye fame runneth alſo vntoothed whether mē hatred report aboue ye truth elſe y• nature chaūged hir courſe beginning courſe life many thing vnnaturally committed none euil captaine ye warre diſpotiō méetely thā peace sundry victory ſomtimes ouerthrows neuer default perſon either hardines politike order frée called diſpence ſomewhat aboue power liberall wt large giftes gat vnſtedfaſt friendſhip faine pill ſpoile place get ſtedfaſt hatred cloſe ſecrete déepe diſſimuler lowly countenaunce arrogant heart outwardlye coumpinable inwardlye hated letting kiſſe hée thought kill diſpiteous cruell euill wil alway ofter ambition either fuertie increaſe eſtate friend foe much indifferent aduauntage grewe ſpared man death whoſe life wythſtoode purpoſe ſlewe owne handes king henry ſixt priſoner tower menthe death king henrie ſixte conſtantly ſaid without commaundement knowledge king would vndoubtedly intended thing haue appointed butcherly office ſome owne borne brother wiſe men alſo wéen drift couertly conueyed lacked helping forth brother clarence death reſiſted openly howbeit ſomewhat men déemed faintly hartily mynded wealth y• thus déeme thinke long time k edwardes lyfe forethought king caſe king brother whoſe life looked euill diet ſhould ſhorten ſhould happen deceaſſe déede child yong déeme intent glad brother death ye duke clarence whoſe life muſt néedes haue hindered ſo intending whether ſame duke clarence kept true nephew yong king enterpriſed king himſelfe al poynt certaintie ſo deuineth vpon coniectures may aſwell ſhoote farre ſhort howbeit haue credible information learned ſelfe night king edward dyed one miſtlebrooke long ere morning came great haſt houſe one pottier dwelling redcroſſe ſtreete without creplegate loxdon haſtie rapping quicklye letten ſhewed vnto pottier king edwarde departed truth man quoth pottier maiſter duke glocester king cauſe ſo thinke harde ſay whether toward thing knewe ſuch thing purpoſed otherwiſe inkeling thereof likely ſpeake nought returne courſe hiſtorie duke gloucester hadde olde foreminded concluſion nowe erſte therevnto moued putte hope occaſion tender age yong prince nephewes oportunitie likelihoode ſpéede putteth man courage neuer intended certaine contriued deſtruction vſurpation regall dignitie vpon himſelfe foraſmuche well wiſte holpe maintaine long continued grudge heartburning betwene quéenes kinred king bloude either partie enuying others aucthoritie nowe thought diuiſion ſhoulde indéede furtherly beginning purſuit hys intent ſure ground foundation al building might firſte vnder pretexte reuenging old diſpleaſure abuſe anger ignorance one partie deſtruction winne hys purpoſe many coulde thoſe could bée wonne myght loſt ere looked therefore one thing certayne hys intent perceyued ſhould ſoone haue made peace betwéene party owne bloud king edwarde life albeit diſſention betwéene friendes ſomewhat irked yet good health ſomewhat leſſe regarded bicauſe thought whatſoeuer buſineſſe ſhoulde fall betwéene himſelfe ſhould alway able rule party laſt ſickneſſe whē perceiued naturall ſtrength ſo ſore enféebled diſpaired al recouerie conſidering youth child albeit nothing leſſe miſtruſted happened yet well foreſéeing many harmes might growe debate youthe child ſhould lacke diſcretion themſelues good counſell friendes either partie ſhould counſell owne commoditie rather pleaſaunt aduiſe wyn themſelues fauour profitable aduertiſement doo child good called ſome variaunce eſpeciall lord marque dorſet quéenes ſonne hir firſt huſbande william lord haſtings noble man lord chamberlaine againe whō quéene ſpecially grudged great fauour king bare alſo thought ſecretly familiar king wantō company hir kinred alſo bare ſore aſwell y• king made▪ captaine calleis office lord riuers brother y• quéene claimed y• king former promiſe diuers great gift receiued y• looked theſe lord diuers party come preſence king lifting vp himſelfe vnderſet pyllows reported wiſe ſaide vnto lordes deare kin • men alies plight lie youthe oration king death bed ſée fée • e leſſe looke lo liue déepely moued care caſe leaue ſuch leaue ſuch childrē like finde ſhould god forbid finde variaunce might hap fall thēſelues warre ere diſcretion would ſerue ſet peace ye ſée youth recken y• onely ſuertie reſt concorde ſuffiſeth y• loue eche hate mē faithfulnes happily would ſuffiſe childhood muſt maintained men aucthority ſlipper youth vnderpropped wt elder coūſel neither cā haue ye giue it▪ ye giue ye grée eche laboureth breake maketh hatred eche others perſon impugneth eche others coūſell muſt néedes long ere good concluſion go forward alſo either party laboreth chief flatterie ſhal haue place thā plaine faithfull aduiſe muſt néedes inſue ye euil bringing vp y• prince whoſe minde tēder youth infect ſhal redily fal miſchief riot draw downe noble realme ruine grace turne wiſdome god ſend y• euil meanes pleaſed beſt ſhal fal furtheſt fauour ſo y• euer length euil drift draw nought good plaine wayes proſper great variaunce hath long bene betwéene alway great cauſes sometime thing right wel intended miſconſtructiō turneth vnto worſe ſmall diſpleaſure done v either owne affectiō euil tongue agréeueth wot well ye neuer ſo great cauſe hatred ye haue loue al men chriſten mē ſhal leaue preacher tell yet wot neare whether preacher word ought moue thā going place al preache ſhal deſire remēber y• one part bloud mine alies ech either kinred affinitie ſpiritual kinred affinitie sacramentes chriſtes church beare weight v y• would god ſhould leſſe moue v charitie ye reſpect fleſhly conſanguinitie lord forbid y• loue togither ye worſe ſelfe cauſe ye ought loue ye better yet y• happeneth finde ſo deadly debate among thē nature lawe moſt ought agrée togither peſtilent serpent ambitiōambition deſire vaine glory ſoueraintie amōg ſtates entreth créepeth forth ſo farre til wt deuiſion variaunce turneth miſchiefe firſt longing next beſt afterward egall beſt laſt chiefe aboue y• beſt immoderate appetite worſhip thereby debate diſſentiō loſſe ſorowe trouble hath wt theſe yéeres grown realme pray god aſwel forget wel remēber thing could aſwel haue foreſéen haue wt paine thē pleaſure proued godes bleſſed lady y• euer othe would neuer haue y• courteſie men knées wt y• loſſe ſo many head ſithen thing paſſed cannot gainecalled much ought beware occaſion haue taken ſo great hurt afore eft ſoones fall occaſion againe thoſe grief paſſed god thanked quiet likely right well proſper wealthfull peare vnder couſins child god ſend life loue two thing leſſe loſſe though god pleaſure yet ſhould realme alway finde king peraduenture good king among ſelues childes raigne fall debate many good man ſhall periſh haply ye ere land finde peace againe wherfore theſe laſt wordes euer looke ſpeake exhorte require loue haue euer borne mée loue haue euer borne vnto loue lord beareth v time forward griefes forgotten eche loue verely truſt ye thing earthly regarde eyther god king affinitie kinred realme owne countrey owne ſuertie therewithall king longer induring ſit vp laid downe ryghte ſide face toward none preſent could refraine wéeping lordes recomforting good wordes could anſwering time thought ſtand pleaſure preſence theyr wordes appeared eche forgaue ioyned handes together appeared déedes harte farre ſunder ſoone king departed noble prince ſonne drew toward london time deceaſſe kept houſholde ludlowe wale countrey béeing farre lawe recourſe juſtice begon farre good waxen wylde robber reuers walking libertie vncorrected encheaſon prince life father ſent thither y• eude y• au • thoritie preſence ſhoulde refraine euill diſpoſed perſons fro boldeneſſe former outrage gouernaunce orderyng yōg prince ſending thither appointed ſir anthonie wood • ile lorde riuers brother vntolord riuers quéene right honorable man valiant hande politike counſell adioyned vnto ſame partie effect euery one neareſt kinne vnto quéene ſo planted nexte aboute prince drifte quéene vnwiſely deuiſed wherby hir bloude might youth rooted prince fauor duke glocester tourned vnto theyr deſtruction vpon grounde ſette foundation vnhappye building ſoeuer perceyued eyther variaunce bearing himſelfe fauour brake vnto ſome mouth ſome writing ſecret meſſengers neyther reaſon wiſe bée ſuffered yong king theyr maiſter kinſman ſhoulde handes cuſtodie mother kinred ſequeſtered maner theyr companye▪ attendaunce whiche euerye one ought faithful ſeruice many farre honorable parte kinne hys mother ſide whoſe bloud quoth ſauing king pleaſure full vnméetelye matched hys whiche nowe ſaye remoued frō king leſſe noble left quoth neyther honorable maieſtie vnto v alſo hys grace ſuretie haue mightieſt friend vnto v little ieopardie ſuffer oure well proued euill willers growe ouer great auctority wyth prince youth namely light beliefe ſoone perſwaded yée remember trowe king edward himſelfe albeit manne age diſcretion yet hée manye thing ruled bende ſtoode eyther wyth hys honour profitte commoditie man elſe excepte onely immoderate aduancemente themſelues whether ſort thir • ted owne weale wo harde wene geſſe ſome folkes friendſhip holden better place king reſpect kinred might peraduenture eaſilye haue betrapped brought confuſion ſome v ere eaſilye haue done ſome alreadye néere royall bloude wée lorde hath wrought thankes grace peril paſt howbeit great growing ſuffer yōg king enemy hād without witting might abuſe name hys commaundement vndoing thing god good prouiſion forbidde whiche good prouiſion none v hath thing leſſe néede late made attonement y• king pleaſure hadde place party willes none v beléeue ſo vnwiſe ouerſoone truſte newe friend made old foe thinke hourely kindenes ſodainly contracte one houre continued yet ſkant fortnight ſhould déeper ſettled ſtomacke long accuſtomed malice manye yeares rooted theſe wordes writing ſuche duke glocester ſoone ſet fire themſelues eathe kindle eſpecial twayne edwarde duke bu • kingham wiliam lord haſtings chamberlain men honour great power tone long ſucceſſion aunceſtrie tother office king fauour theſe two beryng eache ſo muche lone hatred vnto quéenes parte point accorded togither wyth duke glocester would vtterly amoue king company hys mother friendes vnder name theyr enimies uppon concluded duke gloucester vnderſtanding lordes whyche time king intended bring vp coronation accompanied ſuche power friend ſhould harde bring purpoſe paſſe without gathering greate aſſemble people manner open warre whereof ende wiſte doubtfull whiche king ſide part ſhould haue face name rebellion ſecretly therfore diner meanes cauſed quéene perſwaded broughte minde neyther néede alſo ſhoulde ieopardous king come vppe ſtrong whereas nowe euerye lorde loued none thing ſtudyed vppon aboute coronation honor king lordes hir kyndred ſhoulde aſſemble king name muche people ſhoulde giue lordes wixte hadde bin ſometime debate feare ſuſpect leaſte ſhoulde gather people king ſafegarde whome man impugned deſtruction hauing regarde theyr olde variaunce newe attonement cauſe ſhould aſſemble partie much people againe theyr defence whoſe power ſhe wiſte wel farre ſtretched thus ſhoulde realme fall • ore hurte thereof ſhoulde enſue likely little moſte harme lyke fall ſhe leaſte woulde worlde woulde put hyr hyr kyndred wight ſaye hadde vnwiſely vntruely alſo broken amitie peace kyng hyr • uſbande ſo prudentlye made betwéene kinne hyrs death bed partie faithfully obſerued quéene wiſe perſwaded ſuche worde ſente vnto hir ſonne vnto hir brother béeing aboute kyng ouer duke glocester hymſelfe lordes chiefe bende wrote vnto king ſo reuerentlye quéenes friendes ſo louingly nothing earthly miſtruſting brought king vp greate haſte good ſpéede ſober companye king hys waye london gone northampton duke glocester buckingham came thither remained behinde lord riuers king vncle intending morrowe followe king stonie stratforde xij myles thence earelye departed made nighte muche friendlye cheare betwéene theſe two duke lord riuers great whyle incontinent openlye greate curteſie departed lorde riuers lodged duke ſecretely fewe theyr moſte priuie friendes ſet counſaile wherein ſpent great parte nighte theyr riſing dawning day ſente priuilye theyr ſeruantes theyr innes lodging giuing thē commaundement make thēſelues ſhortly readie lordes horſſebackewarde uppon whyche meſſages manye theyr folke attendaunt manye lord riuers ſeruauntes vnreadye nowe theſe duke taken alſo theyr cuſtody keyes inne none ſhoulde paſſe forth without licēce ouer thys highe waye towarde stonie stratforde king laye hadde beſtowed certaine theyr folke ſhoulde ſende backe againe compell returne anye man gotten northampton towarde stonie stratforde tyll ſhoulde giue licence much duke thēſelues intēded ſhew theyr diligence firſte ſhoulde daye attende vpon king highneſſe towne thus bare folke hande lord riuers vnderſtoode gate cloſed wayes euery ſide beſet neyther ſeruauntes himſelfe ſuffered goe perceiuing wel ſo great thing without knowledge begun naughte comparing thys manner preſent wyth hys laſt night chéere ſo fewe houres ſo great change maruellouſly miſliked howbeit ſith coulde gette awaye kéepe himſelfe cloſe would leaſt ſhould ſéeme hyde himſelf ſome ſecrete fear fault wherof ſaw ſuch cauſe hymſelf determined vpon ſuretie conſcience go boldelie inquire matter mighte meane whome ſ • one ſawe beganne quarrel ſaye intended ſet diſtaunce betwéene kyng bring confuſion ſhould lye hys power beganne wel ſpoken man goodly wiſe excuſe himſelfe tarryed ende aunſweare ſhortly tooke hymthe l riuers put vvarde put warde done forthwyth wente horſſebacke tooke waye stonie stratforde founde king wyth hys companye readie leape horſſebacke depart forwarde leaue lodging bycauſe ſtraighte companyes ſoone came hys preſēce light adown companye duke buckingham ſayd go afore gentleman yeoman kéepe roomes thus goodly aray came king theyr knées verye humble wyſe ſalued grace whiche receyued ioyous amiable maner nothing earthlye knowing miſtruſting yet euen preſence piked quarrell lorde rycharde lord▪ grey gray▪ king brother mother ſaying lorde marque brother lorde riuers uncle compaſſed rule king realme ſet variance among ſtates ſubdue deſtroye noble bloude realme toward accompliſhing whereof ſayd lorde marque entred tower london thence taken kyngs treaſure ſente menne sea thing theſe duke wiſt well done good purpoſes neceſſarie whole counſaile london ſauing ſomewhat muſt ſay unto word king aunſwered brother marque hath done cannot ſaye good faith dare well aunſweare mine vncle riuers brother innocent ſuche matter yea liege quoth duke buckingham haue kept theyr dealing theſe matter farre fro knowledge good grace forthwyth areſted lord richard ſir th vaughā knight king preſence brought king al back vnto northampton tooke againe counſell ſent away frō king whō pleaſed thē ſet new ſeruaunts ſuch liked better thē dealing wept nothing content booted dinner duke glocester ſente diſhe owne table lord riuers praying good cheare ſhould well ynough thanked duke prayed meſſenger beare nephew lord richard ſame meſſage hys comforte one whome ſuch aduerſitie ſtrāge himſelfe bin dayes vre therewith therfore could beare better cōfortable curteſie duke glocester ſent lord riuers thethe death l riuers others lord richarde ſir thomas vaughan northe countrey diuerſe place priſon afterwarde pomfraite concluſion beheaded wiſe duke glocester toke vppon hymſelfe order gouernaunce yong king muche honoure humble reuerence hée conueyed vpward toward citie anone tydings matter came haſtily quéene little midnighte following ſoreſt wiſe king hir ſon taken hir brother hir ſonne friend arreſted ſente man wiſt whether bée done god wot tydings quéene great flight heauineſſe bewayling hir childes raigne hir friendes miſchaunce hir owne infortune damning time euer ſhe diſſwaded gathering power aboute kyng gatte hyr ſelfe haſte poſſible wyth hir yō ger sonne hyr daughter pallaice westminster whiche ſhe laye sanctuariethe qu taketh sanctuarie lodging hyr ſelfe hyr companye abbot place came one likewiſe long midnighte lorde chamberlayne vnto archbiſhoppe yorke chancellour englande place far frō westminster ſhewed ſeruauntes hée tydings ſo great importaunce hys maiſter gaue charge forbeare reſte letted wake admitte meſſenger bedde ſide whome hearde theſe duke gone backe wyth king grace stonie stratforde vnto northampton notwythſtanding syr quoth lorde ſendeth lordſhippe worde feare aſſureth ſhall well aſſure quoth archebiſhoppe well wyll neuer ſo well haue ſéene therevpon meſſenger departed cauſed haſte ſernauntes called vp ſo owne houſholde euerye man weaponed tooke greate ſeale came yet daye vnto quéene founde much heauineſſe rumble haſt buſineſſe cariage conueyaunce hyr ſtuffe sanctuarie cheſtes coffer packes fardel truſſed men backes man vnoccupied ſome lading ſome going ſome diſcharging ſome comming ſome breaking walles bring next way ſome yet drewe helpe carry wrong way quéene hir ſelfe ſate alone alowe ruſhes al deſolate diſmayde whome archebiſhoppe comforted beſte manner coulde ſhewing hir truſted matter nothing ſo ſore ſhe toke putte good hope feare ye meſſage ſent lord chamberlaine ah wo worth hym quoth ſhe one laboureth deſtroye bloud madam quoth yée good chéere aſſure crowne king ſon nowe haue ſhall morrowe crowne hys brother haue greate ſeale whyche likewiſe noble prince huſbande deliuered vnto ſo héere deliuer vnto vſe behoofe ſonne therewith betooke hir greate ſeale departed home againe yet dawning daye whiche time mighte chamber windowe ſée thamis full boates duke glocesters ſeruauntes watching man ſhoulde go sanctuarie none could paſſe vnſearched great commotion murmur well place ſpecially citie people diuerſly diuining vpō deling ſome lord knightes gentleman eyther fauour quéen feare themſelues aſſembled ſundry company wente flockmeale harneys manye alſo reckoned thys demeanour attempted ſo ſpeciallye againſt lord againſt king himſelfe diſturbaunce coronation lordes aſſembled togither towarde whiche méeting archbiſhoppe yorke fearing woulde aſcribed indéede ouermuch lightneſſe ſo ſuddainely hadde yéelded vppe greate ſeale quéene cuſtodie thereof nothing perteyned wythout ſpeciall commaundement king ſecretely ſent ſeale againe brought cuſtomable manner méeting lorde haſting whoſe trouth toward ye king man doubted néeded doubt perſwaded lordes beléeue duke glocester ſure faſtly faithfull prince lord riuers lorde richarde knightes matter attempted againſt duke glocester buckingham put vnder areſt ſuretie king ieopardie alſo ſafegarde longer ſhoulde remayne till matter duke onely alſo lord ye king counſayle indifferently examyned diſcretions ordered eyther iudged appeaſed one thing aduiſed beware iudged matter farre forth ere knew trueth turning theyr priuate grudge common hurte yrking prouoking men vnto anger diſturbing king coronation toward duke cōming vp might peraduenture bring matter ſo farre ioynte ſhoulde neuer broughte frame againe whiche ſtrife ſhould happe lykely come fielde though party thing equal yet ſhoulde aucthoritie ſide king himſelfe theſe perſwaſions lord haſtings whereof part himſelfe beleeued parte wiſt contrarie theſe commotion ſomwhat appeaſed ſpecially duke glocester buckinghā wer ſo néere came ſo ſhortly king none manner none voyce ſemblance coronation cauſing fame blowen theſe lord knight taken contriued deſtruction duke glocester buckingham noble bloud realme end thē ſelues would alone demeane gouern king pleaſure coulourable proofe therof ſuch duke ſeruauntes rode carte ſtuffe taken among ſtuffe maruel thoughe ſome harneys breaking vppe houſholde muſt néedes eyther brought awaye caſt away ſhewed vnto people wayes went loe héere •• rels harneys theſe traytours hadde priuilye conueyed theyr carriage deſtroy noble lordes withal deuiſe albeit made matter wiſe men vnlikely well perceyuing intendours ſuch purpoſe would rather haue hadde theyr harneys backes haue bound vppe barrel yet much part commō people therwith wel ſatiſfied ſayd almoyſe hang king approched néere citie edmonde shaa goldſmith maior william white iohn matthew sherifes al alderman scarlet fiue hundered horſſe citizen violet receyued reuerently harneſey ryding thence accompanyedthe king cō ming londō citie whiche entred fourth daye maye firſt laſte yeare raigne duke gloucester bare hym open ſight ſo reuerently prince ſemblaunce lowlineſſe great obloquie ſo late ſodainly fallen ſo gret truſt ye counſel next aſſēbled made mā choſe thought moſt méete protector ye king hys realme ſo thatthe protectour made deſtenie follie lambe betaken woolfe kéepe whych counſayle alſo archbyſhop yorke chauncelor englande whyche hadde delyuered vppe greate seale quéene thereof greately reprooued seale taken hym delyuered doctor ruſſell byſhoppe lincolne wiſethe bishop lincolne made lord chauncellour man good muche experience one beſte learned menne vndoubtedly englande hys time dyuers lordes knightes appointed vnto dyuers roumes lorde chamberlaine ſome kepte ſtill theyr office nowe ſo protector ſo ſore thirſted finiſhing begunne thought euery daye yeare till atchéeued yet durſte hée attempte long halfe hys pray hande well witting depoſed one brother realme woulde fall hée either remaynèd sanctuarie ſhoulde happily ſhortelye conueyed hys father libertie wherfore incontinent nexte méeting lordes counſaile propoſed vnto hainous déede quéenthe protectours oration procéeding greate malice towarde kyngs counſailours ſhe ſhoulde kéepe sanctuarie king brother hym whoſe ſpeciall pleaſure comforte haue brother hym hir done none intente bring lordes obloquie murmure people thoughe truſted king brother aſſente noble lande appointed king neareſt friendes tuition hys owne royall perſon proſperitie whereof ſtandeth quoth kéeping enimies ill vyande partly alſo recreation moderate pleaſure whiche cannot hys tenuer youth take companye auncient perſons familiar conuerſation thoſe neither far vnder farre aboue age naytheleſſe eſtate conuenient accompanye hys noble maieſtie wherefore whome rather wyth hys owne brother anye man thinke conſideration whyche thinke manne thinketh loueth king let conſider ſometyme wythout ſmall thing greater cannot ſtande verilye redoundeth greatlye diſhonour king hyghneſſe v bene aboute grace haue runne euerye man mouth realme alſo land euil word walke far ye king brother ſhold fain kepe sāctuary euery mā wil wéene ye mā wil ſo nought ſuch euil opiniō faſtned men heart hard wraſte may grow grief thā mā deuine wherfore thinketh worſt ſend vnto y• q redreſſe matter ſome honorable truſtie man ſuche tendereth kyngs weale honoure hys counſayle alſo fauour credence wyth hyr conſiderations none ſéemeth méetely reuerende father héere preſent lord cardinall maye matter doe moſt good man pleaſe take payne doubt hys goodneſſe refuſe king ſake wealth yong duke himſelf king moſt honorable brother ſoueraigne lord himſelfe moſt déere nephew conſidered thereby ſhal ceaſſed ſlaunderous rumor obloquie nowe going hurtes au • yded thereof mighte enſue muche reſte quiet growe realme ſhe percaſe ſo obſtinate ſo preciſely ſet vpon hir wil neyther wiſe faithful aduertiſement moue hir anye mannes reaſon contente hir ſhall mine aduiſe king authoritie fetche priſon bring hym hys noble preſence whoſe continuall companye ſhall ſo well chéeriſhed ſo honorablye intreated al world ſhal honor hir reproche perceyue onely malice frowardeneſſe follie cauſed hir kéepe minde matter time except lordſhippes thing perceiue contrarie neuer ſhall god grace ſo wedde ſelfe mine owne wil ſhal readie change vpon better aduiſes protectoure hadde ſayde counſayle affirmed motion good reaſonable king duke brother honorable thing ſhould ceaſe greate murmure realme mother mighte good meanes enduced deliuer thing archbiſhop yorke agréed alſo thereto moſt conuenient tooke vpon moue hir therin doe vttermoſt deuoire howbeit ſhe coulde wiſe intreated hyr good to▪ deliuer thought ſuch spiritualtie preſent wiſe attempted take againſt hir wil would besanctuarie thing ſhoulde turne greate grudge men high diſpleaſure god priuiledge holye place ſhoulde nowe broken whiche ſo many yeares bene kepte king pope ſo good grā ted ſo many hadde confirmed holy ground fiue hundred yeares agoe saint peter hys owne perſon ſpirite accompanyed wyth great multitude angel night ſo ſpeciallye hallowed dedicate god proofe whereof haue yet abbay peter cope ſhewe time hitherward ther neuer ſo vndeuoute king durſt ſacred place violate ſo holy byſhop durſt preſume conſecrate therefore quoth archbiſhop yorke god forbid man ſhould thing earthly enterpriſe breake immunitie libertie ſacred sanctuarie hath bene ſafegard ſo many good mannes life▪ truſt quoth god grace ſhall néede manner néede woulde ſhold doe truſt ſhe ſhall wyth reaſon contented thing good manner obtayned happen bring ſo paſſe yet ſhal toward ſo far forth beſt ye ſhal al wel perceiue lacke denoire mother dreade womaniſhe feare ſhall lette womaniſhe feare nay womaniſhe frowardeneſſe quoth duke buckingham dare take vpon ſoule ſhe wel knoweth ſhe néedeth ſuch thing feare eyther hir ſonne hir ſelfe hyr héere man wil warre woman would god ſome men hir kinne woman ſhoulde ſoone reſte howebeit none hyr kynne leſſe loued hyr kinne owne euil deſeruing natheleſſe loued neither hyr hir kinne yet cauſe think ſhoulde hate king noble brother whoſe grace ourſelues kinne whoſe honour ſhe muche deſired diſhonour muche regarde tooke wealth hir owne ſhée woulde loath ſuffer king v ſhe haue witte woulde god ſhée good ſhe hathe 〈…〉 de witte ſhe reckneth hir ſelfe wiſer ſhée thinketh ſome whoſe faithfull minde ſhée nothing doubteth verily beléeueth knoweth woulde ſorie hys harme hir ſelfe yet woulde haue hym hir ſhe byde thinke content hir ſhe come thence byde ſuche place maye honor thē ſhe refuſe deliuerāce follow y• coūſaile thē whoſe wiſdome ſhe knoweth whoſe truth ſhe wel truſteth ethe perceiue y• frowardnes letteth hir feare go ſuppoſe y• ſhe feare may let hir fear hir ſhadow ſhe feareth dely▪ner hym ought feare leaue hir hāds ſhe caſte ſuche fonde doubt ſhe feare hys hurte wil ſhe feare ſhal fetcht thence for▪ ſhe wyll ſoone thinke men ſet god forbid vpon ſo great miſchief sanctuarie woulde little lette whiche good men myghte thinketh without ſinne ſomewhat leſſe regarde doe nowe ſhée doubte leaſte hée mighte fetched hir likely ynough ſhe ſhall ſende hym ſome realme uerily looke none doubte ſhe ſore mindeth lette thereof ſhe might happen bring paſſe great maiſtrie letting hir alone world would ſay wiſe ſorte counfailours aboute king let brother caſte awaye vnder noſes therfore enſure faithfully minde wil rather maugre hir mind fetch away leaue till hir frowardneſſe fonde feare conuey away yet wil breake sāctuarie therfore verily ſith y• priuiledges place like haue bin long continued hée y• would breake good fayth wer begin would ſhoulde make yet ſaye naye déede pitie ſuch men ſea euil dettours haue brought pouertie ſhold haue ſome place libertie kéepe theyr body daunger cruel creditours alſo crown happen hath done come queſtion whyle eyther parte taketh traytors wil wel ſome place refuge théeues whiche theſe place full neuer fall crafte fall therto pitie sanctuarie ſhoulde ſerue muche manquellers god bad take aulter kil murther wilful wher otherwiſe néede sanctuary y• god appointed olde lawe eyther neceſſitie defence miſfortune draweth déede pardon ſerueth whych eyther lawe graunteth courſe king pitie may looke sanctuarie men whome anye fauourable neceſſitie compelled goe thyther ſée tother ſide ſort cō monly therin thē whō wilful vnthriftineſſe hath brought naught rabble théeues murtherers malitious heynous traytours two place ſpecially tone elbowe citie tother bowelsvveſtminſt •• ▪ saint martin • dare well auowe weye good doe wyth hurte commeth yée ſhall finde much better lacke haue thys ſaye althoughe abuſed nowe bée ſo long haue bene feare euer wyll bée whyle menne afrayde ſette handes mendmente though god saint peter patron vngracious liuing vnthriftes riot runne debt vpon boldneſſethe abuſe sanctuary theſe place yea rich men runne thyther poore men good buylde ſpende bidde creditours go whiſtle men wiues runne thyther huſbandes plate ſay dare abide huſbāds beating théeues bring thither ſtollen good liue thereon deuiſe newe robbery nightlye ſteale robbe reaue kill come agayne though thoſe place gaue ſafegarde harme haue done licence alſo howbeit much miſchief wiſe men would ſet hand might amended great thanks god breach priuiledge reſidue ſith ſo long ago wote neare pope prince piteous politike hath granted men ſince certaine religious feare haue broken lette v take payne therewyth let god name ſtand force farre forth reaſon wil whiche fully ſo farre forthe may ſerue let v fetching forthe thys noble man hys honor wealth place whych neyther sanctuarie man sanctuarie ſerueth alway defende body man ſtandeth daunger abroade greate hurte alſo lawful hurt▪ againſt vnlawful harmes neuer pope king intēded priuiledge one place priuiledge hath euery place knoweth man place wherein lawfull one man wrong man vnlawfully take hurt libertie k law nature forbiddeth euery place maketh regarde euerye man euerye place sanctuarie man lawfull meanes peryll néedeth tuition ſome ſpeciall priuiledge onely ground cauſe sanctuary neceſſitie noble prince farre whoſe loue king nature kindred proueth whoſe innocencie world tender youth proueth ſo sanctuarie neither none néedeth alſo none haue men come sāctuarie come baptiſme require theyr godfather muſt aſke himſelf muſt haue reaſon ſith man hath cauſe haue whoſe conſcience owne fault maketh fayne néede require hath yonder babe diſcretion require néede dare ſay would ryght angrie wyth kéepe hym would thynke without ſcruple conſcience without breach priuiledge ſomwhat homely wyth sanctuarie men déede one goe sanctuarie others man good ſhould king▪ leauing body libertie ſatiſfie partie good euen wythin sanctuarie neyther kyng pope gyue place ſuche priuiledge ſhall diſcharge man hys debtes able pay dyuers clergie preſent whither ſaid pleaſure thought agréed playnely law god church good sanctuarie man ſhoulde deliuered payment hys debtes ſtollen good owner onely lybertie reſerued hym get hys liuing labour hys handes verily quoth duke thynke ſay trueth man wyfe take sanctuarie bycauſe ſhe liſt runne hir huſband woulde wéene ſhe could alledge none cauſe may lawfully wythout diſpleaſure saint peter take hir saint peter church arme body may taken sanctuarie ſayth byde childe wyll take sanctuarie becauſe feareth goe schole hys maiſter muſt let alone ſimple ſample yet leſſe reaſon caſe therein thoughe chyldiſhe feare yet leaſtwyſe ſome feare herein none verily haue often heard sanctuarie men neuer heard earſt sanctuarie child therefore concluſion mynde ſo may haue deſerued néede thinke ſuertie let kéepe bée sanctuarie man neyther hath wiſedome deſire malice deſerue whoſe life libertie lawfull proceſſe ſtand ieoperdie taketh one sanctuarie doe good ſaye playnely breaketh sanctuarie duke done temporall men whole good part ſpiritual alſo thinkyng hurt earthly ment toward yong babe condiſcended effect delyuered ſhould fetched howbeit thought beſt auoyding manner rumor lorde cardinall ſhould firſt aſſay get hir good therevppon counſell came vnto starre chamber westminster lorde cardinall leauyng protector counſell starre chamber departed sanctuarie quéene dyuers lordes reſpect hys honour ſhée ſhould preſence ſo many perceyue thys errande one man mynde protector intended matter truſt one man alone elſe ſhée finally determyned kéepe hym ſome companie happily ſecrete inſtruction incontinent maugre hir mynde take leaue hir reſpite conuey ſhée lykely mynde matter broken hir hir time would wiſe ſerue hir quéene theſe lordes come togyther preſence lorde cardinall ſhewed vnto hir thoughte vnto protector vnto whole counſell hir kéepyng king brother place thing whych highly ſounded onely great rumour people obloquie alſo importable griefe diſpleaſure king royal maieſtie whoſe grace ſingular comforte haue hys naturall brother companye diſhonour theyrs hirs alſo ſuffer hym sanctuarie though one brother ſtoode danger perill ſhewed hir counſell therefore ſent hym vnto hir require hir deliuerie hym myght bée broughte vnto kyngs preſence hys libertie place reckoned pryſon ſhoulde bée demeaned accordyng hys eſtate ſhée thys doyng ſhoulde doe great good realme pleaſure counſell profite hir ſelfe ſuccour hyr friendes diſtreſſe • uer wiſte wel ſhée ſpecially tendred onely great comforte honour kyng alſo young duke hymſelfe whoſe greate wealth bée together well many greater cauſes alſo theyr diſporte recreation thyng lord eſtéemed • leyght though ſéeme lyghteprotector▪ well pondering theyr youth without recreation play cannot endure ſtraunger coniecture age eſtates ſo méetely poynt eyther lord quoth quéene ſay nay y• werethe queen •• aunſvver • • ery conuenient y• gentleman ye require company king brother good fayth mée thynketh great commoditie yet bein cuſtodie mother tender age conſidred y• elder ſpecially y• yonger beſides hys infancie alſo néedeth good looking hath béene ſo ſore diſeaſed vexed ſikeneſſe ſo newlye rather little amended well recouered dare put perſon earthly truſt kéeping ſelfe onely conſidering phi •• tions ſay alſo finde double perill recidiuation firſt ſickneſſe diſeaſe nature beyng ſore laboured forewéeried weakened wa • eth leſſe able beare ſuſtaine newe ſurfette albeit myght founde would happily doe beſte vnto hym yet none eyther knoweth better order hym ſo long haue kept hym tenderly lyke cheryſhe hym hys owne mother bare hym man denyeth good madame quoth cardinall grace folke moſt neceſſarie chyldren ſo would counſel onely content glad ye myght ſtande wyth pleaſure ſuch place myght ſtand wyth honour doe appoynt ſelfe tarrie héere thynke conuenient duke yorke wyth king honorably lybertie comfort héere sanctuarie man diſhonour obloquie ſith alway ſo great neceſſytie haue chylde bée mother occaſion may ſometime bée ſuch y• ſhould expedient kéepe elſewhere well appeareth ſuch time déereſt ſonne prince nowe king ſhoulde honour good order countrey kéepe houſholde wale farre company grace well content ſelfe well content quoth quéen yet caſe like one health ſicke caſe maruell greatly lord protector ſo deſirous haue hym kéeping chyld hys ſickeneſſe miſcarrie nature yet myght runne ſclaunder ſuſpition fraude call thing ſo ſore agaynſt childes honour theyrs alſo bydeth place honor thereto ſuffer bide man doubteth ſhall beſt kepte héere whyle héere yet intende come forth ieoperd ſelfe friendes would god rather ſuertie thā ieoperdie madame quoth lord know thing ſhould ieoperdie nay verily ſir quoth ſhée ſhoulde priſon neyther bée trowe great maruell though feare leaſt thoſe haue letted put dureſſe without colour let little procure theyr deſtruction without cauſe cardinal made countenaunce lorde ſhoulde harp vpon ſtring ſaid quéene nothing doubted thoſe lordes hir honorable kynne yet remayned vnder arreſt ſhoulde vppon matter examined doe well ynough towarde hir noble perſon neyther coulde anye manner ieoperdie whereby ſhoulde truſt quoth quéene gyltleſſe though giltie enimyes better loued hate ſake ſo • éere kynne kyng howe farre would helpe god ſend grace hu •• therefore purpoſe yet depart hence gentleman ſonne mynde ſhall bée tyll ſée aſſure ſée ſome men ſo gréedie without ſubſtantiall cauſe haue hym maketh much fearder delyuer truely madame quoth fearder deliuer feader bin men ſuffer kéepe leaſt cauſeleſſe feare might cauſe farther conuey many thinke haue priuiledge place neyther haue wyll aſke malice deſerue therefore recken priuiledge broken though fetche ye finally refuſe deliuer verily thinke much dread hath lorde uncle • ender loue beareth leaſt grace ſhoulde hap ſend away syr quoth quéene hath protector ſo tenderthe queene zeale yt feareth nothing leaſt ſhoulde eſcape thinketh woulde ſend hence whych neyther plyght ſend place coulde recken hym ſure ſure sanctuarie whereof neuer tyraunt yet ſo diuellyſhe durſt preſume breake truſt god ſtrong withſtand aduerſaries euer ſonne deſerue sanctuarie therfore haue forſooth hath founde goodly gloſe place may defend théefe may ſaue innocent ieoperdie hath néede thereof would god troth protector pray god may proue protector troweth perceyue vnto hys paynted proceſſe draweth honorable duke byde comfortable brother bycauſe king lacketh playfellowe ye ſure pray god ſend better playfellowes hym maketh ſo high matter vpon ſuch tryfelyng pretext though coulde none founde play wyth king hys brother hath luſte play ſickeneſſe come sanctuarie ſafegarde play though prince yong could play •• rth peeres child coulde playe kinred part agrée much worſe ſtraungers childe require priuiledge tolde ſo ſhall heare aſke howbeit ga • matter ſuppoſe coulde aſke ſuppoſe woulde aſke it▪ ſuppoſe woulde aſke goe ſay ſhall aſke priuiledge ſelfe ſay againſt taketh breaketh ye sanctuarie serueth libertie perſon good ye may hence take horſe may take child fro alſo ward learned counſell ſheweth mée ſithe hath nothing diſcent holden knightes ſeruice law maketh mother gardaine may man ſuppoſe take warde sanctuarie without breache sanctuarie priuiledge coulde ſerue aſke himſelfe yet ſith law committeth cuſtodie may require except law giue childe gardaine onely good landes diſcharging •• e ſafekéeping hys bodie onely landes good ſerue ¶ example ſufficient obtaine priuiledge forthis betvveene marke ¶ marke vvas vvritten englith tranſlated hiſtorie vvhich vvrot latten child néede far ſéeke place queſtiō whether childe may take benefit mine ſonne king borne kept cradle preſerued proſperous fortune pray god long continue know firſt time haue taken sanctuarie lorde huſbande baniſhed thruſt hys kingdome fled hither great childe bare prince lorde huſband returned ſafe agayne victorie went hence welcome home hence brought babe prince vnto father firſt tooke armes pray god ſonnes palace may great ſauegarde vnto nowe raigning place ſomtime ye king enimie place intēd kéepe brother ſith c wherfore intend kéepe ſince man law ſerueth ye gardaine kéepe infant law nature ye mother kéepe hir child god law priuiledgeth y• sanctuarie sanctuarie ſon ſith feare put ye protector hand yt hath brother alreadie fayled inheritor ye crowne cauſe feare hath man doe examine yet feare farther ye lawe feareth learned mē tell forbyddeth euery mā cuſtodie whoſe death may inherite leſſe land kingdome whoſoeuer ye breaketh holy sactuarie pray god ſhortly ſend néede sanctuarie may come taken sanctuarie woulde mortall enimie lord cardinall perceyuing quéene wared euer longer alſo ſhe began kindle chafe ſpeake byting word againſt protector ſuch neither beléeued alſo loath heare ſaid hir finall concluſion woulde longer diſpute matter ſhe content deliuer duke lordes preſent durſt lay owne body ſoule pledge onely ſuertie alſo eſtate ſhe woulde giue reſolute anſwere contrarie woulde forthwith depart ſhift ſo would buſineſſe afterwardes neuer intended moue hir matter ſhe thought al alſo ſaue hirſelf lacked either wit truth wit ſo dull could nothing perceiue protector intended truth ſhould procure hir ſonne delyuered handes ſhoulde perceyue toward childe euill intended quéene theſe wordes ſtoode good greate ſtudie foraſmuch hir ſéemed cardinall ready departe ſome remnant protector himſelfe readie hand ſo ſhe verily thought ſhée coulde kéepe ſhoulde incontinent taken thence conuey elſewhere neither ſhe time ſerue hir place determined perſons appointed thing vnreadie meſſage came hir ſ • ſodainely nothing leſſe looking haue fetcht sanctuarie ſhe thoughte nowe beſet • ſuch place y• could conueyed vntaken partly ſhe thoughte might fortune hir feare falſe ſo wel ſhe wiſte eyther néedeleſſe bootleſſe • wherfore ſhe ſhould néedes goe frō ſhe déemed beſt deliuer ouer cardinal faith ſhe nothing doubted ſome lordes neither ſhe ſawe ſhe feared leaſt might deceiued ſo ſhe wel aſſured would corrupted thē thought ſhe ſhould yet make ye warely looke circumſpectly ſée ſuertie ſhe hir owne hand betooke thē truſt ye laſt ſhe tooke ye yong duke hand ſaid vnto lord lord quoth ſhe al lord neither ſo vnwiſe miſtruſt wittes ſo ſuſpicious miſtruſt truthes thing purpoſe make ſuch proofe either lacked mighte turne great ſorow realme much harme great reproch loe quoth ſhe gentlemā dout could kéepe ſafe would whatſoeuer mā ſay doubt alſo ſome abrode ſo deadly enimies vnto bloud y• wiſt lay body would let haue alſo experience ye deſire kingdom knoweth kinred brother hath bene ye brother bane may y• nephewes ſure vncle eche theſe childrē others defence ſunder eche liues lieth others body kéepe one ſafe ſure nothing thē perillous thā one place wiſe marchant aduētureth good one ſhip al notwithſtāding deliuer brother kéepe hand whō ſhal aſk thē afore god world faithful ye ye wote well knowe well wiſe power ſtrength kéepe liſt neyther lack ye ſelf lack helpe caſe ye elſe may leaue one thing beſéeche truſt father put euer truſt ye put nowe y• far ye thinke y• feare much well ware feare far little therwithall ſaide vnto child farewel mine ſwéete ſon▪ god ſend good kéeping let kiſſe yet ere go god knoweth whē ſhall kiſſe together againe therwith ſhe kiſſed bleſſed turned hir back wept went hir way leauing ye child wéeping faſt y• lord cardinal thoſe lord wt receiued yong duke brought y• ſtar chamber y• protector tooke armes kiſſed theſe word welcome lord euen wt al hart ſaid y• ofo diſsimulation likelihood thought thervpon forthwith brought vnto king brother biſhops palace paules thence citie honorably tower ye y• day neuer came abrode ¶ protector y• child handsthis betvveene marke ¶ marke vvas vvritten english tranſlated hiſtorie vvhich vvrote lattin opened himſelf boldly certaine men alſo chiefly y• duke buckinghā although know y• many thought y• duke priuie al y• protector coū ſel euen frō beginning ſome protector friend ſaid y• duke firſt mouer protector matter ſending priuie meſſenger vnto ſtraight k edward death againe knew better ſubtil wit y• protector denie y• euer opened enterpriſe y• duke vntil brought paſſe y• thing rehearſed whē impriſoned y• quéens kinſfolks gotten hir ſonnes owne hand opened reſt purpoſe leſſe feare thought méet y• matter ſpecially duke woon purpoſe thought ſtrength half increaſed matter broken vnto ye duke ſubtill folkes ſuch craft maſters handling ſuch wicked deuiſes declared vnto yong king offended kinſfolks ſake euer able would reuenge woulde prick forward thervnto eſcaped would remember impriſonment elſe put deathe without doubte yong king woulde carefull deathes whoſe impriſonment grieuous vnto repenting duke ſhould nothing auaile way left redéeme offence benefites ſhoulde ſooner deſtroy himſelfe ſaue king brother kinſfolkes ſawe ſuch place impriſoned protector might wyth beck deſtroy doubt woulde doe déede new enterpriſe attempted lykely protector prouided priuie garde hymſelfe ſo ſpyalles duke traynes catche ſhoulde agaynſt hym peraduenture leaſt ſuſpected ſtate thing diſpoſitions mē ſuch man coulde well tell mighte truſt might feare theſe thing ſuch lyke beyng beaten duke mynde brought point repented way entred yet woulde goe forthe ſame ſince begunne woulde ſtoutely goe throughe therefore wicked enterpriſe beléeued coulde voyded bent hymſelfe went determined ſince common miſchiefe could amended would turne much might owne commoditie agréed protector ſhoulde haue duke aide make king protector lawfull ſonne ſhould marrie duke daughter protector ſhould graunt quiet poſſeſſion • ledome hertford claimed inheritance could neuer obtayne king edwardes tyme beſides theſe requeſts y• duke y• protector minde promiſed hym great quantitie king treaſure houſholde ſtuffe thus poynt betwéene themſelues went prepare y• coronation yong king would haue ſéeme myght turne eye mindes men frō perceiuing drift lord ſent partes y• realme came thick y• ſolemnitie protector duke ſent y• lord cardinal archbiſhop yorke lord chauncellour y• biſhop elie y• lord stanley lord haſtings lorde chamberlaine wt many noble men common deuiſe coronation one place faſt another place contriuing contrarie make protector king coūcell albeit adhibited ſecret yet began ſome maner muttering among y• people though ſhould long wel though neyther wyſt feared wherefore ſuch great thing men harte ſecret inſtinct nature miſgiue ſea without winde ſwelleth himſelf ſomtime tempeſt ſome one man happily ſomewhat perceiuing filled many men ſuſpition though ſhewed men knew howbeit ſomewhat dealing ſelf made men muſe matter though councell cloſe little little folke withdrew tower drew croſbies biſhops gate ſtreete protector kept houſhold protector reſort king manner deſolate ſome buſineſſe made ſute ſome friend ſecretly warned might happily turne good muche attendant king without protector appointment remoued alſo diuers prince olde ſeruaunts ſet new thus many thing cōming togither partly chaunce partly purpoſe cauſed length cōmon people onely y• wound wt wind wiſe men alſo ſome lord eke marke matter muſe thereon ſo farre forth lorde stanley earle darbie wiſely miſtruſted ſayde vnto lorde haſtings muche miſlyked theſe two ſeueral councels quoth talke one matter ye one place little wote wherof talke place lorde quoth lorde haſtings life neuer doubt one man neuer thence neuer thing moued ſhould ſound amiſſe toward ſhoulde mine eares ere well mouthes ment catesby whiche hys néere ſecretecatesbie counſell verie familiarly vſed moſt weightie matter put man ſo ſpeciall truſt reckening himſelfe man ſo liefe ſithe well wyſte man ſo muche beholden catesby man well learned lawes land ſpeciall fauour lorde chamberlaine good authoritie much rule bare ye countie leycester lorde chamberleynes power chiefely laye ſurely great pitie eyther truth leſſe wit diſſimulation onely kept miſchiefe vp lorde haſtings put ſo ſpeciall truſt lorde stanley departed diuers lordes broken daunce many yll ſignes ſawe conſtrues beſt ſurely thought coulde harme toward councell intended catesby truth protector duke buckingham made verie good ſemblaunce vnto lorde haſtings kept much companie vndoubtedly protector loued well loth haue loſt ſauing feare leaſt lyfe ſhoulde haue quaiied purpoſe cauſe moued catesby proue wyth ſome wordes caſt farre whether coulde thinke poſſible winne lorde haſtings vnto part catesby whether aſſayed aſſayed reported vnto founde ſo faſt heard ſpeake ſo terrible word durſt breake trueth lorde chamberlayne verye truſt ſhewed vnto catesby diſtruſt began haue matter therefore hée fearing leaſt theyr motion might lorde haſtings miniſhe credence wherevnto onely matter leaned procured protector haſtily rid much rather truſted death obtayne muche rule lorde haſtings bare coūtrey onely deſire wherof allectiue induced partner one ſpeciall contriuer horrible treaſon wherevpon ſoone wit fryday thirtéenth day june many lordes aſſembled tower ſat councell deuiſing honourable ſolemnitie king coronation tyme appoynted ſo neare approched pageantes ſubtiltyes making daye night westminster much vitayle kylled therefore afterward caſt away theſe lordes ſo ſitting together communing thys matter protector came amongſt firſt ix clocke ſaluting courteouſly excuſing hymſelf bene ſo long ſaying merily bene ſléeper day little talkyng ſayde vnto byſhop elie lorde haue verye good strawberies garden holborne require let v haue meſſe gladly lorde quoth woulde god ſome better thing readie pleaſure therwith haſt ſent hys ſeruant meſſe strawberies protector ſet lordes faſt communing therevpon praying ſpare little departed thence ſoone one houre betwéene x xj returned chamber among changed wonderfull ſoure angrie countenance knitting ye browes frowning fretting gnawing lippes ſo ſat hym downe place lordes much diſmayde ſore maruelling manner ſodaine change thing ſhould aile whē ſitten ſtill thus began worthy haue compaſſe imagine deſtruction mée beyng ſo néere bloud vnto king protector royall perſon realme queſtion lordes ſat ſore aſtonyed muſing much queſtion ſhoulde ment euery man wyſt himſelfe cleare lord chamberlaine loue betwéene thoughte might boldeſt aunſwered ſayde worthy puniſhed heynous traytors whatſoeuer affyrmed ſame quoth yonder ſorcereſſe brother wyfe hir meaning ye quéene theſe word many ye lord greatly abaſhed y• fauoured hir ye lord haſtings minde better content y• moued hir thā whō loued better albeit hart ſomwhat grudged yt afore made counſel matter taking hir kinred putting death aſſent deuiſed beheaded pomfret thys ſelf ſame day ware yt deuiſed yt himſelf ſhould beheaded ye ſame day london ſaide protector ye ſhall ſée wiſe ſorcereſſe witch hir counſell shore wife affinitie haue ſorcerie witchcrafte waſted body therewith plucked vp dublet ſléeue elbow vpō left arme ſhewed weriſh withered arme ſmal neuer thervpō euery man minde ſore miſgaue wel perceiuing y• matter quarrel well wiſt y• quéene wiſe goe ſuch folly alſo ſhe would yet would ſhe folke leaſt make shore wife counſell woman ſhe moſt hated concubine whome king hir huſbande moſt loued alſo manne preſent well knew arme euer ſuche ſince hys byrth naytheleſſe lorde chamberlayne death kyng edward kept shore wyfe ſomewhat doted king lyfe ſauing ſayde forbare hir reuerence toward k elſe certayn kind fidelitic friend aunſweared ſayd certaynly lord haue ſo heynouſly done worthie heynous puniſhment quoth protector thou ſerueſt wéene iffes andes tell thée haue ſo done make good thy bodye traytour therewith great anger clapped fyſt vpon bourd great rappe token giuen one cried treaſon without chamber therewith doore clapped come ruſhing men harneſſe many chamber myght holde anone protector ſayd lord haſtings arreſt thée traytour mée lord quoth yea thée traitour quoth protector another let flie lorde stanley ſhrunke ſtroke fellthe lorde stā ley vvounded vnder ye table elſe head béen cleft téeth ſhortly ſhrāke yet came bloud eares al quickly beſtowed diuers chamber except lorde chamberlaine protector bad ſpéede ſhriue apace saint paule quoth dinner till ſée thy head booted aſke heauily tooke prieſt auenture made ſhort ſhrift longer would ſuffred protector made ſo much haſt dinner might goe till done ſauing hys othe brought forth gréene beſyde chappell within towre head layde downe vppon long logge tymber ſtriken afterward body head enterred windſor beſide ye body king edward maruellous caſe heare eyther warning ſhoulde haue boyded token coulde voyde ſelfe night next death lord stanley ſente truſtie ſecrete meſſenger vnto mydnight haſte requiring riſe ride awaye hym diſpoſed vtterly longer byde hethe lorde stanley dreame hadde ſo fearefull dreame whiche thoughte boare tuſkes ſo raſed ye head bloud ran ſhoulders much protector gaue boare cogniſance dreame made ſo fearefull impreſſion heart throughly determined longer tarrie hys horſſe readie lord haſtings would goe wyth hym ride yet ſo farre ſame nighte ſhoulde daunger ere daye ha good lord quoth lorde haſtings meſſenger leaneth lorde thy maiſter ſo muche ſuche trifle hath ſuch fayth dreames whiche eyther owne feare fantaſieth doe riſe nightes reſt reaſon day thought tell plaine witchcraft beléeue ſuch dreames whiche token thing come thinketh y• mighte likely make thē true going caught brought back friend fayle fléers thē ye boare cauſe likelye race v tuſkes folke y• fled ſome falſehoode wherfore eyther peril none déede rather going byding ſhoulde néeds coſt fal peril one way yet lieffer y• men ſhould ſée mennes falſehoode thinke eyther owne faulte fainte hearte therefore go thy maiſter manne commende pray merry haue feare enſure ſure manne hée woteth mine owne hande god ſende grace ſir quoth meſſenger went waye certaine alſo riding towards tower ſame morning whiche beheaded horſſe twice thrice ſtumbled almoſte falling thing albeit eache man wote wel dayly happeneth ſuch miſchance toward yet hath bin olde rite cuſtome obſerued token oftentimes notably foregoing ſome great miſfortune followeth warning enuyous ſkorne ſame morning ere vp came knight vnto curteſie accompany counſell trueth ſent protector haſt thitherwardes ſecrete confederacie purpoſe meane man time nowe great authoritie knight happened lorde chamberlayne waye ſtay horſſe commune prieſt mette tower streete brake tale ſayde merily lorde praye come whereto talke ſo long prieſte haue néede prieſt yet therewith laughed vpon hym though would ſaye yée ſhall haue ſoone ſo little wiſt tother mente ſo little miſtruſted neuer merier neuer ſo ful good hope life ſelfe thing often ſéene ſigne change ſhal rather let thing paſſe y• vaine ſuretie man minde ſo neare death upon tower wharfe ſo neare place wher head ſoone met one haſtings purſiuaunt owne name theyr méeting place put remembraunce another time whiche hadde happened méete lyke manner togither ſame place whiche tyme lord chamberlain bin accuſed vnto king edward lorde riuers quéenes brother ſuche wiſe laſted long far fallen ye king indignation ſtoode great feare himſelf muche mette purſiuaunt ſame place ieopardie ſo well paſſed gaue hym great pleaſure talke thereof hadde talked thereof ſame place whyle therin therefore ſayde ah haſtings arte thou remembred met thée heauie hearte yea lorde quoth remember well thanked god got good harme thereby thou wouldeſt ſaye ſo quoth thou kn • weſt much knowe whyche fewe knowe elſe yet mo ſhal ſhortly ment lordes quéenes kyndred taken ſhould daye beheaded ponfraite • well wiſt nothing ware hung ouer heade fayth man quoth neuer ſo ſorie neuer ſtoode ſo great dreade life dyd thou mette lo howe worlde turned nowe ſtand mine enimies daunger thou mayeſt happe heare hereafter neuer life ſo mery neuer ſo great ſuretie good god blindneſſe mortall nature moſt feared good ſuretie reckened himſelf ſureſt loſt life within two hour thus ended thys honourable man good knight athe deſcription lord haſtings gentle greate aucthoritie hys prince lyuing ſomewhat diſſolute playne open hys enimie ſecrete friend eaſie beguile good hearte courage foreſtudied perilles louing man paſſing wel beloued faithful truſtie ynough truſting much flew fame lord death ſwiftlye citie ſo forth like winde euery man eare protector immediately dinner intending ſette ſome colour vpon matter ſent haſt many ſubſtantial men citie tower theyr comming himſelfe duke buckingham ſtoode harneſſed olde yll faring briganders ſuch man ſhoulde wéene would vouchſafe haue put vpon backes except ſome ſodain neceſſitie conſtrained protectour ſhewed lorde chamberlaine conſpiracie contriued haue ſodainely deſtroyed hym duke ſame daye counſel intended yet well knowne whiche treaſon hée neuer knowledge tenne clocke ſame forenoone ſodain feare droue put defence ſuche harneys came next hande ſo hadde god holpen miſchief turned vpon woulde haue done thys requyred report euery man aunſwered fayre though manne miſtruſted matter trothe manne beléeued yet appeaſing people minde ſent immediately dinner al haſt herault armes wyth proclamation made throughe citie thethe protector proclamation kyngs name conteyning lord haſtings diuerſe trayterous purpoſe conſpired ſame daye haue ſlaine lorde protectour duke buckingham ſitting counſell haue taken vpon rule king realme theyr pleaſure thereby pill ſpoyle whome liſt vncontrolled much matter proclamation deuiſed ſlaunder lorde chamberlayne euil counſayler king father inticing manye thing highly redounding miniſhing honour vniuerſall hurte realme euill companye ſiniſter procuring vngracious enſample wel manye thing dicious liuing inordinate abuſion hys bodie wyth manye alſo ſpeciallye wyth shore wiſe whiche one alſo hys moſte ſecret counſaile thys heynons treaſon laye nightlye namely night laſt paſt nexte death ſo leſſe maruayle vngratious liuing broughte vnhappy ending whiche nowe putte vnto moſte dread commaundemente king highneſſe honorable faythfull counſayle bothe hys demerites ſo openly taken hys falſlye conceyued treaſon alſo leaſte delaying execution might haue encouraged miſchieuous perſons partner conſpiracie gather aſſemble themſelues togither making ſome greate commotion hys delyueraunce whoſe hope nowe well deſerued death politikely repreſſed al ye realm ſhould god grace reſt good quiet peace proclamation made wythin two houres beheaded ſo curiouſly indited ſo faire written parchment ſo well ſette hand therewith ſelfe ſo long proceſſe euery childe might well perceyue prepared ye time betwéene death proclayming coulde ſkant haue ſufficed vnto bare writing alone béene paper ſcribled forth haſte aduenture vpon proclayming thereof one ſcholemaſter paules chaunce ſtanding comparing ſhortneſſe time length matter ſayd vnto ſtoode gay goodly caſt foule caſt away haſte merchaunt aunſweared written prophecie nowe anger couetiſe protectour ſent houſe shore wife hir huſbande dwelled hyr ſpoyled hir euer ſhe aboue value two thrée thouſande marke ſent hyr body priſon layde vnto hyr manner ſake ſhe wente aboute bewitch ſhe counſaile lord chāberlaine deſtroy cō cluſion colour coulde faſten vppon theſe matter layde heynouſly hir charge y• thing hir ſelfe could denye world wiſt true naytheleſſe euery manne laughed heare ſo ſodainely ſo highly taken ſhe nought hir body cauſe good continent prince cleane faultleſſe himſelfe ſente heauen vicious world amendment men manner cauſed biſhop london put hyr open penaunce going croſſe proceſſion vpon sonday taper hir hande whiche ſhe went countenance pace demure ſo womanly albeit ſhe al array ſaue hir kyrtle onlye yet wente ſhe ſo faire louely namely wondering people caſte comely rudde hir chéekes ſhe moſt miſſe yt hir great ſhame wanne hir much prayſe among thoſe wer amorous hir bodie curious hir ſoule manye good folke alſo hated hir liuing glad ſée ſin corrected yet pitied hir penaunce ethan reioyced therein conſidered protector procured corrupt intent vertuous affection woman borne london worſhipfullye friendedthe deſcription shore vvife honeſtly brought vp wel maried ſauing ſomwhat ſoone hir huſband honeſt citizen▪ yong godly good ſubſtāce much coupled ere ſhe wel ripe ſhe feruently loued whō ſhe neuer longed happily thing ye eaſily made hir incline vnto king appetite hée required hir howbeit reſpect royaltie hope gay apparell eaſe pleaſure wanton wealth able ſoone pierce ſoft tender hearte king abuſed hir anone hir huſband honeſt mā one y• could good preſuming touch king concubine left hir vp altogither king died lord chamberlain tooke hyr whiche king dayes albeit ſore enamoured vpon hir yet forebare hir eyther reuerence certaine friendly faythfulneſſe proper ſhe fayre nothing hir bodie would haue chaunged woulde haue wiſhed hir ſomewhat higher thus ſay knewe hir hir youth albeit ſome nowe ſée hir yet ſhe liueth déeme hir neuer haue bene wel viſaged whoſe iudgement ſéemeth ſomewhat like though men ſhould geſſe beautie one long departed hir ſcalpe taken charnel houſe ſhe olde leane withered dryed vp nothing left riueld ſkin hard bone yet euen ſuch ſo wel aduiſe hir viſage might geſſe deuiſe part filled woulde make faire face yet delited men ſo much hir beautie hir pleaſaunt behauiour proper wit ſhe coulde reade well write merrie companye readie quicke aunſwere neyther mute full bable ſometime taunting without diſpleaſure without diſporte king would ſay thrée concubine whichking edvvards three concubine thrée diuerſe property diuerſly excelled one merieſt another wylieſt thirde holyeſt harlot realme one man could get church lightly place bed two ſomewhat greater perſonages natheleſſe humility content nameleſſe forbeare praiſe thoſe property ye merieſt shors wife whō king therfore tooke ſpeciall pleaſure many hir loued whoſe fauour ſaye troth ſinne belie diuel ſhe neuer abuſed mās hurt manye mannes comforte reliefe kyng tooke diſpleaſure ſhe would mitigate appeaſe mynde men fauour ſhée woulde bryng grace manye hadde highlye offended ſhée obtayned pardon great forfeytures ſhe gat men remiſſion finally many weightie ſutes ſhe ſtoode many men great ſteade eyther none ſmall rewardes thoſe rather gaye riche eyther ſhe content déede ſelfe well done ſhée delyted bée ſued vnto ſhewe ſhée able doe king wanton woman wealthy al wayes couetous doubt ſome ſhall thinke woman ſleyghte thing written ſet among remembrance great matter whych ſhall ſpeciallye thinke happilye ſhall eſtéeme hir onely nowe ſée hir ſéemeth chaunce ſo muche worthy remembred much ſhe nowe beggerlye condition vnfriended worne acquaintaunce good ſubſtaunce great fauour prince greate ſute ſéekyng thoſe thoſe dayes buſineſſe ſpéede manye men theyr tymes famous infamye theyr yl déeds hir doings wer much leſſe albeit much leſſe remēbred bycauſe ſo euil mē vſe haue euill turne write marble ſo doeth v good turne write duſte whiche worſt proued hir day ſhe beggeth manye thys day lyuing y• day begged ſhe bin ſo deuiſed protectour counſayle ſelfe daye whych lord chamberlayne beheaded tower london aboute ſelfe ſame houre without aſſent beheaded ponfraite foreremembred lord knightes taken king northampton stonie stratforde thing done preſence order ſir richarde ratcliffe knight whoſe ſeruice protectoursir richarde ratclife ſpecially vſed counſell execution ſuch lawleſſe enterpriſes man bene long ſecrete wyth hauing experience worlde ſhrewde witte ſhort rude ſpéech rough boyſterous behauyour bolde miſchiefe farre pitie al feare god knight bringing thē ye priſon ſcaffold ſhewing people traytours ſuffering declare ſpeake innocency leaſt word might haue inclyned men pitie tothe lord riuers beheaded hate protector part cauſed haſtily wythout iudgement proces manner order beheaded without earthly gilt onely good mē true kyng nigh quéene nowe lorde chamberlaine theſe lordes knightes thus beheaded ridde way thoughte protector whyle men muſed matter ment lord realme theyr owne ſtrengthes mā wiſte thinke whome truſte ere euer ſhoulde haue ſpace diſpute diſgeſt matter make party beſt haſtily purſue purpoſe put himſelfe poſſeſſion crown ere men could haue time deuiſe way reſiſt nowe ſtudie meane thys matter ſelfe ſo heynous might firſt broken people ſuch wiſe might well taken thys councell tooke diuerſe ſuche thought méetlye truſted likelye induced parte able ſtande ſteade eyther power policie among whome made co • nlaile edmonde shaa edmond shaa maior lōdō knight maior london vpon truſt owne aduauncement whereof proude hearte highlye deſirous ſhould frame citie theyr appetite spirituall men toke ſuch wit authoritie among people opinion learning •• ſcrupulous conſcience among theſe hadde iohn shaa clearke brother todoctour shaa frier penker maior fryer penker pro • inciall augustine fryer doctours diuinitie great preacher learning vertue fame thā learning gretly eſtéemed among people neuer theſe two tone sermon prayſe protecte •• coronation tother ſo ful tedious flatterie •• eares coulde abide penker ſermon ſo loſt voyce fain leaue come downe midſt doctour shaa ſermon loſt honeſtie ſoone life • erys ſhame worlde whiche durſte neuer come abroade frier forced ſhame ſo harmed leſſe ſome doubt many thinke penker counſayle matter coronation common maner fel flatterie namely ſith sermon incontinent vppon saint marie hoſpitall eaſter certaine doctor shaa counſayle beginning ſo farre forth determined ſhould firſt breake matter sermō paules croſſe whiche ſhould authoritie preaching incline people protector ghoſtly purpoſe labour ſtudie deuiſe ſome conuenient pretext whyche people ſhoulde content depoſe prince accepte protector king▪ diuerſe thing deuiſed thie • thing weighte inuention reſted thys ſhould alledge baſtardie▪ eyther king▪ edward himſelfe child ſhould ſéeme diſabled inherite crowne dyke yorke prince laye burſtardie king edwarde founded openlie rebuke protectours owne mother mother point coulde none colour protende owne mother aduoutreſſe notwithſtanding thys purpoſe letted na • leſſe woulde poynt ſhoulde loſſe fauourably handled euen fully plaine directly matter ſhoulde touched aſlope • ra • tily thou 〈…〉 ſpared 〈…〉 ſpeake al troth feare diſpleaſure poynt concerning baſtardie deuiſed ſurmiſe king edwardes child woulde ſhould openly declared inforced vttermoſt colour pretext whereof cannot wel perceyued firſte repeate ſome thing long done king edward mariage king edwarde fourth hadde depoſed king henrie ſixth peaceable poſſeſſiō y• realm determining himſelfe marie requiſite himſelfe realme ſent ouer ambaſſade earle warwicke noble men companye vnto spaine intreate conclude mariage betwéene king edwarde king daughter spaine thyng earle warwicke founde party ſo towarde willing ſpéedilyé according inſtructions without difficultie brought matter good cō cluſion happened meane ſeaſon came make ſute petition king dame elizabeth gray quéene time widowe bornedame elizabeth gray noble bloude ſpecially hyr mother whiche dutch bedforde ere ſhe married lorde woodfielde hyr father howbeit dame elizabeth hir ſelfe ſeruice wyth quéene margaret wife vnto king henrie ſixth maryed vnto one iohn gray eſquire king henrie made knight vppon fielde bernet heath saint albons againſt king edwarde little enioyed knighthoode ſame fielde ſlaine done earle warwicke ambaſſade aboute afore remembred mariage thys péere ladie made humble ſute vnto ye king ſhe might reſtored vnto ſuch ſmall landes hir late huſbande giuen hyr ioynture whome kyng behelde hearde hyr ſpeake ſhe fayre goodly fauour moderate ſtature wel made wiſe pitied hir alſo waxed enamoured hir takyng hir ſecretly aſide beganne enter talking familiarly whoſe appetite ſhe perceyued ſhe vertuouſly denyed hym ſhe ſo wiſely ſo good maner word ſo wel ſet ſhe rather kindled deſire quenched finallye manye méeting muche wooyng manye greate promiſes ſhe well eſpyed king affection towarde hyr ſo greatelye encreaſed ſhée durſte ſomewhat boldely ſay hir minde whoſe heart ſhe perceyned feruently ſet fall worde concluſion ſhe ſhewed playne ſhée wyſte hyr ſelfe ſimple wife ſo thoughte ſhe hir ſelfe good hys concubine king muche maruelling hir conſtancie hée hadde bene wonte elſe ſo ſtiffelye ſayde naye ſo muche eſtéemed hir continencie chaſtitye hée ſette hyr vertue ſteade poſſeſſion rich thus takyng counſayle deſire determined poſſible haſte • mary hir thus appointed hadde betwéene twaine enſured hir aſked counſaile hys friendes ſuche manner might perceiue booted greatly ſay nay notwithſtanding dutch yorke mother ſo ſore moued ther wt ye ſhe diſwaded mariage much ſhe poſſible mightthe king mother alleaging ye honor profite ſurety alſo marie noble progenie realme whervpon depended great ſtrength eſtate ye affinitie great poſſibilitie encreaſe poſſeſſion coulde well otherwiſe doe ſtanding earle warwick ſo far moued alreadye likely take wel • al voiage wer ſuch wiſe fruſtrate apointments deluded ſhe ſayd alſo yt princely mary owne ſubiecte greate occaſion leading therevnto poſſeſſions commoditie depending therevpon onely rich man woulde marie mayde little wanton votage vpon hyr perſon mariage many mo cōmende maydens fortune maiſters wiſedome yet therin ſhe ſayd ther honeſtie honor mariage much betwéene merchaunte owne mayde ſo greate difference betwéene king widow whoſe perſon albeit nothyng miſlyked yet ſhe ſayde nothing ſo excellent mighte bée founde diuerſe méetly quoth ſhée eſtate maydens alſo wheras widowhead elizabeth gray though ſhe thing conuenient ſhoulde yet ſuffice ſéemeth refrayne hir mariage ſithe vnſitting thing blemiſhe high diſparagemente ſacred maieſtie prince ought nigh approche prieſthoode cleaneſſe doth dignitie defouled bigamie firſt mariage king mother ſayde made hir aunſwerethe king • ſvvere mother part earneſt part play merily wyſte himſelfe hyr rule albeit woulde gladlye ſhe ſhould take wel yet point minde toke ſhe well otherwiſe howbeit ſomewhat ſatiſfie hir ſayde albeit mariage beyng spiritual thing oughte rather made reſpect god hys grace enclyneth party loue togtiher truſted hys regarde temporall aduā tage yet naytheleſſe ſéemed mariage euen worldly conſidered vnprofitable reckened amitie earthly nation ſo neceſſarie friēdſhip thought likly beare ſo muche heartie fauour diſdayned marie one owne lande yet outward aliaunce thought ſo requiſite would finde meanes enter therevnto much better kinne party coulde contented marye himſelfe ſhould happily neuer loue poſſibilitie poſſeſſions leaſe fruite pleaſure alredy ſmal pleaſure taketh man euer hath beſide wiued againſt appetite doubt quoth yée ſaye yt euery point comparable hir therfore let thē like wedde reaſon miſlike man y• marry liketh ſure yt couſin warwicke neither loueth ſo little grudge y• loue ſo vnreaſonable looke yt ſhold choyſe wife rather ruled eie mine though ward y• wer boūd mary ye appointment gardaine would bea k y• cōditiō forbear mine libertie choiſe mine mariage poſſibilitie inheritāce new affinitie ſtrange land oft occaſion trouble thā profite haue alreadie title meanes ſo much ſufficeth get kéepe well one man dayes ſhe widow hath already child god bleſſed ladie bacheler haue ſome ſo eache v hath proofe nether v like barraine therefore madame pray contente truſt god ſhe ſhal bring forth yong prince ſhall pleaſe bigamie let biſhop hardly lay way come take order vnderſtād forbiddē prieſt neuer wiſt yet yt forbiddē prince dutch theſe word nothing appeaſed ſéeing king ſo ſette thereon ſhe coulde pul back ſo highly ſhe diſdayned vnder pretext hir dutie godwarde ſhe deuiſed diſturbe mariage rather helpe y• ſhould marie one dame elizabeth lucy king hadde alſo long gotten childe wherfore king mother openly obiected againſt mariage diſcharge hir conſcience king ſure dame elizabeth lucy hir huſbandeelizabeth lucy god reaſon wordes ſuch obſtacle made matter eyther biſhops durſt k would procéed ſolemnizatiō wedding til theſe ſame wer clearly purged troth wel openly teſtifyed whervpon dame eliz lucy ſente albeit ſhe king mother many put good comforte affirme ſhe enſured vnto king yet ſhe ſolemnly ſworn ſay troth ſhe confeſſed neuer enſured howbeit ſhe ſayde grace ſpake ſo louing word vnto hir ſhe verily hoped woulde haue maried hir yt bene ſuch kinde wordes ſhe would neuer haue ſhewed ſuch kindnes let ſo kindly get hir child examination ſolemnly taken clearlythe king mariage perceyued none impedimente king gret feaſt honorable ſolemnitie maried dame elizabeth gray pretext treaſon haue bene kindred aliaunce neare familiaritie longer acquaintaunce thoſe anye tyme king enimies one time halfe realme thus neither good ſuertie yet brought bodyes ieoperdie beſide common aduenture open warre albeitopen vvarre euer occaſion much miſchiefe yet neuer ſo miſchieuous people fall diſtaunce among themſelues none earthly nation ſo deadly ſo peſtilent hapneth among v among v neuer ſo long continued diſſention ſo many battayles ſeaſon ſo cruell ſo deadly foughtē king dayes deade god forgiue ſoule whoſe time whoſe occaſion getting garland kéeping leaſing winning againe hath coſt engliſh bloud hath twice winning fraunce inwarde warre amongciuill vvarre ſelues hath bene ſo great effuſion auncient noble bloud realme ſcarcely halfe remayneth great enféebling deſtruction many good woman▪ great dolor huſbande friendes honeſt people themſelues ſo much regarde cleanneſſe houſe chaſtitie theyr wiues child leauer leaſe al haue beſide haue ſuch villanie done abyding yet ye people ſingular cauſe wel kindly entreat part realme onely prince noble citie hys eſpeciall chamber ſpeciall well renowmed citie oflondon king eſpeciall chamber hys realme much honourable fame receiueth among nation alſo ye without great coſte ſundrie peril ieoperdies warres hare euen ſpeciall • auour parte whyche • kinde myndes borne houſe yorke ſithe hée hathe nothyng syr quoth maior percaſe perceyue well ſhall wée mende quoth helpe ſomewhat louder hée rehearſed ſame matter agayne order wordes ſo well ornately naytheleſſe ſo euidentlye playne wyth voyce geſture countenaunce ſo comely ſo conuenient euery man muche maruelled hearde thought neuer theyr liues heard ſo euil tale ſo well tolde wonder feare eche lookt ſhoulde ſpeake firſt one worde aunſwered people ſtoode ſtyll mydnight ſo muche rowning amongeſt myght ſéeme commune beſt doe maior ſawe hée partner councell drewe aboute duke ſayde people béene accuſtomed ſpoken vnto recorder mouth citie happily
