rehearſall common y• duke twice rehearſed himſelfe recorder ſo tempered hys tale ſhewed euery thing duke wordes parte hys owne noting chaunge made people alway one ſtoode béene men amaſed wherevppon duke rowned vnto maior ſayde maruellous obſtinate ſilence turned vnto people agayne theſe wordes deare friendes wée come mooue thing whiche peraduenture wée ſo greatlye needed lordes thys realme common party might haue ſufficed ſauing wée ſache loue beare ſo much ſet woulde gladlye doe without thing whiche partner weale honour ſéemeth either ſée wey wherefore require giue v anſweare one whether yée ininded al y• noble realm haue noble prince protector king theſe wordes people beganne whiſper among themſelues ſecretely voice neither lowde diſtinct ſounde ſwarme bee tyll laſt neather end hall buſhment duke ſeruauntes naſhfieldes longing protector ſome prentiſes laddes thruſt hall among preaſe beganne ſodainly men backes crye loude theyr throtes woulde gyue • king richarde king richarde threwe vp cappes token ioy ſtoode caſt backe head maruelling thereof nothing ſayde duke maior ſawe manner wiſelye turned theyr purpoſe ſayde goodly crye ioyfull heare euerye man one voyce man ſaying nay wherefore friendes quoth duke ſince perceiue whole myndes haue noble man k wherof ſhall make grace ſo effectuall report doubt ſhall redounde vnto great wēale commodytie wee require ye ye morow go v vnto noble graced make humble requeſt▪ vnto maner remembred lord came dow • e company diſſolued departed part ſad ſome glad femblance merrie and▪ ſome thoſe came thither wyth duke able diſſemble ſorrow faine barke turne face wall dolour heart burſt eye morrowe maior aldermenthe maiors comming baynards caſtell chiefe commoner citie beſt maner apparelled aſſembling themſelues together reſorted vnto baynardes castell protector lay place repayred alſo accordyng theyr appoyntment duke buckingham diuerſe noble men wyth beſyde many knightes gentleman therevppon duke ſent worde vnto lorde protector great honorable companie moue great matter vnto grace wherevpon protector made difficultie come vnto firſt knewe ſome part errand thoughe doubted partly diſtruſted comming number vnto ſo ſodenly without warning knowledge whether came good harme duke ſhewed vnto maior might therby ſée little protector looked matter ſent vnto meſſenger ſuche louing meſſage againe ſo humbly beſought vouchſafe might reſort preſence purpoſe intent woulde vnto none perſon part diſcloſe laſt came forth chamber yet downe vnto ſtoode aboue gallerie ouer might ſée ſpeake though woulde yet come néere tyll ment vpon duke buckinghā firſt made humble poſition vnto behalfe grace • ould pardon licence purpoſe vnto ••••• intent • •• comming without diſpleaſure without pardon obteined durſt bolde moue matter whiche albeit ment muche honour grace wealthe realme beſide yet ſure howe grace woulde take woulde wyſe offende protector verie gentle himſelfe alſo longed ſore witte ment gaue leaue purpoſe lyked verily truſting good minde hée bare none thing woulde intende vnto warde wherewith ought grieued duke thys leaue pardon ſpeake waxed hée bolde ſhew intent purpoſe cauſes moouing therevnto ye haue heard finally beſéeche grace woulde like accuſtomed goodnes zeale vnto realme nowe eye pitie beholde long continued diſtreſſe decaye ſame ſet gracious handes redreſſe amendment thereof taking vpon crowne gouernaunce thys realme accordyng ryght tytle lawfully deſcended vnto laude god profite lande vnto hys grace ſo muche honour leſſe payne neuer prince raygned vppon people ſo glad lyue vnder hys obeyſaunce people thys realme vnder protector hearde propoſition looked verie ſtraungely therat anſwered albeit ye partly knewe thing alledged true yet ſuch entire loue bare vnto king ed child y• ſo much regarded honor realmes crowne one whiche hée neuer deſyrous y• coulde finde heart poynt enclyne theyr deſire nation truth well knowne ſhoulde peraduenture thoughte owne ambitious minde deuiſe depoſe prince take himſelfe crowne infamie woulde haue honour ſtayned crowne euer perceyued much labour payne pleaſure hym would ſo vſe woulde worthie haue notwithſtanding onely pardoned motion made alſo thanked loue heartie fauour bare hym praying hys ſake gyue beare ſame prince vnder hée woulde bée content lyue hys labour counſell farre ſhould lyke king vſe would doe vttermoſt deuoyre ſet realme good ſtate whyche alreadie lyttle whyle hys protectorſhippe prayſe gyuen god well begunne malice ſuche occaſion contrarie new intended bée nowe partly good policie partly god ſpeciall prouidence man prouiſion repreſſed uppon aunſwere giuen duke protectours licence lyttle rowned aſwell wyth noble men aboute hym maior recorder london vppon lyke pardon deſired obteyned ſhewed aloude vnto protector finall concluſion realme appoynted king edwardes lyne ſhould longer raygne vpon hadde ſo farre gone nowe ſuertie retreate thoughte weale vniuerſall take waye althoughe yet begonne wherfore would lyke grace take crowne vppon hym woulde humbly beſéeche therevnto woulde giue reſolute aunſwere contrarie woulde lothe heare muſt néedes ſéeke ſhoulde fayle fynde ſome noble man would theſe wordes muche moued protectour elſe euerie man may wit woulde neuer likelyhood haue enclyned therevnto hée ſawe none waye eyther muſt take elſe hée hys goe ſayde vnto lordes common sith wée perceyue well realme ſo ſet whereof wée bée ſorie ſuffer wiſe king edwardes lyne gouerne whome man earthly gouerne agaynſt wylles wel alſo perceyue man whome crowne iuſt tytle appertayne ſelfe verie ryghte heyre lawfully begotten bodie moſt deare father richarde late duke yorke whiche tytle nowe ioyned election noble common thys realme wée tytles poſſible take moſt effectuall wée bée content agrée fauourably enclyne petition requeſt accordyng ſame herethe protector taketh vpon king wée take vppon v royall eſtate preeminence kingdome two noble realmes englande fraunce one daye forwarde v heyres rule gouerne defende god grace good helpe get agayne ſubdue eſtabliſhe euer due obedience vnto thys realme englande aduauncement wherof wée neuer aſke god longer liue intend procure great ſhoute cry king richarde king richarde lordes went vp king ſo tyme called people departed talking diuerſely matter euery man hys fantafie gaue much talked maruelled manner dealing matter partes made ſo ſtraunge thoughe neyther euer communed thereof ſelues wyſte manne ſo dull hearde hée perceyued well ynoughe matter made betwéene howbeit ſome excuſed agayne ſayd muſte doone good order menne muſt ſomtyme manner ſake aknowen knowe conſecration byſhop euerye man woteth well paying bulles hée purpoſeth one thoughe paye nothing elſe yet muſt twyce aſked whether byſhop muſte twice ſaye nay thyrde tyme take compelled therevnto owne ſtage play people know right well hée playeth sowdaine percaſe ſowter yet one ſhoulde know ſo little good ſhew ſeaſō acquaintance hée hath hym call hym owne name ſtandeth maieſtie one tormentor myghte hap breake head worthy marring play ſo ſayde theſe matter king game ſtage playes part played vpon ſcaffoldes poore men looker y• wiſe meddle ſomtime ſtep vp play poſſibilitie hanged er • dye sir iames tyrell dyed tower hil beheaded treaſon king richarde himſelf yée ſhal hereafter heare • laine fielde hacked hewed enimies hand caried horſſeback dead heare deſpight torne tagged like cur dog miſchiefe hee tooke within leſſe thrée yeres miſchief yet al mean time ſpent much paine trouble outward much feare anguiſhe ſorrow within haue hearde credible report ſuche ſecrete hys chamberlaine abhominable déede done neuer quiet minde neuer thought hymſelfe ſure went abroade hys eyen whirled hys bodie painely fen • ed hys hande euer vpon dag • er▪ hys countenaunce maner like one alwayes readie ſtrik • againe toke ill reſt nyghtes lay long waking muſing ſo • e wearied care watche rather ſlumbred ſlept troubled fearefull dreames ſodainely ſometime duke fell • diuerſe folke diuerſe wiſe pretended thys duke haue certaine ben enformed ſoone duke glocester vppon death king edwarde came yorke ſolemne funeral ſeruice king▪ edward ſent thyther moſt glocester aduertiſed hys deſire cauſed dead night▪ al folk auoyded brought vnto ſecrete chamber whe •• perſall▪ maiſters recōmendation ſhewed hym ſecretly ſent ſhew new world would take ſuch partas woulde way • e vpon hym wyth • thouſande good fellowes • néede meſſenger ſente backe thankes ſome ſe • r • ate inſtruction protector minde yet mette hym agayne farther frō maſter within dayes highlye conſpired againſte man would maruell whereof change grewe ſurely occaſion variance dyuers men diuerſly reported ha • e ſaid heard ſay yt duke little coronation among thinges required protector duke hertford • land pretended himſelfe iuſte inheritor foraſmuch title whiche claymed inheritance ſomewhat interlaced title crowne line king henry depriued protector conceyued ſuche indignation reiected duke requeſte many ſpitefull minatorie wordes ſo wounded hart hatred miſtruſte neuer toulde endure looke right king richard euer feared owne life ſo far forth▪ protector rode throughe london towarde coronation hée fayned himſelfe ſicke bycauſe woulde ride takyng euill parte ſente worde riſe come ride woulde make carryed wherevpon rode euill notwithſtanding morrow roſe feaſt fayning hymſelfe ſicke kyng richard ſaid done hatred deſpite ſaide euer continually • ch liued ſuch hatred diſtruſt ye duke v • tily loked haue bin murthered glocester natheleſſe faire manner departed ſurely ſome right ſecrete daye deny many right wiſe men thinke vnlikely déepe diſſembling nature thoſe men cō ſidered néede gréene worlde protector duke▪ perill duke ſtoode fel ſuſpition tyrant eyther protectour woulde giue duke occaſion diſpleaſure duke protectour occaſion miſtruſte verylye men thinke king richard anye ſuch opinion conceyued would neuer haue ſuffered eſcape hand uery troth duke high minded man euill could beare glorie ſo haue heard ſome ſay ſawe duke ſuch time crowne firſt ſet vpon protector head hys eye coulde abyde ſight thereof wryed heade another waye men ſaye troth wel eaſe king richarde well knowen ill taken demaunde duke vncurteouſly reiected greate giftes high beheſtes moſt louing truſtie manner departed glocester ſoone comming home brecknocke hauing ther cuſtodie commaundement king richarde doctor morton byſhoppe ely yée hearde taken counſel tower waxed familiar whoſe wiſedome abuſed pride owne deliueraunce duke deſtruction biſhop man gret natural witte wel learned honorable behauiour lacking wiſe wayes winne fauour bin faſt vpon part king henrie parte wealth naytheleſſe lefte forſooke woe fledde realme quéene prince whyle king▪ edwarde hadde king priſon neuer came home fielde whiche loſte parte vtterly ſubdued • faſt fayth wiſedome onelye contente receiue alſo woed come hadde thenceforth ſecreate truſt ſpeciall fauour whiche nothing deceiued ye haue hearde king edward death firſte taken tyrante hys truth king founde meane ſet duke toppe ioyned gentleman togither aide king henry deuiſing firſt marriage betwéene king edwardes daughter faith declared good ſeruice maſters infinit benefite realm ye coniunction thoſe two blouds one whoſe ſeueral title long enquieted land fled realme went rome neuer minding meddle wite worlde till noble prince king henry ſeauenth gate hym home agayne made hym archebyſhoppe canterbury chauncelor englande wherevnto pope ioined honor cardinal thus lyuing many dayes muche honor one man mighte well wiſhe ended ſo godly death god mercie well changed life man therefore aboute tell long often alternate proofe well proſperitie aduers fortune hadde gotten greate experience verye mother miſtreſſe wiſedome déepe inſighte pollitique worldly driftes whereby perceyuing nowe thys duke glad commune fed faire wordes many pleaſaunt prayſes perceyuing proceſſe communication duke pride balke oute little bredde enuie towarde glorye king thereby féeling eaſie fall oute matter well handled craftely ſought wayes pricke forwarde taking alwayes occaſion hys commyng ſo kéeping himſelfe ſo cloſe within bound rather ſéemed follow leade duke firſte beganne praiſe boaſt king ſhewe howe muche profite realme ſhoulde take raigne lorde morton anſwered surely lord • ollie lye would ſweare contrarie lordſhip would wéene beléeue y• world would haue gone wold haue wiſhed k henry ſon crown king ed god hadde ordered looſe king edwarde raigne neuer ſo madde woulde deade manne ſtriue againſt quicke king edward faithfull chaplaine glad woulde haue bin chylde hadde ſuccéeded howbeit ſecrete iudgemente god haue otherwiſe prouided purpoſe ſpurre againſt pricke laboure ſette vppe god pulleth downe late protector king euen left ſaying y• already meddled muche wyth world would day meddle hys booke beades longed ſore heare woulde haue ſayde bycauſe ended king ſo ſodainely ſtopped exhorted ſo familiarly betwéene twayne bolde ſay whatſoeuer thoughte whereof faythfullye promiſed ſhoulde neuer come hurte peraduenture good woulde wéene himſelfe intended vſe faithfull ſecrete aduiſe counſell whiche hée ſayde cauſe procured king haue hym cuſtodie might recken himſelf home elſe bin putte handes whome hée ſhoulde haue founde like fauour biſhoppe righte humblye thanked hym ſayde good faith lord loue talke much prince thing perill thoughe worde wythout faulte muche ſhall taken partie meane pleaſeth prince conſ • rue euer thinke eſops tale lion hadde proclaymed payne death ſhould none horned beaſt abide wood one forhead bunch fleſh • led away great pace foxe ſaw run ſo faſt aſked whether made haſte hée aunſwered fayth neuer wote recke ſo wer hence bicauſe thys proclamation made horned beaſts foole quoth foxe thou mayſt abyde wel ynough lion meant thée none horne thine heade marry quoth hée wote wel ynough call horne duke laughed merily tale ſaid l warrāt neyther liō bore ſhall pike matter thing ſpoken ſhal neuer come eares good faith sir ſayde biſhop thing ſay taken well afore god meant coulde deſerue thankes yet taken wéene woulde might happen turne little good leſſer longed duke yet muche witte wherevpon biſhoppe ſaide good faith lord late protector ſith king poſſeſſion purpoſe diſpute title weale realme whereof grace hath gouernaunce wherof ſelfe one poore member wiſhe thoſe good ability whereof hath alredy righte many little néeding prayſe might yet haue pleaſed god better ſtore haue giuen ſome ſuch excellente vertues méete rule realme lord hath planted perſon grace left againe duke ſomewhat maruayling hys ſodaynethis follovveth abridged edvvard hall pauſes ſaide lorde note often breathing ſodayne ſtoppyng communication ſo intelligence wordes neyther come anye perfecte ſentence whereby eyther mighte haue knowledge entente nowe towarde king affection beare towarde compariſon good quality aſcribed v maketh little muſe thinking y• haue ſome priuie imagination imprinted hearte abaſhed diſcloſe eſpecially honor aſſure ſecrete caſe deafe dome byſhop ſomewhat bolder conſidering duke promiſe moſte animated bycauſe knewe duke deſirous magnified alſo perceyued inwarde hatred whiche bare towarde king richard hée opened hys ſtomake botome ſaide ſingular good lorde ſith tyme capti • itie whyche béeyng grace cuſtody maye rather call libertie ſtraight impriſonment au • yding ydleneſſe mother vyces reading bookes auncient pamphlet haue founde ſentence written▪ manne borne frée libertie himſelfe onely one part duty oweth parent parte friend kinſfolkes natiue countrey firſte taſted pleaſaunte flattering worlde demaundeth debte forgotten whyche ſaying cauſeth conſider caſe realme natiue countrey nowe ſtandeth eſtate aſſuraunce time hathe cōtinued gouernor haue ruler might haue plainely perceiue realme caſe muſt néeds decay brought confuſiō one hope haue whē conſider youre noble perſonage iuſtice indifferencie feruent zeale ardent loue toward naturall country like maner loue countrey toward great learning pregnant witte eloquence ſo much doth abounde perſon muſte néedes thinke realme fortunate whyche hathe ſuch prince ſtore méete apt gouernor ſide call memorie good quality late protector nowe called king ſo violated tyranny ſo altred vſurped authoritie ſo clouded blinde ambition muſte néedes ſay neither méete king ſo noble realme ſo famous realme méete gouerned ſuch tyrant firſt enterprice obtaine crowne begunne murther dyuers noble perſonages ſecondarily procéed againſte owne naturall mother declaring hir openlye woman giuen carnall affection diſſoulute lyuing declaring furthermore hys two brother two nephewes baſtardes borne aduo • trey yet contented obtayned garlande hée cauſed two pore innocent nephewes committed ſhamefully murthered bloude whiche little babe dayly cry god earth vengeaunce ſure tie ſhall realme perſon eyther life goodes vnder ſuche cruell prince whych regardeth deſtruction owne bloud leſſe loſſe nowe conclude what▪ meane toward noble perſon ſay affirme loue god linage natiue coūtry muſt ſelf take vpon y• crown realme ye maintenāce honour ſame alſo deliueraunce natural countreymē bondage ſuch tyrante ſelf wil refuſe take vpon ye crown realme thē adiure faith y• owe god deuiſe ſome way realme may brought ſome conuenient regiment vnder ſome good gouernour whē b▪ ended ſaying ſighed ſpake gret ſo y• night cōmoned 〈…〉 ore next daye duke ſent b vnto ſayd l ely▪ muſt néedes hart thinke mouth confeſſe ſure friende truſtie counſaylour verye louer countrey ſith laſt communicatiō haue diſcloſed ſecrets hart touching ye new vſurper crowne alſo haue little touched •• auncement two noble family yorke lancaster ſhal likewiſe declare vnto priuie entents ſecrete cogitation beginne king edwarde▪ deceaſed beganne ſtudye deliberation ponder maner realme ſhoulde gouerned perſwaded wyth ſelfe take part wyth duke glocester thought cleane without diſſimulation tractable without iniurie ſo mean made protector king realm whiche auathoritie gotten neuer ceaſed printly require lord wel ſpirituall temporall might take vppon hym crowne till prince came age xxiiij yeares able gouerne realme ſufficient king thing ſaw ſomewhat ſticke brought inſtrumēts autentike doctor proctor notary law depoſitions diuers witneſſes teſtifying king edwardes child baſtards whiche depoſitions thought true nowe knowe fayned ſayde depoſitions v read diligentlye hearde hée ſtoode vppe bare headed ſaying well lordes euen would nephewes ſhould haue wrong ſo praye nothing right theſe witneſſes ſayings famous doctours true onelye vndubitate heyre richarde plantagenet duke yorke adiudged verye heire crowne realme aucthoritie parliament whyche thynges ſo learned men veritie v declared cauſed take lawful vndoubted prince soueraigne lorde ſo agayne aide protector made king crowned king full poſſeſſion realme caſte awaye olde condition ſelfe ſued parte earle hereford landes brother kyng edward wrongfully detained alſo requyred haue office highe coneſtableſhip englande diuers noble aunceſtours time haue hadde long deſcent continued firſte ſute hée firſt delay afterward deny gaue ſuche vnkind wordes though neuer furthered al ſuffred paciētly whē informed death two yong innocentes lord heart inwardly grudged ſo much abhorred ye ſight toke leaue court returned brecknocke iourney returned diuerſe imaginatiōs depriue vnnatural vncle frſt ſanti • ed y• liſt take vpon crowne way made playne occaſion giuen ſawe dyſdayned lord temporall accurſed lordes ſpiritual diuerſe cogitation matter rode betwéene worcester bridgenorth▪ encountred lady margaret counteſſe richmonde wife ye lord stanley daughter ſole heire iohn duke somerſet grandfather elder brother ſo ſhe hir ſonne garle richmond betwéene gate enter maieſtie royall getting crowne little comoned concernyng ſonne departed beganne diſpute wt ſelfe whether beſt take vpon election nobilitie communaltie take power thus ſtanding ye wauering ambiguitie conſidered firſt y• offi • e dutie pain king ſurely think mortall men iuſtlye truely obſerue excepte hée • ée elected god king dauid remembred toke gouernaunce realme daughter king edwarde theyr ally bothe hys ſake muche helpned alſo greate iniurye done muche pytied woulde neuer ceaſe barke one ſyde mée sen • b • abye cooſin earle richemonde hys aydes kinſfolke wyll ſurelye attempte eyther • yte pierſe mée ſyde ſo life rule ſhoulde euer hang vnquiet • pubte deathe depoſition ſayde two ly • age yorke lancaster ſhoulde ioyne one againſte mée ſurelye matched wherefore haue cléerelye determyned vtterlye relinquiſhe imagination concerning obtayning crowne told counteſſe richmond returne newe named king méeting high waye prayed firſt kinred ſake ſecondly loue bare grandfather duke humfrey whiche ſworne brother hir father moue king good hir ſon hencie earle richmonde licenſe fauour returne againe england pleaſure ſo doe ſhe promiſed earle hir ſonne ſhoulde marrie one king edward daughter appointment king without anye thing demaunded ſayde eſpouſalles king fauoure whiche requeſt ſ •• ne ouer paſſed departed ſeruice called memorie matter bente earle richmonde heire houſe lancaster ſhal take wife lady elizabeth eldeſt daughter k edwarde marriage houſes yorke lancaster maye vnite one duke ſayde biſhop morton whiche fauoured euer houſe lancaster •• wonde • ous ioyfull imagination tended effecte leaſt duke courage ſhoulde ſwage • minde alter ſayde duke lord buckingham ſithe god • prouiſion incōparable wiſedome thys noble coniunction firſt moued neceſſarie conſider perſons ſhall firſte make pri •• e polliticke concluſion troth quoth duke beginne wyth ladye richmonde earles mother whyche knoweth brytaine ſith begin waye ſayde byſhoppe haue olde friende wyth counteſſe called reignalde bray ſhall ſend iyoc •• pleaſure▪ ſo byſhoppe wrode come brecke ••• ke ſtreight came backe meſſenger▪ dirke biſhoppe declared hadde deuiſed prefermente earle richmonde ſonne hys▪ ladye land maiſtreſſe willyng hyr firſte compaſſe howe obtayne good wyll quéene elizabeth alſo hir eldeſt daughter ſecretly ſend hir ſonne britaine declare highe honour prepared would ſweare marrye lady elizabeth ſoone king realme reynold bray glad heart returned counteſſe ladie bray gone byſhoppe tolde duke iſle elie could make many friendes enterpriſe duke knewe true yet lothe loſe companie ſuch counſeller gaue byſhoppe fayre wordes ſaying ſhoulde ſhortly departe well accompanied feare enemy biſhop duke company aſſembled ſecretly diſguiſed night departed came elie founde money friendes ſo ſayled flaunders earle richmond good ſeruice reynold bray declared meſſage counteſſe maruaile ſhe glad wherefore ſhe deuiſed meanes hold breake matter quéene elazabeth sanctuarie westminster hauing hir family certayne wel • hman called lewes learned phiſicke nowe hauing opportunitie breake hir minde vnto declared time come hir ſonne ſhould bée ioyned marriage ladye elizabeth daughter heyre king edward king richard ſhoulde honour eſtate detected required goe quéene elizabeth meſſenger one▪ came friendly viſite hir tyme place ſhould ſerue make hir priuie deuiſe phiſition good diligence repayred quéene ſaw tyme conuenient ſaid vnto hir madame although imagination verye ſimple yet entire affection beare child ſo bolde vtter vnto ſecrete conceit haue compaſſed brayne remember great loſſe haue ſuſtayned death louing huſband great ſorow haue ſuffered cruell murther innocent chyldren leſſe doe daylye ſtudie howe bring heart comforte alſo reuenge quarrell child cruell tyraunt king richard firſt conſider battayle miſchiefe hath riſen diſ • ention betwéene two houſes yorke lancaster two family may ioyned one doubt y• line ſhall againe reſtored great ioye comforte knowe madame houſe lancaster earle richmond nexte bloud houſe yorke daughter nowe heyres ye coulde inuent meane howe couple eldeſt daughter earle richemond matrimonie doubt vſurper ſhould bée ſhortly depoſed heire agayne hir ryght reſtored quéene heard thys friendly motion ſhée inſtantly beſought hym béene firſt inuenter ſo good enterpriſe would deſiſt folow ſame requrring would reſorte counteſie richemond mother earle henrie declare hir quéenee behalfe friendes king edwarde▪ hir huſband ſhould aſſiſt take part erle richemond hir ſonne ſo woulde take othe kingdome obteyned eſpouſe lady elizabeth hir daughter c lewes ſo ſpedde buſineſſe made final • en • buſyneſſe betwéene two mother ſo ladye margaret counteſſe richemond brought good hope preferment hir ſonne made reynold bray chiefe ſolicitor conſpiraoie geuyng hym charge ſecretely inuegle ſuche perſons nobilitie ioyne wyth hir take hir parte knewe faythfull reynold bray within fewe dayes broughte lure ſir gyles daubeney ſir iohn ch • nie richard guilford thomas rame eſquiers others meane ſeaſon counteſſe richemond ſeat chriſtopher vrfwike britaine erle richmond declare agréementes betwéene hir quéene agréed ſhe rementbring duke buckingham one firſt inuentors enterpriſe ſent hugh conway eſquier britaine great ſum money hir ſonne giuyng charge declare earle great loue ye moſt part nobilitie realme bare toward wylling neglect ſo good occaſion offered ſpéede fettle minde returne englande giuing counſell take land wale ye earle receyued ioyfull meſſage brake duke britayne ſecretes aduertiſing hym entered ſure ſtedfaſt hope obtayne crowne england deſiring hym helpe towarde atchieuing enterpriſe duke promiſed performed whervpon earle ſent england hugh conway thomas ram declare comming ſhortly england meane ſeaſon chiefe conſpiracie england beganne many enterpriſes beyng neuer ſo priuely handled yet knowledge thereof came kyng richard becauſe knewe duke buckingham bée chiefe heade ayde commination thought moſt neceſſarie plucke hym parte vppon adreſſed louing letter duke exhorte duke come courte duke required kyng pardon hym excuſing himſelfe well king richard content wyth excuſe directed duke letter wyth checkyng wordes commaunding hym wythout delaye repayre hys preſence duke made meſſenger determinate aunſwere woulde come mortall enemye immediatelye prepared warre agaynſte hym meanes thomas marque dorſet came sancturie gathered great bande men yorke ſhire ſyr edwarde courtney peter brother byſhoppe excester rayſed armie deuonſhire cornewall kent • ir richard calfortle gentleman rayſes comparrie king richarde meane tyme gotten together great ſtrength remoued london towarde saliſburie entent myght ſet duke army king ſtarce two dayes tourney saliſburie▪ duke buckingham accompanyed great powre wilde welchmen ende forſooke duke powre marched foreſt dene intending haue paſſed ryuer seuerne glocester haue ioyned armie courtneys weſterne men done doubte king richard béene great ieoperdie could attayne seuerne ſyde force continuall raine riuer roſe ſo high ouerflowed countrey adioyning rage water laſted x dayes inundacie paſſages ſo cloſed neyther ye duke could come ouer seuerne complices hym • wing time welchmen lyngering ydle wythout money victuall ſodainly ſcaled departed duke thus left almoſt alone neceſſitie compelled flie conueyed himſelfe houſe humfrey baniſter ſeruaht beſide shreweſburie tenderly brought vp whē knowne adherent euery man ſhifted himſelfe fled ſome ſayled britaine among peter courtney byſhop excester ſir edward courtney brother thomas marque dorſet iohn lord welles ſir iohn bourchier ſir edmond woodvile brother quéene elizabeth ſir robert willoughbie ſir gyles daubney ſir thomas arundale ſir iohn cheynie two brothren ſir william barkerley ſir william brandō thomas brother ſir richard edgecombe iohn halwell edwarde pownyngs c proclamation made thouſande pound promiſed ſo coulde bring duke buckingham vpon humfrey baniſter bewrayed gueſt andhumfrey baniſter betrayeth maiſter maiſter iohn mitton sherife shropſhire whiche ſtronge powre apprehended duke little groue adioyning manor humfrey baniſter great haſte conueyed citie saliſburie king richard kept houſholde baniſter afterbaniſter trayed maiſter miſerably plagued let like traitor looke like vvorſe vvithout ſpeedie repentance betrayed maiſter ſonne heire waxed mad dyed bore ſtye eldeſt daughter ſodainely ſtriken foule leperie ſeconde ſonne maruellouſly deformed lymmes made lame yonger ſonne ſmall puddle drowned himſelfe extreme age arraygned found guiltie murther clergie ſaued thouſande pounde▪ king richarde gaue one farthing ſaying woulde vntrue ſo good maiſter would falſe duke confeſſed whole conſpiracieduke buckingham beheaded vpon ſecond nouember without araignement iudgement saliſburie beheaded whileſt theſe thing thus handled england henrie earle richmond prepared armie fiue thouſand briton fortie wel furniſhed ſhippes al thyngs prepared day ſetting forward appoynted xij october whole armie hoyſed vp ſayles tooke ſea toward night wind turned ſo huge tempeſt aroſe ſhips diſperſed ſunder ſome driuen normandie ſome againe britaine morning tempeſt aſſwaged earle approched south parte england mouth hauen pole dorcet might ſée bankes full men warre appoynted defend arriuall wherfore gaue charge man ſhoulde lande vntil ſuch tyme whole nauie aſſembled perceyued none ſhips appeare hoyſed vp ankers away arriued ſafe normandie returned lande britaine ſoone aduertiſed duke buckingham loſte hys head marque dorcet great number noble men england little enquired hym meane ſeaſon king richarde apprehended diuers partes realme certaine gentleman ye earle richmondes faction amongſt ſir george browne ſir roger clifford iiij put death london y• iij december sir thomas sentlegar marryed duches excester king owne ſiſter rame diuers executed excester xxx december great fire leaden hall infire leaden hall london london brent much houſing ſtocks gunnes like prouiſion belonging ye citie king richard called parliament y• which1484 attainted earle richemond perſons • led realme feare cauſe enemyes natural countrie landes good confiſcate king vſe yet notwithſtanding laid people great taxe troubleſome ſeaſon nothing maruelledanno reg 2 lorde stanley bene taken conſidering working lady margaret wyfe mother▪ earle richemond muche enterpryſe woman hym reputed regarde eſtimation lorde stanley hir huſband purged hym ſelfe innocent attemptes hir committed giuen charge kéepe hir ſome ſecrete place home without hauing ſeruaunt company ſo thence forth ſhée ſhoulde neuer ſend letter hir ſonne friendes kyng myghte bée moleſted commaundement whyle put execution yéere king richard began high towre westminster remaineth yet vnfiniſhed alſo cauſed thek henry ſixt remoued vvindſo • body king henry ſixte remoued cherteſey abbey surrey buried windſor nowe reſteth xij auguſt richard cheſter thomas britaine 28 september sherifes ralph auſtry 6 februarie tho hill grocer 28 october w stocker draper maiors 24 sep anno 1485 iohn ward grocer 29 sep william collingborne made ryme iij kingcolingborne executed richards coūſellers lord louell ſir richard ratclife ſir william catesby ratte catte louell dogge rule england vnder hogge drawne frō westmin towre london y• hyll hanged headed quartered king richard conſidering y• • ities concluded betwéene prince cauſe realmes fortified double power ſay owne ſtrength ayde friendes practiſed league king scot long made diuers incurſions roades realme englande therefore ſued haue truce peace concluded wherfore commiſſioners appointed met notingham end concluded iij yéeres certaine article xv numbertruce vvith scotland three yeeres peace thus concluded king richard nowe doubtyng owne people continually vexed feare returne earle richmond complices wherfore nothing purpoſe agayne price prayer attempt duke britaine whoſe territorie y• erle abode deliuer hand wherfore incontinent ſent certaine ambaſſadors duke britaine tooke vpon king richard ſhoulde yéerely pay aunſwere duke britaine al reuenewes rente profites landes poſſeſſions well belonging earle richmond noble gentlemā erles companie time would kéepe continuall priſon reſtrayne libertie orator furniſhed theſe inſtructions ariued britaine could ſpeake wt duke reaſon y• weakned long dayly infirmitie began waxe ydle remembraunce whiche cauſe peter landoyſe chiefe treaſurer ruled thing pleaſure vnto engliſh ambaſſadors moued meſſage offering ſame rewardes land ſhould haue offered duke peter faythfully promiſed accompliſhe king richardes requeſt ſo kept promiſe wyth fortune ſo fauourable publike weale england deadly compact tooke none effect iohn morton byſhop elie ſoiourning flaunders al craftie deuiſe certified wherfore ſent chriſtopher vrſwike declare earle richemond deceyt giuing charge haſt poſſible company retire britaine fraunce theſe newes came earle incontinent ſent charles french king requiring myght ſafely paſſe fraunce deſire graunted earle reſt diſpatched priuily mought fraunce man ſuſſpecting departure erle tooke iourney charles frenche king whō great thanks giuen diſcloſed occaſion acceſſe perſon required helpe ſuccour intent myghte returne nobilitie realme whō generally called take vpō crowne king charles promyſed ayde bad hym good comforte aſſured woulde gladly ſhewe to1485 bountifull liberalitie while earle richemond thus attended frenche court iohn vere earle oxforde ſo perſwaded iames blonte captaine hame caſtle ſir iohn forteskewe porter towne calleis ſelfe ſet libertie alſo leauing fruitfull office condeſcended goe fraunce earle richemond meane ſeaſon king richard credibly aduertiſed promiſes othes earle confederate made ſworne erles meanes engliſh men paſſed britaine fraunce wherefore manner deſperate imagining howe infringe earles purpoſe meane ſo mariage lady elizabeth niece ſhould pretend clayme crowne came minde thing onely deteſtable much cruell put execution cléerelye determined reconcile fauour brother wife quéene elizabeth ſo meanes earle richemond affinitie nice ſhoulde bée vtterly defrauded ingenious remedie coulde bée otherwyſe inuented ſhoulde happen quéene anne hys wyfe departe worlde himſelfe woulde rather take wyfe hys coſin nice ladye elizabeth lacke affinitie whole realme ſhoulde runne ruyne wherefore hée ſent quéene sanctuarie diuers often meſſengers whiche ſhoulde excuſe hym thing agaynſt hir attempted ſhoulde ſo largelye promyſe promotion onely hir hir ſonne thomas marque dorſet ſhoulde bryng hir poſſible ſome wan hope meſſengers ſo perſwaded quéene ſhée beganne ſomewhat • ent ſo muche ſhée faythfully promyſed yéelde hir ſelfe kyngs wyll pleaſure ſo ſhée firſt delyuered vnto kyng richardes handes hir fyue daughter afterwarde ſhée ſent letter marque hir ſonne beyng paris wyth earle richemond wylling hym wyſe repayre englande prouided great honour aſſertayning hym offence party forgiuen forgotten king richarde hadde thus pleaſed mutable mynde quéene elizabeth cauſed hir daughter bée conueyed palace ſolempne receyuing nowe nothing contrarie purpoſe • ut manſion voyde wyfe firſt 〈…〉 abſtayned bedde companye hys wyfe complayned many infortunate barrenneſſe wife procured common rumor publiſhed among common people quéene dead quéen heard tell ſo horrible rumor hir death ſprong amongſt communaltie ſhe ſore ſuſpected world almoſt ende hir long howſoeuer fortuned quéene departed life due ſolemnitie buryed westminster king thus loſed bond matrimony began caſt fancie lady elizabeth hys néece making much ſuite haue hir ioyned lawfull matrimonie bycauſe men mayden hir ſelfe moſt deteſted thys vnlawfull copulation hée determined deferre matter till quiet caſe thys ſeaſon oppreſſed weighty affayres euery ſyde conſidering dayly parte nobilitie ſayled france priuily fauoured earle richmond amongſt noble men whome hée moſt ſuſpected theſe principall thomas▪ lorde stanley sir wyllyam stanley hys brother gilbert talbot ſixe hundred whoſe purpoſe though king richard ignorant yet gaue credence one leaſt lord stanley bycauſe ioyned matrimonie wyth lady margaret mother earle richmond ſayde▪ lorde stanley would haue departed hys countrey king wyſe woulde ſuffer hym departe lefte hoſtageanno reg 3 courte george stanley lord strange firſt begotten ſonne heire whyle kyng richarde thus troubled ſodeynely hée hearde newes caſtell hame delyuered handes earle richmonde meanes earle oxford onely alſo iames blunt captayne caſtell fledde france ayde earle richmond henry earle richmond obteyning king charles ſmall crue men borowing certayne ſummes money hym dyuers hys priuate friendes hée departed french court came citie roane whyle taryed making prouiſion harefleete mouth riuer seyne thing neceſſarye hys nauye tydings broughte hym kyng richarde béeyng wythout child widdower intended ſhortly marrye wyth lady elizabeth hys brother daughter whyche newes hée tooke ſmall momente thys thyng onely tooke away hys companyous theyr hope obteyne happye enterpriſe reaſon whereof hée iudged hys friendes englande woulde ſhrinke yet notwithſtanding earle henry richmonde bycauſe woulde longer linger wéerie hys friendes lyuing betwéene hope feare determined haſt conuenient ſette forwarde caryed hys shippes armour weapon vitiayle ordinance expedient warre béeyng done onely accompanyed wyth two thouſande men ſmall number shyppes weyed vp hys anckers kalendes auguſt hée ſayled harefleete wyth ſo proſperous wynde ſeauenth day afterhenry earle richmond landed milford hauen hée arriued wale euening port called milford hauen incontinente tooke lande came place called dale sunne riſing remoued hereford weſt receyued people wyth great ioy thence remoued cardigan fiue mile hereford weſt whether came earle richard griffith men power ſame day came iohn morgan wyth hys men earle aduanced forwarde making abode anye place ſodeynly hée aſcertayned sir walter harbert rice appe thomas harneſſe hym readye encounter wyth hys armye ſtoppe theyr paſſage wherefore firſt determined ſet vpon eyther deſtroye take fauour hys power gyue battayle king richarde intent friendes ſhoulde knowe de • teritie attempted enterpriſe forwarde ſent meſſengers letter inſtructions ladye margaret mother lorde stanley brother talbot declaring holpe ayde friendes intended paſſe ouer riuer seuerne shrewſburie ſo paſſe directly citie london requiring ſpeciall truſt hope fidelitie woulde méete waye diligent preparation theſe meſſengers departed marched forward towardes shrewſburie paſſage mette ſaluted rice ap thomas goodly band welchmen ſubmitted himſelfe whole order commaundement meane tyme meſſengers laden rewardes returned ſame daye entred shrewſburie made relation friendes readie poyntes doe thing myghte doe earle henrie continued iourney came little towne called newporte pitched campe little hyll adioyning repoſing himſelfe nyghte euenyng ſame day came ſir george talbot whole power young earle shrewſburie beyng warde accounted ij thouſand men thus power increaſing arriued towne stafforde pauſed whome came ſir william stanley accompanyed fewe perſons earle departed thence lytchfield lay without walles campe night next morning entred towne lyke prince receiued day two lorde stanley hauing band almoſt fiue thouſand men lodged ſame towne hearing ye earle richemond marching thetherward gaue hym place diſlodging repaired towne called adrestone abiding comming ye earle auoyde ſuſpition afraide leaſt ſhould ſéene openly fawtor ayder earle ſonne law day batiayle king richard yet vtterly put miſtruſt woulde put ſome cruel death ſonne heire apparāt george lord strange king richard hoſtage king richard ſeaſon kéeping houſe caſtle notingham informed earle richmond ſuch baniſhed men fled england arryued wale thing neceſſarie enterpriſe vnpurueyed weake nothing méete withſtande power ſuche king hadde appointed reſiſt yet notwithſtandyng ſent iohn duke norfolke henrie earle northumberlande thomas earle surrey hys truſtie friendes willyng muſter viewe theyr ſeruauntes tenaunts electe moſte couragious actiue perſons whole number repaire preſence al ſpéede alſo wrote robert brakenburie lieutenaunt ye tower commaundyng power come armie bring fellow armes bouchier ſir walter hungerford diuers knight eſquiers caſt ſmall ſuſpition thus ordring affayres tidings came earle richmond paſſed seuerne come shrewſburie detriment encombraunce meſſage ſore mooued cryed contrarie othe deceyued haſte ſent viewe way enemyes kepte paſſed declared king earle encamped ye towne litchfield wherof whē perfect knowledge hauing cōtinuall repayre ſubiects incōtinently made battayles ſet forwarde toward ye way enimies reported intended paſſe kéeping array great pomp entred y• towne leycester sunne ſet earle richmond reyſed campe lichfield tomworth midde way paſſing ſaluted sir walter hungerford sir thomas bourchier knightes diuers others ſubmitted themſelues pleaſure diuers noble perſonages likewiſe reſorted withall power hapned progreſſion earle richmond ſtrange chance little afrayd bycauſe could aſſured father law thomas lord stanley whiche yet enclyned neyther partie wherfore earle accompanyed twenty light horſemen lingring iourney behind hoſt meane whole armie came towne tomworth▪ darkeneſſe coulde perceyue ſteppes paſſed wandred hyther thither ſéeking companye abode little uillage thrée mile armie tarried night next morning dawning returned good fortune came armie excuſing himſelfe haue gone way ignorance purpoſe excuſe made priuily departed agayne downe aderstone lorde stanley sir william brother band abiding earle came father law little cloſe ſaluted sir william brother conſulted giue battayle king richard would abide whome knew farre huge armie euening ſame day▪ sir iohn sauage sir brian san • ord sir▪ simon digby many leauing king richarde turned came earle richmond elect companye men meane ſeaſon king richard marched place méete two battayles encounterbattayle boſvvorth uillage called boſworth farre leyceſter pitched field refreſhed armie tooke reſt next day king richard furniſhed men abiliments warre bringing men camp ye playne ordered forewarde maruellous length appoynted horſemen footemen forefront placed archer ouer battayle captayne iohn duke norffolke whome thomas earle surrey hys ſonne long vauntgard followed king richarde ſtrong company approued men warre hauyng horſemen wing ſides battayle earle richmond returned communication wyth hys friendes hée wyth diligence pitched hys fielde iuſt campe hys enimies lodged nighte morning betime▪ cauſed hys men put theyr armour apparrell themſelues fight gyue battayle ſente lorde stanley requiring hym wyth hys men approche néere hys armye helpe ſet souldyers array anſwered earle ſhoulde ſette hys owne men good order whyle hée woulde come hym tyme conueniente earle made hys forewarde ſomewhat ſingle ſlender according ſmall number hys people front hée placed archer whome hée made captayne iohn earle oxforde right wing battayle appoynted sir gilbert talbot leader lefte wing aſſigned sir iohn sauedge hée wyth ayde lord stanley accompanyed wyth earle pembrooke hauyng good companye horſſemen ſmall number footemenne hys whole number excéeded fyue thouſande menne beſyde power stanley whereof thrée thouſand fielde vnder sir william stanley kyngs number double ſo much theſe armyes thus ordred men ready ſet forwarde king richard called hys chiefetaynes togyther perſwadyng valiaunt c people vnfaythfull ende hys nephewes vntrue vnnaturall begynnyng earle richmond knewe king ſo néere embattayled rode aboute hys armie giuyng comfortable wordes men whiche made pithie oration perſwadyng haue victorie fyght iuſt quarrell ſcantlye finiſhed hys ſaying one armye eſpyed betwéene bothe armyes great marriſhe earle lefte hys ryght hande ſo doyng hadde sunne hys backe face hys enemyes king ſawe earles companye paſſed marriſhe commaunded wyth haſte ſet vpon terrible ſhotte ſides paſſed armyes ioyned came hande ſtrokes whiche incounter lorde stanley ioyned earle earle oxforde meane ſeaſon fearing leaſt company fighting ſhould compaſſed enemy gaue commaundement man ſhould go aboue x foote frō standard commaundement knowne kni • themſelues together ceaſed litle frō fighting enemy ſodainely abaſhed matter miſtruſting ſome fraude began alſo pauſe earle oxford bringing band together one part ſet enemy freſhly againe aduerſaryes perceyuing placed men ſlender thinne thicke broade behynde begynnyng agayne battayle whyle two fore wardes thus mortally foughte kyng richarde admoniſhed earle richmond accompanyed wyth ſmall number men armes farre approched hym perfectly knewe hys perſonage béeyng inflamed yre put hys ſpurres hys horſe rode ſide range battayle leauyng vauntgardes fighting wyth • earein wreſt ranne towarde earle perceyued well king furiou • lye comming towarde bycauſe whole hope wealth purpoſe bée determined battayle • e gladlye pr • fere • •• encounter body body man man king richarde ſet ſo ſharply firſt brunt ouerthrew earles ſtandard ſlew ſir william brandon ſtā derdbearer▪ matched hand hande ſir iohn cheny man great force ſtrength▪ would haue •• ſ • ed ſaide iohn man fully ouerthrowne ſo making open paſſage dint ſworde went forwarde earle richmonde withſtoode hys violence kept ſwords point longer companion thought almoſt diſpaire victorie ſodainelye recomforted ſir william stanley whiche came ſuccour 3000 tall men inſtaunt king richards men driuen backe fled himſelfe manfully fighting middle enimies flaine meane ſeaſon earle oxforde ayde lorde stanley long fight diſcō • ited fore ward king richarde wherof greate number ſlaine chaſe greateſt number yt came fielde neuer gaue ſtroke battaile died fewe aboue number perſons nobilitie flaine iohn duke norffolke walter lord▪ ferrers chartley ſir richarde ratclife robert brakenburie liuetenāt tower many gentleman moe ſir william catesby learned lawes realme one thiefe counſellours late king diuerſe two dayes beheaded leicester amongſt ranne awaye were▪ syr frauncis vicount louel humfry stafforde thomas stafford brother toke sanctuarie saint iohns glocester erle richmond part wer ſlayn ſcarce 100 perſons amongſt whō principal ſir william brandon ſtandardbearer battel fought boſworth lecesterſhire 22 auguſt yeare lord 1485 whole conflict •• udured little aboue two hour earle thus obtained victorie rendered thankes god ſouldiours ••• litie people cryed king henry king henry lord stanley ſa •• good people tooke crowne kyng richarde whiche founde amongeſt ſpoile fielde ſette earles head thoughe hée béene elected kyng voyce people whole campe remoued towne leicester reſted two dayes meane ſeaſon dead corp king richarde ſhamefully carryed towne leicester gorgeouſlye daye pompe departed ſame towne body • naked ſkinne ſo muche one clowte aboute hym truſſed behinde purſiuant armes like hogge calfe head armes hanging one ſide horſſe leg ſide ſprinckled myre bloud brought gray frier church within town homely buried raigned two temperaunce grauitie notwithſtandyng manye greate occaſions trouble warre kept realme right good order greately reuerenced forraine prince forenamed xxij auguſt greate fyreparſon saint mildreds bren • bredſtreete london whiche fire brente parſon saint mildreds one man parſonage king henry departure leicester ſente ſir robert willoughbey knight manour sherenton yorke edwarde plantagenet earle parſon whome named yeoman guarde ſeauenth nouember beganne parliamente westmi • ster eſtabliſhing thing whiche cauſed proclaimed al men pardoned al offence ſhoulde reſtored landes good would ſubmit themſelues clemency began remember eſpecial friendes ſome aduannced honor dignitie ſome enriched poſſeſſions good beginne lord chandew brytaine made earle bath ſir gyles dawbeney made lord dawbeny ſir robert willoughby lorde broke edward stafford eldeſt ſonne henrie late buckingham reſtored dignitie poſſeſſions parliament diſſolued king redéemed marque dorſet ſir iohn bourcher left pledge paris mony borrowed ſent alſo flaunders iohn morton byſhop ely eightéenth daye ianuarie king henrie married lady elizabeth eldeſt daughter edward fourth whiche meanes two family yorke lancaster long bene great diuiſion vnited made one king henrie ſente lorde treaſurer maiſter bray vnto lorde maior london requiring1486 loane king hym citizen preſte 6000 markes wherefore maior hys brother common graunted preſt two thouſand pound leuied cō panies ward preſt repayred againe yeare next followinganno reg 2 wheate ſold iij ſhillings buſhell bay ſalt like price moneth september quéene elizabeth deliuered hir firſt ſon named arthur winchester iohn perciuall hugh clopton 28 septemb sir henry collet mercer 28 octob beautifull croſſe cheape newe builded towarde building whereof thomas fiſher mercer gaue 600 markes sir richarde simon wily prieſt came geralde erle kildare deputie irelande preſented hym lad scholler named lambert fained ye ſonne george duke clarence lately eſcaped tower london childe hadde learned prieſte ſuch princely behauiour lightly moued earle manye noble irelande tendering bloude royall rycharde plantagenet george ſonne alſo maligning aduancement houſe lancaster henry ſeauenth eyther thinke make world wéene thought verily childe edward earle warwicke duke clarence lawfull ſonne althoughe king henrie thā halfe marred ſport ſhewing right earle thorowe ſtreates london yet lady margaret dutch burgoigne ſiſter edwarde fourth iohn de la poole hir nephewe lorde louell ſir thomas broughton knight capitaines thys conſpiracy deuiſed abuſe colour yong earles name preferring purpoſe came good agréed depoſe lambert erecte verye erle déede nowe priſoner tower whoſe quarrell pretended fight déemed likely ſhould haue béene made awaye wherfore blazed ireland kyng mocke ſubiects ſchooled boye take vpon earle warwickes name ſhewed hym aboute london blind eies ſimple folke defeate lawfull inheritor duke clarence theyr countreyman protectour hys lyfe whoſe lynage alſo diuided tytle crowne al ye haſt aſſemble diueline chriſtes church crowned idoll honouring tytles emperiall feaſting triumphing rearing mighty ſhowtes cry carying thence king caſtel vppon tall men ſhoulders might ſéene noted ſurely honourable boy looke vppon thys meane tyme earle lincolne lordedward hall louell hadde gotten ayde ſayde margaret aboute 2000 almaines martin swart germaine martiall actes verye experte capitaine ſo ſayling ireland citie diuelin cauſed yong lambert bée proclaymed king englande ſo greate multitude iriſhemen whome thomas gerardine capitaine ſailed englande wyth newe king landed fowdrey within little lancaster truſting ayded money ſir thomas broughton one chiefeſt thys conſpiracy kyng henrie ſléepyng matter gathered hys hoſt togither ouer whych duke bedforde earle oxforde chiefe capitaines went couentrie certified erle lincolne landed lancaster newe king remoued notingham ſhortly came george talbot earle shrewſburie lorde straunge ſir iohn cheyney manye ſpace earle lincolne beyng entred yorkeſhire directed way newarke vppon trent little village called stoke thrée four mile newark nighe king armye planted campe nexte daye following king diuided hys number thrée battailes approched nighe town stoke bothe army ioyned foughte egrelye bothe partes length kyngs forewarde ſette vppon aduerſaries wyth ſuche violence ſlewe manye putte payd twelue penny euery mā tooke fortie ſhillings wage xij euery mā womā xv yeres vpward 4 aprill king ſent great nauie twelue thouſand men sea may euen edmond de la poole beheaded tower hill brother richard ſlayne france king henry hauing ſent ouer great puiſſant armieking henry beſeegeth turvvyne france beſéege citie turwine himſelfe accompanyed many noble men vj c archer gard white gabberdines tooke ship douer laſt june morning king ſhipped made sayle armie followed number foure hundred shippes winde ſo brought ſame night caleis hauen nexte morrowe firſt july thomas lord howard admirall england landed whitſandbay entred ſpoyled brent towne returned shippes xxj july king paſſed towne caleis goodly array battell tooke ye field notwithſtanding foreward king great armie turwine yet king owne battayle made thrée battayles lord liſle marſhall hoſt captayne forewarde vnder thrée thouſand men sir richard carew thrée hundred men right hand wing foreward lorde darcy thrée c men wing left hand ſcourers foreriders battayle northumberland men light gelding earle eſſex lieutenant generall speares sir iohn pechy vicegouernour horſemen king wente viij c almaynes plump came standert redde dragon next banner lady nexte trinitie vnder whiche king houſhold went banner armes england borne sir henry guildford vnder banner king himſelfe diuers noble men number thrée thouſand mē duke buckingham vj c men ye king left hand right hād sir edw poynings vj c mē egall wt almains l burgainie wt viij c mē wing right hande ſir william compton retinue byſhoppe winchester fox maiſter thomas wolſey afterward cardinall eighte hundred manner rerewarde ſir anthony oughtred ſir iohn neuell king ſpeares followed foure hundred ſo whole armye eleauen thouſande thrée hundred men maiſter ordināce ſet forth king artillerie faulcons slyngs bombard powder ſtones bowes arrowes ſuche thing neceſſarye fielde whole number carriage thirtéene hundred leader driuers ſame ninetéene hundred men king laye firſte nighte betwixte calkewell freydon nexte night caſtel gwiſnes bocarde next night laye beſide arde good waye wythout engliſhe pale little beyonde dernome came greate hoſte french men purpoſed haue ſette vpon kyng hoſte kepte ground ſhotte greate ordinaunce wherewyth aray french men▪ broken fourth auguſt king good order battell came citie turwine planted ſiege warlike wiſe eleuenth day auguſt maximilian emperor came king henrye receiued greate triumph betwéene aire campe emperor ſeruants reteyned king englande wage daye euery perſon according degrée emperor king ſouldioure ware croſſe saint george roſe ſo hée traine came king campe thirtéenth auguſt receyued wyth greate magnificence thrée twentith auguſt towne turwine turvvine yeelded k henry giuen ouer vnto kyng england wyth condition men towne mighte ſafely paſſe wyth horſſe harneſſe ſo foure twentith auguſte came oute towne foure thou • men warre moewell appointed whereof ſixe hundred well horſed theyr ſtandardes borne ſixe twentith auguſt king remoued singate agréed walles gate bulwarkes tower turwine ſhoulde defaced razed caſte downe whyche concluſion emperoureturvviue raced brent ſent word saint omers aire whych ioyous tydings ſente thither pioners ſo engliſhe pioners brake wals gate tower filled ditch fiered towne except cathedrall churche palaice ordinaunce king ſente aire kept vſe concluded king perſon ſhoulde laye hys ſiege citie turney wherefore hée ſente forwarde thrée goodly battayles firſte conducted earle shrewſburie ſeconde battell led king hymſelfe wyth whome emperour rerewarde conducted lorde harbert ſo firſte nyghte laye campe beſide aire fourtéenth september king hys armye came beatwin morrowe paſſed forwarde came ſtraite forde whiche greate difficultie paſſed next day paſſed bridge called fount anandiew c one twentith daye september kyng remoued hys campe towarde tourney lodged wythin thrée myles citie whyche nighte came hym emperour palſgraue people aboutking henry • ieged turney tourney theyr gòodes fledde citie yet citie hadde menne warre defende wyth multitude inhabitantes citie well repleniſhed kyng came aray battell tourney planted ordinaunce rounde abonte citie dyuers french caſte rampiers made ſo citizen coulde iſſue oute ayde come wherevpon length wéete nyne twentith september citie yéelded king appointed lorde • iſle lorde burgeyny lorde willoughby take poſſeſſion whyche wyth ſixe thouſande menne entered citie tooke market place walles mayſter thomas wolſey king almoner called citizen ſware kyng englande number whiche citizen four ſcore thouſande ſeconde daye october king entred citie turney ordayned ſir edwarde poynings knight order garter hys lieuetenaunt wyth captaines horſemen archer artillerie conuenient hée made hys almoner thomas wolſey byſhoppe tourney returned callaice ſayledthomas vvoolſey bishop turney thence douer foure twentyth october meane tyme iames king scottes notwithſtanding ſworne kéepe peace inuaded lande mightye armye good dilligence quéene pollicie manhoode earle surrey king lieuetenannt himſelfe ſlaine bramstone vpon piperd hill thrée byſhoppes two abbot twelue earles ſeuentéene lord beſides knight gentleman ſeauentéene thouſande scottes ordinaunces ſtuffe taken ninth september ſlaine engliſhe men aboute fiue thouſande dead body king scottes broughte vp london ſo conueyed haue bin enformed perſons good credite thomas wolſey poore man ſonne ipſwich aſcending thomas vvolſey 1516 countie suffolke borne child apt learned meanes parent conuayde uniuerſitie oxford ſhortly proſpered ſo learning made batcheler anno reg 8 batcheler art xv yeares old art paſſed fiftéene yeares age called moſt commonly uniuerſitie boy batcheler thus proſpering learning made fellow maudelin
