paulet héeles pleaſure neyther forgotten forgiuen schoolemayſter mounted dignitie chancellour england ſente mayſter paulet many ſharp word enioyned attend vntill diſmiſſed depart london without licence obteyned ſo continued therewithvvolſeys impriſonment reuenged middle temple ſpace fiue ſixe yeares lay gate houſe next ſtréete hée reedifyed ſumptuouſly garniſhing ſame ouergatehouſe middle temple nevv builded outſide cardinal armes hatte cogniſances deuiſes ſo glorious ſorte thought thereby haue appeaſed olde diſpleaſure deceaſſe lorde marqueſſe thys schoolemayſter conſidering himſelfe ſimple beneficed man haue loſt fellowſhip colledge much reliefe thought long vnprogided ſome help trauell thereabout fell acquayntance one sir iohn naphant sir iohn naphant treaſurer caleis thomas vvolſey chaplayne graue auntient knight great •• caleis vnder king henry ſeauenth knight hée ſerued behaued hymſelfe ſo diſcretely obteyned eſpeciall fauour mayſter ſo muche committed charge hys office vnto hys chaplayne vnderſtand office treaſureſhip caleis conſideration hys greate age diſcharged hys roome returned agayne englande hys inſtant labour hys chaplaynethomas vvolſey vvas chapleyne henry vij▪ promoted bée kyngs chaplayne hée caſt ancker porte promotion wrought ſhall ſomewhat declare hauing • uſt occaſion ſight king dayly reaſon hée ſayde maſſe hym hys cloſet bée • ng done ſpēt day ydleneſſe would attend vpon thoſe whome thought beare moſt rule counſell tyme doctor fox biſhop winchester secretarie lord priuie ſeale alſo sir thomas louell knight ſage counſellor mayſter wardes conneſtable tower theſe graue counſellors proces time perceyued chapleyne haue fine witte thought méete perſon preferred wittie affaire chanced certayne ſeaſon king vrgent occaſion ſend embaſſador vnto emperour maximilian lay preſent low countrey flanders farre caleis biſhop winchester sir thomas louell whome king counſelled debated vppon embaſſage ſaw conuenient occaſion preferre king chapleyne whoſe witte eloquence learning highly commended king king commanded bring chapleyne preſence whome fell communication great matter perceyuing witte fyne thoughte hym ſufficiente commaunding hym therevpon prepare hymſelfe hys iourney hauing hys depeach tooke hys leaue king richmond noone ſo came london four clocke barge graues ende ready launch forth proſperousthomas vvolſey embaſſadour emperour tyde winde without abode entred barge ſo paſſed foorth ſuche ſpéede hée arriued graues ende within little thrée houres hée tarryed longer poſt horſſes prouiding trauayled ſo ſpéedily hée came douer nexte morning whereas paſſengers readye vnder sayle caleis paſſenger without tarrying entred ſayled foorth wyth long noone hée arriued calleis hauing poſt horſſes departed thence ſuch ſpéede night emperour diſcloſed whole ſumme embaſſage y• emperor required ſpéedie expedition granted emperour ſo next day cléerely diſpatched king requeſtes fully accompliſhed time made longer delay tooke poſt horſſes night rode towarde caleis conducted thyther ſuch perſons emperour appoynted opening gate caleis came thither paſſengers readie returne england iourney forward ſo muche arriued douer tenne clocke noone hauing poſt horſſes came court richmond ſame night taking ſome reſt vntill morning repayred king firſt comming bedchamber cloſet whome king ſawe hée checked iourney sir quoth may pleaſe youre highneſſe haue already bin emperour diſpatched affayres truſt grace contentation preſented king letter credence emperoure king great confuſe wonder ſpéedy returne procéedings diſſembled wonder demanded whether encountred purſiuant ſent vnto ſuppoſing london letter concerning neceſſary matter neglected conſultatiō yes forſooth quoth chaplayne met yeſterday way hauing vnderſtanding grace letter pleaſure haue withſtanding bin ſo bold vpon mine owne diſcretion perceyuing matter neceſſary behalfe diſpatch ſame foraſmuch haue excéeded grace commiſſion moſt humbly require grace pardon king reioycing little ſayd we▪ pardon thereof alſo giue princely thankes procéeding therein alſo good ſpéedie exployte commanding time take reſt repaire agayne dinner relation ambaſſade embaſſador ſaw tyme repaired king counſayle declared effect affaire ſo exactly ſuch grauitie eloquence counſell heard commended eſtéeming expedition almoſt beyond capacitie man king gaue time deanerie lincolne thēcethomas vvolſey deane lincolne forward grew eſtimation authoritie promoted king hys almoner death king henry ſeauenth andthomas vvolſey king almoner flouriſhing youth king henry eyght thys almoner handled himſelfe ſo politiquely ſoone found meanes made one king counſailethomas vvolſey priuie counſayle vvith king henry eyght grow fauour king whome king gaue houſe bridewell fleete ſtreete ſometyme sir richard empſons kept houſe familie ſo dayly attended vpon king eſpeciall fauour great ſute made vnto ſentences wittie perſwaſions counſell chamber alwayes ſo pithie counſayle occaſion moued continually aſſigned expoſitor king procéedings whome king receyued ſuch leaning fantaſie moſt earneſt readyeſt counſayle aduance king pleaſure king therefore eſtéemed ſo highly counſaylors put great fauour ſo much king committed vnto diſpoſition almoner perceyuing tooke vpon therefore diſcharge king weightie troubleſome buſineſſe per • wading king ſhould néede ſpare time pleaſure buſineſſe ſhould happen counſell whereas counſaylours would diuers time perſwade king haue ſometime recourſe counſell chamber heare done almoner would perſwade contrarie delighted much thus almoner ruled ſuch hys policie witte bring paſſe hygh fauoure maiſter almoner ruled vnder king maiſter almouer thus perſeuered fauour vntill laſt came preſents giftes reward ſo plentifully lacked nothing might eyther pleaſe fantaſie enrich coffer thus procéeding fortune bliſfulneſſe chanced warres betwéene realmes englande france open ſo much king béeing fully perſwaded hys moſt royall perſon inuade hys foraigne enimies puiſſant armye wherefore neceſſarye thys royall enterpriſe ſhoulde bée ſpéedily prouided furniſhed euery degrée thing apt conueniente ſame expedition whereof king thought man witte ſo méete policie paynefull trauayle hys almoner whome therefore committed hys whole truſt therein hée tooke vpon hym whole charge buſineſſe brought thing good paſſe decent order manner victualles prouiſions neceſſaryes conueniente ſo noble voyage armie thing béeyng hym perfected king aduanced hys royall enterpriſe paſſed sea marched forwarde good order battayle vntill hée came ſtrong towne turwyne whyche hée layde hys ſéege aſſayled ſtrongly continually ſuch vehemente aſſaultes within ſhort ſpace yéelded vnto hys maieſtie vnto place emperour maximilian repaired vnto king greate armie like mightie prince taking king grace wage rare thing ſeldome ſéene emperour fighte vnder king banner thus king obteyned puiſſant fort taken poſſeſſion thereof ſette thynges due order defence preſeruation thereof hys vſe departed thence marched towarde citie turney layde hys ſéege like manner gaue ſo fierce ſharpe aſſault conſtreyned fine force render towne vnto victorious maieſtie time king gaue almoner biſhoprike ſame seathomas vvolſey bishop turney towards hys paynes diligence ſuſteyned iourney king eſtabliſhed thing agréeable pleaſure furniſhed ſame noble captaynes men warre ſafegard towne hée returned agayne englande taking diuers noble perſonages france priſoners duke longuile uicount clarimont whiche taken skirmiſhe whoſe returne immediately sea lincolne fell voyde death doctor smith late biſhop benefice grace gaue almoner late biſhop turney elect negligent take poſſeſſion thereof andthomas vvolſey bishop lincolne made ſpéede could hys conſecration ſolemnization whereof ended found meanes gate poſſeſſion predeceſſors goodes hand long doctor bambridge archbiſhop yorke dyed rome king embaſſador vnto sea king immediately preſented hys late newe biſhop lincolne ſo thrée biſhoprickes hand one yeare giuen hym prepared tranſlation sea lincolne vntothomas vvolſey archbishop york sea yorke whiche ſolemnization done béeing archbyſhop prima angliae thought himſelfe ſufficiente compare canterbury therevppon erected hys croſſe court euery place well within precinct iuriſdiction canterbury anye place muche canterbury claymeth ſuperioritie ouer yorke ouer biſhoprikes within englande cauſe claymeth knowledge aunciente obedience yorke abate aduauncing hys croſſe preſence croſſe canterburie notwythſtanding yorke nothing minding deſiſte bearing thereof manner ſayde béefore cauſed hys croſſe aduaunced well preſence canterburie elſewhere wherefore canterburie moued therewith gaue vnto yorke certayne checke hys preſumption reaſon whereof engendred ſome grudge betwéene yorke caunterburie yorke intending prouide ſome ſuche meanes hée woulde bée rather ſuperior dignitie canterburie eyther obedient equall hym wherefore hée obtayned made prieſte cardinall legatus de latere vnto whome pope ſente cardinal hat wyththomas vvolſey cardinall certayne bulles hys aucthoritie behalfe yet ſhall vnderſtande pope ſente hym thys worthye hatte dignitie iewell hys honoure aucthoritie whych conueyed varlet budget ſéemed menne bée perſon ſmall eſtimation wherfore yorke beyng aduertiſed baſeneſſe meſſenger people opinion thought méete hys honour iewell ſhould conueyed ſo ſimple perſon therefore cauſed ſtopped way immediatly arriualin england newly furniſhed manner apparell wyth kynde coſtlye ſilkes whyche ſéemed decent ſuche hyghe embaſſador done encountred vppon blacke heath receyued wyth greate aſſemblye prelate luſtie gallant gentleman thence conducted throughe london greate triumph greate ſpéedie preparation made westminster abbey confirmation acceptance thys hygh order dignitie whyche executed byſhoppes abbot aboute nyghe london wyth theyr rych myters cope ornament done ſo ſolempne wiſe bene ſéene like vnleſſe bin coronation myghty prince king obtayning thys dignitie thoughte himſelfe mée • e beare aucthoritie among temporall power among ſpirituall iuriſdiction wherefore remembring well tawntes ſuſtained canterburie hauing reſpecte aduauncement worldlye honor promotion found mean king made lord chancelourthomas vvolſey lord chācelour englande canterburie whiche chanceloure diſmiſſed continued roume ſince long deceaſſe henrie ſeauenth nowe poſſeſſion chancelorſhippe endued wyth promotion archebyſhoppe cardinall de latere hauyng power correcte canterburie al byſhops ſpirituall perſons aſſemble hys conuocation would aſſigne hée tooke vpon hym correction matter iuriſdictions viſited ſpirituall houſes hauing euerye dioceſſe maner spirituall miniſters commiſſaries scribe apparators al officer furniſh hys court preſented preuention pleaſed vnto al benefice throughout thys realme aduauncing legantine iuriſdiction honor hadde maiſters faculty maiſters ceremontarum ſuche glorifying dignitie two great croſſes syluer one hys archebyſhopricke hys legacie borne whyther ſo euer wente rode two talleſt prieſtes hée coulde gette wythin realme encreaſe gaines alſo byſhopricke durham abbey saint albons commendation doctor foxe byſhopthomas vvolſey byshoppe vvincheſter winchester dyed ſurrendred durham ryngs handes tooke winchester hys hande firme biſhoprickes bathe worcester hereforde ſoraſmuch incumbent ſtrangers made abode continually beyond sea owne country elſe rome whence ſente legation thys realme vnto king rewarde departure kyng henrie ſeauenth gaue thoſe biſhoprickes béeing ſtrangers thoughte méete aſſuraunce ſuffer cardinal haue benefice conuenient ſumme mony payd yearely remayned either troubled charge ſame yearely burdened conueyance theyr reuenues vnto ſo al ſpiritual preſentations theſe byſhoprickes fully hys diſpoſition prefer liſted alſo greate number daylye attending vpon hym noble men worthye gentleman ſmall number talleſt yeoman coulde gette realme inſomuche well nobleman gentleman coulde prefer tall yeoman ſeruice ye ſhal vnderſtande hallthe order cardinalies houſe continually thrée boordes kepte thrée ſeueral principall officer ſay stewarde whych alwayes prieſt treaſourer knight comptroller eſquier alſo cofferer béeyng doctor thrée marſhalles thrée yeoman uſhers hall beſides two groomes almoner hal kitchen two clearks kitchen clearke comptroller surueyor dreſſor clearke spicerie whyche togither kepte alſo continuall meſſe hal alſo hys hall kitchin hée maiſter cooke twoo cooke laborer child kitchin twelue perſons foure yeoman scullerie foure yeoman ſiluer scullerie two yeoman paſtry two paſtelers vnder yeoman priuie kitchin maſter cooke went daylye ueluet sattin wyth chayne golde wyth two yeoman groome scalding houſe yeoman twoo groomes pantery twoo perſons buttrey two yeoman two groomes twoo page yewrye lykewiſe seller thrée yeoman thrée page hys chaundrey two wafarie two wardrobe beddes maiſter wardrobe • perſons laundry yeoman groome thirtie page two yeoman purueyors one groome bake houſe yeoman two groomes wood yarde yeoman groome barne one garden yeoman two groomes porter gate twoo yeoman two groomes yeoman hys barge maiſter hys horſe clearke stable yeoman ſame sadler farrier yeoman hys chariot sumpter man yeoman styrrop muleter ſixetéene groomes hys stable euery kepte foure gelding almorie yeoman groome inthomas vvolſeys chappell hys chappel hadde deane greate diuine man excellent learning subdeane repeater quire goſpeller piſtler ſinging prieſtes ten maſter child secular chappell ſinging men twelue ſinging child tenne one ſeruant awaite vppon child reueſtry yeoman two groomes ouer beſides dyuers reteiners came thither principal feaſtes furniture hys chappell paſſeth capacitie declare number coſtly ornamentes riche iewels occupyed ſame continuallye hathe béene ſéene proceſſion aboute hall 44 rich coapes one ſute worne beſides riche croſſes candleſtickes ornamentes furniture ſame hée two croſſebearers two piller bearer hys great chamber hys priuy chamber theſe perſons fyrſte chiefe chamberlaine uizchamberlaine gentleman uſhers beſides one priuie chamber hadde twelue daylye wayters gentleman wayters hys priuye chamber hadde ſixe lordes nyne tenne hadde eche two men allowed attend vpon except erle darby allowed fiue men gentleman cup bearer caruers sewer beth priuie chamber great chamber wyth gentleman dayly wayters fortie perſons ofyeomen uſhers ſixe groomes chamber eight yeoman chamber fiue fortie daylye alſo almoſe men ſometime number ſometime attending borde doctor chapleines beſides chappell ſixetéene daylye clearke cloſet secretary two two clearkes signet foure counſellours learned lawe aſmuche neceſſarie haue dyuers officer chauncerie attende vppon hym ſaye clearke crowne ryding clearke clearke hamper chafer waxe clearke checke well vppon chapleins yeoman chamber hée alſo foure footemen whyche garniſhed riche running coates ſo euer rode anye iourney hée harraulte armes sergeant armes phiſition poticarie foure minſtrels kéeper tent armorer inſtructer hys ward two yeoman hys wardrobe hys robe kéeper hys chamber continuallye court alſo houſe surueyor yorke clearke gréene cloth theſe dayly attending downe lying vpriſing meales kepte greate chamber continuall borde chamberers gentleman officer hauing wyth meſſe yong lord gentleman beſides theſe neuer officer gentleman worthy perſon allowed houſe ſome thrée ſome two al one leaſte whiche grewe greate number perſons thus far • ute checker roll beſides officer ſeruantes •• teyners futers moſte commoulye dyned hallthomas vvolſey tvvice embaſſador emperour charles thus furniſhed ſente twice embaſſade emperor charles fifth diuers vrgent cauſes touchyng king maieſtie thought ſo noble prince cardinall moſte méete ſente wherefore readye take vppon hym charge thereof furniſhed degrées purpoſes moſte lyke greate prince firſte procéeded forth furniſhed lyke cardinall hys gentleman béeyng verye many number clothed lyuerie coates crimoſin ueluet beſt wyth chaines golde aboute theyr neckes hys yeoman meane officer coates fine scarlet garded blacke ueluet hande broade thus furniſhed twice ſente flaunders emperour lying bruges moſt highly entertain diſcharging al charge mēs houſe within town bruges wherein gentlemā cardinal lodged recourſe owner commaunded emperoures officer vpon paine liues ſhoulde take mony anye thing cardinalles ſeruantes diode take anye kinde victuall althoughe diſpoſed make anye coſtlye banquet commaunding forthermore ſaide hoſtes ſée y• lacked ſuch thing honeſtly required honeſty pleaſure alſo emperor officer euery night wēt town frō houſe houſe whereas engliſh gentlemē repaſt lodged ſerued liueries night done maner firſt officer brought houſe caſt fine manchet ſiluer two great pot white wine sugar waighte pounde white light yellowe lightes ware boule ſiluer wyth goblet drinke euerye night ſtaffe▪ torche order liueries euerye nighte morning ſame officer came fetch away ſtuffe woulde accompte hoſtes gentleman coſtes ſpent daye thus emperoure entertayned cardinall traine time embaſſage done returned englande great triumphe nowe hys order going westminster hall dayly terme firſte ere came hys priuie chamber hearde ſeruice cloſet ſaid hys ſeruice wyth hys chaplaine goyng againe hys priuy chamber woulde demaunde ſeruants readyneſſe furniſhed hys chamber preſence wayghting chamber thereof aduertized came oute hys priuy chamber aboute eighte clocke apparelled red ſaye hys vpper garment eyther fine scarlet elſe fine crimoſin taffata moſt commonlye fine crimoſin satten engrayned hys pillion fine scarlet necke ſette inner ſide wyth blacke ueluet tippet sable aboute hys necke holding hys hand orenge wherof ſubſtance within taken oute filled vppe againe wyth part sponge wherein uineger confection againſte peſtilent ayres whyche hée moſte commonlye helde hys noſe came among anye preace elſe peſtered wyth manye ſuters béefore borne firſte broade seale englande hys cardinales hat lorde ſome gentlemanne worſhippe right ſolempnely ſoone entred chāber preſence two great croſſes attending borne hym cried gentleman uſhers going bare headed ſaide lordes maiſters make waye lordes grace thus went downe hall wyth sergeant armes hym bearing greate mace siluer two gentleman carying twoo greate pillers siluer came hall dore hys mule trapped crimo • n ueluet wyth saddle ſame guilte ſtyrrops attending vpponhym mounted hys two croſſebearers piller bearer like caſe vppon greate horſes trapped fine scarlet marched forward traine noble men gentleman hauing footman four number hym bearing eache guilte polare hand thus paſſed forth vntill came westminster hall dore lighted wente vppe thys manner chauncerie starre chamber howbeit moſte commonlye woulde goe chancerie ſtay barre made hym beneath chancerie righte hande commune ſometyme wyth judge ſome▪ time perſons done woulde repayre chancerie ſitting vntill eleauen clocke hearing ſutes determining matter thence woulde dyuers time go starre chamber occaſion ſerued neyther ſpared highe ne lowe iudged euery ſtate accordyng merites deſert vſed alſo euerye sondaye reſorte courte béeyng moſte parte yeare greenewiche hys former triumphes takyng hys barge hys ſtayres furniſhed wyth yeoman ſtandyng vppon bailes hys gentleman béeyng wythin aboute hym landed againe three crane vintr • e thence hée rode vpon mule croſſe pillar hat broade seale carryed afore hym horſebacke thamis ſtreete▪ vntill came billingſgate tooke barge againe ſo rowed greenewiche receyued lordes chiefe officer king houſe treaſurer comptroller ſo conuyed vnto king chamber court wonderfully furniſhed wyth noble men gentleman dinner among lord hauing ſome conſultation king councell woulde departe homewarde like triumph thus greate honour triumph glory raigned long ſeaſon ruling thynges within realme appertayning vnto king houſe alwayes reſorted nobleman gentleman feaſting banqueting embaſſadors dyuers time al right nobly pleaſed king recreation repayre cardinalles houſe didde dyuers tymes yeare wanted preparation furniture banquet ſette forth maſkes mummery ſo gorgeous ſorte coſtly maner heauen beholde wanted dame damoiſels méete apte daunce maſkers garniſh place tyme kinde muſicke harmony wyth fine voice bothe menne chyldren one tyme kyng came ſodainely thither maſkea maske banquet wyth dozen maſkers garmentes like shepheards made fine cloth golde crimoſin satten paned cappes ſame wyth uiſars good viſnomy haires beardes eyther fine goldewyre ſilke black ſilke hauing ſixetéene torchbearer beſides drum perſons wyth uiſars clothed satten ſame colour hys entring hall hée came water water gate wythout noiſe layd diuers chābers gun charged shot hys landing ſhotte whyche made ſuche tumble ye ayre like thunder made nobleman gentleman ladyes gentlewoman • uſe ſhoulde meane comming ſo ſodainelye • itting quiet ſolempne banquet vnder ſorte firſt yée ſhall vnderſtande table ſette chamber preſence iuſt couered lorde cardinall ſitting vnder cloth eſtate hauing hys ſeruice alone ſette lady wyth nobleman gentleman gentlewoman throughout table chamber one ſide whych made ioyned one table whiche order deuice done lorde sandes lorde chamberlaine king syr henrie gilforde comptroller kinges maieſties houſe immediately greate chamberlaine ſayde comptroller ſente looke ſhoulde meane thoughe knewe nothing matter looking oute windowes thamis retourned againe ſhewed hym ſéemed nobleman straungers arryued hys bridge comming embaſſadoures ſome forreine prince quoth cardinal deſire bycauſe ſpeake frenche▪ take paine goe hall receyue according eſtates conducte chamber ſhall ſée v theſe noble perſonages beyng mery oure banquet deſiring ſitte downe v take parte fare wente hée incontinent downe hall whereas receyued wyth twentie newe torch conueyed vppe chamber wyth ſuche noyſe drummes flewtes ſeldome hadde béene hearde like theyr entring chamber twoo twoo togyther went directlye cardinall hée ſate ſaluted hym reuerentlye whome lorde chamberlaine ſaide sir muche bée straungers ſpeake engliſhe haue deſired declare vnto hauyng vnderſtanding triumphaunt banquet aſſembled ſuche number excellent dame coulde doe leſſe vnder ſupporte youre grace repayre hyther viewe well incomparable beautie accompanye mumme chaunce daunce ſir require youre grace licence accompliſhe ſaide cauſe comming whome cardinall ſaide well content ſhould ſo doe went maſkers firſt ſaluted al dame returned moſte worthieſt opened greate cuppe golde filled wyth crownes péeces golde whome ſette certaine péeces golde caſt thus peruſing ladyes gentlewoman ſome loſte ſome wonne peruſing maner al lady returned cardinal greate reuerence powring downe golde ſo lefte cup whych aboue twoo hundred crown quoth cardinall ſo caſte dice wan whereat made great noiſe ioy thenquoth cardinall lord chamberlain pray quoth would ſhew ſéemeth ſhould nobleman amongeſt méete occupye ſeate place whome woulde moſte gladly ſurrender ſame according duety knewe ſpake lorde chamberlaine frenche rownding eare lorde chamberlaine ſaide lorde cardinall sir quoth confeſſe among ſuche noble perſonage whome grace appointe hym oute reſt content diſcloſe hymſelfe accept place cardinal taking good aduiſement among laſte quoth ſéemes gentleman wyth blacke bearde ſhoulde euen aroſe oute hys chayre offered ſame gentleman blacke bearde cap hande perſon whome offered chayre sir edwarde neuil comely knight much reſembled king perſon maſke anye king perceyuing cardinall ſo deceyued could forbeare laughing pulled hys viſar maſter neuels alſo daſhed ſuche pleaſaunt countenaunce chéere al noble eſtates aſſembled perceiuing king among reioyced much cardinal eft ſoones deſired highneſſe take place eſtate whome king aunſwered woulde goe firſte ſhifte hys apparell ſo departed lorde cardinalles chamber newe apparelled whych tyme diſhes banquet cleane taken vppe table ſpred againe new cleane perfumed clothes euery man woman ſitting ſtil vntill king maſkers came among againe newe apparelled king tooke ſeate vnder cloth eſtate commaunding euery perſon ſit ſtill came newe banquet kyng reſt throughout table wherein ſerued two hundred diuers diſhes coſtly deuiſes ſuttilties thus paſſed forth night banqueting dauncing triumphes great comforte king pleaſant regard nobilitie aſſembled thus paſſed cardinall time day daye yeare yeare ſuche greate wealth ioy triumph glorie hauyng alwayes hys ſide king eſpecial fauor vntil fortune enuied proſperous eſtate mayſter maſon maiſter carpenter thrée hundred maſons fiue hundred carpenter one hundred joyners many paynters glazier tylours smith artificer england flaunders number two thouſande ſaide pallaice begunne ninetéenth marche whyche tymber boughte holand whyche tymber ſo long ſame bounden togyther brought calleis wythout ſhippe ſhippe myghte receiue tymber boorde conueyed of1519 englande thus builded goodlyeſt pallaice tymber euer wroughte ſo curiouſly garniſhed wythin wythout prouiſion made englande flaunders victuall wine thynges neceſſarie furniture feaſting banqueting came englande orleaunce kyng armes france made proclamation courte kyng england frenche kyng campe betwéene arde guiſnes eightéene aydes june nexte enſuing ſhould abide al commers gentleman tylt tourney barrier quéene readineſſe haue paſſed sea heard emperor charles comming arriued hith kent landed douer ſixe twentith may mette lorde cardinall wolſey conducted ſhoare douer caſtel lodged nexte morning king henrie came riding canterburie caſtel douer ſaluted emperour whitſonday earely morning theſe two noble prince tooke horſes rode citie caunterburie onelye ſolempniſe feaſt pentecoſte alſo ſée quéene aunte noble perſonages realme englande quéene hir traine ladyes receyued welcomed emperour caunterburie remayned tyll thurſday nexte following whyche laſte maye tooke hys leaue king ladyes ſo rode sandwich tooke hys ship ſayled flaunders ſame daye kyng made ſayle porte douer landed caleis aboute eleauen clocke wyth quéene ladyes manye noble realme number perſons king quéenes ſide 4334 horſes 1637 beſides perſons frenche quéenes duke suffolke hir huſbandes cardinalles fourth june king wyth hys noble well quéene hir traine lady whole number noble remoued frō calleis guiſnes moſte noble royall lodging ſéene pallaice made quadrant euerye quadrant 328 foote long whyche compaſſe 1312 foote aboute ſeauenth june king england fraunce met campe betwéene guiſnes arde wyth bothe swordes drawne borne tenth june king englande dyned frenche quéene towne arde frenche kyng dyned ſame day wyth quéene england new pallaice made caſtel guiſnes houſe moſte ſumptuous coſtlye rich hath béen • ſéene thys theſe two king mette euery daye campe wyth diuers lord iuſted turneyed fourtéene dayes two quéenes met guiſnes arde dyuers tymes foure twentith june theſe two king quéens retinue met camp juſts kept banqueted daūced maſkings diſguiſings like bin lightly ſéene almoſt night following tooke leaue departed xxv june king england quéene court remoued guiſnes towne caleis reſted tenth july king goodly company rode towne grauelin flanders mette charles emperour next morrow emperour lady margaret emperours aunt ducheſſe sauoy many great eſtates came king england towne caleis whereby lord ſtates england diſplaced lodging ſolace againſt comming buildedbanqueting houſe tovvne caleis richard turpin banqueting houſe eyght hundred foote compaſſe like theatre goodly deuiſe builded ſuch manner thinke neuer ſéene ſixtéene principal made great maſtes betwixt euery maſt four twentie foote outſides cloſed boorde canuas ouer within round ſides made thrée scaffold loftes one aboue another men woman ſtand vpon midſt ſame banqueting houſe ſet vp great piller timber made eyght great maſtes bound togither iron band holde togither hundred four thirtie • ote length coſt ſixe pound thirtéene ſhillings foure penny ſet vpright banqueting houſe couered • uer canuas faſtned rope iron faſt might deuiſed within ſayd houſe paynted heauens starres sunne moone clowdes diuers thing made aboue ouer men head ther great image wicker couered made like great men diuers ſtrange nation diuers reaſons written countreys likened armes thoſe countreys hanging alſo made many ſhips vnder ſayle windmilles going high piller timber ſtoode vpright midſt made stage timber organ inſtruments ſtande men play muſitions pageant playde king england emperour ſhould banquet morning ſame day winde beganne riſe night blew canuas element withbanqueting houſe defaced tempeſt starres sunne moone clowdes wind blew aboue thouſand torch lightes waxe prepared giue light banquet king ſeates made great rich beſides thing daſhed loſt ſame night king fiftéene perſons richly apparelled maſke went emperours lodging chamber preſence daunced reuelled departed twelfth july emperour lady margaret ſupped king quéene checker ſame night eyght companyes maſkers euery company twelue perſons gold siluer ueluet richly apparelled fourtéenth july emperour departed caleis toward grauelin eyghtéenth july king englande quéene departed caleis towards calbais iohn skeuington mer taylor iohn kyeme 28 sep sherifes maior sir iohn bruges draper 28 october king henry kepte chriſtmas manour greenewich much nobleneſſe open court tenth day february owne perſon iuſted commers time edward▪ duke buckingham accuſedduke buckingham accuſed 1521 high treaſon wherefore king directed letter ſayd duke béeing hys manour thornebury glocesterſhire incontinent ſhould come preſence commandement duke obeyed came vptoanno reg 13 london ſtreightwayes arreſted sir henry merney captayne gard conuayde tower london ſixtéenth aprill whiche time duke chancellour taken confeſſed matter high treaſon concerning king perſon alſo attached monke order carthuſians henton priory iohn delaker duke confeſſor theſe priſoners tower shortly duke croſſed frier london wherein placed thirtéene aged poore people haue dwelling • entfrée two ſhillings ſixe penny péece firſte day euery moneth euer ſixth march french king attached engliſhmens countrey michaell engliſh nicholas iennings 28 septemb sherifes george monex choſen maior would takemaior elected vpon wherefore condemned thouſande marke fine diſcharge whereof gaue vnto citie water philip conſpiracy • couentrie schoole mayſter king henxmen chriſtopher pickering clearke king larder anthony manuile gentleman intended haue taken king treaſure subſedie collector ſame came toward brent iedworth scotlande and1524 tooke diuers holdes duke albany beſéeged caſtell warke readineſſe great armie inuadeanno reg 1 • england heard earle surrey comming fledde scotland fiue twentith may deceaſſed sir thomas louell knight garter endfield ſame moneth deceaſſed thomas lord howard duke norffolke ſouldiers guiſnes tooke great bootie faire towne morguiſon sir robert iernegan wyth certayne dimilances caleis tooke diuers french priſoners firſt september doctour hanyball mayſter ofa golden roſe ſent frō rome e hall rolles receyued london embaſſadour clement ſeauenth pope whiche brought roſe gold token king preſented windſore trée forged fine golde wrought branch leaues flower reſembling roſes ſet potte golde potte thrée féete • tike faſhion meaſure halfe pinte vppermoſt roſe faire saphire leape pearced bigneſſe acorne trée height halfe engliſh yard breadth foote ralph dodmer william roche 28 september sherifes maior sir william bayly draper 28 october chanced yeare paſſed grudge breake betwéene french king duke burbon ſo much duke ſafegard life fledde french king dominion whereof cardinall wolſey hauing intelligence compriſed head king ſoueraigne lord could obteyne generall warre againſt french king conſidering duke burbon fledde vnto emperour inuite like purpoſe wherefore hauing imagination head thought good mouea policie cardinall vvolſey end turned againſt himſelfe king matter king aduertiſed héereof conceyuing cardinal inuention laſt came conſultation among counſell ſo concluded embaſſade ſhould ſente emperour matter whome king emperour ſhould ioyne thoſe warres againſt french king duke burbon ſhouldthe duke burbon champion k england againſt king france king champion generall fielde great number good souldiours ouer beſides emperours armie ſmall king ſhould pay vnto duke monethly wage himſelfe retinue ſo much sir iohn ruſſell sir iohn ruſſel lay continually beyond sea ſecret place receyue money king pay ſame monethly duke ſo duke began warres french king owne territorie dukedome king confiſked owne hand perfectly knowne vnto duke enimies ayde england thus wrought french king much diſpleaſure ſo much french king conſtreyned1525 prepare puiſſant armie owne perſon reſiſt duke power force king droue take pauy ſtrong towne italy hys hoſt ſecuritie whereas king encamped hym wonderouſly ſtrong intending encloſe duke ſhould iſſue forth yet notwithſtanding duke many time iſſue forth ſkirmiſhed king let v returne agayne cardinall wolſey ſéemed ſodeinly altered frenchanno reg 17 emperiall howſoeuer came ſo paſſe french king lying camp ſent ſecretly englande priuie perſon wittie man treate peace betwixt french king king perſon named iohn iokin kept ſecretly might frenchman borne italian man great eſtimation france ſubtile witte elected entreate ſuch embaſſade french king giuen commiſſion iokin ſecretly conuayde vnto richmond remayned vntill cardinall reſortediohn iokin meſſenger french king thither vnto eaſter tearme ended kept feaſt whitſontide ſolemnely ſeaſon cardinall cauſed diuers time iokin dine thus continued iokin england long vntill laſt ſhould brought paſſe matter commiſſion ſente immediatly reſtreynt sir iohn ruſſell thoſe partes made abiding beyond sea ſhoulde reteyne monethes wage ſtill hys • ands vntill king pleaſure knowne ſhould haue bin payde duke burbon bée • ng wyth hys retinue encamped within towne •• •••• want whereof day duke hys •• n ſore diſmayde ſaw ••• ey brought wont béeing ſo dan •• rous caſe victualles beganne ſ • ant • nd déere imagined many wayes ſhoulde •• lette ſome ſayde thys ſome ſayde ſo miſtruſted nothing leſſe cauſe thereof ſo much laſt wante victualles neceſſaries souldyoures captaynes beganne grudge mutter laſt lacke victual like periſh souldyours extremitie came captaine y• duke burbon ſayd sir muſt bée force neceſſitie conſtreyned yéelde v vp enimies better v ſo ſterue lyke dogges duke ſaw extremitie ſayde vnto wéeping eye sir quoth yée valiant men noble heartes haue ſerued héere right worthelie neceſſitie whereof perticipant doe little lament▪ ſhall deſire noble heart courage ſo take patience day twayne ſuccour come king england doubt nothing deceyue v well agrée ſhall put oure ſelues liues vnto mercy lorde wherewith agréeable tarrying comming king money vntill tearme two dayes paſt duke ſéeing remedie called noble captaynes souldyoures hym wéeping ſayde yée noble men captaynes ſée remedie thys neceſſitie eyther wée muſt yéeld v vnto enimies elſe •• miſhe yéelde towne ſelues know mercie enimies parte paſſ • cruelty knowe well • ſhall ſuffer death moſt cruelly come hand •• ſelfe therefore doe lamente 〈…〉 youre ſakes youre liues ſafegar • youre perſons ſo yée might eſcape dang •• oure enimies handes woulde moſt gladly 〈…〉 death therefore good companyons moſt noble souldyoures ſhall require conſider daungerous miſerie calamitie wée ſtande ſell 〈…〉 liues moſt dearely rather murthered lyk • beaſtes yée wyll bée agréeable wée wyll take vpon v thys nighte gyue oure enimes aſſaulte meanes wée maye eyther eſcape elſe gyue ouerthrowe thus better die fielde lyke men lyue priſoners captiuitle miſerie whiche agréed quoth duke yée perceyue enimies campe ſtrong waye enter vppon one ſo planted wyth ordinance ſtrength men poſſible atteyne oure enimies wayes fighte wyth campe alſo nowe late perceyue haue hadde ſmall doubt v ſo muche haue kepte verye ſlender watche therefore deuice ſhall bée thus ſhall iſſue towne aboute dead nighte v number bée moſt delyuereſt aſſaulte theyr campe ſhall gyue aſſaulte righte ſecretly euen directly agaynſte place entrie whyche ſtrong inuincible youre fierce valiant aſſaulte ſhall campe ſo doubtfull turne ſtrength entrie lyeth ouer agaynſt aſſaulte beate youre purpoſe iſſue poſterne come place theyr ſtrength newly turned ware enter fight theyr camp winne ordinance whiche haue newly burned beate wyth theyr owne •• ce pleaſed wonderous well ••• pared daye purpoſed deuiſe •• kepte ſecret cloſe without anye noyſe •• tte péeces within towne whyche gaue theyr enimies leſſe • eare aſſaulte •• • yghte wente theyr tentes cowched 〈…〉 nothyng miſtruſting afterwarde immediately happened vnto tyme came men reſt aſſaylants iſſued towne according appoyntment gaue ſo cruell fierce aſſault camp much poſſible reſiſt them▪ euen duke declared souldiours within compelled turne ſhotte lay entrie againſt aſſaylants iſſued duke fiftéene ſixtéene thouſand men ſecretly night enimies priuie comming vntill entred fielde entrie tooke ordinance lay ſlew gunner hée charged péeces againſt enimies ſlewe wonderfully cutte downe tentes pauilions murthered many within ere ware comming ſo wanne field euer kingfrench king taken could ariſe reſcue ſo much king taken hys lodging euer harneſſed tentes robbed ſpoyled wonderous rith ſpoyle ſearch king coffer duke burbon found league vnder great seale england newly made betwéene king england french king perceyued began ſmell impediment money ſhould haue come vnto king hauing vpon due ſearch intelligence matter deuiſed cardinall englande duke conceyued ſuche indignation héerevpon agaynſt cardinall incontinente hée wente vnto rome intended ſacke towne haue taken pope firſt aſſaulte walles duke firſt man ſtayne yet notwithſtanding hys captaynes continued aſſaulte ſaſt wanne towne pope fledderome ſacked people fled vnto castell saint angell hée continued long calamitie notwithſtanding yée haue hear • ▪ newes brought england taking french king great triumph made ioy thereof ninth march ſuch time cardinall wolſey determinedcardinall vvolſey ſuppreſſeth occupying certayne theyr groundes monkes refuſing ſatiſfie requeſts ſtreightway picked quarrell agaynſte houſe gaue information cardinall agaynſte taking ſmall occaſion commaunded houſe bée diſſolued bée cōuerted hys new colledge thys irreligeous robberie done conſcience patch vp pride whiche priuate wealth coulde furniſhe puniſhmente hath ſince enſued god hande ſayeth myne authour partly ſelues haue ſéene thoſe fyue perſons two fell diſcorde betwéene themſelues one ſlewe ſuruiuor hanged thirde drowned hymſelfe well fourth béeing well knowne valued worth two hundreth pounde became thrée yeares ſo poore hée begged hys dying day fifth called doctor allane béeyng thiefe executor theſe doyngs cruelly maymed irelande euen ſuche tyme hée biſhop cardinall falling king gréeuous diſpleaſure depoſed dyed miſerably colledges whiche hée meante haue made ſo glorious building came neuer good effect pope clement himſelfe whoſe authoritie theſe houſes throwne downe ground encloſed dangerous ſéege within caſtell saint angell rome emperialles citie rome pitifully ſacked himſelfe narrowly eſcaped life tower greenewich yeare buildedgreenevvich tovver builded creation bridewell eyghtéenth chancellour duchy lancaster made anſwere ſaying much reioyced king firſt conſidered hys power might haue oppreſſed hys pitie reléeued wherefore would héere kindneſſe ſhoulde ſhewe hym none vnkindneſſe whereby corne fayled ſore yeare following deliuerie french king emperours1527 bondage ſonnes receyued hoſtage emperours king england ſecuritie allanno reg 19 ſuch demaundes requeſtes ſhould demaunded french king cardinall wolſey lamenting french king calamitie pope great aduerſitie yet remayned caſtell angell trauelled could king counſell take ſome order quietneſſe laſt thought good ſayde westminster throughe london ouer london bridge hauing hym gentleman thrée rancke ueluet coates moſte greate chaines golde aboute neckes hys yeoman followed hym nobleman gentleman ſeruants al orenge tawney coates cardinalles hat • thomas cardinall embrodered vpon coates aſwell hys owne ſeruants al reſte gentleman ſeruantes hys sumpter mule whyche twentie cariage carte hys traine paſſed rode like cardinall verye ſumptuouſlye hys mule wyth ſpare mule ſpare horſe trapped crimoſin ueluet vpon veluet ſtirrops guilt folowing hym twoo great croſſes ſiluer two great pillers ſiluer king broade seale englande hys cardinal hat gentlemanne carying hys ualence otherwiſe called cloake▪ bagge whyche made fine scarlet altogyther embrodered richly golde hauing cloake thus paſſed forth throughe london waye euerye daye iourney thus furniſhed hauing hys harbengers euerye place whych prepared lodging hys traine firſt iourney made twoo myles beyond dertford kent vnto ſir thomas wiltſhires houſe reſte hys traine lodged dertford countrey thereaboutes nexte daye marched rocheſ ••• lodged byſhoppes pallaice reſt traine citie strowde third day rode feuerſham lodged abbey traine towne ſome countrey thereaboutes fourth daye rode caunterburie encountred wyth worſhipfull town country lodged priorie christchurch hys traine citie continued thrée dayes whiche ſeaſon greate fayre towne reaſon feaſt thomas canterburie whych daye ſolempne proceſſion wherein cardinal went apparelled hys legantine ornamentes hys hat heade commaunded monk quéere ſing letany ſorte sanctum maria pro papa nostra clemente cardinall knéeling stoole quéere dore monk quéere ſtoode body church ſinging letany eleauenth july cardinall arriued calleis receiued officer counſell towne maior towne maior staple proceſſion lauterne gate knéeled made prayer done paſſed vntill came saint mary churche whence repayred greate number nobleman gentleman béeing péeres towne vnto place called checker lodged kepte houſe long abode towne traine carriage landed euery thing prepared iourney called hys nobleman gentleman beyng ſeruants vnto hys priuie chamber al aſſembled hym ſayde haue called hither intent declare vnto conſider duetie beare good ſemblably beare ſéeing intendment aucthoritie haue commiſſion whiche diligent ſ • ruice wil remember hereafter therefore meane declare ſame directly king secondly ſhewe nature frenche men thirdely inſtructe howe reuerence yée ſhall vſe honor king maieſtie enforme howe ye ſhall entertaine accompanye frenche men ye ſhall méete anye time firſt poynt ye ſhall vnderſtand king maieſtie certaine waightie affaire grace hathe aduauncement royall dignitie aſſigned iorney lieuetenant reuerence belongeth ſame tell parte muſte vertue commiſſion lieuetenantſhip aſ • ume take vppon eſtéemed honor degrées ſeruice highneſſe preſence méete due nothyng neglected hys royall eſtate due appertinent parte yée ſhall ſée wyll omit one iote thereof therefore bycauſe ye ſhal ignorant dutie caſe one chiefe cauſes youre aſſembly willing haue fauour alſo charge king name ye doe forget ſame time place euerye one obſerue duety vnto accordingly ye w •• return auoide king •••• gnation▪ obtaine deſerue hys highneſſe thankes whiche ſette forth eache ſhall deſerue nowe ſeconde point nature frenche men ſuche firſte méeting familiar bin acquainted wyth long commune frenche tongue though ye vnderſtoode euerye worde therefore vſe like maner familiar wyth ſpeake natural tongue ſpeake agayne vnto▪ engliſhe tongue vnderſtande ſhall vnderſtande ſpeakyng merilye one gentlemenne welche manne ſayde rice quoth hée ſpeake welche doubt thy ſpeache ſhall defuſe hym hys frenche ſhal • hée thus quoth againe lette youre entertainement behauior according order gentleneſſe humilitie may reported departure thence ye gentleman right good behauiour muche gentleneſſe ye men knowe dueties soueraigne lord maiſter eſtéeming muche youre greate reuerence thus ſhall ye onelye obtaine youre ſelues greate commendation praiſe ſame alſo aduaunce honor prince countrey nowe go wayes admoniſhed al theſe pointes prepare ſelues againſte morrowe intende god willing ſet forwarde nexte morrowe béeing mary magdalen day thyngs béeing furniſhed cardinal aduanced calleis wyth ſuche number blacke ueluet coates hath béene ſeldome ſéene embaſſador al péeres calleis guiſnes al gentleman beſides traine béeyng garniſhed blacke ueluet coates chaines golde thus paſſed hée forwarde wyth traine gentleman thrée rancke ſuppoſall endured thrée quarter myle length hauyng croſſes accuſtomed glorious furniture carryed haue rehearſed excepte broade seale whyche lefte calleis wyth doctour taylour maiſter rolles vntil returne paſſing thus hys way ſcantly rydden myle beganne raine ſo vehemently lightly béene ſéene like whyche endured vntill came boloinge ere came sandingfielde cardinal loraine goodly yong gentleman encountred cardinall englande receyued great ioy reuerence▪ ſo paſſed forth wyth cardinal communication vntil came nigh vnto ſaide sandingfielde whych place religion ſtanding betwéene engliſhefrenche emperours dominion beyng newter holding neyther awayted le countie brian capitaine pycardie greate number • radiates albenois ſtandyng arraye greate péece gréene oates harneſſe vpon high horſes paſſing cardinall wing vnto bolongne ſo throughe picardie▪ ••• cardinal doubted ſomewhat emperour ſhould lay ſome ambuſh betray hym whyche cauſe french kyng commaunded attende vppon hym aſſuraunce perſon thus rode vntil came within one engliſhe myle bolongne encountred hym worſhipfull citizen towne bolongne hauing learned man made vnto hym oration latine vnto whyche cardinall ſemblably made anſweare done monſieur de bee capitaine bolongne retinue gentleman mette wyth horſebacke al aſſembly rode town lighting abbey gate thence conueyed wyth proceſſion abbey churche offered went abbey hys lodging traine lodged high baſe townes next morning hée rode mutterell ser lemere like caſe encountred worſhipful towne al one lyuerie hauing learned man make oration vnto thē latine whome aunſwered alſo latine entred gate canapie made readie ſilke embrodered letter hat euen men coates lighted footemen ſame fée due office nowe made dyuers pageant ioy comming called frenche tong al place throughe realme rode came le cardinall pacifique nexte daye hée tooke hys iourney towardes abvile hée encountred wyth diuers gentleman towne countrey ſo recey • ed towne pageant rode thorough towne hauing lyke canapie borne ouer richer ſo broughte hys lodgy • g thys towne remayned eyght dayes reſorted dayly diuers frenche king counſell ſitting counſell euerye daye continually feaſting time came hys departing towne rode caſtell beyonde water called le chanel de picqiny adioyning ſaide watch vpon rocke wythin whyche colledge prieſts ſcituation whereof much like vnto caſtel windſore receiued ſolemnne proceſſion lodged nighte nexte morning cardinall rode towarde amiens paſſing way encountred noble perſonages made diuers oration whiche anſwered extempore afterwarde frenche king goodly company mette cardinal embraced eche preace ſo thicke diuers leg hurt horſes king cardinall right hande rode forth towardes amiens euery engliſhe gentleman accompanyed fraunce traine theſe two • prince endured two long engliſhe myles nobly receyued towne amiens ſhot gun coſtly pageant vntil king brought cardinall lodging departed nighte king lodged biſhoppes pallaice next daye dinner cardinal rode courte king whiche time king kepte bedde yet neuertheleſſe cardinall came bed▪chamber one king halfe like wiſe denided long gallerie béetwéen thē made midſt ſtrong wal window dore king cardinal would many time méete ſame window talke diuers time woulde goe ſaid dore came lord cardinal y• lord chancelor france al king counſellers toke great paine dayly conſultation inſomuch y• cardinall england fel chancelor france laying hys charge went hinder league whyche comming cōcluded inſomuch madam regent hir ſelf many noble france much labor trauel coulde ſcarcely bring cardinal former ſtate communitation ſuche wroth againſt chancelor theſe meanes brought thing paſſe could attaine whiche feare affection matter heades counſell ſo vnder gyrdle next morning conflict roſe early foure clocke ſate downe write letter englande vnto king commaundyng hys chapleines prepare hym ready ſay maſſe inſomuch chaplaine ſtoode veſtures vntill four clocke afternoone al ſeaſon cardinal neuer roſe eate drinke make water continually wrote aboute houre foure afternoone made end commaunding chriſtopher gunner king ſeruant without delay ride poſt englande thoſe letter whome diſpatched away euer dranke went maſſe ſaid ſeruice chapleine went bothe dinner ſupper nexte night cardinall made great suppe • madam regent quéene nauar ••• ate eſtates lady noble woman middeſt ſaid banquet▪ king fraunce ni •••• ▪ came ſo day • elye vnlooked tooke place loweſt parte banqu • t▪ ſupper banquet finiſhed ladyes gentleman fell daūcing ſo paſſed awaye moſte nighte ere departed shortely king cauſed wilde bore lodged reſt champaigne thither cardinal rode wyth hym ſée hym hunt▪ lady regent number ladyes damoiſels ſtandyng chariot looking toyle oute ſide whyche pitched purpoſe among ſtoode cardinal regarde hunting madam regent chariot wythin toyle king diuers minion gentleman fraunce readye furnyſhed thys highe daungerous enteprice hunting king beyng doublet hozen ſhéepes colour cloth hauing •• ippe brace greate white greyhoundes armed maner reſte king gentleman appoynted hunte bore likewiſe doublet hoſs▪ holdyng eache theyr handes verye ſharpe bore ſpeares king commaunded kéepers vncouche bore euerye perſon béeing within toile ſhould go ſtanding among whome dyuers gentleman yeoman englande▪ incontinent bore iſſued den followed hounde came plaine béeing ſcaled whyle gazing vpon people incontinent pierced hounde ſpyed lyttle buſhe ſtanding behinde banke ouer ditche vnder whiche laye two frenche gentleman thither fledde truſting haue defended himſelfe thruſt head ſnuffing ſame buſhe whyche cauſed two gentleman flye thence danger death bore purſuite hunter hounde driuen thence ranne ſtraighte one cardinalles foote▪men ta •• yong yeoman hadde handes •••• line whiche faine defende hymſelf bore greate bore continually • oyning hym tuſkes ſo faine laſte pitche iaueline grounde betwéene bore whiche bore brake force hys foyning yeoman drew hys ſword ſtoode defence therewith hunter came reſcue putte againe flight fledde yong gentleman england called maiſter henry ratcliffe ſonne heyre lorde fitz walter borrowed chance frenche▪ gentleman fine ſharp bore ſpeare thruſte bore mouth ſo throate wherevpon paſtime ended cardinall paſſing diuers dayes conſultation matter ioy wyth ryſing euerye man place cardinall cauſed thē ſit ſtill kéepe roumes beyng hys apparell rode called chayre ſate midſt highe table anone came vppe ſeconde courſe ſo many diſhes ſuttleties deuiſes aboue hundred number whiche ſo goodly proportion coſtly think french men neuer ſawe like wonder leſſe worthy indéede caſtels wyth image ſame paules church quantitie • counterfaited paynter ſhoulde haue painted cloth wall beaſtes byrdes perſonages moſte likely made counterfaited ſome fightyng wyth swordes ſome wyth gunnes croſſebowes ſome vaughting leaping ſome dauncing ladyes ſome gaue ſame gentleman france commaunding ſhoulde made goodly cace preſeruation thereof haſte might conuey ſame hys countrey tooke lord bole gold filled ipocraſe putting hys cappe ſayde drinke kyng soueraigne lord next vnto king maſter therwith dranke good draught done deſired graund maiſter pledge hym cuppe whyche well worth fiue hundred markes ſo cauſed bourdes pledge theſe twoo royall prince wente cuppes ſo merily aboute manye frenche menne faine ledde beddes roſe vppe cardinall went hys priui • chamber pul bootes ſhifte hym wente ſupper priuie chamber▪ making verye ſhorte ſupper returned chamber preſence among frenche menne vſing ſo louingly familiarly coulde commende hym muche whileſt communication paſtimes al lyueries ſerued chābers euerye chamber hadde baſon ewer ſiluer great liuery pot ſiluer ſome guilt yea ſome chamber hadde two lyuerie pot wyth wine béere ſiluer candleſticke white plaine hauing twoo cizes ſtaffe torche ware fine manchet chete loafe thus euerye chamber furniſhed al houſe yet cupbords two banquetting chamber touched thus time conuenient conueyed lodging reſted night morning dyned cardinall ſo departed windſore returne ſtrangers windſore place order therof much commended day approched king inuited courte firſte dyned daū • ing paſtimes done time ſupper came banquetting chamber tylte yarde greenewiche whyche place theſe ſtrangers conducted honor eſtimation plate ſome valewe thrée foure hundred pound ſome ſome leſſe beſides greate gift receyued king gownes ueluet riche furres greate chaynes golde goodlye horſes wyth dyuers giftes leaſte knowe opinion learned thoſe uniuerſities concerning marriage betwixt king henry quéene katherine ſometime brother wife marriage ſéemed bée vnlawfull affirmed vnder perticular ſeale euery uniuerſititie moneths aprill may june july cardinall1527 campeius legate cardinall wolſey ſate blacke frier london broughtanno reg 21 queſtion king mariage quéene katherine vnlawfull theſe two legate ſate judgesthe king mariage vvith queene katherine called queſtion blacke frier whome king quéene aſſited ſommoned appeare court platted table bench manner conſiſtorie one ſeate reyſed higher judge ſitte midſt ſaid judge al oft aboue thrée degrées high cloth eſtate hanged chaire royall vnder ſame wherein ſate king beſides ſome diſtance ſate quéene vnder judge féete ſate scribe officer chiefe scribe doctor stephen caller court one cooke winchester king judge within court ſate archbiſhop canterbury warham biſhops ſtoode endes within counſellours learned spirituall lawes well king quéenes doctor law king doctor simpſon doctor bell diuers proctor ſame ſide doctor peter doctor tregon • others ſide quéene doctor fiſher doctor standiſh doctor ridley thus court furniſhed judge commanded ſilence whileſt commiſſon red court people aſſembled done scribe commaunded crier call king name king henry england come court c king anſwered ſayde héere called hée quéene name katherine quéene englande come court c made anſwere roſe hir chaire bycauſe ſhe could come king directly diſtance ſeuered betwéene ſhe wente aboute court came king knéeling downe hys féete whome ſhe ſayde effect followeth sir quoth ſhe deſire iuſtice right take ſome pitie vpon poore woman▪ stranger borne dominion hauing héere indifferent counſell leſſe aſſurance frendſhip ala sir haue offended occaſion diſpleaſure haue ſhewed intending thus put ſorte take god judge haue bin true humble wife euer confirmable pleaſure neuer contraryed gayneſayde thing thereof béeing alwayes contented thing wherein anye delight whether little much without grudge diſpleaſure loued ſake whome loued whether friendes enimies haue bin wife theſe twentye yeares moe haue dyuers child iuſt cauſe alledge agaynſte eyther diſhoneſtie matter lawfull put contente departe ſhame rebuke none pray let haue juſtice youre hande king father hys tyme excellente witte king spayne father ferdinando reckned one wiſeſt prince raigned spayne many yeares doubted gathered wiſe counſellours vnto euery realme wiſedomes thought méete thought marriage betwéene good lawfull c wherefore humblye deſire ſpare untill may knowe councell friendes spayne wyll aduertiſe take youre pleaſure bée fulfilled wyth ſhe aroſe vp making low curteſie king departed thence king béeyng aduertiſed ſhe ready goe houſe commanded crier call hir agayne called hir theſe wordes katherine quéene englande come courte wyth quoth mayſter griffith madame bée called agayne quoth ſhe maketh matter wyll tarrie goe youre wayes thus ſhe departed wythoute anye aunſwere tyme anye neuer woulde appeare court king perceyuing ſhe departed ſayde theſe wordes effect much quoth quéene gone hir abſence declare onto hathe bene true obediente confirmable wife would wiſh deſire ſhe hath vertuous quality ought woman hir dignitie baſer eſtate ſhe alſo ſurely noble woman borne hir condition well declare ſame quoth cardinall wolſey sir moſt humbly require highneſſe declare audience whether haue bin chiefe firſt mouer matter vnto maieſtie greatly ſuſpected héerein lord cardinall quoth king well excuſe matter mary quoth ye haue bin rather againſt tempting héereof ſetter forward mouer ſame ſpeciall cauſe moued vnto matter certayne ſcrupuloſitie pricked cōſcience vpon certaine word ſpoken time biſhop bayon french embaſſador bin hyther ſente vpon debating marriage concluded betwéene daughter lady mary duke orleance ſecond ſonne king france vpon reſolution determination ſame deſired reſpect aduertiſe king mayſter thereof whether daughter mary ſhould legitimate reſpect marriage woman ſometime brother wife worde • conceyued within ſecret bottome conſcience engendred ſuche ſcrupulous doubt conſcience incontiently accombred vexed diſquieted whereby thought ſelfe bée greatly danger god indignation appeared ſéemed rather ſente v iſſue male ſuch iſſues male ſaid wife died incontient came worlde ſo doubted great diſpleaſure god behalfe thus conſcience toſſed waues ſcrupulous conſcience partly deſpaire haue iſſue already lady wife behoued conſider ſtate realme danger ſtoode lacke prince ſuccéede thought good releaſſe weighty burthou •• ake conſcience alſo quiet eſtate worthy realme attempt law therein whether may lawfully take another wi • e lawfully whome god may ſende iſſue caſe firſt copulation good without carnall concupiſcen • e diſpleaſure miſliking quéenes perſon age whome would well contented continue marriage may ſtand lawes god woman aliue poynt▪ conſiſteth doubt go trie learning wiſedome iudgement prelate paſtoures realme domini •• héere aſſembled purpoſe whoſe conſcience 〈…〉 learning haue committed charge iudgement according whiche god willing right well content ſubmit 〈…〉 part obey ſame wherein perceyued ••• ſc • ence ſo ••• tfull moued confeſſion ••• 〈…〉 •• 〈…〉 ghoſtly father ••• much • • 〈…〉 〈…〉 ſelf ſome doubt •• ued 〈…〉 counſell lord wherevpon moued lord canterbury firſt haue •• ence much metropolitane put matter queſtion ſo lordes granted vnder seales héere ſhewed truth quoth archbiſhop canterbury king roſe vp court adiourned vntill another day next court day cardinal ſate againe time counſell ſides 〈…〉 anſwere king counſell alledged matrimonie lawfull beginning bycauſe ••• nall copulation betwéene prince arthure quéene matter vehemently touched ſide proue alledged many reaſons ••• ilitudes truth anſwered negatiuely againe ſide ſéemed former allegation doubtfull tryed man knewe truth thus court paſſed seſſions seſſions day day certayne seſſions king ſent two cardinalles quéene bridewell perſwade hir wiſedomes aduiſe hir ſurrender whole matter king hand hir owne conſent ſhould much better hir honour ſtand triall law thereby condemned whiche ſhoulde ſéeme much hir diſhonour cardinalles béeing queenes chamber preſence gentleman uſher aduertiſed quéene cardinalles come ſpeake hir • roſe vp skeyne white th • ead hir ••• ke came hir▪ chamber preſence cardinalles attending whoſe comming quoth ſh • pleaſure pleaſe grace quoth cardinall wolſey goe int • pri • ie chamber ſhew cauſe oure comming lord quoth ſhe yée haue thing ſay ſpeake openly theſe f •• ke feare nothing yée ſay againſt would worlde ſhould heare ſée therefore ſpeake minde began cardinall ſpeake hir latine nay good lord quoth ſhe ſpeake engliſh • forſ • th quoth cardinall good madame pleaſe come knowe mind diſpoſed matter betwéene king alſo declare ſecretly opinion councell vnto whiche zeale obedience beare vnto grace lord quoth ſhe thanke youre god make anſwere requeſt ſo ſodeinly ſet among maydes worke thinking full little ſuch matter wherein néedeth longer deliberation better head mine make anſwere fo • néede councell caſe toucheth ſo néere councel friendſhip find england profite thinke lord engliſhman councell friendly againſt king pleaſure ſubiect nay forſ • th counſell whome put truſt spayne mine owne countrey lordes poore woman lacking witte anſwere ſuch noble perſons wiſedome ſo waightie matter therefore pray good vnto poore woman deſtitute friend héere forrayne region counſell alſo glad heare therewith ſhe tooke cardinall hand lēdde hir priuie chamber cardinall tarried ſeaſon talking quéene communication ended departed king making relation hir talke thus caſe went forward frō court court till came judgemente ſo euery men expected iūdgement would giuen next day day king came thither ſet downe chaire within dore end y• galery opened directly againſt iudgemēt ſeate heare iudgement giuen time procéedings openly red lattin done king counſell y• barre called iudgemēt y• quoth cardinall campeius wil giue iudgemēt till haue made relation y• pope procéedings whoſe councel cōmandemēt •• ſe wil obſerue caſe doubtful alſo party defendāt wil make anſwer héere doth rather apeale frō v ſuppoſing y• indifferent wherefore ••• ourne court time according order y• court rome y• court diſſolued done protracting concluſion matter • henry tooke diſpleaſātly cardinall depart ſimply vnto aſher houſe ſcituate nigh vnto hampton court belonging biſhopricke winchester cardinall demanded commiſſion gaue ſuch authoritie anſwered againe ſufficient commiſſioners authoritie doe leſſe king mouth notwithſtanding woulde wiſe agrée behalfe withoute further▪ knowledge authoritie ſaying great seale deliuered king perſon enioy miniſtration • hereof roome chancellor tearme life whereof ſuretie king letter pattents matter greatly debated betwéene many great wordes ſo much duke ſayne depart againe without purpoſe r • de windeſore king made report accordingly next day returned walles gallory one ſide cloth gold cloth tiſſue cloth siluer rich cloth bodken diuers colour ſide hanged richeſt ſuite coapes owne prouiſion made hys colledges oxford ipſwich euer ſéene england two kinde plate euery parcell content ounce thereof thus thing prepared giuing charge ſaid ſtuffe remaining euery office deliuered king make anſwere charge order ſuch euery officer charged ye receipt countrey abbot prior hauing notice ſtaulatiō ſent ſuch prouiſion victuall almoſt incredible whiche vnknowne cardinall much preuented diſappoynted purpoſe reaſon arreſted high treaſon yée ſhall vpon alhallowen day hauing boordes ende dyuers chaplaynes ſitting dinner ye ſhall vnderſtand cardinalles great croſſe ſtoode corner table end leaning againſt hanging bordes end taken vp conuenient time chaplaines ariſe one doctor auguſtine venetian phiſition cardinall riſing table hauing vppon great gowne boyſteous ueluet ouerthrew croſſe whiche • rayling downe along tappet point one croſſes brake doctor bonars head thatdoctor bonars head broke bloud ran downe company ſtanding greatly aſtonied chance cardinall perceyuing ſame demanded matter meant ſodeine amaze ſhewed fall croſſe vppon doctor bonars head hath quoth drawne bloud yea forſooth lord quoth caſt head aſide ſaid ſhaking head malum omen therewith ſaid grace roſe table went chamber marke ſignificatiō cardinal expounded matter pomfret fall firſt ye ſhall vnderſtand croſſe bare archbiſhop yorke ſignified himſelfe auguſtine phiſition ouerthrewe croſſe accuſed cardinall whereby enimies caught occaſion ouerthrow fell ſeruants place kéepe gate knowe ſeruant ye haue able kéepe gate purpoſe whatſoeuer alſo keyes deliuered lord mayſter wherefore pray pardon whatſoeuer ye ſhall commaund miniſtratiō mine office ſhall good quoth earle hold booke cōmaunded lay hand theron thou ſhalt • weare quoth thou ſhalt well truly kéepe gate king vſe doe ſuch thing ſhall commaund ye ſhal let paſſe neither theſe gate ſuch ye commaunded v oth receiued keyes earles hand theſe doings knewe cardinall nothing ſtopped ſteire ſo none went vp cardinal chamber came downe could go vp againe laſt one eſcaped ſhewed cardinall earle hall wherat cardinall maruelled would beléeue cōmaunded gentleman bring truth going downe ſtaires ſaw earle northumberland returned ſaid quoth cardinall • haue dined feare officer prouided ſtore good fiſhe make ſome honourable chéere let table ſtande quoth roſe vp going downe y• ſtaires encountred earle cōming vp tayle ſoone cardinal eſpied y• earle put • ay ſaid lord ye moſt hartily welcome ſo embraced cardinall tooke earle hand ••• vp chamber whome followed number earles ſe •• ant thence led bedchamber al alone earle ſaid vnto cardinall ſoft voice laying hande vpō arme lord arreſt high▪ treaſon word ye cardinal maruellouſly aſtonied ſtā ding ſtil good ſpace laſt quoth cardinall authority haue arreſt forſooth l quoth • earle haue cōmiſſiō ſo cōmiſſion quoth may ſée nay ſir may ſayde earle well quoth cardinall obey reſt debating matter betwéene chamber ſo buſie walſh arreſting doctor auguſtine dore ye pallace ſaying vnto go traytor ſhal make thée laſt walſh entred cardinal chamber began plucke hoode knéeled cardinall vnto cardinal ſaid come hither gentlemā let ſpeake sir héere lord northumberland hath arreſted whoſe authoritie ſheweth ye ioyned pray ſhew indéede lord quoth walſh ſheweth truth well quoth cardinall pray let ſée sir beſéech quoth walſh hold v excuſed annexed cōmiſſiō certaine inſtructions may ſée well quoth ye cardinall trow ye one king priuie chamber name walſh content yéeld lord northumberland without ſée commiſſion worſt king priuie chamber ſufficiēt arreſt greateſt péere realme king commandement without commiſſion therefore put commiſſion authoritie execution ſpare obey king take god judge neuer offended kyng worde déede earle called chamber diuers gentleman owne ſeruauntes taken cardinalles keyes put cuſtodie earles gentleman went houſe ſet thing order thē ſent doctor auguſtine▪ away london much ſpéede could boune vnto horſſe like traytor sunday toward night ere cardinal conuayd cawod lodged night abbey pomfret next day remoued towarde daneaster lodged blacke frier nexte day remoued shefilde parke earle shrewſburie lady traine gentlemē gentlewoman receyued much honor departed great number gentleman conducted thether cardinall thus y• earle shrewſburie cōtinued xviij dayes vpō whome earle appointed diuers gentleman attend cōtinually ſée ſhould lacke nothing béeing ſerued owne chamber honourably houſe euery day earle would repaire vnto commune cardinall thus remained earle shrewſburie aboute fortnight came paſſe certaine time ſate dinner chāber hauing boords end meſſe gentleman chaplaines kéepe company toward y• end dinner come eating hys fruites colour perceyued often change whereby iudged▪ good health vpon one ofthe cardinall • ickne ••• gentleman ſaid sir ſéemes well eaſe whome anſwered loude voice forfooth quoth taken ſod • inly thing ſtomacke lyeth along colde whetſtone wind pray go po • icarie enquire •• haue thing wil breake winde vpward went earle ſh • wed eſtate cardinall deſired earle cauſed poticarie called demanded thing would breake wind vpward man body anſwered ſuch geare quoth earle fetch ſome thē y• apoticary fetched white cōfectiō fair paper ſhewed y• erle cōmanded one giue ye aſſay therof y• ſame brought cardinall receiued vp al mouth immediatly ſurely auoided much wind vpward • quoth ye may ſée wind nowe well eaſed thanke god ſo roſe frō table went hys prayer done came ſuche looſeneſſe cauſed •• go ſtoole long ye erle shrewſburie came y• gallery ye cardinall met ſitting vpon bench ye erle aſked moſt lamētably anſwered thanked gentle entertainment sir quoth erle ye remember ye haue often wiſhed come king make anſwer▪ haue writtē ye king y• behalf making priuie lamentation ye inwardly haue receiued hys diſpleaſure accepteth al doings therin friend accuſtoind ſuch caſes wherfore wold aduiſe plucke vp hart agaſt enimies doubt iorney highneſſe ſhal much aduancement king hath ſent worſhipful knight maiſter kingſton 24 old ſeruāts ye guard intēt ye may ſafely come maieſtie ſir quoth cardinal trow maſter kingſton cōſtable tower • ea quoth y• erle aſſure elected ye king one friend wel quoth cardinal god wil ſo ſubiect fortune true man ready accept ſuch chance ſhal folow end pray maſter kingſton quoth earle wil ſend hym pray ſo ••• th cardinal whoſe meſſage came ſoone cardinal eſpyed made haſt encounter cōming knéeled ſaluted king behalf whō ye cardinal barehaded offered take vp ſaid pray ſtande vp knéele wretch repleat miſerie eſtéeming ſelfe vile ab • ecte vtterly caſt away without deſert god knoweth 〈◊〉 ſaid maſter kingſton humble reuerence sir y• king hath commonded vnto thanke highnes quot • cardinall truſt health yea quoth maiſter kingſton commanded ſaye ſhoulde aſſure ſelfe beareth muche good wil euer willeth good chéere report hath bin made▪ y• ye ſhould cōmit againſt hym certain heinous crime thinketh vntrue yet doe leſſe ſende triall take iorney owne pleaſure cōmanding attendant vpon you▪ therfore ſir pray ſhall pleaſure take iorney ſhall ready gi • e attēdāce maiſter kingſton quoth thāke newes ſir luſtie haue béen late▪ would ride poſt diſeaſed flixe maketh weake ſhal wyth al ſpéede make ready ryde morrow night came cardinall waxed ſicke laſke whyche cauſed continually go ſtoole al night▪ inſomuch night 50▪ ſtooles therefore conſideration infirmitie cauſed tarry al day next day tooke iorney maiſter kingſton guard til came houſe earle shrewſburies called hardwike hall lay al night euill eaſe▪ nexte day rode notingham •• lodged night ſicke nexte daye rode leicester abbey waye waxed ſo ſicke almoſte fallen mule ſo night came abbey leicester comming gate abbot al cou • nt met diuers torch light whome honourablye receyued welcommed whome cardinall ſayde father abbot come hyther laye bone among riding ſo ſtill vntil came ſ • ayres chamber alighted hys mule maiſter kingſton led vppe ſtayres ſoone chamber went bedde▪ satterday nighte encreaſed ſicker ſicker vntil monday men thought woulde haue dyed tuiſday saint andrewes euen maiſter kingſton came hym bade good morrowe • • e clocke aſked howe didde sir quoth tarry pleaſure god render vppe poore ſoule handes ſo •• r quoth maiſter kingſtone wyth grace god yée ſhall liue doe verye well yée good chéere nay good ſooth maiſter kingſtone diſeaſe ſuche liue haue hadde ſome experience phiſicke thus haue fluxe continuall feuer nature whereof alteration ſame wythin eyghte dayes either muſte enſue excorrition entra • le • ra • ſie elſe preſent death▪ beſte death ſuppoſe thys eyghte daye yée ſée alteration remedy ſaue though may liue daye twaine death muſte enſue syr quoth maiſter kingſtone bée ſuche penſiueneſſe doubting thing good faith ye néede well wel maiſter kingſtone quoth cardinall ſée matter howe framed hadde ſerued god diligently haue done king woulde haue gyuen ouer grey haires iuſte rewarde muſte receiue diligent paine ſtudy haue hadde doe ſeruice regarding ſeruice god onelye ſatiſfie pleaſure pray haue moſte humbly commended vnto royall maieſtye beſéeche behalfe call hys prince •• e remembraunce matter procéeding betwéene hym▪ beginning worlde progreſſe ſame c maiſter kingſtone farewell ſaye wiſhe thing haue good ſucceſſe tyme draweth faſt euen beganne drawe ſpeach length tongue faile eye béeyng ſette▪ whoſe ſighte fayled hym dydde putte hym remembraunce chryſte hys paſſion ••• ſed • yeoman y• ••• ard • ſtand ſée dye 〈◊〉 wor •• departure incontinent clocke ſtroke eyght gaue vp ghoſt departed preſent life whych cauſed ſome call remembrance howe ſaide daye •• ght clocke ſhoulde loſe maiſter ende fall pride arrogancie menexample pride arrogancie exalted fortune dignity hys tyme haughtieſt man hys procéedings alyue hauing reſpecte honor perſon hys baſtarde ſonne duke norffolke lord treaſurer england duke suffolke marqueſſe excester erles darby arundale oxforde surrey rutlande vicount liſle king edwarde fourth baſtarde ſonne lord matrauers norton ſir richarde sandes ſir iohn neuell thyrtie eſquiers manye gentlemenne theyr traines towne calleis thys ſeaſon xxiiij c beddes ſtabling two thouſande horſes beſides uillages xxj october king henrie rode towarde boloigne waye sandingfielde mette frenche king many noble france rode al boloigne lodged xxv october king henrie returned againe calleis accompanied frenche king king nauarre cardinall loraine many duke byſhoppes great eſtates fraunce gaſ • oine brytaine normandie xxviij october kyng henrie made king nauarre knight garter nexte daye frenche king king nauarre greate lordes fraunce rode againe boloigne king henrie englande rode wyth sandingfielde made frenche king coſtlye banquet thrée king departed like louing brother great amitie xiiij nouēber king henrie landed douer richard reynold nicholas pinchon 28 september sherifes iohn martin butcher sir stephen pecocke haberdaſher 28 october maior kyng henrie kepte hys chriſtmaſſe greenewiche chriſtmaſſe ſir thomas audeley lord kéeper great seale made lord chauncelor england beganne parliament whiche enacted perſon ſhoulde appeale anye cauſe oute thys realme court rome alſo quéene katherine ſhoulde thenceforth called quéene princeſſe dowager prince arthur twelfth aprill eaſter euen ladye1533 anno reg 25 anne bolleine hadde béene priuily marryed kyng henrie wente hir cloſet openly quéene proclaymed quéene englande ſixe twentith aprill arthure plantagenet ſonne illegitime kyng edwarde fourth created viſcount liſle bridewell twelfth may pauier towne clearke london hung himſelfe king highneſſe addreſſed letter maior communaltie london ſignifying vnto pleaſure ſolempnize coronation moſt deare welbeloued wife quéene anne westminster whitſonday next enſuing willing make preparation well fetche hir grace greenewiche tower water ſée citie garniſhed wyth pageant place accuſtomed honor hir grace ſhée ſhoulde conueyed tower westminster wherevppon common counſell called commaundement gyuen haberdaſhers whiche craft maior ſhoulde prepare barge bachelers wyth wafter foyſte garniſhed wyth banner lyke vſe maior preſented westminster morrowe feaſt saint simon iude alſo craftes commaunded prepare barge garniſhe onely banner accuſtomed alſo decke target ſides barge ſette vppe ſuche ſéemely banner banneret hadde hal • e coulde get furniſhe theyr ſayde barge euery barge haue minſtrels according whych commaundement greate preparation made thyngs neceſſary ſuche noble triumph nine twentith daye may béeing thurſeday▪ maior brother scarlet ſuch knightes hadde collar eſſes reſidue hauyng greate chaines counſell citie aſſembled saint marie hill one clocke deſcended newe ſteire barge whyche garniſhed manye goodly banner ſtreamers richly couered whiche barge shalmes shagebuſhes▪ dyuers inſtruments muſicke whiche played continually maior hys brother barge ſéeing company number fiftie barge readye waite vppon them▪ gaue commaundement company barge ſhould rowe nearer another twice length barge ſée order kepte thrée whirries prepared euerye one two officer call kéepe order whyche commaundement giuen ſet forth order hereafter deſcribed firſte maiors barge foiſte wafter full ordinaunce whyche foyſte greate redd • dragon continuallye •••• ng caſting wilde fire rounde aboute ſayde foiſte ſtoode terrible monſtrous wild men casting fire▪ making hideous noiſe nexte foiſte good diſtaunce came maiors barge whoſe righte hande ••• bachelers barge whyche trum 〈…〉 dyuers melodious inſtrumentes 〈…〉 ſayde barge ſaile yardes toppe •••• elles hanged wyth ryche cloth golde 〈…〉 foreſhippe sterne two greate banner ryche beaten wyth armes king quéene aud ſoppe caſtell alſo long ſtreamer newly beaten ſaide armes ſides barge ſette full flagges banner deuices companyes haberdaſhers merchaunt aduenturers laſſerers cordes hanged wyth innumerable penſelles hauing lyttle belle endes whyche made goodlye noyſe goodlye ſighte wauering winde ſide barge thrée dozen scutcheon mettall armos kyng quéene whiche beaten vppon ſquare buckeram deuided ſo righte ſide hadde king▪ colour lefte ſide quéenes whyche scutcheon faſtened clothes golde ſiluer hauging deckes lefte hand maior foyſte whyche mounte mounte ſtoode white faulcon crowned vppon roote golde enuironed wyth white roſes redde whyche quéenes deuice aboute whyche mounte ſate uirgins ſinging playing melodiouſlye next mayor followed hys felowſhippe haberdaſhers nexte mercer grocer ſo euerye company hys order laſte maiors sheriffes officer euery company hauing melodie barge ſelues goodly garniſhed wyth banne • ſome couered wyth sylke ſome wyth arras ſuche like goodly ſight beholde thy • • er rowed greenewiche pointe beyende greenwiche turned backward order▪ • wéete maiors sherifs officer firſte meaneſt crafte nexte ſo aſcencendyng vpper moſte crafte order maior laſte thy goe paules chriſtmaſſe order wed downe warde greenewiche towne▪ caſte ancker makyng greate melodie thrée clocke quéene apparelled riche cloth golde entred hir barge accompanyed wyth dyuers ladyes gentlewoman incontinent citizen ſet forward order theyr minſtrels continually playing y• bachelers barge going quéenes right hand whyche ſhée tooke greate pleaſure beholde aboute quéenes barge manye noble menne duke suffolke marque dorcet earle wiltſhire hir father earles arundale darby rutland worcester huntington suſſex oxforde many byſhops noble men euerye one hys barge whyche goodly ſight beholde ſhée thus accompanyed rowed towardes tower meane waye shippes whyche commanded lye ſhoare letting barge ſhotte dyuers peales gunnes ere ſhe landed maruellous ſhotte tower neuer hearde like hir landing mette wyth hir lord chamberlaine officer armes brought hir king whych receyued hir louing countenance poſterne water ſide kiſſed hir ſhée turned backe agayne thanked mayor citizen wyth manye goodly wordes ſo entred tower whyche entrye citizen houered tower makyng greate melodie went alande none aſſigned lande maior recorder two alderman ſpeake people ſtoode euerye ſhoare beholde ſighte hée ſa • e beléeue friday dinner ſerued king ſuche appoynted hys higheneſſe knight bathe whiche dinner brought chamber nighte bathed ſhriuen
