may quéenethe conueying queen anne citie vveſtm conueyed london order followeth intente horſes ſhoulde ſlide pauement people ſhoulde hurte horſes highe ſtréetes where▪throughe quéene ſhould paſſe graueled tower vnto temple barre rayled eche ſide wythin whiche raile ſtoode craftes along order grace churche merchauntes stiliarde ſtoode vntill lyttle conduite cheape alderman ſtoode ſide ſtréete ſtoode coneſtables citie apparelled ueluet silke wyth greate ſtaues handes cauſe people giue roume kéepe good order ſtréetes ſomewhat ordered mayor gowne crimoſin veluet riche collar eſſes two footemen clothed white red damaſke rode tower giue hys attendaunce quéene whome sherifes officer awaite till came tower hill taking leaue rode downe high ſtréetes commaunding coneſtables ſée roume good order kept ſo wente ſtoode alderman cheape quéen hir traine ſhould come graceſtreete cornehill hanged fine scarlet crimoſin grayned clothes ſome place riche arras moſte part cheape hanged cloth tiſſhew golde ueluet many riche hanging whyche made goodlye ſhewe windowes repleniſhed lady gentlewoman beholde quéene hir traine ſhoulde paſſe firſte quéenes company ſette forwarde twelue french men belonging frenche embaſſadoure clothed contes blewe ueluet wyth ſléeues yellow blew ueluet horſes trapped cloſe trapper blewe ſarſenet powdred white croſſes marched gentleman eſquiers knight two two iudges knight bathe violet gownes hood purfled miniuer like doctor abbot baron biſhoppes earles marqueſſes lorde chanceloure englande hym archebyſhoppe yorke embaſſadoure venice archebyſhoppe caunterburie embaſſadour fraunce rode twoo eſquyers honor wyth robe eſtate rolled worne bauldrikewiſe aboute neckes wyth cappes eſtate repreſenting duke normandie aquitaine rode mayor london wyth hys mace garter hys coate armes whyche bare alſo hys mace westminster hall rode lorde wyllyam howarde wyth marſhalls rod deputy hys brother duke norffolke marſhall englande whyche embaſſadoure fraunce hys righte hande rode charles duke suffolk daye highe coneſtable englande bearing warder ſiluer appertayning office coneſtableſhippe lordes moſte parte clothed crimoſin ueluet quéenes ſeruauntes officer armes scarlet next quéene rode hir chancelor bare headed sergeaunts officer armes rode ſides lord came quéene white litter white cloth golde couered bailled whyche ledde twoo palfrey clad white damaſke downe grounde heade ledde hir footemen ſhée hadde kertle white cloth tiſſue mantle ſame ſurred wyth ermyn hir haire hangyng downe hir heade ſhée hadde coy • e wyth circlet aboute full ryche ſtones ouer hir borne canapie cloth golde wyth foure guylte ſtaues foure ſiluer belle bearyng whyche canapie appoynted ſixetéene knightes foure beare one ſpace foote foure ſpace according owne appoyntment nexte quéene rode lorde browghe hir chamberlayne nexte wyllyam coffim maſter hir horſes leading ſpare horſe wyth ſyde saddell trapped downe wyth cloth tiſſewe hym rode ſeauen lady crimoſin ueluet turned vppe wyth cloth golde tiſſewe theyr horſes trapped wyth golde twoo chariot couered wyth redde cloth golde firſte chariote twoo lady whyche olde dutcheſſe norffolke olde marchioneſſe dorcet ſeconde chariot foure ladyes crimoſin ueluet rode ſeauen ladyes ſame ſute horſes trapped came thyrde charyot white wyth ſyxe ladyes crimoſin ueluet nexte came fourth chariot red eyghte ladyes alſo crimoſin whome followed thirtie gentlewoman ueluet sylke lyuerie ladyes whome gaue theyr attendaunce followed guarde coates goldeſmyths worke whyche order rode forthe tyll came fanchurche made pageaunt child apparelled like merchantes whyche welcomed hir citie wyth twoo proper propoſitions bothe frenche engliſhe thence ſhe rode vnto grace churche corner coſtlye maruellous cunning pageaunt made merchantes stiliarde therein mounte pernaſſus wyth fountaine helicon whyche white marble foure ſtreames wythoute pype dydde ryſe ell hyghe mette togyther little cuppe aboue fountaine whych fountaine ranne abundantly rackte reyniſhe wine till night mountaine ſate apollo hys féete ſate caliope euery ſide mountayne ſate foure muſes playing ſeuerall ſwéete inſtrumentes theyr féete epigrammes poeſies written golden letter whyche euerye muſe according hir propertie praiſed quéene thence quéene wyth hir traine paſſed leaden hall goodly pageaunte tipe heauenly roſe vnder tippe goodly roote golde ſette little mountaine enuironed wyth red roſes white oute typpe came downe faulcon whyte ſette vppon roote incontinent came downe angel wyth greate melodie ſette cloſe crowne gold faulcons head ſame pageant ſate saint anne wyth hir iſſue beneath hir vnder mary cleophe ſate hir foure child whiche chyldren one made goodlye oration quéen fruitefulneſſe saint anne hir generation truſting lyke fruite ſhoulde come hir ſhée paſſed conduite cornehill thrée grace ſe • te throne afore whome ſpring grace continually running wine afore fountaine ſate poet declaring propertie euery grace done euery lady hirſelf according hir propertie gaue quéene ſeuerall gifte grace done ſhe paſſed greate conduite cheape whiche newly painted wyth armes deuiſes whiche couduite goodlye fountaine ſette ende ranne continually wine white claret afternoone ſo ſhe rode standarde whyche richely painted image king quéenes hanged banner armes toppe maruellous ſwéete harmony bothe song inſtruments ſhe wente forwarde croſſe whyche newly guilte till ſhe came alderman ſtoode maiſter baker recorder came hir wyth lowe reuerence making proper briefe propoſition gaue hir name citie thouſand mark golde purſe golde whyche ſhée thankefullye accepted wyth manye good wordes ſo rode little conduite riche pageaunt full melody song whyche pageaunte pallas iuno venus afore ſtoode mercurie whiche name thrée goddeſſes gaue hir ball gold deuided thrée ſignifying thrée giftes theſe thrée goddeſſes gaue hir ſay wiſedom rich felicitie ſhe entred pawles gate prettie pageant ſate thrée ladyes richly clothed circle head written regina anna proſper procéede raigne lady midſt tablet written veni amica coronaberis vnder table ſate angell cloſe crowne lady ſitting right hand tablet siluer whiche written domine dirige greſſus meos third lady tablet gold letter azure written confido domino vnder féete written regina anna paris regis de ſanguine natam et paries populis aurea ſaecla tuis theſe ladyes caſt downe wafer whiche • ayd two uerſes written thence ſhe paſſed eaſt ende pawles church againſt schoole ſtoode scaffolde child well apparelled ſayde hir diuers goodly uerſes poet tranſlated engliſh honor king hir ſhe highly commended • came ludgate whiche gate new garniſhed gold biſe leades saint martin church ſtoode goodly quéere ſinging men child ſang new ballet made prayſe hir grace ſhe paſt ludgate ſhe procéeded towarde fléeteſtréete conduite newly paynted armes angle refreſhed shalmes melodiouſly ſounding upon conduite made tower foure turret euery turret ſtoode one cardinall vertues token property ſeueral ſpeaches promiſing quéene neuer leaue hir ayding comforting hir midſt tower cloſely ſuch ſeuerall ſolemne inſtruments ſéemed heauenly noyſe much regarded prayſed beſides conduite ran wine claret redde noone ſo ſhe hir company maior rode forth temple barre newly paynted repaired ſtoode alſo diuers ſinging men child till ſhe came westminster hall whiche richly hanged cloth arras newly glaſed midſt hall ſhe taken hir litter ſo ledde vp high deſke vnder cloth eſtate whoſe left hande cupbord tenne ſtages high maruellous riche beautifull beholde within little ſeaſon broughte quéene ſolemne ſeruice greate ſtanding ſpice plate voyde ſpice ſutteltyes ipocraſe wynes whyche ſhe ſente downe hir ladyes ladyes drunke ſhe gaue harty thankes lordes ladyes maior giuen attendance hir ſo withdrew hirſelfe fewe ladyes white hall ſo hir chamber ſhifted hir wente hir barge ſecretely king manour westminster ſhe reſted night whitſonday firſt june maior cladde crimſon ueluet coller aldermencoronation queene anne sheriffes skarlet counſell citie tooke barge crane ſeauen clocke came westminster welcomed brought hall mayſter treaſurer king houſe ſo gaue attendance till quéene ſhoulde come foorth betwéene eyght nine clocke ſhe came hall ſtoode vnder cloth eſtate came king chappell monkes westminster riche coapes manye biſhops abbot coapes miter went midſt hall ſtoode ſeaſon ray cloath ſpread quéenes ſtanding hall pallace sanctuarie whiche rayled ſides high altare westminster ray cloth caſt officer armes appoynted order accuſtomed firſt went gentleman eſquires knightes alderman london cloakes scarlet caſt ouer thier gownes scarlet judge mantle scarlet coyfes followed knightes bath béeing lordes euery man hauing white lace left ſléeue followed baron uicountes parliament roabes scarlet came earles marqueſſes duke roabes eſtate crimſon ueluet furred ermin poudered according theyr degrées came lord chancellor roabe scarlet open bordered lettice hym came king chappell monkes ſolemnely ſinging proceſſion came abbot biſhops mitered sergeant officer armes maior london mace garter coate armes marqueſſe dorcet hys roabe eſtate bare scepter gold earle arundell bare rodde iuorie doue togither alone earle oxford high chamberlayne england bare crowne duke suffolke roabe eſtate day high steward england hauing long white rodde hys hande lorde william haward rodde marſhalſhip euery knight garter coller order procéeded foorth quéene circote roabe purple ueluet furred ermine hir heare coyfe circlet ſhe saterday ouer hir borne canapie foure cinque porte chrimſon point blew red hanging ſléeues biſhops london winchester bare vp lappes quéenes robe hir trayne long borne old duches norffolke hir followed ladyes lord wiues circotes scarlet narrow ſléeues breſt letice barres powder according degrées ouer mantel scarlet furred euery mantel letice necke like neckerchefe likewiſe poudered ſo pouderings theyr degrées might knowne followed ladyes béeing knightes wiues gownes scarlet narrowe ſléeues without traynes edged lettice likewiſe quéenes gentlewoman ſhe thus brought high place made midſt church betwéene quéere high altare ſhe ſet rich chaire ſhe reſted ſhe deſcended downe high altare proſtrated hirſelfe biſhop canterbury ſayd certayne collect ouer hir ſhe roſe biſhop annoynted hir head breſt ſhe led vp agayne hir chaire diuers oriſons ſayd archbiſhop ſet crowne saint edward hir head deliuered hir scepter golde hir right hand rodde yuory doue yt left hand quéere ſong te deum c▪ done biſhop tooke crowne saint edward heauie ſet hir head the▪ crowne made hir ſo went maſſe offering begonne ſhe deſcended downe offered crowned ſo aſcended vp agayne ſate hir chaire till agnus ſhe wente downe knéeled high alter ſhe receyued archbiſhop holy sacrament went vp place agayne maſſe done ſhe went saint edward shrine offered whiche offering done ſhe withdrewe hir little place made purpoſe one ſide quéere meane ſeaſon euery ducheſſe put hir bonet coronell gold wrought flower euery marchioneſſe put demy coronell gold euery counteſſe playne circle gold without flower euery king armes put crowne copper gilt worne till night quéene little repoſed hir company returned ſame order ſet forth y• quéene went crowned ſo ladyes aforeſayd hir right hand ſuſteyned earle wilſhire hir father hir left hand lord talbot deputie earle shrewſburie lord furniuall father ſhe sanctuarie within pallace trumpet playde maruellous freſhly ſo ſhe brought westminster hall ſo hir withdrawing chamber time lord judge maior alderman put robe mantle clokes tooke theyr whodes neckes caſt ſhoulders lordes ſate onely circotes judge alderman gownes lord ſerued day ſerued circotes whodes ſhoulders alſo diuers officer king houſe lordes circotes whodes scarlet edged miniuer treaſurer comptroller mayſter jewell houſe circotes gilt quéene hir chamber euery lordethe ſetting dinner qu anne ought ſeruice coronation prepare according dutie duke suffolke high steward england richly apparelled doblet jacket ſet orient pearle hys gowne chrimſon ueluet embrothered courſer trapped cloſe trapper head ground chrimſon ueluet ſet full letter gold goldſmiths worke hauing long white rodde hand left 〈◊〉 rode lord william deputie brother earle marſhall marſhals rodde whoſe gowne chrimſon ueluet hys horſſe trapper purple ueluet cut white sattin einbrothered white lion earle oxford high chamberlayne earle eſſex caruer earle suſſex sewer earle arundell chiefe butler whome twelue citizen london giue theyr attendance cupbord earle darby cupbearer uicount liſle panter lorde burgeyny chiefe larder lorde bray almouer hys copartner maior oxforde kepte buttrey barre thomas wyat choſen ewerer sir henry wyat hys father thyngs readye ordered quéene vnder hir canapye came hall waſhed ſate downe middeſt table vnder hir cloath eſtate right ſyde hyr chayre ſtoode counteſſe oxforde widowe hyr lefte hande ſtoode counteſſe worcester dynner ſeaſon whyche dyuers tymes dynner tyme dyd holde fyne cloath quéenes face ſhe liſt ſpitte otherwiſe hir pleaſure table ende ſate archbiſhop canterbury right hande quéene middeſt betwéene archbiſhop counteſſe oxforde ſtoode earle oxforde white ſtaffe dynner tyme quéenes féete vnder table ſate two gentlewoman dinner tyme theſe thyngs thus ordered came duke suffolke lorde william howarde ſell ſuch price offered prieſt ſtanding likewiſe wiſhed haue ſaid néede men lincolneſhire pacifyed within ſixe dayescommotion yorkeshire began inſurrection yorkeſhire ſame cauſes people gathered number fortie thouſand tooke archbiſhop yorke lord darcy cauſed ſworne partie agaynſte thoſe rebelles kyng ſente duke norffolke duke suffolke earle shrewſhurie marqueſſe excester wyth greate armye wyth whome battayle appoynted haue béene foughte euen saint simon iude god woulde fell ſuche rayne nighte two armyes coulde méete wherevppon deſyred duke northfolke ſue vnto kyngs maieſtie theyr pardon myghte haue liberty c whyche duke promiſed rode poſte kyng lying windeſore know pleaſure ſo appeaſed sir robert aske commotion appeaſed chiefe rebellion came london pardoned rewarded great giftes sir ralph euers kept skarbrow caſtel north béeingsir ralph euers good ſeruice north ſixe wéekes beſéeged rebelles twentye dayes whereof companye whiche onely friend ſeruants tenant ſerued good forced ſuſteyne themſelues bread water yet kept ſame ſafe end ſayd rebellion ſo deliuered king henry ſente hym ſoone ſerue bordures againſt scotland great credite continued ſeruice kéeping scottes without hurt england ſuch obedience within twentie mile bordures scotlande fore againſt scotte commandement ſo continued till killed anno 1545 robert paget mer taylor william bowyer 28 se sherifes enquire ſaide ſtripe inqueſts found gilty iudgement loſe right hande wherevpon called execution firſt sergeant chirurgion wyth hys inſtrumentes apperteyning office sergeant woodyard mallet blocke wherevpon hand ſhould lye mayſter cooke king knife sergeant larder ſet knife right ioynt sergeant farrer ſearing iron ſeare veynes serieant poultrey cocke cocke ſhould haue head ſmitten vpon ſame blocke ſame knife yeoman chaundrie ſeare clothes yeoman skolerie panne fire heate iron chafer water coole endes iron two formes officer ſette ſtuffe sergeant celler wine ale béere yeoman ewrie sergeantes ſtéede abſente wyth baſon ewre towel thus euery man hys office readye execution called foorth sir william pickering knight marſhall bring ſayde edmonde kneuet hée broughte barre chiefe juſtice declared hym treſpaſſe ſayde kneuet confeſſing hymſelfe bée giltye humblye ſubmitted hym king mercie offence hée iudged loſe hand alſo body remayne priſon landes goodes king pleaſure ſayde sir edmund kneuet deſired king benigne grace would pardon right hande take left quoth right hand ſpared may héereafter doe ſuche good ſeruice grace ſhall pleaſe appoynt ſubmiſſion requeſt juſtices forthwith enformed king goodneſſe conſidering gentle heart ſayde edmund good reporte lord ladyes graunted hym pardon ſhould loſe neyther hand land goodes ſhould goe frée libertie lord leonard gray endited certain point treaſon committed alledged agaynſte ſeaſon king lieutenant ireland witte deliuering nephew girald fitz garard brother thomas fitz garard executed alſo cauſed certaine iriſhmen countrey good ſeruice ireland france place greatly commendation although happe thus loſe head ſame day ſuffered executed saint thomas watering thrée gentleman iohn mantell iohn frowdes george roydon reported meaning bunt ye parke nicholas pelham eſquier laughton ſame countie suſſex béeyng accompanyed ſayde mantel frowdes roydon iohn cheyney thomas iſley gentleman richarde middleton iohn goldwell yeoman paſſed houſe hurstmonſeux laſte aprill night ſeaſon towarde ſame parke intended ſo hunt commyng place called pikehay pariſhe hillingley found one iohn buſbrigge iames busbrigge richarde somener ſtanding togither fell quarrelling enſued fray betwixte ſayde lorde dacres company one part ſaid iohn iames busbrig richard somener ſo much ſaid iohn busbrigge receyued ſuch hurt dyed thereof ſeconde may nexte enſuing wherevpon well ſayd lorde dacres thoſe wyth hym diuers likewiſe appointed go another way méete ſayd parke indited murther ſeauen twentith june lord dacres himſelfe arraigned lord audley walden lord chauncelor ſitting day high steward englande péeres realme condemned ſayde lorde dacres dye tranſgreſſion afterwardes nine twentith june saint peter daye eleauen clocke forenoone sheriffes london accordingly appointed readye tower haue receiued ſaide priſoner haue led execution tower hill priſoner ſhould come forth tower heire gentleman lord chancelors houſe came king name commaunded ſtay execution till two clocke afternoone whyche cauſed many thinke king woulde haue graunted pardon neuertheleſſe thrée clocke ſame afternoone brought forth tower delyuered sheriffes led foote betwixte vnto tyborne dyed body buryed churche saint sepulchre paſte foure twentie yeres age came thus throughe greate miſhappe hys ende whome many ſore lamented likewiſe thrée gentleman mantell frowdes roydon ſaide yong lord right towardly gentlemā ſuch one many conceiued great hope better proofe ſmal mone lamentation made indéede thought induced attempt ſuche follis occaſioned death ſome delyuer till sheriffes came ſelues ende deliuered howbeit matter ſo takē common houſe sheriffes clearks fiue officer wyth partie plaintife ſent tower sheriffes london ſent tovver anno reg 34 laye two dayes deliuered ye speaker common houſe sheriffes deliuered charge excepte twentie pounde fées maye kyng tooke loane money ſuch valued worth fifty pound vpwarde moneth auguſt iames erle deſmond irelande earle deſmoude came ſubmitted himſelfe king ſo returned firſte october greate oneale irelande wasthe greate oneale created earle tiron hys baſe ſonne mathew oneale baron donmagan shane oneale onely ſonne bodye lawfully begotten little eſtéemed duke norffolke entred scotland one twentithduke norffolke entred scotlande october burning waſting march tarried wythoute anye battel proffered king scottes vntill middeſt nouember henry hoblethorne henry hancots 28 september sherifes maior iohn coates salter 28 october departure oure armye scotlande kyng scottes made roade englande muche harme laſte ſir thomas wharton ſir williamscots ouerthrovvne muſgraue wyth fewe bordurers met scot number 15000 ouerthrowne whiche conflicte taken lorde maxwell earles glencarne saſſilles wyth capitaines army number one twentie saint thomas euen apoſtle broughte tower london laye night nexte daye king charge apparelled ſilke rode citie westminster ſworne true priſoners deliuered cuſtodie dyuers noble menne whyche honorably entertained newyeares tide ſent home againe agréeing certaine article 9 february proclamation made wherebyvvhite meate licenced bee eaten lent people licenced eate white meates magdalen day beginning auguſt french king determining take iſles garneſea ierſea ſet ſodeinlythe french king galley inuaded garneſea ierſea vpon shippes great number galeis ſo manfully encountred king nauie loſſe thouſand men great ſpoyle galleis forced retire france de • • purpoſe xvj auguſt man hanged without biſhopſgate london one ſent waltham executed diuers many place viij auguſt french embaſſadours gaue afrenchmen apprehended defiance lorde protectour wherevpon frenchman goodes béeing denizen apprehended rebel norffolke suffolke encamped thēſelues mount surrey wood called saint nicholas wood néere vnto norwich▪ agaynſt whome▪ sir iohn dudley earle warwike went • n armye great number gentleman méeting rebelles ſuche daunger thought haue dyed place god confoundeth purpoſe rebel brought ſo paſſe well al place partly power cōſtreined partly promiſe • ar •• n perſwaded ſubmitte themſelues prince earle warwike entred citie norwich xxvij auguſt •• ainethe earle vvarvvicke vvent againſt rebel norvvich aboue fiue thouſand rebel taken chiefe captayne robert ket windham • anner whiche mighte diſpend land fiftie pound yeare worth moueables aboue thouſand markes put iane lady marie eldeſt daughter king henrie eighte keninghall castell norffolke wyth hir earle bathe ſir thomas cornwallis alſo earle suſſex maiſter henrie ratcliffe ſonne •• mmyng towardes hir wherevppon ſpéedy councell concluded duke suffolke certayne nobleman ſhould go towards lady mary ••• che hir vp tower thys firſte determined night ſame daye ſaide voyage duke suffolke cleane diſſolued ſpeciall meanes lady iane hys daughter takyng matter heauily wyth wéepyng teares made requeſt whole councel hir father might • arry home hir company whervppon councel perſwaded duke northumberlande take voyage vpon ſaying man 〈…〉 ſo •• therefore bycauſe hadde atchieued victorie norffolke already therefore ſo feared 〈…〉 none durſte li •• e vp weapon againſt 〈…〉 beſte man warre realme well ordering campes souldicures bothe battaile tentes alſo experience knowledge wiſdome coulde bothe animate army wittie perſwaſions alſo pacifie alay hys ennimyes pride wyth hys ſtowte courage elſe diſſuade néede enterpriſe▪ finally ſaid ſhort long quéene wiſe graunte hir father ſhall take vpon wherefore quoth thinke good may pleaſe grace lyeth remedy matter well quoth duke ſince ye thinke good mine go doubting fidelitie quéenes maieſtie whych leaue youre cuſtodie ſo nighte ſente bothe lordes knightes ſhoulde goe wyth hym cauſed thing prepared accordynglye wente councell ladye iane tolde hir theyr concluſion humblye thanked duke reſeruing hir father home beſéeched vſe hys diligence whereto aunſwered woulde doe hym laye morrowe following greate preparation made duke early mornyng called owne harneſſe ſawe made ready durham place appointed retinue méete ſame daye carte laden munition artillerie fielde péeces ſet forwarde ſame forenoone duke moued efte ſoones counſell ſende power hym determined ſame méete wyth hym newe market promiſed woulde ſayde ſome lordes theſe noble perſonages whole army nowe goe forth well behalfe eſtabliſhing quéenes highneſſe ſhall aduenture body lyues amongeſt bloudy ſtrokes cruell 〈◊〉 aduerſaries open fieldes alſo wée leaue conſeruation ſelues chyldren family home altogyther committed youre truth fidelity whome thoughte ye woulde throughe malice conſpyracie diſſention leaue v youre friendes bryars betraye v wée coulde well ſundry wayes foreſee prouide owne ſafegards •• anye betraying v doe nowe vppon onelye truſte faithfulneſſe youre honor whereof thinke ſelues moſte aſſured wée hazarde oure liues whyche truſte promiſe ye ſhall violate hoping thereby lyfe promotion yet ſhall god coumpt innocent blouds neyther acquite ſacred holy othe allegeaunce made fréely thys vertuous lady quéenes highneſſe enficement rather force placed •• hir ownſéeking requeſt conſider alſo god cauſe whyche preferment hys worde •• • e papiſtes entraunce hathe béene yée haue alwayes layde originall grounde wherevpon ye •• en firſte motion graunted goodwils con ••• t therevnto handes writing appeareth •• inke contrarye yée meane deceyte thoughs forthewyth yet hereafter god reuenge ſame ſaye thys trouble ſome tyme wyſh vſe conſtant heartes abandoning malice enuye priuate affection therewithall firſte courſe lord came vp wherefore duke ſhut vp talke wyth theſe wordes ha • e ſpoken thys ſorte • ppon anye miſtruſte haue youre trueth • whyche alwayes haue euer hitherto conceiued truſty confidence haue put remembrance thereof chance variance ſo euer might grow amongſt mine abſence pray wiſh worſe good ſpéede iorney ye woulde haue ſelues lord ſaith one ye miſtruſte anye v matter grace farre deceyued whyche v waſhe hys handes cleane thereof ſhoulde ſhrincke one culpable v excuſe himſelfe guiltleſſe therefore herein doubt farre caſte praye god quoth duke let v go dinner ſo ſate downe dinner duke wente quéene commiſſion tyme ſealed lieutenantſhippe army tooke leaue hir ſo didde certaine lordes alſo duke came councell chamber tooke leaue earle arundale prayed god grace ſaying ſorie chance goe beare companye whoſe preſence could finde hys hearte ſpende hys blo • de euen féete earle arundale tooke thomas louell duke boy hande ſaide farewel gentle thomas al heart duke l marque northampton lorde grey dyuers tooke barge went one maiſter iernigham rayſing power ladye mary behalfe hearing thereof came thither wherevppon captaines tooke boate wente shippes saylers ſouldiors aſked maiſter iernigham woulde haue whether would haue captaines ſaid yea mary ſaide ye ſhall haue throwe bottome sea captaines ſaide forthwith would ſerue quéene mary willingly ſo broughte forth men conueyed great ordinaunce commyng theſe shippes ladye mary wonderfull ioyous afterwarde doubted little duke puiſſaunce newes therof broughte tower eche manne beganne draw backward ouer word greater miſchiefe broughte tower ſaye nobleman tenaunts refuſed ſerue lord againſt quéen marie duke thoughte long ſuccoures wrote ſomewhat ſharplye councell tower behalfe well lacke men munition flender aunſweare againe time forward certaine councell wéete earle pembrooke ſir thomas cheyney lorde warden ſought gette oute tower conſulte london coulde yet ſixetéenth iuly sonday doctor ridley biſhoppe london commaundement councel prea • hed paules croſſe vehementlye perſwaded • eople title ye lady iane late proclaimed quéene • nd inueyed earneſtly againſte title lady mary c ſame ſixetéenth iuly lorde treaſurer •• ne oute tower houſe london nighte •• quéene mary among threwe vppe hy • owne cap wythin houre letter councell ſaid ſhoulde forthwith diſmiſſ • army come within tenne myles london▪ fo • woulde fight wyth hym rumour • ſooner abroade euerie man departed ſhortlye duke arreſted king colledge 〈…〉 one maiſter slegge sergeant armes laſte letter brought councell london al 〈…〉 ſhoulde goe eche way wherevpon duke ſayde 〈…〉 kepte yée doe wrong withdrawe libertie ſée counſels letter wythoute exception men ſhoulde go whither would wordes kepte hym nobleman ſete libertie ſo contynued night inſomuche earle warwicke readye morning haue rode away came erle arundel frō quéen ye duke chamber went méete ſoone ſaw earle arundale fel hys knées deſired hym good loue god cōſider ſaith haue done nothing cō ſents whole councell lorde quoth earle arundale ſente hither quéenes maieſtie hir name doe arreaſt obey lorde quoth beſéeche lorde arundale quoth duke vſe mercy towardes mée knowing caſe lorde quoth earle yée ſhoulde haue ſought mercie ſooner muſte doe accordyng commaundement therewith committed charge guarde gentleman ſtoode xxv july duke brought vp tower london vnder conducte henry earle arundale thus matter ended without bradford one threwe dagger hym whych hit ſide poſte pulpit anda dagger throvvne preacher rebounded backe againe greate waye vppon mayſter bradford brake hys ſpeach forced hymſelfe helpe iohn rogers duke arraigned westminster hall thomas duke norffolke high steward englande duke northumberland wyth greate reuerence towardes judge proteſted hys faith allegeance quéene whome confeſſed gréeuouſly haue offended ſaide meante ſpeake anye thing defence tact requeſted vnderſtand opinion courte twoo poyntes firſt▪ whether • man anye acte aucthoritie prince councel warrant greate seale england doyng nothing without ſame might charged treaſon thing whiche might doe warrant thereof secondly whether ſuch perſons equally culpable crime thoſe whoſe letter commaundementes directed doyngs myghte bée hys judge paſſe vppon hys tryall hys péeres wherevnto aunſweared cōncerning firſte greate seate whiche layde hys warrant▪ séale lawful quéene realme paſſed aucthoritie seale uſurper therefore coulde warrant hym ſecond alleadged anye déepely bée touched caſe hymſelfe yet ſo long atteynder recorde agaynſte neuer leſſe perſons able lawe paſſe vppon anye tryall bée chalenged therefore prince pleaſure whyche aunſweare duke vſed fewe wordes confeſſed inditement whoſe example▪ priſoners arraigned like therevppon iudgement iudgement gyuen▪ duke ſaid beſéech lord humble futers quéenes maieſtie graunte mée foure requeſtes whyche theſe▪ • yr ••• maye haue death whyche noble 〈…〉 haue hadde tymes paſte other▪ secondartly hir maieſtie gratious chyldren whyche maye hereafter doe good ſeruice conſyderyng wente commaundement theyr father trée willes thyrdlye maye haue appoynted ſome learned manne inſtruction quiet conſcience fourthlye ſhée ſende twoo councell commune wyth mée whome declare ſuche matter wherevnto ſubiecte thanks hys mercifull goodnes hath cauſed learne one litle darke corne • 〈…〉 〈…〉 ▪ euer learned trauell ſo many place haue bin ſay haue ſéene god vnſearcheable wonderous workes infinite mercy haue ſéene ſelfe throughly nothing lump ſinne earth duſt vileneſſe moſt vileſt haue ſéene know world dayne deceiptfull tranſitorie ſhort wicked loathſome workes thereof ſight god maieſtie neyther regardeth ſhe man • ee proude men mighty one neyther deſpiſeth humbleneſſe poore lowly • ſame world finally haue ſéene death néere hanging ouer euery man head yet vncertayne time vnknowne men little feared ſhould feare death ſadde therefore haue ſéene two dye mine eye yea within hearing mine eares neyther ſ • rinckling bloud ſheading thereof bloudy axe ſelfe ſhall make afrayd taking leaue ſame pray pray come good fellow quoth art thou muſt déede forgiue thée heart knéeled downe laying head blocke ſayd ſée méete 〈…〉 necke pray thée ſtrike yet haue prayer ſay done ſtrike god citie •• r •• cloth gold • thouſand marlies •• l • ſhe rode forth paules churchyarde againſt schoole one maiſter heywod ſate pageant vnder uine made hir oration latine engliſh one peter dutchman ſtoode weathercocke paules ſtéeple holding ſtreamer hand fiue yard long waning therof ſtoode ſometime one foote ſhooke knéeled knées greate maruell people made two scaffoldes vnder one aboue croſſe hauing torch ſtreamers ſet one ouer bole croſſe likewiſe ſet ſtreamers torch could burne wind ſo great ſaid peter ſixtéene pound thirtéene ſhillings fourpence giuen hym citie coſtes paynes ſtuffe pageant made againſt deane paules gate quereſters paules playde uials ſong ludgate newly repaired paynted richly hanged minſtrels playing ſinging there▪ another pageant conduit fléeteſtréete temple barre newly paynted hanged thus ſhe paſſed white hall weſtminster ſhe tooke hir leaue lord maior giuing hym greate thankes ſor paynes citie coſt morrow firſt day october quéene went water old pallace remayned till eleuen clocke went foote vpon blew cloath rayled eyther ſide vnto saint peter church ſhe ſolemnely crowned a▪ noynted biſhop winchester coronation ceremony ſolemnities vſed according old cuſtome fully ended till nigh foure clocke night ſhe returned church whome borne thrée ſwords ſheathed one naked great ſeruice day done westminster hall dinner diuers nobleman would aſke long time twenty day october barge graues end catch running vpon hir ouerturned fourtéenegraues end barge ouerturned perſons drowned ſixtéene ſaued ſwimming sir thomas white merchant taylor 28 october maior sir thomas white worthy patron protector poore scholers learning renued rather erected acharitable deedes sir tho vvhite colledge oxford called saint iohns colledge bernard colledge alſo erected schooles bristow reading moreouer worſhipfull citizen life time gaue citie bristow two thouſand pound ready money purchaſe land yearely value 120 pound decréed maior burgeſes communaltye bristow anno 1567 ſo yearely tearme ten yeares next enſuing ſhould cauſe payd bristow one hundred pound lawfull money firſt 800 pound lent ſixtéene poore yong men clothier frée men ſame towne ſpace tenne yeares fiftie pound péece putting ſufficient ſureties ſame end ten yeares lent ſixtéene diſcretion maior alderman foure common counſell ſayde citie two hundred pound employed prouiſion corne reliefe poore ſame citie ready money without gaine taken end tenne yeares feaſt day saint barthelmew ſhall anno 1577 merchant taylor hall london vnto maior communaltie citie yorke attourney aucthoriſed hundred four pound lent vnto four yong men ſayde citie yorke fréemen inhabitant clothier alway preferred viz euery fiue twenty pound haue occupie ſame terme tenne yeares without paying thing loane four pound ouerplus 104 pound pleaſure maior communaltie paine taken reſcepts paymentes ſayd 100 pounde like order poyntes taken deliuerie 104 pound yeare 1578 citie canterbury yeare 1579 reading 1580 company england third nouember weathercocke paules ſet vp cocke wayed fortie pound lengthvveathercock paules bill tayle four foote breadth ouer wing thrée foote halfe cocke béeing copper ouer gilt thirtéenth nouember doctor cranmer archbiſhop canterbury lady iane proclaymed quéene lord guilford hir huſband arraigned guild hall london condemned treaſon parliament diſſolued ſixth december one twentith december begannelatine ſeruice church throughout england church ſeruice done latine enacted laſt parliamente ſame bin left laſt yeare king henry eyght beginning moneth january emperour ſent noble man called ecmondane certayne embaſſadors england conclude marriage betwéene king phillip ſonne quéene mary englande fourtéenth january stephen gardener biſhop winchester lord chancellour england chamber preſence westminster made lordes nobilitie gentleman oration eloquent wherein hée declared quéenes maieſtie partly amitie waightie conſiderations muche ſuite emperours prince spaynes behalfe made determined conſent counſell nobilitie match hir ſelfe ſayde prince moſt godly lawfull matrimonie declared ſhe ſhould haue hir ioynter thirtie thouſand duckets yeare lowe countrey flanders iſſue happened betwéene two lawfully begotten ſhould bée heire well kingdome spayne alſo ſayde lowe countrey ſayde therefore bound thanke god ſo noble worthy famous prince would vouchſafe ſo humble hymſelfe thys marriage take vppon hym rather subiect otherwiſe quéene hir counſell ſhoulde rule thynges •• e dyd ſhoulde bée counſell stranger neyther haue cuſtodie anye fortes caſtels c beare anye rule office • quéenes houſe elſewhere englande • yuers article hym rehearſed •• e hée ſayde quéenes pleaſure requeſt •• lyke good subiectes hir ſake woulde moſt ••• inglye receyue reuerence ioy honoure next day lord maior london bréethren aldermē ſent court bring fortie head commoner citie vnto whome counſell lord chancellour made like oration deſiring behaue themſelues like good ſubiects humbleneſſe reioycing purpoſe marriage ſo gréeuouſly taken diuers men religion ſuchconſpiracy ſort conſpired againſt quéene matter broken time appoynted men thought would haue brought much trouble daunger xxv january sir iohn gage lord chamberlayne certified lord maior london sir thomascommotion kent sir thomas vviat wyat certayne rebel vp kent aboute maydestone wherevpon great watche kepte night lord maior rode peruſe ſame euery night two alderman like day time gate citie warded ſubſtantiall citizēs xxvij january lord treaſurer came guild hall counſell requeſt citizen prepare fiue hundred footemen well harneſſed go agaynſte wyat granted made ready ſame night morrow deliuered captaines ſent graueſend water xxix january duke norffolke captayne gard ſouldiersthe duke norffolke ſente againſt vvyat captaine souldiers ſent london minded aſſault rochester caſtell wyat people lay ſetting forward theſevvyat ſtrengthened vvith queenes ordinance men duke ſent mayſter nory herault vnto rocheſter quéenes proclamation pardon ſuch would deſiſt purpoſe comming bridge woulde haue gone citie kept bridge would ſuffer till captayne came laſt granted ſame read •• citie holding dagge againſt cryed ſpeak •• ſoftly elſe would ſhoote thorough ſo would ſuffer people heare proclamation béeing ended man cryed done nothing wherefore ſhould néede pardon quarrell taken hande would lyue dye neuertheleſſe laſt sir george harpar receyued pardon outwardly béeing receiued vnder duke norffolkes protection came forwarde againſte kentiſhmen euen company ſet readineſſe marched forward toward bridge brette béeing captayne fiue hundred londoner parte foreward turned himſelfe aboute drawing ſword ſayd theſe like word mayſters go fight againſt natiue countreymen england friend quarrell vnrightfull partly wicked conſidering great manyfolde miſeries like fall vpon v ſhall vnder rule proude spanyards héere aſſembled make reſiſtance comming auoyding ſo great miſchiefes inconueniences likely light vpon themſelues euery v whole realme wherefore thinke engliſh heart ought ſay againſt much leſſe fighting withſtande therefore others meaning ſuch ranke hym ſpende bloud quarrell worthy captayne mayſter wyat gentleman héere aſſembled word pronounced man turned ordinance agaynſt folowers therevpon cryed wyat wyat ſodeyne noyſe duke captayne gard béeing abaſhed fledde forthwith immediatly came mayſter wyat hys company horſſebacke ruſhing amongſt well garde londoner ſayde ſo many wyll come tarrye wyth v ſhall welcome ſo many wyll departe good leaue haue ſo • londoner parte gard thrée • artes retinue wente campe kentiſhmen ſtill remayned diſcomfiture duke loſt eyght péeces braſſe munition ordinance himſelfe hardly eſcaped laſt january wyat company came dertforde next day came full whole greenewich depeford remayned thurſeday fryday foorenone satterday fryday candlemas day moſt parte houſholders london maior alderman harneſſe yea day dayes juſtices sergeant lawe lawyer pleaded harneſſe meane time henry duke suffolke father lady iane fléeing leycesterſhire warwikeſhire ſmall companye diuers place went made proclamation agaynſt quéenes marriage prince spayne c people enclined firſt february proclamation made london duke suffolke diſcomfited fled two bréethren alſo sir peter carow vnckle sir gawyn carow gibbes fledde france quéene pardon whole camp kentiſhmen except wyat harpar rudſtone iſeley ſoeuer could take sir thomas wyat except ſayde foure perſons ſhould haue hundred pound land hym heires euer ſame day afternoone candlemas euen common citie aſſembled liueries guild hall whether quéene hir lord ladyes camequeene mary came guild hall london riding westminster vehement wordes againſt wyat declared ſhe meant otherwiſe marrie counſell ſhould thinke honourable commodious realme ſhe could continue vnmaryed ſhe done greateſt part hir age therefore willed truly aſſiſt hir repreſſing ſuch contrarie duty rebelled ſhe done vnderſtanding many london fauour wyat part ſhe appoynted lord william howard lieutenant oflord vvilliam hovvard lieutenant citie citie earle pembroke general field prepared thyngs neceſſarie theyr purpoſe meane ſeaſon wéete third day februaryvvyat came southvvarke thrée clocke noone sir thomas wyat kentiſhmen marched forwarde depeford towards london fiue ancient béeing eſtimation two thouſand comming ſo ſoone perceyued ſhot white tower ſixe eyght ſhotte miſſed ſometime ſhooting ouer ſometime ſhort knowledge thereof london forth draw bridge cut downe bridge gate ſhutte maior sheriffes harneſſed commanded man ſhutte ſhoppes windowes ready harneſſed dores chance ſoeuer might happen time wyat entred kentstreete ſo saint george churche southwarke himſelfe part hys company came good aray downe barmondſey ſtreete ſuffered peaceably enter southwarke without repulſe anye ſtroke ſtricken eyther inhabitant yet many men countrey innes reyſed brought thither lorde william haue gone againſt ſayd wyat ioyned themſelues kentiſhmen inhabitantes beſt enterteyned immediatly vpon ſayde wyat comming hée made proclamation souldyour ſhoulde take anye thyng hée ſhoulde pay hys commyng reſiſt spaniſh kyng c bridge foote layde two péeces ordinance beganne greate trenche betwéene bridge hym hée layde one péece ordinance sainte george one going bermondſey ſtreete one toward biſhop winchester houſe shroue tueſday ſixth february sir thomas wyat remoued southwarke towarde kingston bridge done vpon occaſion nighte hys departing southwarke chance onevvyat remoued southvvarke lieutenant men tower named thomas menchen rowed sculler ouer againſt biſhop winchester place waterman tower ſtaire deſired ſayde lieutenant man take ſo béeing eſpyed wyat men ſeauen harguebuſſes called land agayne would whereupon man diſcharged péece killed ſayd waterman forthwith falling downe dead sculler much payne rowed bridge tower wharffe lieutenant man dead man boate thing ſooner knowne lieutenant euen ſame night next morning bent ſeauen great péeces ordinance euluerings demicanons full againſt foote bridge againſt southwarke two stéeples saint oliues saint mary oueryes beſides péeces white tower one culuering diueling tower thrée fauconets ouer water gate ſo ſoone inhabitant southwarke vnderſtoode certayne men woman came wyat moſt lamentable wiſe ſaying sir like vtterly vndone deſtroyed ſake oure houſes ſhall bée throwne downe vpon head vtter ſpoyle thys borough ſhotte tower ready bente charged towardes v loue god therefore take pitie vppon v whiche wordes hée béeyng partly abaſhed ſtayde awhile ſayde pray friendes bée contente whyle ſoone eaſe miſchiefe god forbid leaſt héere ſhould killed hurt behalfe ſo moſt ſpéedye manner hée martched awaye marched towards kingstone met chance merchantvviat marched tovvards kingſtone named chriſtopher dorell whome called ſaying coſen dorell pray commend vnto citizen londoner ſay vnto libertie fréedome offered woulde receyue neyther woulde admitte enter within gate theyr fréedome diſburthening theyr gréefes oppreſſion stranger would haue franckely ſpente blond cauſe quarrell nowe well appeareth theyr vnthankefulneſſe v friendes meaneth ſo much good therefore leſſe bée moned héereafter miſerable tyrannie stranger ſhall oppreſſe ſo hée wente forwarde daye nighte hée came kingstone bridge broken kepte ſyde two hundreth men wherefore wyat cauſed two péeces ordinance layde ende bridge whiche ſo feared ſyde durſt abyde cauſed hée thrée foure hys souldyers leape thamis ſwimme ſyde lewſed weſterne barge whyche lay tyed ſo brought ouer meanes paſſed water woonderfull paynes hée tooke himſelfe comming foote amongſt neyther dyd ſtay anye whitte nyghte came almoſt brayneforde euer diſcryed quéenes ſcoutes chaunce méeting brette hys companye brette ſayde ſcoute backe villayne thou goe farther diſcouer thing héere thou ſhalte dye hande ſcoute returned great haſt ſame day afternoone two men hangedexecution paules churchyard gibbet paules church yard marciall law one ſeruant duke suffolke late sheriffe leycester baker one white coates ſent citie agaynſte wyat ſame day came tidings duke bréethren taken ſame day towards night laden tenne twelue carte ordināce billes pike speares bowes arrowes powlder ſhotte ſhouels mattockes baſkets munition two cul • erings one sacre thrée fawcons fawconet ſtuffe ſtayde paules church yard ſame night alſo aboute fy • e clocke trompetter went warned horſſemen men armes saint iames field footemen alſo ſixe clocke next morning quéenes ſcoute vpon returne court declared wyat béeing brayneforde whiche ſodeyne newes made courte wonderfullye afrayde drommes went london four clocke commanding souldiours armour ſo charing croſſe wyat hearing earle pembroke come field ſtayde knightes bridge vntill day men wéerie trauell night day alſo partly féebled faint hauing receyued ſmall ſuſtenance ſince comming southwarke reſtleſſe ſmall ado london likewiſe tower made great preparation defence tenne cloke earle pembroke ſet troupe horſſemen hill high way aboue newe bridge ouer againſt saint iames footemen ſet two battels ſomewhat lower néerer charing croſſe lane turning downe bricke wall iſlington ward ſet alſo certayne horſſemen planted ordinance vpon hill ſide meane ſeaſon wyat company planted ordinance vpponvvyat saint iames fielde hill beyond saint iames almoſt ouer againſt parke corner himſelfe word ſpoken souldyers came downe old lane foote hard court gate saint iames four fiue auntients menne marching good array cuthbert vaughan two antients turned downe towarde westminster earle pembroke horſſemen houered whyle without mouing vntill paſſed ſauing tayle vpon ſet cut marched forward array neuer ſtayd returned ayde theyr tayle greate ordinance ſhotte freſhly ſydes wyat ordinance ouerſhotte troupe horſſemen quéenes ordinance one péece ſtrake thrée wyat company rancke vpon head ſlaying ſtrake wall parke harme done greate ſhotte neyther partie quéenes whole battayle footemen ſtanding ſtill wyat paſſed along wall towardes charing croſſe ſayde horſſemen ſet vppon parte ſoone forced backe charing croſſe ſtoode sir iohn gage lorde chamberlayne wyth garde number béeing almoſt thouſande vppon wyat comming ſhotte hys companye laſt fledde court gate certayne purſued forced wyth ſhotte ſhutte court gate againſt thys repulſe ſayde lorde chamberlayne others ſo amazed manye cryed treaſon courte hadde thought earle pembroke aſſaulting tayle hys enimies hadde gone wyat takyng hys parte agaynſt quéene running trying ladyes gentlewoman ſhutting dores windowes ſuche ſhriking noyſe wonderfull heare wyat wyth hys menne marched ſtill forwarde along temple barre ſo thorough fleetestreete tyll hée came bell sauadge inne nigh vnto ludgate wythout reſiſtance hys menne goyng good order array ſayde strand certayne lorde treaſurers hand number thrée hundreth men whereof lorde chidioke powlet ſonne captayne met ſo going one ſide paſſed going ſide without thing ſaying alſo ſtrange ſayde wyat hys company paſſed along greate companye harneſſed men whiche ſtoode ſides ſtréetes without anye withſtanding marched forward fléeteſtréete moſt ſwords drawne ſome cryed quéene mary hath graunted oure requeſt giuen v pardon ſayde quéene hath pardoned v thus ſome wyat men came euen ludgate knocked calling come ſaying wyat whome quéene graunted haue requeſtes lorde william howarde ſtoode gate ſayde auant traytor thou ſhalt come héere wyat ſtayde reſted hym vppon ſtall ouer agaynſte bell sauadge gate laſt ſéeing hée could gette citie béeing deceyued ayde hée hoped returned backe agayne array towards charing croſſe neuer ſtopped till hée came temple barre certayne horſſemen came fielde mette face beganne fyghte agayne tyll clarenſus herraulte came ſayde mayſter wyat sir beſt counſell yéelde ſée thys daye gone agaynſtevvyat taken reſiſting gette good bée death theſe souldioures youre great perill soule perchance maye fynde quéene mercifull rather yée ſtint ſo greate bloudſhead lyke héere bée wyat héerewyth béeyng ſomewhat aſtonyed although hée ſawe hys menne bente fyghte ſayde well ſhall néedes yéelde wyll yéelde gentleman whome sir mawrice barkeley came ſtreight bade hym leape vp behynde hym another tooke thomas cobham wyllyam kneuet ſo carryed behinde vpō horſſes courte taking menne ſides ſaide thys conflicte one pikeman ſetting backe wall saint iames kepte ſeauentéene horſſemen hym greate tyme laſte ſlaine whole number bothe ſides ſlaine thys battaile paſſed fortie perſons farre coulde learned viewed feld many ſore hurte noyſe woman child conflicte charing croſſe ſo greate hearde toppe white tower alſo great ſhotte well diſcerned saint iames fielde ſtoode vpon leades marque northampton ſir nicholas poines ſir thomas pope maiſter iohn seimer fiue clocke thomas wiat william kneuet thomas cobham two brother name mantel alexander vviat ſent tovver bret broughte ſir henrie ierningham water tower priſoners ſir philip deny receyued bulwarke wiat paſſed ſaide goe traitor neuer ſuche traytor englande whome ſir thomas wiat turned ſaide traitor woulde thou ſhouldeſt well knowe thou arte traitor point honeſte man call ſo ſo went forth came tower gate ſir thomas bridge lieuetenant tooke wicket firſte mantele ſaide ah thou traitour haſt thou thy companye wrought holding hys head ſaide nothing came thomas kneuet whome maiſter chamberlaine gentleman porter tower tooke came alexander bret whome ſir thomas pope tooke boſome ſaying oh traitoure howe couldeſt thou finde thy hearte worke ſuche villany take wage truſted ouer bande men fall hir enimyes returning againſte hir battell bret anſwered yea haue offended caſe came thomas cobham whome ſir thomas poines tooke ſaid ala maſter cobham wind headed worke ſuch treaſon aunſwered oh ſir ſeduced came ſir thomas wyat whome ſir iohn bridge tooke collar ſaide oh thou villaine vnhappy traytour howe couldeſt thou finde thy hearte worke ſuch deteſtable treaſon quéenes maieſtie gaue thée thy life liuing already althoughe thou diddeſt béefore time beare armes fielde againſt hir yéeld hir battel c ſaith law muſte paſſe vpon thée woulde ſticke thée throughe dagger whyche wyat holding hys armes vnder ſide lookyng gréeuouſlye grimme looke vpon lieutenant ſaid maiſtery nowe ſo paſſed thomas wyat hadde ſhyrte maile wyth ſléeues fayre thereon ueluet caſſocke yellow lace windlace dag hanging thereon paire bootes legges head fayre hatte ueluet broade boneworke lace aboute william kneuet thomas cobham bret like apparelled morrow next day folowing brought tower priſoners george cobham ſir wyllyam cobham anthony kneuet hugh booth thomas vain robert rudſtone ſir george harper edwarde wyat edward fogge george moore cutbert vaughan tenth february earle huntington gentlemenne number thrée hundred horſſemenne broughte tower priſoner duke suffolke lord iohn grey hys brother couentrie duke hadde remayned thrée dayes taking houſe cuſtody chriſtopher warren alderman eleauenth day ſir henry iſley fledde brought tower priſoner old fréeſe coate olde payre hoſen apparell worth foure ſhillings ſame daye came twoo culpepers one cromar thomas rampton duke suffolks ſecretary twelfth february monday tenne clocke went tower scaffold tower hill lorde guilforde dudley ſonne duke northumberlande huſband lady iane grey daughter duke suffolke without bulwarke gate maiſter thomas offley one sheriffes london receyued hym brought scaffolde ſmall declaration knéeled downe ſaid prayer holdyng vppe hys eye handes heauen wyth teares laſt deſired people pray hym beheaded hys body beyng layde carre hys head cloth broughte chappel within tower ladye iane whoſe lodging maiſter partridge houſe ſée hys deade carcaſſe taken oute carre well ſhe ſée hym aliue going death ſight hir worſe thā death time scaffolde made vpon gréene ouer againſte white tower lady iane dye vppon béeing nothyng abaſhed neyther feare hir owne death whyche approched neyther wyth ſighte dead carcaſſe hir huſbande broughte chappel came forth lieuetenaunt leading hir wt countenance nothing abaſhed neither hir eies thing moiſtned teares booke hir hande wherein ſhe prayed vntill ſhée came ſaid scaffolde whereon ſhe mounted ſhe beheaded whoſe death haſtened feare trouble ſtirre hir tytle lyke hir father attempted fourtéenth fiftéenth february aboute number fiftie wyat faction hanged twenty paire gallows made purpoſe diuers place citie▪ xvij februarye proclamation made straungers ſhoulde auoide realme within xxiiij dayes nexte enſuing vpon paine goodes confiſcate al frée denizen merchant embaſſadors excepted xviij february bright one captaines londoner fledde wiat two twentie perſons kentiſhmen deliuered sheriffe kent executed dyuers place kent thekentishmen pardoned moſte parte pardoned xxij february certaine wiats faction number four hundred led westminster coupled togither halter neckes tylt yarde quéene looked forth hir gallery pardoned themduke suffolk beheaded xxiij february henrie grey duke suffolke beheaded tower hill xj marche william lorde howard admirall englande created baron howard effingham westminster erle deuonshire ſent tovver xv march earle deuonſhire apprehended committed tower ſuſpition haue cō ſented wiats conſpyracie xviij marche palmſonday lady elizabeth quéenes ſiſter lord treaſurer earle suſſex conueyed tower london fromparliament westminster water tj aprill parliament beganne westminster whyche appoynted haue béene kepte oxforde baron created v aprill ſir iohn williams created baron tame saint iames vij april ſir edward north created baron chartlege saint iames viij aprill ſir iohn bridge created baron chondoys sudley saint iames catte hanged cheape ſame viij aprill sonday catte hir head ſhorne likeneſſe ueſtment caſte ouer hir hir fore téete tyed togither round péece paper like ſinging cake betwixte hanged gallowes cheape neare croſſe pariſh saint mathew whyche catte taken downe carryed biſhoppe london cauſed ſame ſhewed paules croſſe preacher doctor pendleton x aprill doctor cranmer archbyſhop canterburie diſputation oxforde doctour ridley byſhoppe london hugh latimer biſhop worcester cōueyed priſoners tower london windſore thence oxforde diſpute wyth diuines learned men contrary opinion xj april ſir thomas wiat beheaded thethomas vviat beheaded tower hill quartred hys quarter ſet vppe dyuers place hys head gallowes hay hill neare hyde parke whence ſhortly ſtolne conueyed awaye xxvtj aprill lorde thomas grey brother late duke suffolke beheaded xiiij may gerrard fitz garret fouretéenth marche laſte paſſed counterfaited certayne ſpeaches houſe withoute alderſgate london thoroughe whyche people whole city wonderfully moleſted men mighte heare voice ſée hir perſon ſaide angell voyce heauen ſome holy ghoſte c thys called spirite wall ſhe hadde laine whiſtling ſtraunge whiſtle made purpoſe whiche giuen hir one drake dyuers companion confederate hir whiche putting thēſelues among preaſſe tooke vppon interprete spirite ſaide expreſſing certaine ſeditious word againſte quéene prince spaine maſſe cōfeſſion c xix july prince spaine arriued southampton fourth day came wincheſter euening going churche honorably receyued byſhoppe greate number noble nexte daye met quéene wyth whome long familiar talke saint james daye marriage ſolempnized betwéene quéene mary harraults proclai •• ed tytle foloweth philip marie grace ofthe king ſtile god king quéene englande fraunce naples hieruſalem ireland defendors faith prince spaine sicile archduke austrich duke frō thence windſore richemont thence water southwarke acompanyed noble men lady king one barge quéeni • landed biſhop wincheſters ſtaires neare mary oueries church ſo paſſed place parke suffolke juſtice xij nouēber parliament began westminster xxiiij nouember cardinall poole came brabant england receiued much honour parliament reſtored hys olde dignitie put king henrie ſhortly came parliament houſe king quéene ſtates preſent declared cauſe legacie firſt exhorting returne communion churche reſtore pope hys due aucthoritie secondly aduertiſed giue thankes god ſent ſo bleſſed king quéene finally ſignified ſo much gret gentleneſſe reſtored honor dignitie moſt erneſtly deſired • ee reſtored heauenly court vnitie ye church nexte day whole courte parliament drewe fourme ſupplication ſumme whereof greatlye repented sciſme hadde lyued therefore deſired king quéene cardinal mean might reſtored boſome churche obedience sea rome nexte daye king quéene cardinall preſent lorde chauncellour declared parliament determined concerning cardinalles requeſt offered king quéene supplication béefore mentioned read cardinall large oration declared howe acceptable repentance nouember lorde maior london queene bruted bee vvith childe wyth alderman scarlet common lyueries aſſembled paules churche nine clocke forenoone doctoure chadſey one prebendes preached quéere preſence biſhoppe london nine biſhoppes read letter ſent quéenes counſell tenour whereof byſhoppe london ſhoulde cauſe te deum ſung church hys dioceſſe wyth continuall prayer quéenes maieſtie whiche conceyued quicke chylde letter read beganne sermon wyth antitheme ne timeas maria inuenisti • nim gratiam apud deum sermon ended te deum ſung ſolempne proceſſion made salue festa dy circuit churche ſeconde englande firſt 〈…〉 frenchne • • ame •• • •• great army within four dayes mayſters thereof▪ caleis loſt englishman ſhortly wan péece • • n ſide sea many ſéemed ſtrange ſuch towne ſo many yeares bin fortified munition could deuiſed ſhould ſo ſhort ſpace taken enimies counſell england reyſed great power haue gone defence towne ſuch tempeſt wind aroſe like many yeares bin ſéene whereby shippe coulde brooke sea till late matter xviij january edward haſtings knight garter lord chamber layne quéene created baron haſtings lowghborough westminster xx january began parliament westminſter parliament moneth march preſt graunted quéene citizen london twentie thouſandea preſt queene pound leuied companyes ſumme repayde agayne quéene bound certayne1558 land alſo allowed intereſt money twelue pound euery hundreth yeare french king • aded flanders ſpoyled brente dunke • k •• king phillip could come reſcue beforedunkirke flanders brent frenchman returned flanders fleming engliſh shippes méeting vpon ſands betwéene dunkerke grauelin • ſlew great number x • july within mile notingham maruellousanno reg 6 tempeſt thunder came two townes beate▪ downe 〈◊〉 church belle caſt ſide church yardes ſome webbes leade four hundreth f •• te field writhen like paire gloues riuer trent ••• ing betwéene two townes water mud bottome caryed quarter mile caſt againſt trées trées pulled vp rootes caſt twelue ſcore alſo child taken forth man hand two speares length hye carryed hundred foote let fall wherewith hys arme broke ſo dyed fiue ſixe men ſlayne neither fleſh ſkinne periſhed fell ſome hayleſtones fiftéene ynches c yeare harueſt time quart • rne ague continued like manner vehemently done laſt yeare paſſed died many olde people ſpecially pri ••• e ſo great number pariſhes vnſerued curate gotten much corne loſt field lacke workemē labourer iohn halſe richard campion 28 september sherifes maior sir thomas leigh mercer 28 october beginning maiors yeare corne roſe fourtéene ſhillings quarter wood waxed ſcant london ſold thirtéene fourtéene ſhillings thouſand • illets cole tenpence ſacke reaſon great death ſickneſſe laſt sommer lacke hēlp carriage king philip abſent realme quéene mary dangerouſly ſicke ended hir life hir manour saint iames charing croſſe xvij nouember yeare 1558 ſhe raigned fiue yeares four monethes odde dayes ſame daye deceaſſed cardinall poole lambheath little two hir phiſitions beſides diuers biſhops noble men quéene mary buryed westminster cardinall poole canterbury ¶ queene elizabeth elizabeth moſt gratious anno reg 1 ſoueraigne lady ſecond daughter king henry viij great comfort englande full conſent proclaimed quéene england france irelande defender fayth c xvij nouember yeare oure lorde god 1558 forthwith porte hauens ſtopped none ſuffered paſſe realme without licence proclamation made forbidding men preach ſaue ſuch ſhould appoynted alſo alter rytes ceremony vſed church ſaue hir grace chappell xxiij nouember quéene elizabeth came fromthe queene commeth hatfild biſhops hatfield hertfordſhire vnto lord northes houſe late charterhouſe london sheriffes london méeting hir grace farther ende barnet towne within shere middleſex ſo rode hir till came charterhouſe gate next alderſgate hir grace remayned monday eyght twentith nouember aboutthe queene • emoueth tovver two clocke noone quéene elizabeth rode lorde northes houſe along barbycane creeplegate along wall biſhopſgate gate richly hanged waytes citie playde ouer againſt king head tauerne scholler paules schoole made ſhort oration hir maieſtie latin uerſes company mercer ſtanding theyr rayles next scholler ſo companyes citie order thence mart lane ende nexte vnto barking church tower ſtreete lorde maior london riding wyth mayſter garter king armes bearing scepter hir maieſtie whiche lorde maior mette hir charterhouſe gate nexte alderſgate mayſter recorder ſaluted hir grace name lorde maior whole citie ſo lordes knightes gentlewoman richly apparelled brought hir tower london hir grace entered mart lane peale gunnes beganne ſhotte tower whiche continued almoſt halfe houre fifth december quéene remoued water tower somerſet place néere strand xiij december corpſe quéene mary honourably conuayed saint iames abbey ofqueene mary buryed westminster placed vnder rich hearſe decked penons banner schutchions armes englande france ſhe dudley created baron liſle afterward ſame day earle warwike westminster yeare englande many monſtrous birthes march mare brought forth foale one body andanno reg 4 two head long tayle growing betwéene two head alſo sow farowed piggemonſtrous birthes foure legges like armes man childe hand finger c aprill sow farrowed pigge two bodyes eight féete one head many calues lambes monſtrous ſome collers ſkinne growing neckes like double ruffes ſhirtes nekercheffes vſed xxiiij may man child borne chichester suſſex hea • ▪ armes legges whereof lyke notamy breſt belly monſtrous bigge nauell long ſtring parte ſingular commendation william allin richard chamberlaine 28 sept sherifes maior anno reg 5 tempeſt leyceſter sir thomas lodge grocer 28 october saterday ye xvj january great tempeſt wind thunder happened towne leycester whiche vncouered 411 bayes houſes ouerturned manye ix x xj february westminster hall ouerſlowen1563 wyth water holland lincolneſhire drowned rage winde water frenchemen huge army aſſembled outeiohn cai •• partes fraunce recouer place paſſage ſtopping whereof power double woe common wealth bred throughe ſeaſon yere putrifactiō aire miſerable infortunate plague among men whyche maruellouſly encreaſed death diuers beſt captain ſouldiors withal folowed cruel quicke ſiege whereat preſent yong kyng hymſelfe quéene hys mother beſte tryed number warlike ſouldiours within whole countrey beſides ſorte yong olde cared life lande ſo aduenture might winne againe cauſe diſtreſſe wyth generall ayde mariſhes made paſſable firme ground whych men great experience thought impoſſible common helpe cannon placed caſtell wals battered ſundrye breach made beyond expectation howbeit rewarded oure gunner made taſte bitter fruit deſperate approche greate terrour annoyaunce earle warwike wyth remnant capitaines ſouldiors couragious order ſtanding ſeuerall breach ready defende aſſaultes whyche perceyued enimy cauſed trumpet ſound blaſt emparle compoſition eyther parte mighte made auoide imminent ſlaughter effuſion bloude offer ſéemed vnméete bothe party concluded towne delyuered nine twentith july wyth condition engliſhemen ſhould departe towne ſorte ſurrendred frenche greateſt part garriſon ſhipped many ſicke perſons lefte behind impotent vnable help themſelues miſery whereof edwarde randolfe eſquier hygh marſhall towne appointed tarry ſée vttermoſte oure compoſition accompliſhed perceiuyng moned naturall pitie countreymen relinquiſhed withoute comforte cauſed ſaide ſicke perſons bée carryed aboorde ſparing ſhoulders time feeble full plague hymſelfe hys men ſtill bearing helping poore creature shipboorde rare facte worthy rewarde doubte remembrance god true recorder mercifull deſerts ye haue hearde plague peſtilence thepeſtilence towne newhauen bringing togither ſuche multitude infection might encreaſe wéeke dyed wythin citie pariſhes two thouſande wherefore ſir iohn white tooke othe outermoſte gate tower london firſte daye december till twelfth anno reg 6 lightning and▪ thunder ſache continuall lightning thunder eſpecially ſame twelfth day night y• like bin ſéene heard man liuing moneth december driuen • hore •• grimſ •• e hertforde hillarye tearme kepte hertforde caſtell beſides waer thys yeare honorable ioyfull peace concluded1564 betwixte quéenes maieſtie frenche kyng realmes dominion subiectes whyche peace proclaymed ſounde trumpet hir caſtell windſore and▪ alſo london thyrtéenth daye aprill plague thankes god cleane ceaſed london eaſter midſommer terme kepte westminster throughe earneſt ſuite armourer vigile saint peter watche citie london vvatche peter euen whyche onelye ſtande higheſt ſtréetes▪ cheape cornehill ſo forth aldgate whyche watche common city chargeable time paſt béene commendably done fifth auguſte quéenes maieſtie hir progreſſe abrah hartwell queenes progreſſe thorough cambridge came uniuerſitie cambridge student inueſted according degrées taken schooles honorably ioyfully receiued king colledge ſhe lye hir continuaunce cambridge▪ dayes hir abode paſſed scholaſticall exerciſes philoſophie phiſicke diuinitie nightes comedy tragedy ſette partlye whole uniuerſitie partly oneale diſcomfited statuta regni hiberniae edmond campion▪ quéenes maieſtie ireland done manye greate outrage partes v • ster yeare▪ wyth hys greate loſſe manfully repelled ſiege dundalke garriſon thereof afterward great valiancie ſir henrie sidney knight order lord deputie irelande ſo diſcomfited ſundry conflictes loſſe 3500 men nowe foreſéeyng hys declination iminant determined put colle • clan ibon▪ vnder conducting alexander oge mec gilliam buske whoſe father vncle shane oneale hadde lately kylled ouerthrow giuen scot neuertheleſſe wel liking perſwaſion went ſaide camp ſecond june▪ diſſembled entertainment quaffing wine gilliam buske▪ burning wyth deſire reuenge father vncles death miniſtryngshane oneale ſlayne quarrelling talke iſſued tent made feay vppon oneales▪ men gathering togither hys scot throng ſodainely entred tent againe wyth ſlaughter▪ swordes hewed péeces shane oneale hys secretarie hys company excepte verye fewe whych eſcaped flyght 8 june ſir thomas sackuile september sherifes maior sir roger martin mercer 28 october drye summer followed ſharpe winter wyth ſuche ſcarcitie fodder hay dyuers place ſame ſolde waighte yorkeſhire peake haye ſolde fiue penny ſtone followed alſo greate death cattel eſpecially horſe ſhéepe moneth january quéenes maieſtie ſente narrow ſeas thrée hir ſhips named antelope swallow aide one barke named phoenix whiche manned v c men hir highneſſe appointed charge thoſe ſhips men mayſter william holſtoke eſquier comptroller hir highneſſe ſhippes commaundement ſtay ſubiects king philip according hys duetie charge▪ hée vſed ſuche diligence eleauenth marche nexte following mette eleauen ſaile flemiſhe▪ hoyes vppon bolongne whyche came roan • foure hundred odde tuunes gaſcoigne french wine whyche intended haue conueyed flaunders william holſtoke ſtayed al ſaide hoyes ſent london made diſcharge fleming diſappointed moreouer eight twentith march▪ ſaid william holſtoke ſeruing antelope preſent admirall company william winter yonger time uizadmirall ſeruing ayde • baſing capitaine •• llowe thomas generley captaine phoenix • te narrowe sea wyth fouretéene ſayle greate h • lkes whych come portingale bounde flaunders theyr chiefe lading béeyng portingale▪ salte yet hadde good ſtore spaniſhe rialles plate alſo greate ſtore spice fourtéene hulkes mainteyne fight ſpace two houres perceyue could preuayle ſayd w holſtoke hys company tooke eyght ſame hulkes whereof ſixe ſent riuer thamis admirall uizadmirall ſayd hulkes two great shippes w holſtoke himſelfe take conuayed harwich diſcharged xxviij march vehement rage tempeſtgreat vvinds windes many veſſels thamis two tiltebeates graueſend ſunke drowned xxvj june deceaſſed thomas yong archbiſhoparchbishop yorke deceaſſed yorke manour shefield encloſedburiall dead prepared wall bricke nigh one acre ground néere vnto bedlem without biſhopſgate place buriall dead ſuche pariſhes london lacked conueniente ground within ſayd pariſhes ſtanding watch saint iohns euen midſomer sir iohn white alderman rode circuite lorde maior ſhould haue done xxvij auguſt andrew gregoreuich sauin embaſſadour muſcouy lauded tower wharffe andembaſſador muſcouy receyued lord maior london alderman sheriffes scarlet merchant aduenturers coates blacke veluet horſebacke conuayd riding citie muſcouy houſe • ding lane lodged plague peſtilence ſome raigning citieterme adiorned london michaelmas terme firſt adiourned vnto thirde nouember vnto hillarie terme next folowing henry bechar william danne 28 september sheriffes xj october thomas haward duke norffolke brought burnam beſide windſore land westminster duke norffolke ſent tovver thence water tower london priſoner sir henry neuill kéeper sir alexander auenon irnemonger 28 october maior maiors feaſt maior went water westminster tooke oth hath bin accuſtomed kept feaſt guild hall leaſt comming togither ſo great multitude infection peſtilēce might haue increaſed wéeke one twentith vnto eyght twentith october dyed citie pariſhes diſeaſes 152 51 accompted dye plague monday fourtéenth nouember thomas percy earles northumberland vveſtmerland rebelled earle northumberland béeing topclife receyued quéenes maieſties letter repaire court ſame day night certayne conſpirators perceyuing ſayde earle wauering vnconſtant promiſe made cauſed ſeruante hys called bekewith hée layde hys bedde buſtle knocke hys chamber dore willing hym haſt ariſe ſhifte hymſelfe hys enimies whome hée tearmed bée sir oſweld vlſtrop mayſter vaghan parke beſette number men wherevpon hée aroſe conuayde hymſelfe away hys kéepers houſe ſame inſtant cauſed belle towne rong backwarde ſo rayſed many could purpoſe▪ next night earle departed thence branspith mette charles neuill earle westmerland theyr confederate time ſundrie proclamation abuſing quéenes ſubiects commaunded hir highneſſe name repaire warlike manner defence ſuretie hir maieſtles perſon ſometymes affirming theyr doyngs bée aduiſe conſent nobilitie realme déede wholly bente manyfeſtly appeared ſpende theyr liues dutifull obedience agaynſte traytors ſometymes pretending conſcience ſake ſéeke reforme religion ſometymes declaring driuen take thys matter hand leaſt otherwiſe raigne prince might take vpon great perill realme xvj day came durham forthwith wentrebels rent byble minſter tare bible communion bokes ſuch therewere ſame night went agayne branspith morrow darington holywater maſſe want veſtments thence ſente horſſemen gather togither ſuche number men coulde xviij earle northumberland went richmond northalarton borow bridge sonday twentithanno reg 12 nouember lady counteſſe northumberland met agayne earle westmerland ripon maſſe get credite among fauourers olde romiſh religion croſſe banner fiue woundes borne richard norton night went borow bridge monday wether • ie whiche daye nighte ſome band entred • dcaster tooke two hundred footemen chacing captaynes leading towards yorke earle suſſex tueſday muſtered clifford moore nigh vnto bramham moore ſixtéene hundred horſſemen four thouſand footemen greateſt number euer thence intended hauethe number rebel marched toward yorke mindes ſodeinly altered report heard sir george bowes muſtered within biſhopricke richmondſhire leuyed greate band wedneſday returned agayne wetherby thurſeday northalerton fryday richmond saterday westmerland wente rabyes hys owne houſe sonday night earle northumberland came monday tueſday wedneſday muſtered richmondſhire biſhopricke beſtowing footemen band vnder captaynes leading ſame day laſt nouember beſéeged barnard barne caſtell vpon teſe builded bybernards caſtel beſeeged barnard bayllioll anno domini 1174 caſtell valiantly defended sir george bowes roberte bowes brother ſpace eleuen dayes meane ſpace earle westmerland lady went durham ſeauen eyght hundred horſe remayned till thirtéenth december ſpace wéete ſeauenth day december sir iohn foſter wardenskirmish vvith rebel middle march accompanyed sir henry percy giue ſayd earle great ſkirmiſh ſixth december sir george bowes put forth caſtell two hundred horſemen whereof two perſons ſlayne thirtie taken rebel tenth december sirbarnards caſtel deliuered rebel george bowes deliuered ſayd caſtell vnder compoſition depart armour munition bagge baggage forthwith marched garriſon towardes yorke meane time wéete xxiiij nouember quéenes maieſtie cauſed ſayd earles northumberland earles northumberland vveſtmerland proclaymed traytors westmerland proclaymed traytors adherent fauourers forthwith prepared army ſent south ſuppreſſion lord scrope sadler treaſurer came yorke ſeruants sonday xj december marched yorke towards topclife x • j tarryed sezay sir george bowes power comming barnards castell foreſayde mette made marſhall armye wente northalarton • icto • croftbridge ſo actay day rebel fledde durham hauing called companye chriſtopher neuill frent hertlepoole fortifying exham abode thrée dayes earle •• ſſex lieutenant power wente actay durham newcastell twentith december exham whence rebel gone nighte naworth counſayling edwarde dacres concerning theyr owne weakeneſſe alſo purſued earle suſſex hys power ſeauen thouſande euen almoſte theyr héeles moreouer earle warwike thethe earle vvarvvike ſent againſt rebel lorde clinton lorde admirall englande lorde ferrers uiſcount hereford afarre greater armye twelue thouſande south whereof ſayde earle warwike generall farre behynde borowbridge nexte nighte two earles northumberlande westmerlande wyth ſundry principall gentlementhe earles northumberland vveſtmerland fledde earle suſſex made iourney scotland generall north lord hunſdon lorde gouernour barwike warden eaſt march mayſter william drewry high marſhall barwike garriſon power fame began iourney scotlande ſame night came warke twelue mile barwike ſo next morrow entred tiuidale marching warlike order brēt ouerthrew raſed ſpoyled caſtels townes village enimies till came caſtell moſſe ſtanding ſtrōg mariſh belōging l bucklugh likewiſe raſed ouerthrowne brent ſo marched forward brent whole countrey till came craling ſame day sir iohn foſter warden thesir iohn foſter vvith garriſon entred scotlād middle march garriſon force ſame entred likewiſe tiuidale vpon expes gate ſixtéene mile warke like order brent raſed ſpoyled countrey till came ſtrong caſtell called craling poſſeſſion mother lord ferniherſt likewiſe ouerthrew raſed brent army mette ſo marched riuer tiuite raſing burning ſpoyling caſtels pyle along riuer till came gedworth lodged curteouſly receyued next day lorde seſ • ord warden middle march scotlande came principall men hys kinred lorde lieutenante ſubmitte themſelues aſſured receyued engliſh rebel ayding aſſiſting neyther made inuaſion englande ninetéenth armie deuided two partes one parte whereof paſſed riuer teuite brent caſtell ferniherst caſtels townes belonging lorde ferniherst huntill bedrell ſo paſſed mint armyes mette agayne ſo brente bothe ſides riuer till came greate towne called hawicke intended haue lodged scottes vnthatched houſes brent thatch ſtréetes themſelues fledde moſt parte theyr goodes induſtrie engliſhmen timber alſo burned thatch ſauing one little houſe ſtone dunlamrickes wherein lord lay night twentith daye armie marched forwardes houſe lorde bucklugh whych ouerthrew powder marched northwarde riuer tiuet brente ſpoyled ſuche caſtels pyle townes belonged lorde fernihurſt bucklogh kinſmen adherent night returned gedworth one twentith day part army went riuer bowbent vnder leading ſayde marſhall mayſter george heron réeper tiuidale ridſdale countrey mette ioyning togither rode burning ſpoyling ſides riuer part marched riuer trile waſted brent ſides riuer returned kilſey lord lieutenant lodged purpoſe beſéege hewme caſtell nighte judge making curteſi • firſt one leg wyth paſſed forth til came middle place made lyke obeyſance ſo paſſing till came bar made like curteſie ſhield held vp aloft ouer head nailor put nether ſtocks ſo bare foote bare legged ſaue ſilke • auilonions ye ankle dublet ſléeues tyed vp aboue elbow bareheaded came aforeſaid ſureties george thorne called bring ſame thorne immediatly ſir henrie cheyney entring vpper ende right hand judge vſed like order coming hys ſide naylor ſide ſo comming bar like obeyſance helde vp ſhield proclamation made none ſhould touch bar preſume come within ſame except ſuch appoynted ſolempne order finiſhed l • chiefe juſtice rehearſing maner bringing writ right simon low anſwere made thervnto paramore procéeding therein paramore chalenged defend right lande battel george thorne gauntlet wherevnto ſayde naylor aunſweared hys lordeſhyp myghte commaunde hym thing willingly would render ſaide ga • tlet thorne excepte hée coulde winne chalenged ſaide thorne playe fixed starres ſaide conſtellation made geometrical figure loſinge wiſe learned menne called rombus thys starre bigneſſe fyrſte appearing ſéemed bigger iupiter muche leſſe venus ſhe ſéemeth greateſt alſo ſaid starre neuer changing hys place carryed daylye motion heauen fixed starres commonlye ſo contynued little little eye appearyng leſſe ſpace almoſte ſixetéene moneths tyme ſo ſmall rather number ſouldiers mentioned paſſed barwike lieth frō whence xxv day april marched edenborough entred ye town ſame day ſommoned▪ y• caſtell forme followeththo churchyard sir william kirkandie ſometime graunge knighte much quéenes maieſtie ſoueraigne lady vpon earneſt requeſt hir deare cooſin y• king sot ſoueraign lorde made hir highneſſe regent nobilitie ſtates realme al good meanes vſed haue reduced dutifull obedience authority treatie hither haue duely hearkened vnto hinderaunce vniuerſall peace realme withholding highneſſe caſtle meaning ſéemeth reſerue ſame receptacle forraine force manifeſt daungers realme ſoueraigneſſe therefore neceſſarie remoue ſo perilous daunger realmes conſideration hir maieſtie hath ſente hir ayde ſuccours men ordinaunce munition vnder charge leading repugnation recouerie ſayde caſtel ſaide king vſe behalfe therefore according hyr maieſties commandement commiſſion ſhal due manner warne require ſummon render deliuer ſaide caſcell whole ordinaunce aſſaylants watching warding trench anſwered within caſtell roughly xvij may began battery caſtell ſo xxx canon ſhotte againſt ſame ſo well beſtowed dauids tower ruines therof force engliſh canon eaſte diligence engliſh gunner diſplaced ordinance caſtell ſtroke one chiefe canon iuſt mouth whereby ſame broken péeces xxvj may aſſault giuen ſcauen clocke morning spurre hardy manhoode aſſaylants wonne ſooner entred engliſhmen general enſigne ſhewed ſpread vpon front toppe thereof great diſcomfort within caſtell meane time whileſt theſe appoynted giue aſſault thus spurre certayne engliſhmen scottes commaunded make countenance aſſault weſt ſide caſtell whereby thoſe aſſaulted spurre might eaſily obteyne purpoſe raſhly aduenturing farther commandement beaten backe repulſed xxviij xxx company ſlayne hurt ſame day towarde night within caſtell drumme demaunded parley graunted aſſurance hoſtilitie houre vnto xxviij may lord peterroc let downe rope caſtell afterward lord graunge himſelfe ſtorma lad 1 • yeres olde drovvned chanell london rayne happened london like long time coulde remembred wherethrough chanels city ſodainelye ryſing ran ſuche forcible courſe towardes common ſhores lad age eightéene yeres minding haue leapte ouer chanell néere vnto downgate borne ouer ſtreame ſame carryed conduit towardes thamis wyth ſuche ſwiftneſſe man wyth ſtaues wayes coulde ſtaye hym tyll came certayne glaſſe houſe whichthe glaſſe houſe brent ſometime ••• croſſed frier hall néere tower london braſt terrible fire wherevnto lord maior alderman sheriffes expedition repaired practiſed meanes poſſible water bucket hooke otherwiſe haue quenched notwithſtanding whereas ſame houſe ſmall time conſumed great quantitie wood making fine drinking glaſſes ſelfe hauing within néere fortie thouſand billet wood conſumed ſtone walles walles greatly defended fire ſpreading farther harme xxvj september pulters wife pariſh offoure chyldren one burden chriſtes church within newgate london deliuered
